webTitle: The A to B of English football

fields.headline: The A to B of English football
fields.standfirst: Sven-Goran Eriksson saw his first two matches as England coach but was treated to only rare glimpses of inspiration, writes Richard Williams
fields.trailText: Time spent in reconnaissance, as Clausewitz said, is never wasted - and at least Sven-Goran Eriksson now knows exactly what he is up against. By choosing to spend his first working weekend in England at Upton Park and Portman Road, he exposed himself to the kind of wholehearted mediocrity which it is his task to transcend.
fields.body:
Time spent in reconnaissance, as Clausewitz said, is never wasted - and at least Sven-Goran Eriksson now knows exactly what he is up against. By choosing to spend his first working weekend in England at Upton Park and Portman Road, he exposed himself to the kind of wholehearted mediocrity which it is his task to transcend.

It would be interesting to know his real opinions on the qualities displayed by the sides standing second, equal third, sixth and 11th in this morning's Premiership table, but he is too astute a diplomat to reveal his innermost thoughts at this early stage, or possibly ever.

It was a weekend of typically English scuffling and hustling. In short, a good time to be watching Lazio, although perhaps not if you were Eriksson, whose half-time cup of tea in the Ipswich boardroom yesterday may have been interrupted by the news coming in from Italy that his old club, recently in free fall, had won 4-3 at Udinese. Sod's law in action, of course, and devoid of significance.

Of the two games attended by Eriksson, Sunderland's 2-0 victory at West Ham offered occasional fleeting glimpses of superior football, while Ipswich Town's defeat of Leicester City by the same score provided the traditional English recipe of a barren first period full of midfield trench warfare followed by a raucous crescendo in the second half.

He must have been pleased by the warmth of the reception he received from both full houses, in particular at Upton Park. "To win a World Cup you've got to have a few West Ham players in the team," the stadium announcer said by way of introduction, but the crowd would have been disappointed that, with one shining exception, their team did little to entertain or instruct England's new coach.

Those who have read Eriksson's new book on the mental side of football, due to be published in an English translation in March, say he divides players into two categories. The first, Type A, is the sort in whose nature ambition is mixed with fear of failure. Type B, by contrast, has the ambition but lacks the inhibiting factor of fear. The proportion in football as a whole, Eriksson believes, is 80% of the former to 20% of the latter. He certainly came across a Type B player on Saturday, when Joe Cole paraded his skills in the West Ham midfield.

Few Sunderland fans will agree with a negative overall verdict on a match which elevated them into second place in the Premiership, but this was an afternoon largely lacking in the virtues of precision and imagination. Within such an unprepossessing landscape, otherwise illuminated only by the sodium glow of Sunderland's work rate, Cole's ability flickered like a distant beacon.

We all love to watch a virtuoso, but managers are only interested when such skill is applied to the practical demands of the day. Announcing himself in the first minute of Saturday's game with a backheel that owed everything to necessity and nothing to a desire to show off, Cole studded the match with moments of inspiration. There were even important tackles on both Sunderland full-backs, demonstrating a willingness to chase back and to commit himself physically.

In his more familiar playmaking guise, Cole put his full range on display. There was a pinpoint 40-yard diagonal ball which landed on Frédéric Kanouté's instep at the far post, an instant turn that forced a foul from Emerson Thome, a willowy slalom through the Sunderland cover to set up a chance for Rigobert Song, and an acceleration between Don Hutchison and Gavin McCann, followed by an exchange of passes with two team-mates, which gave him an opportunity wasted by a shot scuffed from inside the penalty area.

Above all there was the moment of supreme originality, in the 65th minute, when he received the ball from Steve Lomas in the inside-right position and, wanting to play the ball through to Paolo Di Canio with the least possible waste of time and the greatest degree of surprise, twisted his right foot behind his left and beat the last line of cover with a pass of stunning simplicity and effectiveness. Di Canio fastened on to the ball and drove in a shot which rebounded off the near post. Without wishing to exaggerate, it was like stepping back 40 years and seeing Alfredo Di Stefano execute a backheel for the first time.

According to Harry Redknapp, Eriksson had kind words to say about Cole after the match. Had he and his assistant, Tord Grip, not left Portman Road a few minutes before the final whistle, no doubt he would have complimented George Burley on the performance of the 28-year-old Marcus Stewart, who scored Ipswich's first goal. Instead Peter Taylor did the job for him. "He caused us a lot of problems with his clever movement," the erstwhile England caretaker said.

Of the other prospects on view in the two games, Frank Lampard looked sluggish, Kevin Phillips busied himself but achieved little, Trevor Sinclair and Michael Gray tussled inconclusively with each other, Gavin McCann enhanced his reputation as a useful midfield all-rounder, Richard Wright exuded competence under little pressure, and Titus Bramble gave every sign of being one for the distant future.

His choice of weekend itinerary cost Eriksson the chance of seeing at first hand the fine displays of Steven Gerrard in Liverpool's victory over Aston Villa, of Paul Robinson in Leeds's win at Manchester City, and of John Terry in Chelsea's draw with Arsenal. He also missed the less encouraging sight of Wes Brown, England's most accomplished young defender, and Michael Owen, the country's most gifted forward, occupying places on the substitutes' benches for Manchester United and Liverpool.

But this was only a start. Eriksson has six weeks to spend in reconnaissance before he needs to come to a conclusion about the 22 best footballers in England. And at the end of that time we shall finally get a clue as to whether, when it comes to international football management, what we have on our hands is a Type A or a Type B.

webTitle: Round up

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: Dave Jones's first home match in charge of Wolves ended in disappointment as a late penalty miss by Kevin Muscat denied his side a win over Portsmouth .
fields.body:
Dave Jones's first home match in charge of Wolves ended in disappointment as a late penalty miss by Kevin Muscat denied his side a win over Portsmouth .

Having taken the lead through Andy Sinton, his first goal in his two years at the club, Wolves were left red-faced when Joleon Lescott and Michael Oakes combined to gift their opponents an equaliser.

Jones was buoyed by the fans' welcome, but Steve Claridge, his opposite number, struck a down-to-earth tone. "At the moment we're mid-table sides," he said. "No better, no worse."

Watford continued their recent renaissance, Tommy Mooney's 16th goal of the season inflicting only a second home defeat on Sheffield United . Birmingham are close behind them in sixth, despite turning a comfortable 3-0 lead into an untidy and sometimes desperate 3-2 win at Barnsley .

QPR secured the shock of the day, making light of their position near the foot of the table in beating high-flying West Brom 2-0. "Our expectations are very high here," said Gary Megson, "but we have a lot of players who are just not performing as they should be." Rangers remain level on points with Crewe - who won 3-1 at Grimsby - at the bottom of the league.

There were shocks too in the Second Division, where last-placed Oxford United beat promotion-chasing Walsall 2-1. Phil Gray scored twice in the first half and, despite a late goal from Dean Keates, the Saddlers slipped to six points behind the leaders, Millwall.

Carlisle 's 1-0 win over Shrewsbury meant that the last-placed team of every division won. Of the Third's other struggling clubs, Exeter threw away a two-goal lead to lose 3-2 at home to Leyton Orient and Torquay were hammered 5-0 at mid-table Blackpool .

webTitle: Liverpool in move for £5m Kirkland

fields.headline: Liverpool in move for £5m Kirkland
fields.trailText: Liverpool are hoping to recruit Coventry City's Chris Kirkland in a deal that could eventually see the youngster become the most expensive goalkeeper in the history of British football.
fields.body:
Liverpool are hoping to recruit Coventry City's Chris Kirkland in a deal that could eventually see the youngster become the most expensive goalkeeper in the history of British football.

The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier has been monitoring Kirkland's progress for several months and is now believed willing to lodge a bid of around £5m.

That sum, were it to be accepted by Coventry, would represent an initial down payment. The fee could rise to more than £8m if Kirkland were to enjoy success at Anfield and win full international honours with England.

Although Liverpool's first-choice goalkeeper, the Dutch international Sander Westerveld, has been the subject of much criticism this season, it is thought unlikely that Houllier would pitch Kirkland straight into the senior side were he successful in his attempts to sign him.

Having already invested in excess of £50m on new players since his managerial partnership with Roy Evans was dissolved just over two years ago, Houllier is still anxious to bolster his squad further as he attempts to end Manchester United's monopoly of the domestic honours.

Paris St-Germain are willing to meet Newcastle United's £3.5m valuation of the 22-year-old left-back Didier Domi but their coach Luis Fernandez has been told to sell players before he can complete the deal. Domi has been absent without leave in Paris since before Christmas and is refusing to return to Tyneside.

Matthew le Tissier will begin his comeback for Southampton reserves today after a 10-week injury lay-off. The 32-year-old Le Tissier has played only two league games this season but will line up against Charlton at Southampton's Staplewood training ground after suffering knee ligament damage against Manchester City in October.

The former England midfielder has to prove his fitness soon as his £1m-a-year contract expires in the summer. Le Tissier was sent off after receiving two yellow cards in a minute against Ipswich reserves earlier this season.

webTitle: Wise switch turns the tide by halves

fields.headline: Wise switch turns the tide by halves
fields.standfirst: David Lacey sees Ranieri's interval reshuffle transform Chelsea from the ridiculous to the sublime
fields.trailText: After Arsenal had slipped below second place for the first time in three months some of their less forgiving supporters booed Arsène Wenger's players off the field. Chelsea fans, however, have long since learned to appreciate the vagaries of performance which make the difference between a cheer and a jeer.
fields.body:
After Arsenal had slipped below second place for the first time in three months some of their less forgiving supporters booed Arsène Wenger's players off the field. Chelsea fans, however, have long since learned to appreciate the vagaries of performance which make the difference between a cheer and a jeer.

In the four months since Claudio Ranieri took over from Gianluca Vialli Chelsea have maintained a metronomic habit of mood and form which their followers must find hypnotic. For much of the time this has amounted to nothing more complex than winning at home and losing away but on Saturday Ranieri's side managed to encapsulate the manic nature of their season within 90 minutes.

Chelsea's capacity for lurching from the sublime to the ridiculous goes back way beyond the moment the club decided that the only way to succeed was to appoint coaches with surnames ending in the letter 'i'. Yet it warmed the heart to see the mercurial tradition so faithfully maintained here, even if this was more a case of sublimity following farce.

In fact so well did Chelsea perform after coming in at half-time 1-0 down there was every reason to believe that not only were they about to achieve their first away league victory of the season but that they would also defeat Arsenal for the first time in 11 Premiership encounters.

Had David Seaman, back after injury, not managed to grab a shot from Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink before it crossed the goalline, the ball having slipped under the Arsenal goalkeeper's body, or Sam Dalla Bona not dragged a clear chance wide, Chelsea might have won. Instead the supporters were left to ponder what could have happened had the formation which led to their team dominating the second half been employed from the kick-off.

Ranieri now limits his post-match meetings with reporters to games which Chelsea lose, arguing that when they win or draw the players are entitled to take the credit. For Chelsea, then, a prolonged period of silence from their coach would be most welcome and already, since they have lost only one of their past eight fixtures, public pronouncements from I, Claudio have more or less dried up.

All the same it would have been helpful to hear the logic behind the idea of starting with a formation which might have been designed to enhance what strengths Arsenal had available in the absence of Dennis Bergkamp, Nwankwo Kanu and Tony Adams.

From the moment, in the third minute, that Robert Pires swung easily inside Dennis Wise and Dalla Bona before directing a precise shot into the far corner of the net it was obvious that on their right flank Chelsea's cover amounted to little more than a bead curtain. Thirteen years ago the success of Wise in stifling the threat of John Barnes on Liverpool's left was crucial to Wimbledon's 1988 FA Cup triumph but asking him to cope with Pires, Silvinho and Sylvain Wiltord surely risked a second transfer request from the Chelsea captain within a week of the first being withdrawn.

Not only that, a system which exposed Frank Leboeuf to the pace of Thierry Henry, restricted the opportunities of Marcel Desailly to move forward from the back, relegated the influence of Wise from fulcrum to factotum and left Hasselbaink up front with scant support suggested an approach by their coach bordering on the fatalistic.

Or maybe something had got lost in translation. Either way Ranieri switched to 4-4-2 for the second half with Albert Ferrer on at right-back, Wise returning to central midfield and the persevering Eidur Gudjohnsen joining Hasselbaink in attack. For Chelsea football became a pleasure again and after John Terry had headed them level, reacting quickly after Seaman had pawed at a corner from Wise, they looked the more likely winners.

Terry, like Jon Harley, is a highly promising young English defender and a further sign that Chelsea's foreign policy is starting to ease in favour of domestic products. Yet the fact that by half-time they were still in the contest was largely down to the Italian goalkeeping of Carlo Cudicini, whose saves from Henry and Fredrik Ljungberg (twice) had Wenger bemoaning another failure to kill a game off.

Arsenal have now taken six points out of a possible 18 and are under pressure from Ipswich for third place. Meanwhile Chelsea, at their present rate of improvement, could finish fifth and win the FA Cup, although the last time they did this the coach was sacked. No wonder Ranieri is not saying very much.

webTitle: Inventor spices up the technology rumour mill

fields.headline: Inventor spices up the technology rumour mill
fields.standfirst: There's hype, and then there's Hype. But, as Simon Jeffery reports, a mysterious new invention could justify the growing speculation
fields.trailText: There's hype, and then there's Hype. But, as Simon Jeffery reports, a mysterious new invention could justify the growing speculation.
fields.body:
First they said it was going to be bigger than the internet. Technology gossips and American journalists had got wind of a new invention so dramatic that it would change the world forever. Then the inventor turned around and said it wasn't such a big deal after all.

The invention, codenamed "Ginger" or "IT", is the subject of intense speculation. Few people know what IT is. The device is hidden away in its inventor's New Hampshire HQ and those who see it are sworn to secrecy.

But it comes highly recommended. Steve Jobs of Apple saw it and said: "You won't have to convince them to architect cities around it. It'll just happen."

Jeff Bezos of Amazon gave out a loud, honking laugh - suggesting that the invention may also be a lot of fun.

So what is it? Inventor Dean Kamen's last creation was a wheelchair that could climb upstairs. Some have read IT as an acronym for "individual transport" and concluded that the world is on the verge of seeing its first mass-market hover car or personal jet pack.

The clues are few. A leaked proposal for a book on the device was published on Inside.com, a website specialising in media and technology news, saying that Ginger would be an alternative to products that are dirty, expensive, sometimes dangerous and often frustrating, especially for city dwellers.

Mr Kamen has since moved to dampen the excitement. In a statement he said: "Spirited speculation about the unknown has led to expectations that are beyond whimsical. We have a promising project, but nothing of the earth shattering nature that people are conjuring up."

One option is that it could be a small scooter powered by a clean (or no) fuel engine. The engine may not - at present - be powerful enough to power a car or truck but, as Mr Kamen said before his retraction, the "core technology and its implementations" will have a "big, broad impact" on social institutions and some "billion-dollar old-line companies".

Of course, nothing tallies. And therein lies the charm. Technology commentator Bob Metcalfe perhaps got closest when he said: "If I invented metal and came out with the first spoon, which would be the big invention, the spoon or metal?"

Some, aside from the upper echelons of the US hi-tech industry, claim to have seen the plans.

An application to the World Intellectual Property Organisation from Mr Kamen describes a "class of transportation vehicles for carrying an individual over ground that is unstable with respect to tipping when not powered."

That may or may not be Ginger - though there is a chance it could be a 21st century Sinclair C5.

However, with Mr Kamen's pedigree as an inventor, the product is unlikely to be a let-down. He dropped out of college in his twenties and built a portable pump to dispense insulin (and other drugs) to patients who had previously required 24-hour observation.

Later, he developed a dialysis machine the size of a telephone directory to make mobile those who had previously been chained to an object with the proportions of a dishwasher.

Silicon Valley venture capitalist John Doerr says that he had been sure that he would not see the development of anything in his lifetime as important as the world wide web - until he saw Ginger.

Aside from the speculation, there is one thing certain about Ginger. The device is sure to make its creator immensely rich. Credit Suisse First Boston expects it to make more money in its first year than any start-up in history - predicting that, in five years, Mr Kamen will be worth more than Bill Gates.

A leaked proposal for a book on the device was published on Inside.com, a website specialising in media and technology news, saying that Ginger would be an alternative to products that are dirty, expensive, sometimes dangerous and often frustrating, especially for city dwellers. Mr Kamen has since moved to dampen the excitement. In a statement he said: "Spirited speculation about the unknown has led to expectations that are beyond whimsical. We have a promising project, but nothing of the earth shattering nature that people are conjuring up." One option is that it could be a small scooter powered by a clean (or no) fuel engine. The engine may not - at present - be powerful enough to power a car or truck but, as Mr Kamen said before his retraction, the "core technology and its implementations" will have a "big, broad impact" on social institutions and some "billion-dollar old-line companies". Of course, nothing tallies. And therein lies the charm. Technology commentator Bob Metcalfe perhaps got closest when he said: "If I invented metal and came out with the first spoon, which would be the big invention, the spoon or metal?" Some, aside from the upper echelons of the US hi-tech industry, claim to have seen the plans. An application to the World Intellectual Property Organisation from Mr Kamen describes a "class of transportation vehicles for carrying an individual over ground that is unstable with respect to tipping when not powered." That may or may not be Ginger - though there is a chance it could be a 21st century Sinclair C5. However, with Mr Kamen's pedigree as an inventor, the product is unlikely to be a let-down. He dropped out of college in his twenties and built a portable pump to dispense insulin (and other drugs) to patients who had previously required 24-hour observation. Later, he developed a dialysis machine the size of a telephone directory to make mobile those who had previously been chained to an object with the proportions of a dishwasher. Silicon Valley venture capitalist John Doerr says that he had been sure that he would not see the development of anything in his lifetime as important as the world wide web - until he saw Ginger. Aside from the speculation, there is one thing certain about Ginger. The device is sure to make its creator immensely rich. Credit Suisse First Boston expects it to make more money in its first year than any start-up in history - predicting that, in five years, Mr Kamen will be worth more than Bill Gates. webTitle: Walsh howler exposes the extremities

fields.headline: Walsh howler exposes the extremities
fields.trailText: The intriguing thing about Sir Alex Ferguson's protestations that the title is anything but won is that he actually believes what he is preaching.
fields.body:
The intriguing thing about Sir Alex Ferguson's protestations that the title is anything but won is that he actually believes what he is preaching.

Every week Manchester United's seventh championship in nine seasons looms closer and every week the manager refrains from engaging in chit-chat about the formality of their third title in succession.

The reasons for his prudence are simple. Ferguson still harbours memories of how Arsenal snatched the title in 1998 after ushering in the new year trailing United by 12 points and, six years before that, how his team were gazumped from another seemingly unassailable position by Howard Wilkinson's Leeds.

For the same to happen this year, however, it would need United to keel over like a felled oak. The idea is lunacy.

Nevertheless the chasm between top and bottom of the table was not emphasised on Saturday until later than United may have anticipated and the catalyst for their win was a ghastly error from Bradford's goalkeeper Gary Walsh. There were times, too, when Bradford's initial plans for containment were replaced by fleeting moments of adventure that threatened to embarrass their guests.

But three goals in the final 18 minutes did not flatter United for their periods of keep-ball, the number of clear-cut chances they fashioned and, above all, the frequency with which Stuart McCall found himself chasing Ryan Giggs with the heavy-hearted desperation of Wile E Coyote pursuing Road Runner.

Injury-free and uninhibited, Giggs is having one of those spells which once prompted Gary Pallister to observe that marking the Welshman could lead to a bad case of twisted blood. "The way I'm feeling, I can't wait for my next touch," Giggs said afterwards.

He produced the game's pièce de résistance with a body-swerving run and shot for United's second goal but the telling damage had been inflicted three minutes earlier when Walsh shaped to hack a clearance upfield only to end up on the seat of his pants. Teddy Sheringham was presented with an open goal and all the gumption that Bradford had displayed until that point was rendered meaningless.

"It would be wrong to crucify Gary," said Bradford's manager Jim Jefferies but it was the game's defining moment and as a former United employee the goalkeeper's swipe at thin air must have been particularly mortifying.

"He knows it was an absolute howler," Jefferies added. "He'll have a tough few days but we won't let him stew. The only way you can pick up a player after something like that is to let him know he will be in the team next week."

By the time United's substitute Luke Chadwick stroked in his first senior goal with an adroit finish from David Beckham's through-ball the home fans were doing their sums.

Bradford's tally of 15 points is three fewer than at this stage last season and it promises to get worse before it gets better. Their next two games are at Sunderland and then Arsenal, neither of whom have lost a home league match all season. Writing off Bradford has proved a hazardous occupation over the past 18 months but this time their position seems irretrievable.

That said, the relegation skirmish promises to be more durable than that for the championship. Of the sides immediately below them, United are far too haughty to regard Sunderland as credible contenders while Arsenal's challenge continues alarmingly to disintegrate.

"We've seen Leeds disappear before and look what happened then [1992]," insisted Ferguson, but those who lust for a contest worthy of the description will carry on being frustrated. United's manager may not be disposed to confess as much but their 11-point advantage is more liable to double than diminish before the end of the season.

webTitle: Reid's mackem miracle grows

fields.headline: Reid's mackem miracle grows
fields.trailText: Peter Reid is not one for long-range predictions. "I don't ever think about Europe," he said flatly. Reid is living for the moment, revelling in one of Sunderland's highest points in their post-war history.
fields.body:
Peter Reid is not one for long-range predictions. "I don't ever think about Europe," he said flatly. Reid is living for the moment, revelling in one of Sunderland's highest points in their post-war history.

The Sunderland manager is just getting on with the job and, in the process, enjoying confounding assumptions. It is hardly his fault that others such as Chelsea and Leeds have fumbled along with Arsenal, the presumed prime challengers to Manchester United, whom Sunderland have, for now, gleefully displaced.

Sunderland are second but nowhere near as high in the purists' popularity tables - which may or may not colour Sven-Goran Eriksson's thinking - but that is all right with Reid. Before thinking of England his players have to impress their manager, a very hard task-master indeed. They did so here, confronted by the creative threat of three of the Premiership's highest talents. But Paolo di Canio, Frédéric Kanouté and Joe Cole finished on the beaten side.

Reid's prescription for Sunderland remaining second in the land - he did not mention United - and emulating a finishing place last achieved in 1935 is based on old values, although not necessarily English ones - eight of his players who appeared here cannot wear the Three Lions crest.

Harry Redknapp's observation that Sunderland are "a bigger, stronger-looking side than us," tells only part of the story of the Premiership's form team, as does Cole's view that "they seem more organised". Reid's work ethic runs through his players veins; their remorseless closing-down, the volume of tackles and their counter-attacking ability all tell of superb fitness.

It may not be pretty but it is certainly effective, which also says much about the weakness of the Premiership. Redknapp was generous if not wholly convinced by Sunderland. "If Sunderland get in the Champions' League, Peter Reid should be manager of the season. They're tough to beat, work very hard and make it difficult for you. But I can still see Leeds in there. And there's Arsenal and Liverpool. As for the title, that's a one-horse race."

Reid's team will examine that near-universal theory when they entertain United on January 30, by which point Sunderland will surely still be the leaders' closest pursuers having beaten Bradford City next Sunday.

Redknapp was looking more to the day when he deploys a team around Cole rather than merely featuring his precocious talents. "Joe is a special talent," said Redknapp. "And you have to find a role and shape your team around him. At the moment he still plays football like a kid in the playground; if he loses the ball he wants to run and get it back. But I'm always willing to take that chance with him."

Sunderland never looked back after the towering Slovakian Stanislav Varga headed in one of Gavin McCann's many teasing dead-ball kicks. At any hint of danger Sunderland swarmed around Di Canio, Cole and Kanouté.

West Ham were then caught unprepared when Don Hutchison scored with a free-kick that Redknapp admitted he had seen the Scotland midfielder perform "three or four times before". The refereeing inconsistencies of Matt Messias continued to anger West Ham fans but by this time Sunderland's supporters were truly in wonderland.

webTitle: Plenty of spin but no delivery

fields.headline: Plenty of spin but no delivery
fields.trailText: The writing was on the wall the moment James Beattie received the Premiership Player of the Month trophy before kick-off. The curse of such awards all but guaranteed that Southampton's striker would not be adding to his 10 goals in 12 previous games. And unfortunately the match caught that empty mood.
fields.body:
The writing was on the wall the moment James Beattie received the Premiership Player of the Month trophy before kick-off. The curse of such awards all but guaranteed that Southampton's striker would not be adding to his 10 goals in 12 previous games. And unfortunately the match caught that empty mood.

No goal, no ideas, no fantasy, not even a yellow card to enliven proceedings. This was an economy-class journey on the Premiership express.

It so often happens when two average teams play each other. Average side versus superior team tends to bring the best out of the lesser side: ie Southampton 1, Leeds 0. Average side versus inferior team tends to bring out the worst in the average team: ie Charlton 1, Dagenham and Redbridge 1. But when two average sides lock horns they tend to bring out the mediocrity in each other.

Of course Charlton were happy to go home with a point from a game in which they were comprehensively outplayed. That for them is all that counts, especially with an away record - eight defeats from 12 matches - that is nothing to write home about.

However there is no hiding the cracks in the seemingly impressive facade of this eighth-placed team, cracks that were exposed in the Boxing Day thrashing at West Ham, the embarrassment of nearly losing to Dagenham and Redbridge in the FA Cup third round and here, where they struggled to produce anything approaching coherence.

If Charlton supporters were only slightly worried about Wednesday's third-round replay at Dagenham and Redbridge's compact little ground they must be sweating buckets by now, especially with their top scorer Jonatan Johansson injured.

It says much about Charlton that their frequent hero is the goalkeeper Dean Kiely, who produced another batch of saves to keep his side in the game here. One, from Beattie's through run and shot in the first half, was impressive. Another, after 76 minutes when Kiely saw Matthew Oakley's shot through a forest of legs but still managed to turn the ball away low down by a post, was brilliant.

Earlier he had also somehow got a touch to divert Oakley's rasping shot against the crossbar. Beattie also saw a long-range effort cleared off the line by Graham Stuart.

At the other end Charlton had all the cutting edge of one of Charlie Whelan's newspaper columns, and hardly troubled Paul Jones in the Southampton goal, though a clean sheet for the fifth home game running will offer scant consolation to Glenn Hoddle. He was hoping to secure a seventh win in eight home games and a rise to the relative safety of mid-table.

"We are disappointed, but for the right reasons," he said. "We had 15 efforts at goal and eight of those were on target but their keeper made a couple of great saves. I am pleased with a clean sheet but we should have won the game."

The Southampton manager was one of the few present to look back on this game with any emotion. For the rest, Saturday's encounter will be like the names of Bond girls - easily forgotten.

webTitle: One Angel may not be enough

fields.headline: One Angel may not be enough
fields.trailText: For a brief moment on Saturday Villa held their own stage. It was at half-time. Juan Pablo Angel, their new £9.5m Colombian, was led out to the centre circle. "Get him on, get him on," chanted the Holte End. But a heavenly host would not have saved Villa.
fields.body:
For a brief moment on Saturday Villa held their own stage. It was at half-time. Juan Pablo Angel, their new £9.5m Colombian, was led out to the centre circle. "Get him on, get him on," chanted the Holte End. But a heavenly host would not have saved Villa.

The signing, subject to a medical, may have saved the chairman Doug Ellis from a fans' protest. It may not save the manager John Gregory from Ellis. Villa's next three league games, after Wednesday's Cup replay with Newcastle, are at Old Trafford, then home to Leeds and Ipswich. By the end of the month Gregory's position may look precarious.

So might be Angel's signature, with a moment's consideration from the player. The medical could reasonably reveal cold feet brought on by acute depression. Villa, with one win in 10 games, are going nowhere. Liverpool, who played them off the field, may be moving forward. It was no contest.

Villa were badly reduced in midfield by suspensions and injury. They have struggled with only Dion Dublin up front for three months, following injuries to Luc Nilis and Julian Joachim. Why, then, did they not show interest in Jari Litmanen who, taken on a free transfer, did most to destroy them on Saturday? Angels are needed on and off the field.

Villa's goal tally is as feeble as their morale, organisation and, alongside their opponents, seemingly ambition. Villa last week offered £12m for Liverpool's fourth-choice striker Robbie Fowler. The offer was rejected. If the Colombian fears to tread, Fowler would be a natural to rush in.

Gérard Houllier insists he needs four strikers and Fowler still has a part to play "if he works his socks off". He was unimpressed, though, by the player's 2am fracas outside a nightclub this month. On Saturday Fowler did not make the bench. In his last game, on New Year's Day, the socks seemed to have fluffy reindeer on the toes; and his running was as woolly as his touch.

As with Alan Shearer, accumulated injuries may have deprived him of the speed off the mark that made him effective. Pursuing his own line off the field makes it difficult to tell. Either way Liverpool, who sent Stan Collymore that way, may have missed their best chance to cash in on a player at risk of seeing his future behind him.

There was no doubting their sense of purpose here until they grew bored of their superiority. Litmanen, inactive for a while at Barcelona, was sharp in all he did, slightly withdrawn on the left, sliding the ball beyond Villa's straining defence, husbanding his fitness. It was an example to Fowler or anyone. Houllier was delighted.

"He gives us different qualities, different options," he said. "He can play behind the two in front. He is an experienced on-and-off striker." Dublin might answer to that too but, without support, he has become more off than on. Angel, says Gregory, "comes with a big fee, a big reputation [17 goals in 17 games for River Plate] and a big responsibility".

The Finn had a key part in the goal of the match, feeding Danny Murphy, whose first-time flick found Steven Gerrard in full stride for an emphatic shot from 20 yards. Gerrard had made 50 yards from providing Litmanen in the first place. He will be satisfied that Sven-Goran Eriksson, already aware of him, has a television.

Houllier was guarded in his enthusiasm. "Step by step he is getting to an interesting level," he said. "He needs to repeat games like this and we must protect him. But, believe me, he is going to be a player. I think he could be another [Patrick] Vieira or [Roy] Keane."

Certainly he showed the all-encompassing range, strong in the tackle, ever available, willing, intelligent and powerful in foray. The force is with him.

To a lesser extent it is with Murphy, who owed his goals before and after to Alpay's error and a deflection that rewarded Emile Heskey's persistence. Who needs a striker, let alone four, with midfielders like this?

The first goal led to an altercation between Alpay and David James that summed up Villa's spirit and ended with the Turk slapping the keeper. It left Gregory "slightly embarrassed" and promising "action". The next few games may find him slightly more embarrassed. But at least on Saturday he had an Angel in waiting.

webTitle: Moody's quick fix as Millwall build up speed

fields.headline: Moody's quick fix as Millwall build up speed
fields.trailText: At least the under-17s are struggling. Gallingly for Second Division rivals and dauntingly for First Division towns and grounds, everything else at Millwall appears to be cushty and getting, ahem, cushtier.
fields.byline: Robert Pryce at the New Den
fields.body:
At least the under-17s are struggling. Gallingly for Second Division rivals and dauntingly for First Division towns and grounds, everything else at Millwall appears to be cushty and getting, ahem, cushtier.

Championship rivals are swatted like bluebottles, hat-tricks arrive by the barrel load and a young team is growing in confidence and understanding. Under Mark McGhee they have won 13 out of 19 league games and climbed from ninth place to four points clear at the top.

On Saturday Paul Moody, hitherto regarded as an old donkey among thoroughbred colts, scored a hat-trick. He now has six goals from his past four games. And Neil Harris, the division's deadliest finisher, revealed another dimension to his game, setting up three goals and only missing out on a fourth assist when Steve Reid somehow wafted a shot over the bar before an open goal.

Harris appears happy to carry an extraordinarily heavy load of expectation - "he's going to get us out of this division," McGhee said - but some of his young team-mates will soon have their day. Lucas Neil, a 23-year-old Australian filling in at full-back, appears a startling talent at this level with his ability to deliver a telling ball with either foot.

Wigan started as though they meant to slow the game down to a pace more suitable to their advanced years but the plan was overturned by the 13th minute, when Moody headed in his first, and then destroyed in the 32nd minute, when Millwall were 2-0 up and Simon Haworth was sent off for trampling on Tim Cahill.

"They're very athletic, powerful and well coached," Bruce Rioch, the Wigan manager, pointed out. "They have good running power all through their team." And it is not only veteran teams who are struggling to keep up.

webTitle: Ipswich find the pressure points

fields.headline: Ipswich find the pressure points
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson's first 48 hours of studying English football first hand has probably offered him little fresh insight into the job of producing a winning England team, but at least he has a better idea of why Manchester United are in a league of their own at the top of the Premiership.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson's first 48 hours of studying English football first hand has probably offered him little fresh insight into the job of producing a winning England team, but at least he has a better idea of why Manchester United are in a league of their own at the top of the Premiership.

Having seen Sunderland move unspectacularly into second place on Saturday, England's new coach watched Ipswich go fourth here yesterday with a victory over Leicester that was a triumph of perseverence rather than inspiration.

Leicester, keen to avoid their third league defeat in a row, appeared to be doing just that having withstood long spells of Ipswich pressure for most of the second half. Then their manager Peter Taylor, England's erstwhile caretaker, sacrificed a striker for an extra defender, whereupon Ipswich won with two free headers in the last 10 minutes.

The goal that ended a frosty stalemate was Marcus Stewart's sixth in as many matches, bringing his total for the season to 16 and convincing his admirers that Eriksson need look no further than the Bristol-born striker to lead England's attack.

Whenever England get a new coach almost any uncapped player in form is assumed to have a chance of an international career. Eriksson was here primarily to run an eye over Richard Wright, Ipswich's once capped goalkeeper, although since Wright had so little to do he must have gone away more impressed by Simon Royce, whose saves kept alive Leicester's hopes of a point.

As for Stewart, well, if he could bring with him the quality of passing and movement that surround him at Portman Road his case for England recognition might amount to something more than media gossip.

In criticising the performance of his own side Taylor summed up Ipswich's style rather well. "They moved around a lot more than us," he declared, "passed the ball better than us and did exceptionally well closing people down. Simon Royce's goalkeeping was the only positive thing to come out of our own performance."

Having already been impressed by Paul Robinson when Leeds United beat Lazio in the Champions League, Eriksson must be wondering what it is about the Premiership that produces second-choice goalkeepers of such a high quality. Royce, back in the Leicester side because of another injury to Tim Flowers, showed excellent agility and anticipation in keeping out headers from Alun Armstrong and Matt Holland as Ipswich increasingly dominated the match.

Patience is one of the prime virtues of Burley's Ipswich side and Eriksson will doubtless have noted that this is one English team that believes good footballing habits will usually prevail. So it proved.

Once Ipswich had created four clear chances early in the second half they never lost the initiative. They nearly went ahead in the 52nd minute when Armstrong met a cross from Jamie Clapham with a header that Stewart volleyed against the bar.

After that a combination of Royce and poor finishing enabled Leicester to survive. Then Taylor decided to replace a striker, Trevor Benjamin, with a centre-back, Phil Gilchrist, for the last quarter-hour, only to see his defence fall apart.

In the 60th minute Gary Rowett allowed Hermann Hreidarsson to slip past him near the byline. The Icelander laid the ball back to Armstrong, whose miscued shot was headed in by Stewart.

With a minute plus stoppage time remaining, Scowcroft met a centre from Fabian Wilnis in like manner. By this time Eriksson had already left - none the wiser maybe but at least with a better idea of what he is up against.

webTitle: Hughes' absence reveals that the future looks perfect for Blackburn

fields.headline: Hughes' absence reveals that the future looks perfect for Blackburn
fields.trailText: Blackburn are looking the part for a return to the Premiership. Graeme Souness watched his ever-improving team comfortably collect their seventh win in eight games to keep up the pressure on Bolton in the race to finish second behind Fulham and, as a bonus, they did it without Mark Hughes.
fields.body:
Blackburn are looking the part for a return to the Premiership. Graeme Souness watched his ever-improving team comfortably collect their seventh win in eight games to keep up the pressure on Bolton in the race to finish second behind Fulham and, as a bonus, they did it without Mark Hughes.

Hughes has been a talismanic figure since his arrival from Everton in October, inspiring Rovers' run from mid-table to third place, so his absence from the game through suspension was bound to be noted.

Souness need not have worried. His younger players have learned from playing alongside the Welshman, although next Sunday's game at Birmingham will prove a sterner test of their ability to cope without Hughes than a weak and woeful Wednesday did.

Few sides have given Brad Friedel such an easy ride here this season, though if Alan Quinn had tucked away Wednesday's only chance after 20 minutes the game might have taken on a different slant.

As it was, Rovers' dominance thereafter served only to suggest that Paul Jewell will have worked a managerial miracle equal to, if not better than, the one he performed in keeping Bradford City in the Premiership last season if he keeps Wednesday in the First this time around.

Blackburn, by contrast, were vibrant. This might not have been their best performance of the season, but they were always full of ideas and Souness has a pair of strikers for the future in Marcus Bent and Matt Jansen. Bent opened the scoring from Jansen's cross after half an hour with his fourth goal since his £1.8m move from Sheffield United, and 10 minutes later Martin Taylor put the game beyond doubt.

"That was Marcus's best afternoon for us yet," said Souness. "He was a constant threat, as was Jansen. They are both only 22 and they have to realise they won't always start together because I have another youngster by the name of Mark Hughes to call upon."

Wednesday were indebted to the on-loan goalkeeper Marlon Beresford. He made a series of fine second-half saves, denying Bent a hat-trick, and then admitted his admiration for Blackburn.

"They've got the quality players to make them tick. This division is still open and any team putting a run together will go up," Beresford said. "The way Rovers are going you have to fancy them."

Bolton might have something to say about that when the two teams meet in the Reebok at the end of next month.

webTitle: Forest fall in the face of a hard winter

fields.headline: Forest fall in the face of a hard winter
fields.trailText: A tumultuous week in the history of Nottingham Forest began just as they did not want yesterday, although the nauseating dread on Trentside must be that the true drama is about to unfold.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the City Ground
fields.body:
A tumultuous week in the history of Nottingham Forest began just as they did not want yesterday, although the nauseating dread on Trentside must be that the true drama is about to unfold.

Palace's first win in five league games deprived David Platt's stuttering team of an opportunity to return to the play-off zone, while the Forest hierarchy steel themselves for what threatens to be a long and acrimonious high court battle.

Tomorrow they will be in London to contest a case brought about by their former directors Irving Scholar and Julian Markham alleging that the value of their shares was substantially and "unlawfully" reduced by Nigel Doughty's £6m investment in the club 18 months ago.

Forest are already heavily in debt, shipping £92,000 a week. Should they lose, they may be forced to return Doughty's money and in the worst-case scenario he would no longer be authorised to guarantee their £6m overdraft.

"We will vigorously defend the charges," said the Forest chairman Eric Barnes, and the club's future could depend on it. Privately, several directors have expressed genuine concerns that losing effectively £12m could threaten Forest's existence.

In the meantime Platt's team must carry on regardless but their chances of a play-off position will depend on curing the malaise that has seen them fail to score in five of their past seven matches. They had David Johnson making his debut here and while Platt proclaimed himself "delighted" with the striker's contribution this was another irksome afternoon for Forest's followers when, yet again, their team's finishing would have failed to trouble a barn door.

Palace look a far more accomplished side than their league position suggests and after holding Sunderland to a draw in the FA Cup, as well as beating Liverpool 2-1 in the first leg of their Worthington Cup semi-final, Alan Smith's team has enjoyed a profitable eight-day spell.

A daisy-cutter from Mikael Forssell put them on their way on 19 minutes and the 19-year-old Finnish international scored his eighth goal in 13 games to double the lead just before half-time. This time the Forest captain Chris Bart-Williams was culpable of a horrible error to present Clinton Morrison with a clear run at goal and the striker unselfishly squared the ball for Forssell to finish from close range.

The second half was a familiar story of Forest possession and misses until their former striker Dougie Freedman settled the contest, converting a low cross from Andrejs Rubins only five minutes after replacing Morrison.

"It's been a great week," said Smith, a glass of vintage red agreeably at his side. "Sunderland, Liverpool and then Forest is anything but easy, but for a young team we've acquitted ourselves extremely well."

Platt, meanwhile, must hope his employers have more good fortune with m'learned friends than his players are having in front of goal.

webTitle: Cottage is a Des res again

fields.headline: Cottage is a Des res again
fields.trailText: Mohamed al Fayed may have been given the brush-off by the Windsors but he can still attract football royalty to Craven Cottage and Desmond Lynam turned up looking irresistibly windswept after enjoying a lengthy walk to the ground.
fields.body:
Mohamed al Fayed may have been given the brush-off by the Windsors but he can still attract football royalty to Craven Cottage and Desmond Lynam turned up looking irresistibly windswept after enjoying a lengthy walk to the ground.

He caught Fulham undergoing a minuscule crisis. Two defeats in two games are not what the cognoscenti of SW6 are accustomed to seeing and Fulham had a point to prove as much to their own fans as those cynics who say they lack the grit to battle their way through a demanding English winter.

Prove it they did. Jean Tigana's players came up against some of the most resolute opposition they have faced this season yet none of them was in the mood to shirk responsibility. Even though they did not play particularly well they carried the game to the visitors and were eventually able to put a gloss on the scoreline through Luis Boa Morte's last-minute half-volley.

"The result was more important than the performance after the last two results, against Man United and Stockport," said Andy Melville, who has assumed the captain's armband following Chris Coleman's car crash. "It was important to bounce back today and get the three points."

Fulham had found it difficult to make progress against a deep-lying back four bolstered by two midfielders - Lee Marshall and Phil Mulryne - who frustrated any attempts at getting passing movements going. As half-time approached without either goalkeeper having been tested it seemed likely that only an exceptional moment of skill would break the deadlock, and Fulham had the man to provide it in Louis Saha.

Receiving the ball with his back to goal, the French striker turned and in the same movement drove a searing shot into the bottom corner. It was his 17th league goal and his 22nd in all competitions this season.

Norwich could find no answer, though they played beyond the capabilities of a side languishing so far down the table. "I think Fulham would have to say they've been in a very good game today against a very committed performance," said Nigel Worthington, experiencing his first official game in charge after stepping up from caretaker-manager.

During that time Norwich had won two and drawn three of their six games but Worthington has still to earn the unanimous approval of fans who suspect his appointment was the cut-price option. Further developments are possible when the Norwich chairman Bob Cooper faces a vote of no confidence at the club's AGM on Thursday.

webTitle: Venables transforms Riverside landscape

fields.headline: Venables transforms Riverside landscape
fields.trailText: The home partisans trundled home bellowing the name of Terry Venables as their coaching saviour continues to work his magic, ensuring Teesside remains engulfed in a sea of Cockney optimism.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
The home partisans trundled home bellowing the name of Terry Venables as their coaching saviour continues to work his magic, ensuring Teesside remains engulfed in a sea of Cockney optimism.

Even in a match which, for almost all of an insipid first half, lived up to its assumed billing as a goalless stalemate, El Tel conjured up a thumping victory. Middlesbrough's biggest win since October 1998 stretched their unbeaten run under the new coach to seven matches and propelled them out of the relegation zone; Derby, beaten for only the second time in seven themselves, slipped back into trouble.

Boro are unrecognisable from the shapeless shambles that had lost eight out of nine matches before Venables arrived. Now his players, from being distinctly off-colour, are vibrant; Hamilton Ricard and Gianluca Festa have a spring in their stride and Christian Karembeu looks the World Cup winner he had forgotten he was. But the lease of life is apparently not all driven by East End inspiration.

"It annoys me when people keep saying it's Tel this and Tel that," said the home captain Paul Ince. "It's not all down to Terry. Our gaffer [Bryan Robson] is still playing an integral part. Tel's come in and turned things around, but they are a partnership and the gaffer should get some credit. It worked at Euro 96 and it's working now."

Robson's role may remain ambiguous, but he is clearly occupied behind the scenes. After Venables earmarked the Bradford City forward Dean Windass as a potential signing, it was Robson who approached the chairman Steve Gibson and prompted a £1m bid last week.

"Bryan takes notice of what I have to say, but it's his decision in the end on signings," Venables said.

Venables's impact has been felt most markedly in their defence. Boro have conceded only two goals in his seven games there - opponents have yet to score from open play against the Teessiders - and they restricted Derby to only two shots on target.

"We're not playing fantasy football, but you have to do the work we did in the first half to be able to play like we did after half-time," said Venables. "We have worked a lot more through the team and, once we had earned it, we played with imagination and finished well."

Derby, too, have discovered defensive stability since Colin Todd's arrival as their coach. The first half served notice of as much; neither side strayed from its rigid formation, the players ever conscious of their defensive roles. It may have had the coaches salivating in satisfaction but it made for a turgid match.

Then, as the interval approached, Derby's solidity was undermined. Ricard crossed from the left and the referee Rob Styles deemed Darryl Powell's tug down on Alen Boksic illegal. The Croatian scored with ease.

"I honestly didn't think it was a penalty," said Powell. "I was back marking Karembeu and Boksic pulled off so I went across to cover him. He felt me, but I don't know how he went down."

A key factor in Derby's new-found obduracy has been their man-mountain Taribo West. With the Nigerian on international duty they buckled after the break; Ince's free-kick found Karembeu, whose perfect cross was headed home by Ugo Ehiogu before Boksic teased Chris Riggott and fired a third beyond Mart Poom.

Ricard's penalty, his first league goal of the season, allowed Boro to score four in the Premiership for the first in 27 months. "It's probably the first time this season that we have been able to enjoy the last few minutes of a game," Ince said. "We looked like a good side. Now we've got to keep believing that."

With the Nigerian on international duty they buckled after the break; Ince's free-kick found Karembeu, whose perfect cross was headed home by Ugo Ehiogu before Boksic teased Chris Riggott and fired a third beyond Mart Poom. webTitle: Dyer's claim is doubly stressed

fields.headline: Dyer's claim is doubly stressed
fields.trailText: If Tord Grip's little book of promising footballers does not already include the name of Kieron Dyer, then England's assistant coach should sharpen his pencil without further delay. Firstly, he must underline Dyer's name at least twice, because he is in invigorating form. But then, to both England's and Newcastle's disquiet, he must add a question mark. These are worrying times.
fields.byline: David Hopps at St James' Park
fields.body:
If Tord Grip's little book of promising footballers does not already include the name of Kieron Dyer, then England's assistant coach should sharpen his pencil without further delay. Firstly, he must underline Dyer's name at least twice, because he is in invigorating form. But then, to both England's and Newcastle's disquiet, he must add a question mark. These are worrying times.

Dyer has not just been the salvation of Newcastle's season; along with such as Beckham, Cole and Gerrard he offers England's new managerial team a midfield quartet of considerable promise. England might be about to get a Grip in more ways than one.

The question mark, though, concerns his recurring shin problems. After witnessing his exhilarating running, it was tempting to suggest that, if he was unfit, the rest of the world must be classified as the walking dead, but Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson viewed the situation much more gravely.

Dyer was absent for two months last season after an operation to free the sheath of his calf muscle. "This is a similar problem," said Robson. "He's been on ice for 24 hours and he just did static warm-ups in the dressing room. He is in a lot of pain and I'm very wary about how it will develop."

But, if Dyer was unfit to play football, then Beethoven was unfit to write symphonies. His electrifying pace and understanding with Nol Solano are a prime reason why Newcastle, stricken by injuries up front and forever shaky in central defence, are seventh in the Premiership. If, as some fear, Dyer is ever sold to finance payments on the main stand, Newcastle's world could come crashing down.

Gary Speed's near-post header from Solano's corner brought Newcastle a fourth-minute lead; Dyer's interchange with Solano enabled Shola Ameobi (a classier version of Paulo Wanchope) to notch his first Newcastle goal after 58 minutes; and then Dyer himself added a third, following another thrilling burst with a crisp finish.

Gordon Strachan, Coventry's manager, praised Dyer as "an exceptional talent; if he had been on our side we would have won easily." Injuries had forced him to switch to an uncommon striker's role but, as Strachan recognised: "When he plays like that, you can hardly suggest he's playing out of position."

While Strachan's pursuit of John Hartson remains in abeyance, Coventry's need for a striker not suffering from Goal Anxiety Syndrome is palpable. With Newcastle's central defensive pairing of Alain Goma and Aaron Hughes vulnerable, Coventry missed half a dozen inviting chances before David Thompson's persistence eventually paid off when his inswinging corner went in off Stephen Glass's ducking head at the far post.

"I've come here with Leeds and Manchester United and not made as many chances as that," bemoaned Strachan.

If those chances do not start going in soon, he might not be coming back with Coventry again.

webTitle: Blank verse for Smith and Graham

fields.headline: Blank verse for Smith and Graham
fields.trailText: The senses of those who stayed in their seats until the most welcome of final whistles echoed through the early-evening gloom had been so dulled by the dubious fare on offer that there was not even a collective will to complain.
fields.body:
The senses of those who stayed in their seats until the most welcome of final whistles echoed through the early-evening gloom had been so dulled by the dubious fare on offer that there was not even a collective will to complain.

True there were isolated jeers and distant cat-calls but, with times so desperately hard for Tottenham on the road and so desperately hard for Everton anywhere, the rival spectators were drawn together and thus united in the belief that, while they had not been entertained, they had at least seen their teams collect something from a match which began slowly and petered out.

Two sides badly depleted by injuries ran gamely through the motions but it was unrewarding tepid stuff, the post-match sight of Tottenham sitting in the top half of the table serving as a reminder that those who would have us believe that the Premiership is the finest league in Europe are fools.

Here was a game Everton should have won at a canter, a sparkling opportunity to stop the rot and place daylight between themselves and those who have been bedevilled by even greater incompetence in recent weeks.

Everton usually fail because they cannot create chances; this time it was their inability to convert eight or so presentable opportunities which proved their undoing.

"I really am disappointed because we did deserve to win the game," said Walter Smith, the manager. "We were always the more likely side and we held sway throughout, both in terms of territorial advantage and possession. It is getting very frustrating because we should have taken more from our recent games. We need a break."

Had Smith chosen to point an accusing finger it would have picked out Kevin Campbell, for the striker missed several chances he would normally have feasted on.

He struck the base of a post and drew the very best out of the Tottenham goalkeeper Neil Sullivan on three other occasions but it was the impotence of those around him - Joe-Max Moore, Niclas Alexandersson, Stephen Hughes et al - which served to make Campbell's uncharacteristic profligacy the afternoon's one abiding memory.

Smith may now decide to join West Ham and Leicester in the chase for Blackburn's £1.8m-rated Christian Dailly as his captain David Weir went off after nine minutes with a calf-muscle injury which may sideline him for five weeks or more.

As for Tottenham, their manager George Graham was grateful for the avoidance of defeat and surprise, surprise, well-nigh ecstatic about their clean sheet.

"Bearing in mind the players we had missing, I'm really delighted," he said. "Just look at what we had on the bench; they only had six league games between them. And [Sergei] Rebrov has been ill all week and really shouldn't have been out there, but we had nobody else.

"In situations like this one I have to seek out the plus points and so, with an away record like ours this season, that really was a good result."

webTitle: The debt football owes to Jimmy Hill

fields.headline: The debt football owes to Jimmy Hill
fields.standfirst: Forty years ago this week, English players won the victory that smashed the limits on their pay.  Frank Keating  recalls the struggle and its consequences
fields.trailText: Wasn't it Queen Mary Tudor who had 'Calais 1558' written on her heart?" asks Jimmy Hill. "Well, when they finally open me up, they'll find 'Ministry of Labour, January 18, 1961' carved on mine."
fields.body:
Wasn't it Queen Mary Tudor who had 'Calais 1558' written on her heart?" asks Jimmy Hill. "Well, when they finally open me up, they'll find 'Ministry of Labour, January 18, 1961' carved on mine."

The good old boy, 73 this summer, still juts his anteater's jaw at you to emphasise every earnest point and opinion - which flow in torrents - and, after each, he breaks into the merry chortles that have always engagingly speckled his sporting progress from £7-a-week Brentford inside-forward to broadcasting eminence.

Wednesday January 18 1961 was as seminal for English professional football as June 1215 was for the English constitution or May 1660 for the English monarchy. On the steps of the ministry that evening, in time to be lead story for the BBC Home Service's seven o'clock Radio Newsreel, the bearded young chairman of the Professional Footballers' Association (by now a stalwart at Fulham) announced that the footballers of England would call off their strike, having successfully won the abolition of the iniquitous maximum wage of £20 a week (£17 in the summer).

Hill made the patriarchal, cigar-chewing Football League president Joe Richards shake hands with him - as well as the Minister of Labour, John Hare, and the chairman of the TUC, Ted Hill - and in no time the pictures of the workers' triumph were circling the world.

Of course, it was not actually as simple as that. The distraught league management committee and its reactionary and apoplectic club chairmen spent the following months prevaricating and repatching the agreement, hedging their bets and going back on their word - but to all intents the slim, athletic (and unlikely) luminary of that cold January evening remained the working-class hero, returning to Fulham to be cheered every time he touched the ball.

By the start of the following season, even the combative league secretary Alan Hardaker was telling his remaining diehard chairmen to pipe down, for they had effectively been routed by Hill and the PFA's impressive realist of a secretary, Cliff Lloyd. Hardaker admitted that Hill's public relations skills had swung the debate decisively a week before that January 18 meeting - and triggered the involvement of a government fearful of having an electorate with no pools coupons to be filled in.

With 344 players from the northern clubs packing the ballroom at Manchester's Grand Hotel, Hill made a stirring call for industrial action on Saturday January 21. Then, on the suggestion of the hawkish Blackburn winger and later Scotland manager, Ally MacLeod, he invited in around 50 waiting journalists to hear him demand: "Is there any man in this room not prepared to strike on Saturday week?"

Remembers Hill, 40 years on: "The unanimous no could have come from the Kop at its loudest." Rheumy eyes bright in reverie of his militant past, the slippered septuagenarian - four wives, five children, double-figures in grandchildren - is now an upright denizen of Surrey's stockbroker belt. He seems hardly to believe it himself.

"I was just a kid really. Of course, I was keen on working-class rights, but I wasn't really what you'd call a political animal. At Brentford I had been collecting the PFA's weekly subs and when they transferred me to Fulham it coincided with their PFA rep Norman Smith giving up the game. So I continued collecting the subs. The only other thing you were expected to do was try and get to the AGM in the summer.

"The first one I attended was in 1956 and for some reason I found myself defending the rather loose-cannon methods of our then chairman, Jimmy Guthrie of Portsmouth. "If our opponents can't stand him he must be doing something right," I said. So as a penalty for not keeping my big trap shut, they promptly elected me to the eight-man committee of management." Within a year, Guthrie had gone and Fulham's Hill was elected PFA chairman.

"I can safely say those extraordinary four years, 1957 to 1961, irrevocably changed my life. Suddenly I was having to argue my case in different parliaments, deal with the media as well as my fellow men in the most delicate matters. A university degree in politics and philosophy couldn't have been more rewarding; the PFA simply gave me a crash course in life and maturity.

"League football had been set in its feudal time warp. January 18 was the watershed, but even in their shell shock the league and its chairmen looked to overturn the agreement. They had spent generations looking down their noses at players and now, even at that meeting at the ministry, they presumed to treat us as inferior beings. Being totally in charge of us was ingrained into their culture. And to find me, not a venerable ex-player but a lad who was still actually playing for a club they controlled, must have been anathema to them."

Not that the young founder of the feast was able to cash in on the PFA's triumph. Fulham in 1961 had a popular and lively side, with Hill, the ungainly but effective Maurice Cook, the clever Graham Leggatt, and the two future internationals, George Cohen and Alan Mullery, all willingly perspiring around the cool captain of England, Johnny Haynes. The chairman was the comedian Tommy Trinder, and, as Hill's battles swirled around that winter, Trinder announced: "Haynes is an entertainer like I am, and if the maximum wage is ever abolished, I will pay him what he is worth, which is £100 a week."

The nation gasped - and, of course, after January 18, Trinder had to fork out. From his home in Scotland, Haynes remembers with a strained smile: "It was just a Trinder publicity stunt really, but when Jimmy had led the troops to victory, Trinder was lumbered. I was into his office with my pen and solicitor's sheet of paper, and a couple of journalists outside, before Trinder could gulp. He had to sign, but I suppose he had the last laugh because I may have been the first £100-a-week player but I played for Fulham another eight years and never got another rise. I was on £100 a week till I packed up."

Hill stayed on £18 a week. He did not play long enough even to negotiate a new contract that September. He had injured his right knee at Luton in January 1960 - when Fulham, lying second in the First Division, had been leading 1-0.

"No substitutes then, and we lost 4-1. Still, we were to finish 10th, still Fulham's highest ever league position. And when my knee was patched up and after all the PFA disputes and triumphs, I was happily back in the first team. But it was only going to be a matter of time."

On March 5 1961, the Sunday Times reported Fulham's 1-0 defeat against Everton: "Brightest spot of the match was the effort of the bearded Hill. Tireless and covering acres of ground, he never gave up till two minutes from the end, trying to force an equaliser, he received a nasty knock."

The "knock" was a severely torn cartilage in the same right knee. It was his last game as a professional. Fulham claimed £10,000 insurance compensation on his injury - and kept it - so seeing as he had been bought from Brentford for £5,000 eight years before, the club made a £5,000 profit on Hill's 277 matches and 41 goals.

The football-mad Boys' Brigade cornet player from Balham, whose first job at 16 had been as a clerk for the London & Lancs insurance company, now prepared for an apprenticeship as a new-fangled "sports agent" with the Bagenal Harvey organisation. That September, however, one of the their clients, the England cricketer Jim Laker, introduced Hill to the chairman of Third Division sluggards Coventry City, Derrick Robins - who suggested lunch at Leamington Spa the next day.

Hill steered Coventry to the First Division before, in 1967, becoming head of sport for London Weekend Television. Six years later, he was headhunted by the BBC, where he continued to point his chin at the nation and vibrantly pontificate on all matters football for more than a quarter of a century until the end of the 1998 World Cup when (like David Coleman) his contract expired and he left with not so much as a note of thanks, private or public.

"Perhaps they lost my address," he says, "but more likely, in terms of manners and common decency, the BBC hierarchy needs some serious tutoring."

Sky Sports now employs the spritely ancient - he has given up riding to hounds but still plays a mean three-setter at tennis - and on Wednesday he can be seen chewing over his great political triumph. Perhaps Sky has located that sepia reel of film from the spring of 1961 of Hill's deadly adversary, Hardaker, indulging in his hobby, fishing for shark off the Cornish coast at Looe. He hauls in a 100-pounder and the boatman gives the poor beast a vicious knobkerrie clout. "Hit it again," demands Hardaker. "It's got a chin like Jimmy Hill."

He chuckles at that. "Hardaker was a tough opponent, all right. I took him out to supper a few years later and he reckoned they would have won easily if only his bosses had offered a deal of, say, a £10 rise and set a new maximum wage at £30. As it was, they let loose a free-for-all.

"Not that I've ever changed my beliefs. The battle we fought was for a player to be free to negotiate for what he was worth with no restrictions. That holds good in 2001, and is nothing to do with the David Beckhams of this world being overpaid - he justifies, earns and deserves his money because a super-wealthy club like Manchester United can happily afford him.

"The stupidity which is rife is that outside the top eight or 10 ultra-rich clubs, there are others demanding, and getting, ludicrous salaries when the clubs simply cannot afford them. Even some Third Division players are on £1,000 a week. For their clubs and directors that just means guaranteeing bank loans and consequent debt, debt, debt. Crazy.

"And then, doing their utmost, they get spat on by the fans for not spending more. I've been a director and chairman of three good, modest clubs - Coventry, Charlton and Fulham - and the abuse you get can be cruel and shameful. I've had a wonderful life, and wouldn't change a moment of it professionally - except that I should never have become a director."

Nice: the old gamekeeper knows, deep down, he should never have jumped the fence; that he should have remained the militant poacher of his youth.

I've been a director and chairman of three good, modest clubs - Coventry, Charlton and Fulham - and the abuse you get can be cruel and shameful. I've had a wonderful life, and wouldn't change a moment of it professionally - except that I should never have become a director." Nice: the old gamekeeper knows, deep down, he should never have jumped the fence; that he should have remained the militant poacher of his youth.

webTitle: So here's to Stan, a true role model

fields.headline: So here's to Stan, a true role model
fields.trailText: As my huge and growing army of followers will be aware, when it comes to slagging off Stan Collymore, this particular professional puts himself very much to the back of the queue. For Darren Tackle, Stan remains very much the man. Organised, together, meticulous in his preparation, this is the man who can leave a club and get the signing-on fee with another one before many of his so-called rivals have even completed their stretching exercises. And he's done it again. He is being shown the door marked exit by his latest club, Bradford, this time before the lettering on his personalised shirt has had time to dry.
fields.body:
As my huge and growing army of followers will be aware, when it comes to slagging off Stan Collymore, this particular professional puts himself very much to the back of the queue. For Darren Tackle, Stan remains very much the man. Organised, together, meticulous in his preparation, this is the man who can leave a club and get the signing-on fee with another one before many of his so-called rivals have even completed their stretching exercises. And he's done it again. He is being shown the door marked exit by his latest club, Bradford, this time before the lettering on his personalised shirt has had time to dry.

And what's he done wrong? Nowt, according to his new manager. Nothing whatsoever, no fire extinguisher scenario, no bird/fist interface, no going AWOL because his old mam had the sniffles. No, face doesn't fit, simple as that. Summat to do with Jim Jefferies being privately appalled by the geezer's work rate or rather total lack thereof.

And what an example to us all Stan offers. Face doesn't fit and he's out. No languishing in the reserves, no months getting bed sores laid up on the bench, no turning up for training and being told to slop out the gaffer's lavs with the YTS kids. Nope, straight out.

So, the Tackle brain being what it is, I is straight on the mobe to Sir Stan seeking information. Advice if you like. How the hell does the geezer manage it? Is it just his game, or can anyone join in? Plus, has he got any of Ulrika's cast-off underwear lying round the house which he could pass on to a deserving cause? And you know what happens when I bells him? No answer. Geezer's too bleedin' lazy to switch his phone on.

Tuesday

Since you ask, not bad thanks. Took the precaution of a little tweak in training which prevented me from have to turn out for the New Year's Day derby, allowing me to spend the night before exploring the possibilities of a new gaff down River Street called the Baa Bar, complete with hill-farming decorative motif. Call it doing my bit to bolster the local economy. Though I didn't pay, obviously.

Faces like mine are there to encourage your ordinary punter, and therefore are not obliged to pick up any sort of tab. Which is what I tried explaining to the bouncer who attempted to stop me leaving the premises without paying up. I think the manager was understanding, but you never know with these non-football types. When I offered him a pair for the Man U game in lieu of your actual financial exchange, he seemed strangely puzzled.

Wednesday

The night in the cells enabled yours truly to catch up with some of the newspaper supplements telling you how to change your lifestyle entering the next decade. Give up smoking, give up the booze, drink water, take exercise, cut out fat. In a nutshell: bollocks. Here, for your delectation etc is the Tackle way to a new you. Especially if you is a woman.

If you're rich and ugly, who do you think they invented plastic surgery for? If you're poor and ugly, who do you think they invented paper bags for? Besides, if you're that bad, stop at home and spare the rest of us the eye-ache.

Thursday

Man U boring or what? That's the other thing the papers is bashing on about, frankly to the point of total tedium. There's Fergie's army winning so easy that the only threat to their title comes from Tiger Woods. Or I think that's what the article says.

Course they is bleedin' boring. Automatons, machine men, not a decent drinking head among them. There's only one answer to that particular new year conundrum: me old mate Stanley. Sign him and make them interesting again all in one neat little parcel. It's about the only chance the rest of us have.
