webTitle: Uefa look to legal move over transfers

fields.headline: Uefa look to legal move over transfers
fields.trailText: The rift between Fifa and Uefa will widen significantly this morning if football's world governing body does not comply with Uefa's request to withdraw proposals to reform the transfer system lodged with the European Commission last week.
fields.body:
The rift between Fifa and Uefa will widen significantly this morning if football's world governing body does not comply with Uefa's request to withdraw proposals to reform the transfer system lodged with the European Commission last week.

The European leagues are due to meet in Switzerland at 10.30am to discuss their reaction to Fifa's effective termination of joint negotiations with the European governing body, Uefa, over the future of the transfer system. They describe the plans Fifa has submitted as being "unacceptable".

Uefa has demanded that Fifa inform the commission that it has scrapped the document by the time the meeting begins this morning. If Fifa refuses to, the leagues will discuss taking action to ensure that they bypass Fifa and put forward separate proposals.

"If Fifa does not withdraw its document, we will need to consider with the leagues what steps need to be taken," a spokesman for Uefa said last night. "One option is that of a legal intervention that will allow direct negotiation with the EC."

This would involve Uefa or the European leagues making a formal intervention in the commission's transfer discussions and registering itself as an interested party.

At present, the commission officially holds all its talks with Fifa as it governs all world transfer regulations. Such a move by the European leagues would force the commission to allow European football to have a seat at the table and express its views, which differ from Fifa's in several key areas.

Among the proposals that Uefa finds unacceptable are that which allows any player to terminate his contract with a club if he has "just sporting cause". This would let a player give three months' notice if he disagreed with his club over tactics or formations.

"If this were allowed to happen, it would kill the game as we know it," said David Dein, the vice-chairman of Arsenal and the Football Association at the weekend. "It's totally impractical and unworkable. The sport would simply become unmanageable and I simply don't understand the rationale. It will make the chasm with Uefa wider than ever before."

Fifa's spokesman Keith Cooper said last night that the request to withdraw the negotiation document was being given urgent priority and would be discussed early this morning by high-ranking officials.

He added that any talk of a Uefa breakaway would be damaging for world football. "A breakaway clearly has to be taken seriously. We have to bear in mind that Fifa is responsible for transfers on a global scale and any form of breakaway would not solve the problems. We have to see this as a world issue."

webTitle: From: Margaret and Harry (13 Jan)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Margaret and Harry
fields.trailText: Sorry to hear you missed the night safari in Singapore; it really is the best of its type. Hope the legs have recovered, you will need them again when you get to South America.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

It seems a long, long time ago when my wife Margaret and I were your airborn companions from Heathrow to Mumbai. We have followed your adventure with great interest since our return from our cruise holiday, which incidentally was excellent. Sorry to hear you missed the night safari in Singapore; it really is the best of its type, and not to be missed. Hope the legs have recovered, you will need them again when you get to South America. Will be in touch later in your epic adventure.

Regards,

Margaret and Harry Northmore

webTitle: 'Neighbourhood managers' to boost run-down areas

fields.headline: 'Neighbourhood managers' to boost run-down areas
fields.trailText: England's poorest areas are set to gain new "neighbourhood managers" charged with ensuring communities get the best deal out of the government's regeneration and funding programmes.
fields.body:
England's poorest areas are set to gain new "neighbourhood managers" charged with ensuring communities get the best deal out of the government's regeneration and funding programmes.

Ministers believe that resources are not being well used in many areas, and that advocates who are accountable to their local communities can help direct funds to where they are most needed.

The managers will also be charged with helping local organisations such as the NHS, police force and local councils tailor their work to meet the needs of residents, who ministers say are too often let down by service providers.

The move is part of an action plan that the government today promised would turn the country's worst neighbourhoods around within the next two decades.

The plan proposes a combination of investment, service targets in areas such as housing, education and unemployment, and better coordination of government services through partnerships between local people.

Prime minister Tony Blair said: "Too many people in deprived neighbourhoods lead lives blighted by joblessness, high crime levels, run down housing and poor health and education. We need to narrow the gap which separates their communities from the rest of society."

The government is investing £45m over the next three years to employ the neighbourhood managers. More than 80 councils will be able to apply to take part in the scheme by identifying neighbourhoods, and developing strategies to improve them.

They have been selected because they contain more than one ward ranked among the 10% most deprived in England and do not already benefit from new deal for communities aid. It is likely that some neighbourhood managers will be recruited from local government. They will each cover areas of up to 5,000 households.

The Conservatives, while not opposed to the measure, said the policy was an attempt to "paper over the cracks" of the government's failure to rejuvenate deprived areas. A spokesman said: "This is no substitute for effective policing."

The proposals are underpinned by the government's concept of "local strategic partnerships" - aimed at bringing residents, community groups and service providers together to focus attention on areas in need.

Ministers will back these partnerships by making £36m available to community groups to help them take part and £50m in small-scale grants to promote community action.

However, only groups in the 88 areas already earmarked for support from the government's £800m neighbourhood renewal fund will be able to benefit from the £50m.

The government claims the plan will:

 Ensure no area has burglary rates three times higher than the national average by 2005;

 Ensure at least 25% of pupils in every school and 38% in every local authority achieve five or more GCSEs at grades A* to C;

 Eliminate substandard housing by 2010, and reduce it by a third by 2004;

 Narrow health inequality (exact target to be set later); and

 Raise employment in the 30 areas with the worst labour market problems and narrow the gap between these and the overall rate.

webTitle: Weights and measures

fields.headline: Weights and measures
fields.standfirst: A Sunderland grocer is fighting for the right to use the imperial system. Is Britain selling out to Brussels by the pound? Simon Jeffery explains
fields.trailText: A Sunderland grocer is fighting for the right to use the imperial system. Is Britain selling out to Brussels by the pound? We explain.
fields.body:
Does it really matter which units we use to buy and sell food?
Yes. Weights and measures, like a currency, are standardised to ease trade across a single market and enforced by law to stop grocers and brewers (for example) selling less than they should.

Who decides?
An agreement to set up a national system of weights and measures was first contained in the Magna Carta (1215). Almost 800 years later, during which time the units changed considerably, Britain's entry into the European economic community was accompanied by an adoption of the metric gram and kilogram alongside the imperial pound and ounce.

So which should we use?
From January 1 2000 it has been illegal to sell goods in imperial measures. The European Union's 1994 Units of Measurements Regulations set up a common system across Europe's single market. But Steven Thoburn, a fruit and vegetable seller from Sunderland, is to go before court claiming the UK parliament's 1985 Weights and Measures Act gives him the right to use the imperial system.

Can traders make up their own measures?
Almost. Some goods, such as bananas or cauliflower, are allowed to be sold by number. Others such as radishes, spring onions and carrots can be sold by the bunch. However, if a customer asks for an imperial measure, the trader has to remind them he cannot legally sell half a pound of potatoes and offer a metric alternative.

Why the fuss?
There are two reasons. Firstly, a kilogram is heavier than a pound so the goods look more expensive (though a trader can advertise his price per 100g.) Secondly, many consider the replacement of imperial measures with the metric system a dreadful imposition from Brussels and wish to retain the older system.

How old is it?
The imperial system, though its origins go back to the middle ages, was codified in 1824 under the reign of George IV. His successor Victoria reigned over its last refinement in 1878.

How long has Britain been using the metric system?
The metric system was first legalised for scientific use in 1864. In 1871 the House of Commons proposed to make metric the only legal system for all purposes, but the proposal was defeated by only five votes. The government established the metrication board in 1969, to help industry go metric in an orderly fashion by 1975. The board was dissolved in 1980 by the Tories.

Where else uses the metric system?
Almost every country in the world, with the exception of the United States, Liberia and Burma. Britain is still not entirely metric - beer and milk are still legally sold in pints.

webTitle: Britain gives £600,000 to earthquake-stricken El Salvador

fields.headline: Britain gives £600,000 to earthquake-stricken El Salvador
fields.standfirst: Graphic: where the quake struck
fields.trailText: Britain has committed more than £600,000 to the rescue effort in earthquake-hit El Salvador, junior international development minister George Foulkes announced today.
fields.body:
Britain has committed more than £600,000 to the rescue effort in earthquake-hit El Salvador, junior international development minister George Foulkes announced today.

He stressed during an emergency statement that the government will "respond sympathetically" to further requests for assistance.

The disaster has claimed the lives of 400 people since Saturday. Many of them have been buried in mass graves.

Authorities said a landslide that wiped out entire families had made it impossible to know the identities of many who died.

Two more people have been found alive, including a small child and a young man whose cellular phone call alerted authorities to his location.

"We always have hope that someone can be found alive, but we have to acknowledge that there is less possibility of finding life," said mayor Oscar Ortiz of Santa Tecla

More than 1,300 people are still missing, many of them in the country's capital San Salvador. An appeal has been made to neighbouring Colombia for 3,000 coffins.

Mr Foulkes urged members of the public who wanted to support the rescue efforts to donate money to Oxfam, the Red Cross and other organisations working in the region.

The Department for International Development's emergency response centre had been operating 24 hours a day since the disaster, said Mr Foulkes. The Royal Navy's West Indies guard ship was not in the area and could not go immediately to El Salvador, he added.

webTitle: Breakthrough in pay dispute

fields.headline: Breakthrough in pay dispute
fields.trailText: Hopes of an end to the lecturers' pay and conditions dispute which has hit exam results for 50,000 students rose this week as vice-chancellors were consulted over a possible deal.
fields.body:
Hopes of an end to the lecturers' pay and conditions dispute which has hit exam results for 50,000 students rose this week as vice-chancellors were consulted over a possible deal.

The potential breakthrough still only involves talks about talks but both sides seem cautiously optimistic that a solution can be thrashed out. In the mean time they are staying tightlipped.

A statement issued after last week's meeting between the Universities and Colleges Employers Association and staff unions said there had been exploratory discussions about the dispute and the proposals of the Bett report into pay and conditions in higher education. (The report is particularly critical of the poor equal opportunities record in universities.)

"Both sides agreed to consult urgently within their own organisations and will be meeting again (on 6 February) once those consultations are completed."

The dispute which also involves administrative and manual staff in universities and colleges of higher education broke out when talks became bogged down over the question of national conditions.

Members of the lecturers' union Natfhe have been withholding exam and assessment marks from students at the new universities. Clerical and manual workers are refusing overtime. Trade unions are expected to suspend their action if talks are resumed.

Tom Wilson, the union's higher education secretary, said more than 50,000 students had been affected, particularly nurses and those doing subjects allied to medicine. In many institutions local deals had been negotiated to allow nurses back onto hospital wards as ancilliaries, with pay to be backdated when their qualifications were confirmed.

The action by 17,000 lecturers was "causing mayhem", claimed Wilson. This view was dismissed by the employers but they are anxious not to let the dispute drag on into the main exam season in the summer. Vice-chancellors are now being consulted on whether they want detailed talks on pay and conditions over the next two years to go ahead.

"Both sides agreed to consult urgently within their own organisations and will be meeting again (on 6 February) once those consultations are completed." The dispute which also involves administrative and manual staff in universities and colleges of higher education broke out when talks became bogged down over the question of national conditions. Members of the lecturers' union Natfhe have been withholding exam and assessment marks from students at the new universities. Clerical and manual workers are refusing overtime. Trade unions are expected to suspend their action if talks are resumed. Tom Wilson, the union's higher education secretary, said more than 50,000 students had been affected, particularly nurses and those doing subjects allied to medicine. In many institutions local deals had been negotiated to allow nurses back onto hospital wards as ancilliaries, with pay to be backdated when their qualifications were confirmed. The action by 17,000 lecturers was "causing mayhem", claimed Wilson. This view was dismissed by the employers but they are anxious not to let the dispute drag on into the main exam season in the summer. Vice-chancellors are now being consulted on whether they want detailed talks on pay and conditions over the next two years to go ahead.

webTitle: Chief executive resigns over bodies scandal

fields.headline: Chief executive resigns over bodies scandal
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the hospital at the centre of the "bodies in the chapel" scandal has resigned, just hours after an official inquiry was launched.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the hospital at the centre of the "bodies in the chapel" scandal has resigned, just hours after an official inquiry was launched.

Ken Williams, chief executive of Bedford Hospital, quit as NHS officials began to investigate why dead bodies were stored in a Chapel of Rest at the hospital after mortuaries became too full.

It is unclear whether NHS officials put pressure on Mr Williams to go after a day of damaging and embarrassing press reports.

Health secretary Alan Milburn was reported to have "hit the roof" when the stories appeared, while NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp called the situation "entirely unnaceptable".

Mr Williams had initially put out statement apologising to relatives and said the incident "would not happen again".

But a statement put out later this evening said that he had resigned.

NHS investigators said they would be interviewing the clinicians and managers who were responsible for deciding to use the Chapel of Rest as a temporary mortuary. Their report is expected to be complete before the end of the week.

Peter Houghton, regional director of NHS eastern region, said: "The preliminary investigation shows that this was a failure of management in general and that no individual member of staff acted against management guidance.

"The chief executive Ken Williams has discussed the findings of the investigation with the chairman of the trust, Prof Andrew Blowers, and myself, and felt it right to stand down. I respect that decision."

The chapel is normally used for laying out a body in a coffin for viewing by relatives.

A spokeswoman for the hospital said staff were dealing with complaints from relatives of people who had died recently and whose bodies might have been pictured in the Chapel of Rest.

"This situation arose because the mortuary was full to capacity and the refrigeration unit that we use as a temporary mortuary had broken down," she said.

"As I understand it the Chapel of Rest was used on a number of days last week. Up to eight bodies were laid out in the chapel. None for more than 24-hours."

She disputed the accusation that Bedford was a "third world hospital" and said it performed well in most departments.

webTitle: Comment: violence tarnishes Barak's re-election prospects

fields.headline: Violence tarnishes Barak's re-election prospects
fields.standfirst:
The latest deaths, of a Jewish settler and a Palestinian boy, almost certainly spell the end of the Israeli prime minister's hopes of winning a second term, says Derek Brown

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The latest deaths, of a Jewish settler and a Palestinian boy, almost certainly spell the end of Ehud Barak's hopes of re-election as Israeli prime minister, says Derek Brown
fields.body:
The string on the Middle East peace yo-yo has again been snapped by gunfire. A Jewish settler has been murdered; a nine-year-old Palestinian boy has died of bullet wounds. Against the tenuous promise of endless negotiations, these are the latest savage realities.

Israel seemingly has no response to Palestinian violence, save more violence. The Palestinians, utterly devoid of effective defences, offer only more desperate protests.

In 16 weeks 366 lives have been lost, according to the running tally kept by news agencies. All but 45 of the dead have been Palestinians. But that imbalance cuts no ice in a society like Israel, which abominates the loss of Jewish life and regrets the deaths of others.

That is why the Israeli army has renewed and redoubled its siege of the Gaza Strip, where the body of 34-year-old Jewish settler Ronni Tsalah was found this morning. He had been shot dead after being abducted from settlement hothouses where he grew tomatoes with the aid of local Palestinian workers.

Already, Israeli leaders have blamed Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority. President Moshe Katsav has described the murder as "barbaric behavior that proves that the Palestinians are not serious about their intentions to attain peace with us".

Prime minister Ehud Barak has pledged: "The murderers will not get away with it; Israel's long arm will reach them and they will be duly punished, as has been done with those responsible for previous attacks against Israeli soldiers and civilians."

It's already happening. Around a million Gazans are being collectively punished. Their seedy, impoverished territory has been effectively carved into four pieces. All entry and exit is barred by Israeli troops. The border with Egypt is tightly sealed and the airport is closed.

Palestinians too have responded to the new gout of blood. They have fired anti-tank rounds at an Israeli strongpoint without effect. They have caused a frisson of fear in the Neveh Ya'acov Jewish neighbourhood of occupied East Jerusalem by firing a volley of shots into it. Tempers in Ramallah are likely to be white-hot this afternoon, which sees the funeral of a nine-year-old boy shot in the head by Israeli fire nine days ago.

Palestinian militants are speaking of holding a "day of rage" this Friday to mark the death in clashes of a Fatah activist whose body was dragged through the streets of Hebron by Israeli paramilitary forces, then allegedly spat on by onlooking settlers.

The blood-crazed mood in the Palestinian territories was underlined by the weekend public executions of two alleged collaborators, condemned out of hand and blown away by firing squads in front of cheering crowds.

So it goes on: systematic repression on the one hand and incoherent rage on the other. The savage irony is that even as fingers were tightening on triggers, Israel and the Palestinians were edging ever closer to a momentous new understanding.

Former prime minister Shimon Peres had talks with Arafat on Saturday night - the most significant meeting by far in the last few months of dreary shadowboxing by more junior officials. Senior negotiators were due to meet again this morning, and security officials from both sides were also expected to hold urgent talks on how to improve the situation.

All that is gone; evaporated by the new violence. For Barak, the renewed confrontation almost certainly spells the end of his crumbling hopes of retaining power in next month's direct prime ministerial election. Already, he is limping far behind his hawkish rightwing challenger Ariel Sharon in the opinion polls.

His own party is deeply divided, with a sizeable component urging the adoption of Peres as a more credible candidate. Israel's sizeable Arab minority, which voted overwhelmingly for Barak in the 1999 election, is disaffected and disillusioned and there is every chance that it will boycott the February 6 poll.

Barak cannot hope to play the security card, which is already held by the bellicose Sharon. But having failed to bring off the peace, he will be tempted to unleash the dogs of war.

webTitle: From: Chloe (15 Jan)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Chloe
fields.trailText: When you're in Kenya, visit Hell's Gate National Park - it's really fun to cycle round (it's one of the few parks where you can do that), but you need to get there early to see any animals.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

I am contacting you with info about places to go in East Africa. I am a volunteer in Kenya so all my suggestions are bargin basement ones!

Nairobi is a dump, and a dangerous dump at that - well, its not that bad, but don't walk around after dark or carry money anywhere obvious. There's not much to do there - although the Giraffe Centre is nice, as you can feed them!

The coast is lovely and very hot most of the time. I like Mombasa - it seems like a nice town to wander round. I always stay on Diani Beach at a place called Diani Beachalets - it's in the rough guide - but I have heard that Bamburi and Malindi are also really nice.

The other side of the country is where I live; however, there is nothing to see where I am as it's somewhat off the tourist trail! Kisumu is a nice relaxed town on the shore of Lake Victoria, but again there's not a whole lot of tourist stuff to do - it depends what you're after. Kakamega rainforest is not too far from there - we stay at a place called Udo's camp (you need a sleeping bag but can stay in huts with beds). I really love the forest; the sun rising over the mist in the trees and the sound of birds and monkeys is something else.

Apparently Mount Elgon, which is a bit further north, is also really nice. Lakes Baringo and Bagoria are also nice and the scenery on the way there is amazing, but they are a long way from anywhere. Lake Naivasha is also nice - we stay at Fisherman's Camp (you can hire bedding as well as a hut). You can get to Hell's Gate National Park from there - it's really fun to cycle round, as it's one of the few parks where you can do that, but you need to get there early to see any animals. Mount Logonot and Crater Lake are also nearby.

I have done a safari to the Masai Mara which I really enjoyed - you see so many animals really close up.

I can't think of any thing else at the moment - hopefully this will keep you going! I will email again if I have any blinding flashes of inspiration. If you want to let me know your plans we could possibly meet up.

I seem to have used the word nice a lot - sorry!

webTitle: Wales offers £20m lifeline to Corus

fields.headline: Wales offers £20m lifeline to Corus
fields.standfirst: Climate levy concessions seek to rescue Llanwern plant
fields.trailText: 15 February: The government and the national assembly for Wales are preparing special concessions to steel group Corus over the climate change levy as part of a package worth up to £20m to help keep open the Llanwern plant near Newport, Gwent.
fields.body:
The government and the national assembly for Wales are preparing special concessions to steel group Corus over the climate change levy as part of a package worth up to £20m to help keep open the Llanwern plant near Newport, Gwent.

This emerged over the weekend as a new study warned that more than 2,000 of Britain's heavy industrial firms face a near-£100m hit from the levy, which takes effect on April 1.

Corus, the Anglo-Dutch group, employs around 32,000 in Britain but has set in train 4,700 redundancies and is planning a further round of job losses and closures, possibly including Llanwern, to staunch losses on its UK carbon steel operations. These are likely to have been some £500m last year.

The Department of Trade and Industry and the national assembly are drawing up a package of aid to Corus, one of the groups facing the heaviest charges under the climate change levy, to alleviate its costs.

The package, worth between £10m and £20m and designed to escape European Union challenges over illegal state aid, would include grants to improve the environment around the south Wales plant which employs around 3,000 people.

Llanwern is the Corus plant most vulnerable to closure under the restructuring plan due to be announced by Sir Brian Moffat, the steel group's chairman and acting chief executive, within the next few weeks. Its closure would be damaging to Labour in the run-up to a general election in May.

Under the package being drawn up by Rhodri Morgan, first minister, and his deputy, Mike German, a Liberal Democrat, with DTI ministers, the national assembly would also buy up surplus land around the plant, ease or defer business rates, help finance research and development, and offer training grants.

Senior assembly sources accepted yesterday that the package might not be enough to deter Corus from shedding jobs at the south Wales plant but could help prevent complete closure.

Their argument has been buttressed by the recent strengthening of the euro which, Mr German estimates, has cut Corus's expected losses this year from £350m to £150m.

Last week the Engineering Employers Federation said many manufacturing firms were now increasing exports to mainland Europe despite a squeeze on prices and margins.

But the EEF warned last night that the climate change levy would cost 2,300 firms with an annual energy bill above £100,000 a net £82m even after taking into account the 0.3% cut in national insurance contributions on offer.

The EEF said the levy would damage competitiveness, prevent companies investing in energy efficiency and penalise those willing to sign challenging efficiency agreements.

The EEF, which wants the Treasury to allow more firms to sign agreements in return for a cut in the levy, said that, if only half of the 2,300 signed up, carbon dioxide emissions would be cut by 1.5m tonnes.

Martin Temple, director general, said: "We have never opposed the need for action on climate change but believe the levy to be one of the mostly badly designed economic instruments in recent times.

"We fail to understand why the Treasury, having accepted the reliability of our data, will not accept alternative proposals which would be of greater benefit to the environment while supporting the competitiveness of manufacturing companies."

webTitle: Madeleine Bunting: When voters aren't happy

fields.headline: When voters aren't happy
fields.standfirst: We're richer, healthier and safer than we've ever been. But it still doesn't add up to a cheerier society
fields.trailText: We're richer, healthier and safer than we've ever been. But it still doesn't add up to a cheerier society
fields.body:
Numbers, numbers, numbers. The election is looming and with it comes a tide of numbers for us to get our heads round. Economic growth, unemployment, tax cuts: the accepted wisdom is that numbers win or lose elections. If a government gets those numbers right, adds a few emotive themes about yobs and asylum seekers - Bob's your uncle, you've got another five years.

But bubbling away beneath these shibboleths of the political establishment, a radical rethink is gaining ground. Broadly summed up, it argues that happiness is a political issue. The Americans put happiness at the heart of their constitution. Jeremy Bentham's guiding principle was "the greatest happiness of the greatest number". Then happiness dropped out of political debate. Nineteenth-century liberalism rigorously divided up what were issues of public concern and those that could be left to private deliberation. It was up to the individual whether you did or didn't find happiness. It was no business of the state.

But that's wearing thin now. Can the state afford to ignore happiness? Five million people a year have some sort of depression-related illness that justifies medical intervention; that's a big bill for the NHS. A survey by the Mental Health Foundation, published last week, found that one in four adults suffers from depression and among students, the proportion has shot up to more than half. Stress levels, according to the economist Andrew Oswald, soared in the 90s, particularly among public-sector workers, leading to Britain having one of the lowest job-satisfaction rates - 36% - in the world. The links to lost days of work, decline in productivity and the exponential rise of those on sickness benefit are all self-evident.

The cost of unhappiness is one of the reasons economists have begun to take happiness seriously. One of the most popular sessions at the annual American Economists Association, which finished last week in New Orleans, was all about the economics of happiness. Professor Oswald cites two other conferences on the same subject in the last year, and argues that it's the new big idea, a dramatic challenge to traditional politics.

"The most important thing expected of governments is to make us richer. But we're now so rich in historical terms that for the normal man or woman, more BMWs or beefburgers are not going to transform the quality of their lives. Material things don't make a difference." Economists can now talk about happiness, Oswald claims, because they now have reliable data on people's sense of well-being and life satisfaction going back 30 years. Over that period, our living standards have increased dramatically, but it hasn't made us happier. Oswald's research shows that rates of happiness in the UK have been absolutely static and have plunged in America.

Depending on which research you plump for, we're either getting more miserable or staying the same; either could throw some light on our political culture of declining voter turnouts and party membership, and its profound cynicism. Doesn't it also begin to make some sense of the prevalent "whatever I vote won't make any difference, they're all the same" attitudes among voters? Such attitudes baffle and frustrate the government, prompting them to ever more attempts to get "their message across". But the message doesn't get through; this attitude is peculiarly impervious to any demonstration of facts, such as increased public spending or economic growth. It's a profoundly emotional reaction not susceptible to debate and persuasion. Election victory on May 3 for Tony Blair will not be a positive endorsement so much as a gesture of resignation, and even in some quarters, of despair.

Into this territory come two new wonderfully subversive books. Firstly, David Boyle has taken on our Gradgrind obsession with measurement in The Tyranny of Numbers, Why Counting Can't Make Us Happy. We love measuring and statistics because it offers the illusion of control but, Boyle asserts, "the closer you get to measuring what's really important, the more it escapes you. Because number-crunching brings a kind of blindness with it. When we measure life, we reduce it." He refers to EF Schumacher's argument in Small Is Beautiful, that cost-benefit analysis was destroying civilisation because it concentrated on differences in quantity while suppressing differences in quality. Boyle warns that, because of our desire to measure, "we are now in a world that is designed to be measured, that praises and promotes people with hard measuring skills and downgrades those with human imaginative ones". The result, he writes, is that "Things that can't be measured - love, creativity, awe, religion, altruism - get forgotten ... and sometimes get ridiculed too."

Boyle describes the unhappy pickle we've got ourselves into, rather than offering how we get out of it. The latter challenge is one taken up with relish by the second book, Politics On the Couch by Andrew Samuels. This is a hugely ambitious bid to recast political debate by a Jungian psychotherapist who explores how to reconnect the private, personal experience to the public realm. He challenges the 19th-century liberal division between public and private, arguing that the compartmentalisation makes no sense for individuals or society. Too many political issues are both; deeply emotional experiences, but influenced by and affecting society. Family policy is an obvious example, but so is equal opportunities, as it reflects the ambivalent and fraught issue of gender. So also is the environment, which, he claims, drawing from his clinical experience, has become a cause of profound anxiety. So is happiness, which is why he proposes a national emotional audit. Could such a suggestion find its way into Yvette Cooper's election manifesto in 2009?

Samuels is bidding to drag psychotherapy back to its original ambition as conceived by Freud and Jung, not just to treat the neuroses of the individual but to grapple with the whole society, its politics and its organisation. His thesis is profoundly optimistic, arguing that the radical, reforming, idealistic political passions have not disappeared but gone underground into myriad personal projects, from alternative lifestyles and organic farming to personal development through psychotherapy. Reconnect these private endeavours to the public realm and it will be the source of renewal. The great illusion of the neo-liberal free marketeers that needs to be shattered is that of our individualistic separateness. What we need is a reappreciation of our connectedness - and of its political, emotional and spiritual elements. So he describes how you put the emotional and spiritual into politics, and the political back into the private.

Both books challenge the rigidity of conventional politics with its unquestioned assumptions about what is and isn't possible, and accuse it of a failure of collective imagination. Many will argue back that happiness only becomes a political issue for someone when they have a job. True. Happiness is part of a new political terrain: let's call it the politics of depressed affluence. It's for when our economy is growing, and unemployment falling and we can afford to shift the focus from how to make two-thirds of society richer than ever before to how to achieve the greatest happiness of the greatest number - meeting emotional and needs as well as material ones. Then we start debating trust, morale, satisfaction, fulfilment and what it is that makes us happy.

The cost of unhappiness is one of the reasons economists have begun to take happiness seriously. One of the most popular sessions at the annual American Economists Association, which finished last week in New Orleans, was all about the economics of happiness. Professor Oswald cites two other conferences on the same subject in the last year, and argues that it's the new big idea, a dramatic challenge to traditional politics. "The most important thing expected of governments is to make us richer. But we're now so rich in historical terms that for the normal man or woman, more BMWs or beefburgers are not going to transform the quality of their lives. Material things don't make a difference." Economists can now talk about happiness, Oswald claims, because they now have reliable data on people's sense of well-being and life satisfaction going back 30 years. Over that period, our living standards have increased dramatically, but it hasn't made us happier. Oswald's research shows that rates of happiness in the UK have been absolutely static and have plunged in America. Depending on which research you plump for, we're either getting more miserable or staying the same; either could throw some light on our political culture of declining voter turnouts and party membership, and its profound cynicism. Doesn't it also begin to make some sense of the prevalent "whatever I vote won't make any difference, they're all the same" attitudes among voters? Such attitudes baffle and frustrate the government, prompting them to ever more attempts to get "their message across". But the message doesn't get through; this attitude is peculiarly impervious to any demonstration of facts, such as increased public spending or economic growth. It's a profoundly emotional reaction not susceptible to debate and persuasion. Election victory on May 3 for Tony Blair will not be a positive endorsement so much as a gesture of resignation, and even in some quarters, of despair. Into this territory come two new wonderfully subversive books. Firstly, David Boyle has taken on our Gradgrind obsession with measurement in The Tyranny of Numbers, Why Counting Can't Make Us Happy. We love measuring and statistics because it offers the illusion of control but, Boyle asserts, "the closer you get to measuring what's really important, the more it escapes you. Because number-crunching brings a kind of blindness with it. When we measure life, we reduce it." He refers to EF Schumacher's argument in Small Is Beautiful, that cost-benefit analysis was destroying civilisation because it concentrated on differences in quantity while suppressing differences in quality. Boyle warns that, because of our desire to measure, "we are now in a world that is designed to be measured, that praises and promotes people with hard measuring skills and downgrades those with human imaginative ones". The result, he writes, is that "Things that can't be measured - love, creativity, awe, religion, altruism - get forgotten ... and sometimes get ridiculed too." Boyle describes the unhappy pickle we've got ourselves into, rather than offering how we get out of it. The latter challenge is one taken up with relish by the second book, Politics On the Couch by Andrew Samuels. This is a hugely ambitious bid to recast political debate by a Jungian psychotherapist who explores how to reconnect the private, personal experience to the public realm. He challenges the 19th-century liberal division between public and private, arguing that the compartmentalisation makes no sense for individuals or society. Too many political issues are both; deeply emotional experiences, but influenced by and affecting society. Family policy is an obvious example, but so is equal opportunities, as it reflects the ambivalent and fraught issue of gender. So also is the environment, which, he claims, drawing from his clinical experience, has become a cause of profound anxiety. So is happiness, which is why he proposes a national emotional audit. Could such a suggestion find its way into Yvette Cooper's election manifesto in 2009? Samuels is bidding to drag psychotherapy back to its original ambition as conceived by Freud and Jung, not just to treat the neuroses of the individual but to grapple with the whole society, its politics and its organisation. His thesis is profoundly optimistic, arguing that the radical, reforming, idealistic political passions have not disappeared but gone underground into myriad personal projects, from alternative lifestyles and organic farming to personal development through psychotherapy. Reconnect these private endeavours to the public realm and it will be the source of renewal. The great illusion of the neo-liberal free marketeers that needs to be shattered is that of our individualistic separateness. What we need is a reappreciation of our connectedness - and of its political, emotional and spiritual elements. So he describes how you put the emotional and spiritual into politics, and the political back into the private. Both books challenge the rigidity of conventional politics with its unquestioned assumptions about what is and isn't possible, and accuse it of a failure of collective imagination. Many will argue back that happiness only becomes a political issue for someone when they have a job. True. Happiness is part of a new political terrain: let's call it the politics of depressed affluence. It's for when our economy is growing, and unemployment falling and we can afford to shift the focus from how to make two-thirds of society richer than ever before to how to achieve the greatest happiness of the greatest number - meeting emotional and needs as well as material ones. Then we start debating trust, morale, satisfaction, fulfilment and what it is that makes us happy. madeleine.bunting@theguardian.com

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Election pledges are hostages to fortune

fields.headline: Promises, promises. I distrust them
fields.standfirst: Empty election pledges are little more than hostages to fortune
fields.trailText: Empty election pledges are little more than hostages to fortune
fields.body:
Almost exactly 30 years ago, Richard Crossman gave the Godkin lectures at Harvard University and made the then original suggestion that election manifestos should be designed not to impress the voters before polling day but to intimidate civil servants afterwards. Crossman's experience of government had begun in the Ministry of Housing, where he had enjoyed an ambivalent relationship with Dame Evelyn Sharpe, his permanent secretary. "The Dame", as he called her, possessed the sort of brutal intellect that Crossman much admired. But he resented her using it to demonstrate that some of his aspirations were unattainable. He thought that he could always win the argument if it ended with him saying: "But we promised."

The theory is not quite as bizarre as it first seems. Back in 1950 all the "experts" told the Conservative policy makers that it was impossible to build more than 200,000 houses in a year. That was what they proposed to promise at the election. But delegates to the annual conference - many of whom could not distinguish between a bricklayer and the old Queen's birthday - thought the target lacked ambition. Lord Woolton, the party chairman, capitulated. The Tory manifesto promised 300,000 houses. "Out of the question," said the civil servants. "But we promised," replied Harold Macmillan, the new minister. The promise was kept.

The story adds to my bewilderment about why, if there is a May election, New Labour will not have fulfilled two of the five promises that appeared on its ridiculous "pledge card". Was there no one in the Home Office or Department for Education who considered the possibility of an early election? And were civil servants not told that the time spent by young offenders in the criminal justice system had to be halved and infant school class sizes had to be cut to under 30 to avoid any possible argument about failure to deliver? One explanation for the otherwise inexplicable behaviour is the subconscious feeling that the promises should not have been made in the first place.

The idea of five key pledges - precise promises complete with exact dates and specific numbers - never had much to do with the honourable doctrine of the manifesto and mandate. It was, in the best tradition of commercial advertising, a gimmick devised to give an impression of moderation and administrative self-confidence - even to voters who could not remember what the five pledges were. John Prescott could remember only four of them when he was commending the pledge card to a Labour conference. So it is unlikely that a harassed mother of twins, rushing into the polling booth on the way home from the shops, thought: "If I vote Labour, NHS waiting lists will be cut by 100,000 before 2002 and the young jobless will fall by 250,000." Nor was she expected to do so. She was meant to think that Tony Blair was not one of those politicians who promise too much and then fail to deliver.

The irony of Labour's present predicament (following a week of allegations that the government cannot be trusted) is that the impression it hoped to create in 1997 was an accurate picture of its true character. The party was determined not to promise more than it could deliver. Its aspirations were both achievable and modest. Indeed, to add paradox to irony, if the government "fails" to fulfil two of the five pledges, that will be because ministers aspired to do too little. Because they feared to exceed the spending plans they had inherited from the Tories, the whole programme was prejudiced for more than two years.

No sensible person would complain that the government will be four months late cutting class sizes and court waiting time. But we do not live in a sensible political climate. Politics has become an argument about images and impression. And the government must take some of the responsibility for reducing the political debate to niggles about which party would most successfully implement the consensus. Each of the five "pledges" related to an initiative that everyone supported. If Labour had promised to raise income tax to finance an improved health service, last week's debate would have been considerably more elevated.

The one bonus that might result from last week's unedifying squabble is a decision by the New Labour leadership to write a different sort of manifesto for the next election. The document's essential purpose is to make clear whose side the party is on. That is the only way in which voters can judge how a government will behave in the unforeseen circumstances that change the course of every parliament. The promise to achieve universally agreed aims more efficiently than the alternative management is proper response to a hostile take-over bid. Politicians should aim higher.

Roy.Hattersley@ukgateway.net

webTitle: Hague says Tories will win shock victory

fields.headline: Hague says Tories will win shock victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: An imperturbable William Hague yesterday brushed aside fresh opinion poll gloom for the Tories and predicted that he would come from behind, as Edward Heath did in 1970, and win the general election expected in May.
fields.body:
An imperturbable William Hague yesterday brushed aside fresh opinion poll gloom for the Tories and predicted that he would come from behind, as Edward Heath did in 1970, and win the general election expected in May.

The Conservative leader coupled his optimism with a well-timed attempt to put Tony Blair on the spot over the prospect of a televised debate between the party leaders, by publicly abandoning his past rejection of a three-way debate involving the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy.

"I think there should be a debate between the party leaders, and I accept without any qualification the terms of the BBC/ITV proposal for two debates in the election campaign. I challenge him to accept that," Mr Hague said on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost programme.

"He needn't think about it for another 10 minutes. Let's have the debates agreed, straight away."

Incumbent prime ministers who expect to win have always rejected debate challenges from underdogs in the past. And Mr Hague spoke as the Sunday Telegraph's Mori poll gave Labour a 21-point lead over the Tories (52% to 31%, with the Lib Dems on 11%). The Sunday Times's NOP poll reported a 48% to 33% Labour lead.

Downing Street last night refused to budge from its ear lier formula that a TV debate is fine in principle but cannot be agreed until the details are finalised. Instead it led a scornful ministerial attack on Mr Hague for wasting his first TV interview of the year on the debate issue rather than on "the things that really matter".

The Tory leader yesterday offered voters glimpses of what a Hague government might do when he spoke of "giving people back their country" after a Labour regime had handed it over to Brussels, to political correctness and to criminals.

He dismissed Labour's claim that his tax-and-spend policies are billions of pounds adrift. He said he planned to cut Labour's promise of £68bn extra public spending on key services to around £60bn, which - the Tories say - is affordable and would help create room for tax cuts.

Challenged by Sir David Frost, Mr Hague insisted that he could save public money by cutting back the extra £1.8bn being spent on Whitehall, making housing benefit more efficient and diverting extra funds in the Home Office budget to pay for more police. Labour called his sums bogus.

On Ann Widdecombe's proposal that new asylum seekers should be housed in secure centres, which Labour claims would cost £3bn, Mr Hague said: "It must follow from our proposals to be tougher about the asylum system that we would deter unwarranted applications for asylum and that costs would come down."

Although he admitted that the Tories still had "more work to do to win people over", Mr Hague's tone astonished Labour and the Lib Dems, whose hopes of a fresh tactical voting squeeze against sitting Tory MPs Mr Hague had called "a little arrogant".

The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, accused Mr Hague of "making up policy on the hoof" and getting confused. The Scottish secretary, John Reid, said Mr Hague had made no positive proposals.

Despite defeatism on the Tory benches the Hague camp has been cheered by a string of local election wins. He also argued that the euro would be a crucial campaign feature.

"I'm in touch with thousands of people and it is because of that I know the next election is all there for the taking," Mr Hague said. "Remember in the 1970 election Ted Heath faced a 14% Labour lead. We have got some work ahead of us, but the Labour party are getting rather complacent about this election and some people in the media are starting to take it for granted. Tony Blair is in for a shock."

webTitle: Best of the rest

fields.headline: Best of the rest
fields.trailText: France
fields.body:
France

At Coventry, Romanian striker Viorel Moldovan spent most of his time sulking on the substitutes' bench. But times change, and so has Moldovan. In Turkey he scored 35 times for Fenerbahce in two seasons - and since joining Nantes in a £3.5m move this summer, he has continued his rich vein of form.

"I'm very happy because I will be playing in the French championship, which is one of the most potent in the world," said Moldovan at the time. And so it has proved - especially for him.

On Saturday Moldovan notched up his 10th goal of the season, as top of the table Nantes scrambled a 1-1 draw at home to Auxerre.

The visitors took the lead when Moussa Saib - remember him Tottenham fans? - caressed a delightful through ball into the path of Djibril Cisse, who slide it past Micakel Landreau. But 17 minutes from time, Moldovan powered home a Eric Carriere free-kick for a deserved equaliser.

"The conditions were difficult and Auxerre built a wall it was difficult to get past," said Nantes coach Raynald Denoueix. "We had a lot of chances, though, and we didn't make the most of them. We have to regret that."

But probably not too much - because all of Nantes' rivals dropped points away from home. Troyes rallied to beat second-placed Lille 2-1, Monaco slipped past third-placed Sedan 1-0 and En Avant Guingamp held Bordeaux to a 1-1 draw.

That leaves Nantes three points clear at the top with 40 points from 23 matches, ahead of Lille on 37 points with Bordeaux and Sedan on 36 and Olympique Lyon and Bastia on 35.

Elsewhere, Olympque Marseille were held 1-1 at home by strugglers Toulouse, while struggling Paris St Germain went down 1-0 at St Etienne.

Portugal

Guess who heads the Portuguese league? No, it's not Sporting, Benfica or Porto, but unfashionable Boavista, who went top for the first time this season after edging past Porto 1-0 in the Oporto derby.

Joaquim Martelinho grabbed the only goal after 31 minutes when he was left unmarked inside the penalty area and easily beat Porto's Russian goalkeeper Serguei Ovchinnikov.

Porto, who were without their top scorer Jesus Pena, were then reduced to 10 men when midfielder Deco Sousa was sent off for a second bookable offence. Boavista could have extended their lead in the 75th minute but Ovchinnkov made a spectacular save to turn a fierce drive from midfielder Pedro Santos away for a corner.

At the halfway stage of the season Boavista have 38 points, one more than Porto and two more than champions Sporting, who beat Maritimo 2-0.

Meanwhile, Benfica continued their revival with a 5-1 home thrashing of Aves. Dutch international Pierre van Hooijdonk scored a hat-trick (two headers, one penalty), and Brazilian striker Rodrigo Fabri, on loan from Real Madrid, also scored twice as Benfica recorded their seventh successive victory. The win took them to joint fifth place, seven points adrift of Boavista.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday tribunal postpones ruling on McGuinness allegation

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday tribunal postpones ruling on McGuinness allegation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: The Bloody Sunday tribunal is to postpone a ruling on security service evidence alleging that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness fired the first shot because of doubts raised about the source of the evidence by ex-MI5 officer David Shayler.
fields.body:
The tribunal investigating the Bloody Sunday killings reconvened today and said it will postpone a ruling on security service evidence alleging that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness fired the first shot that day because of doubts raised about the source of the evidence by ex-MI5 officer David Shayler.

Mr Shayler wrote in yesterday's Observer that the agent who made the allegations about Mr McGuinness was a known liar who was eventually "terminated" as an intelligence informant.

The informant - codenamed "Infliction"  is alleged to have claimed that Mr McGuinness - currently Northern Ireland education minister - "fired the first shot and nobody knows.... this seems to be on McGuinness's conscience. He has spoken to Infliction about it several times".

However other sections of the documents are heavily censored - a position the lawyers for the bereaved and injured are attempting to overturn.

Mr Shayler - himself charged with breaching the Official Secrets Act - said he intended to provide his information about Infliction to the tribunal. An application submitted by home secretary Jack Straw seeks to restrict publication of material about two security service agents - Infliction and another informer known as Observer B - and their handlers.

The chair of the inquiry, Lord Saville of Newdigate, said that in light of Mr Shayler's allegations any decision on the evidence from the security service will be delayed by a week or two.

Mr McGuinness has so far refused to provide a statement to the inquiry, which has heard allegations that he was officer commanding of the IRA in the city at the time.

The tribunal, which was established in 1998, has been hearing evidence in public since March and could continue for another two years. At the start of this year's proceedings today, witnesses gave their accounts of the shootings.

Witness Noel Moore, whose uncle was among the 13 men killed on Londonderry's Bogside 29 years ago, told the tribunal that he had been in the main body of the anti-internment march on Rossville Street when he heard two shots ring out.

Moore said that through the crush he could hear British soldiers. "Everyone was trying to find some space to run," he said. "I thought I could hear the voices of soldiers. I distinctly remember hearing English accents.

"Moments later panic set in when news circulated that someone had been shot and the crowd moved off the main road, towards the high-rise Rossville Flats, hearing more intense gunfire as they ran," he said.

"Everyone who was running in the car park was lifting up dust as they ran," he said. "At the time it looked as though something had been fired in the car park, there was so much smoke. It reminded me of a cattle stampede in a western movie."

Another witness, Sean Barr, described his "overwhelming feeling of disbelief" when he saw John Johnston wounded. Mr Johnston, 59, was shot along with 15-year-old Damien Donaghy on the fringe of the Bogside around 15 minutes before paratroopers drove into the district and the main shootings happened. Mr Johnston died later that year.

Mr Barr, who was 16 at the time, said Mr Johnston was "a respectable, elderly man and not the sort of person who would be associated with any rioting".

Barr said he believed the shots were probably a ploy by the army to draw out the IRA into a gun battle and said: "The soldiers were under no threat at the time."

Witness Noel Moore, whose uncle was among the 13 men killed on Londonderry's Bogside 29 years ago, told the tribunal that he had been in the main body of the anti-internment march on Rossville Street when he heard two shots ring out. Moore said that through the crush he could hear British soldiers. "Everyone was trying to find some space to run," he said. "I thought I could hear the voices of soldiers. I distinctly remember hearing English accents. "Moments later panic set in when news circulated that someone had been shot and the crowd moved off the main road, towards the high-rise Rossville Flats, hearing more intense gunfire as they ran," he said. "Everyone who was running in the car park was lifting up dust as they ran," he said. "At the time it looked as though something had been fired in the car park, there was so much smoke. It reminded me of a cattle stampede in a western movie." Another witness, Sean Barr, described his "overwhelming feeling of disbelief" when he saw John Johnston wounded. Mr Johnston, 59, was shot along with 15-year-old Damien Donaghy on the fringe of the Bogside around 15 minutes before paratroopers drove into the district and the main shootings happened. Mr Johnston died later that year. Mr Barr, who was 16 at the time, said Mr Johnston was "a respectable, elderly man and not the sort of person who would be associated with any rioting". Barr said he believed the shots were probably a ploy by the army to draw out the IRA into a gun battle and said: "The soldiers were under no threat at the time." webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: For the love of God will somebody pick a winner? Blue Square's Patrick Murray surveys the latest wreckage
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £159.69, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £39.53, Paul MacInnes = £33.35
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £159.69, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £39.53, Paul MacInnes = £33.35

Scott Murray: Arsenal v Chelsea: Chelsea to win: £10 @ 10/3

An unbeaten home side takes on a team yet to win away - I know I say avoid the obvious but backing Chelsea is taking it too far I fear. As for Mr Murray's "they're due one" comments, frankly I expect better of Scott; this is the sort of talk I expect in a dingy smoke-filled betting office in the stupider end of London not in the intellectual hotpot that is the Football Unlimited office.

Hindsight is a wonderful thing, I know, but I have to think that a better market to play on in this case was the Asian handicap where Chelsea could be backed at evens not to lose. With a draw always more likely than a Chelsea win, in my eyes at least, this would seem to be the way forward in this case.

But then, in view of his very healthy Blue Square account balance accrued through bets just like this one, who am I to argue with the legend that is Scott Murray.

Sean Ingle: Real Sociedad v Athletic Bilbao: Real Sociedad to win: £10 at 11/8

Mr Ingle promises us a new beginning, a new Sean fulfilling his obvious potential and turning his season around a la Middlesbrough. Alas he hasn't got off to a winning start but just as Terry Venables will inevitably do better than the hapless Robson so the new Mr I will inevitably do better than the old Mr I given time.

Value singles on obscure matches, what more could a punting mentor/ Chinese dictator ask for? Better luck next week Mr I. I will be cheering you on, honest.

Julian Rouche of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Rennes to win at Metz: £5 @ 13/8

A valiant attempt by the inestimable Mr Rouche, a value single on an obscure match cruelly thwarted by an eighty-sixth minute equaliser. The name of Meyrieu will live long in the FUPC hall of infamy. Sadly the bankroll has now fallen below forty pounds, but with four months of punting left there's still time to get it all back. The important thing is not to panic; keep plugging away at the value and it will pay off.

Don't I say that every week? And does it ever actually happen? Nevertheless I still believe it. This time next year, Rodney

Paul MacInnes: West Ham v Sunderland: Half-time/full-time draw/draw £4 @ 4/1

Blimey, not a multiple to be found among our intrepid punters this week, what is the world coming to? Not a single winner either unfortunately, a bit of a kick in the mouth for the Murray doctrine of value singles but value is a long term strategy, Rome wasn't built in a day, you can't make an omelette without breaking eggs and other more or less appropriate cliches.

For Mr MacInnes, unfortunately, losers are becoming a serious matter but as I never tire of saying it is a marathon not a sprint and as long as one keeps one's discipline and self-belief the situation is retrievable. A little less flippancy and a little more cold hard logic might help but I understand Mr M is a busy man and we should, I guess, never forget we are in the entertainment business. Dull 0-0 draws may bring home the bacon but do they keep the customers happy? Probably, particularly if you've got a tenner on no goalscorer.

But enough of this. With the NFL season drawing to an end the real gambling value is over until next September; betting on association football is always a struggle by comparison, but not an insurmountable struggle, and I will return next week to continue my 'value singles' crusade.

Until then, happy punting.

webTitle: Bridging the gender gap

fields.headline: Bridging the gender gap
fields.standfirst: Can the government do anything but watch as the educational divide between the sexes grows wider each year? Lee Elliot Major considers the gender debate
fields.trailText: Can the government do anything but watch as the educational divide between the sexes grows wider each year? Lee Elliot Major considers the gender debate.
fields.body:
It seems that there is now no stopping the advance of the educationally superior sex. Newly-released figures for last yearÕs degree results show that women students for first time outnumbered men in the total of firsts gained by university graduates. The results mark yet another educational milestone for females in what has been a year of academic triumphs over their male inferiors.

In a world where education is now a pre-requisite for a half-decent job, the future omens for the male are not good. And the further you look back down the education chain, the grimmer it gets. Girls achieved a higher proportion of A-grades for the first time in last yearÕs A-level results. The results for GCSEs showed that girls secured more top grades than boys across a greater number of subjects than ever before. And 25% more girls than boys achieved expected reading standards at age 11. In a decadeÕs time, top male graduates could be an endangered species.

Can the government do anything but watch as the educational gender divide grows wider? Suggestions for improving the performance of boys come thick and fast: more male teachers, more vocational and craft based courses, a return to single-sex classrooms, schools and colleges, even allowing boys to start schooling at a later age than girls. But there is no easy solution. It is a complex cocktail of economic, social, cultural and genetic factors which appears to alienate males from schools, colleges and universities. Despite an inferior academic record overall, until now, men could always point to their domination of top-class degrees: this was the last bastion of male supremacy. Male students, it was argued, took more risks than their more steady, systematic female counterparts, producing the academic elite which made up for male shortcomings elsewhere. Every year the results appeared to bear out this stereotype. Men got more firsts. Women got more upper seconds.

But all that has now changed with the latest degree results. Just under 11,000 female students secured top class degree honours in 2000 (almost 1,000 up on the 1999 figures), compared with 10,800 firsts for male graduates. Meanwhile, 67,500 females secured upper seconds compared with just over 42,000 males. This, remember, when males outnumber females in the population as a whole for this age group.

Some will point out that in proportional terms, men still secure more first class degrees, and that the higher number of female firsts is an inevitable consequence of more women taking finals in the first place. But this ignores the unstoppable trend over recent years: females have been improving their academic grades throughout the education system for a decade. The results represent just one more breakthrough; many more are likely to come. Furthermore, despite their lower numbers, more male graduates secured the lowest degree grades.

The gender gap is by no means uniform. It widens and narrows for different academic disciplines and universities. A chasm emerges when girls are compared with boys from the poorest groups.

While they have made great strides in the maths and sciences in schools, girls have yet to overtake men in the numbers and results that they do in the arts, humanities and social sciences. University degree courses, in fact, increasingly reflect a gender split in academic preferences: few women for example opt for engineering and the physical sciences.

The signs are that it is particularly working class males who are disenfranchised from the education system. Boys make up the majority of the Ôlost generationÕ - the 150,000 or so 16-18 year olds without any qualifications or official jobs. And the gender gap all but disappears in independent schools, and the most socially exclusive universities such as Cambridge and Oxford. Although it appears only a matter of time before the ivory towers of Oxbridge succumb to the rise of the female student: 48% of Cambridge enrolments last year were female, up 3% on the previous year.

So why are men turning away from education at a time when its economic and social worth cannot be overstated? One theory is that the educational underachievement is a symptom of a much more fundamental dilemma for the male race: a crisis in identity as traditional manufacturing jobs and family roles disappear. This feeling of hopelessness, it is argued, has already percolated through to even young boys. The international evidence substantiates this view: a widening gender gap is witnessed by other nations experiencing the same shift from manufacturing to service industries. In the US and Australia, concerns are now focusing on male anti-social and destructive behaviour, both inside and outside school: boys dominate the statistics for school suspensions and expulsions, suicides, road deaths, and deliquency.

Studies suggest that boys from very early on are under pressure to conform to a masculine stereotype - the macho, rebellious, unemotional male to whom study, school and authority are an anathema. Boys actively participate in their underachievement as part of the rejection of school. A recent UN study revealed the same phenomenon in many other countries. In the Caribbean, unlike the majority of the developing world, boys are doing significantly worse than girls at school. The reason? Schools were for ÔsissiesÕ. Is our education system failing to teach males in ways which better suit them? There are after all basic biological differences in the way females and males learn and communicate. Girls develop different skills at different rates, boys prefer to learn actively, rather than passively. Education ministers have vowed to recruit more male teachers in primary schools to provide role models for boys. They have also said that each school needs to develop its own individual strategy to tackle the underachievement of boys.

These small steps are to be welcomed. But it hardly amounts to the systematic response needed if the gaping educational divide is to be narrowed.

webTitle: ITV ditches peak-time target

fields.headline: ITV ditches peak-time target
fields.standfirst: Jan 15: ITV switches targets
fields.trailText:
5.45pm: ITV has taken up the ratings gauntlet thrown down by the BBC by scrapping its peak-time share target, reports Jason Deans.
Jan 15: ITV switches targets
fields.body:
ITV has taken up the peak-time ratings gauntlet thrown down by the BBC in October when it moved the BBC1 late evening news to 10pm.

The commercial broadcaster has scrapped its peak-time share target and will instead focus on maintaining its ratings lead over BBC1 in 2001.

This after ITV failed to hit its 38.5% share target in 2000, managing only 37.1%.

ITV is taking as its benchmark as the average peak-time lead over BBC1 for the past five years, which is 7.4 percentage points, or a 24% lead over its rivals.

The target appears easily achievable.

Last year the gap was 9.2 percentage points and in the first two weeks of 2001 it has widened to 11.6.

This is one of two new main and three secondary goals ITV has set itself for 2001.

Overall, the broadcaster has moved away from the ever more difficult task of increasing audience share year on year. The new goals are pitched at the less ambitious level of sustaining ITV's existing ratings performance.

"We believe that by delivering these goals ITV will have a very confident future," said John Hardie, ITV marketing and commercial director.

"ITV will continue to be the country's most powerful marketing tool, uniquely delivering fast, effective television reach."

ITV's second major goal is to maintain its position as the most watched channel in digital homes. In 2000 the broadcaster had a 20.7% share of all-day viewing in digital homes, while BBC1 had 19.2%.

The secondary goals are:

 To maintain the supply of big audience shows, taking the 2000 figure of 1,700 individual programmes with audiences above 5m as the benchmark

 To win back daytime share from BBC1. In 2000 the gap was 4 percentage points

 To sustain the delivery of ABC1s and 16 to 34-year-olds, measured in terms of total supply of impacts.

webTitle: El Salvador buries quake victims in mass graves

fields.headline: El Salvador buries quake victims in mass graves
fields.standfirst: Graphic: where the quake struck
fields.trailText: Authorities in El Salvador today said many of the 400 earthquake victims were buried in mass graves.
fields.body:
Authorities in El Salvador today said many of the 400 earthquake victims were buried in mass graves.

A landslide triggered by the earthquake had wiped out entire families, making it impossible to identify many of the dead.

Distraught relatives lined up yesterday at an improvised morgue in a bloodstained alleyway to identify some of those mangled and entombed in Saturday's quake, which measured 7.6 on the Richter scale.

But the need to dispose of the mounting number of corpses cheated some of the chance for closure.

One woman looking for a pair of missing cousins showed up at the morgue in the half-buried Las Colinas district, only to find out that two children who matched their description had already been sent to a mass burial. "My cousins are similar to the ages of the ones you buried, and they are missing," 18-year-old Kenya Marbella told soldiers, who said it was too late to see the bodies. "How could you just throw bodies in the ground like that?

With no refrigeration facilities, and bodies and body parts piling up in the alley near the quake-triggered landslide that covered Las Colinas in a wall of dirt, there was little choice but mass burial, said coroner Mario Alfredo Hernandez. About half of the corpses were unidentified, he said.

With aftershocks measuring up to 5.4 on the Richter scale rattling the unstable mass of soil and rubble, there was no safe place to keep the 182 bodies found in the area so far.

Some corpses lay peacefully on the pavement as if the victims were sleeping. Some were covered in bin liners.

El Salvador's president, Francisco Flores, has asked Colombia to send 300 coffins.

Red Cross official Mildred Sandoval said 403 deaths had been confirmed across the central American country. Police also reported 2,000 injured, 4,692 houses destroyed and 16,148 damaged. Authorities said about 1,000 people were still missing, most in Las Colinas, six miles east of the capital, San Salvador.

Saturday's earthquake off of El Salvador's coast was felt from northern Panama to central Mexico - a distance of more than 1,100 miles. Yesterday's aftershocks were centered within a few miles of the capital, according to local seismologists.

Pope John Paul II urged international assistance for the nation of 6m. Offers of help came from Mexico, the United States, Germany, Spain, Taiwan, Britain, Panama, even Guatemala, which itself suffered six deaths in the quake.

Unlike on Saturday night in El Salvador, when hundreds of survivors steered diggers to areas where their family members might be buried, markedly fewer people waited for relatives and friends to emerge from the immense landslide yesterday.

"Most of those that are under there now were with their families when they died," said police officer Rafael Hernandez. "With everyone already dead, there is no one here to claim many of the bodies we find now."

But as some gave up hope, one survivor was found from beneath tons of soil late last night.

Workers rescued 22-year-old Sergio Moreno, who was trapped for 30 hours under slabs of concrete. He had drawn rescuers' attention by tapping on the concrete.

Red Cross volunteer Lucio Castellano said Mr Moreno had suffered dehydration and a cut leg but was in good condition otherwise.

Yesterday afternoon, a powerful aftershock caused more of the hillside to collapse, sending rescuers fleeing in panic. Nobody was injured.

Specially trained dogs, sent in from the United States and Mexico, sniffed for the living and the dead under the blinding sun.

One led authorities to the battered body of a Las Colinas man who was wearing nothing but a navy blue bathing suit when the earthquake killed him. His body went unclaimed.

Meanwhile, those who could identify their dead held hundreds of funerals yesterday. "Oh, mama, tell me how this could happen, tell me what else I could have done," stammered Jose Cruz Torres, who buried three sisters and three grandchildren yesterday. "It's like the world here is upside down."
