webTitle: Wales offers £20m lifeline to Corus

fields.headline: Wales offers £20m lifeline to Corus
fields.standfirst: Climate levy concessions seek to rescue Llanwern plant
fields.trailText: The government and the national assembly for Wales are preparing special concessions to steel group Corus over the climate change levy as part of a package worth up to £20m to help keep open the Llanwern plant near Newport, Gwent.
fields.body:
The government and the national assembly for Wales are preparing special concessions to steel group Corus over the climate change levy as part of a package worth up to £20m to help keep open the Llanwern plant near Newport, Gwent.

This emerged over the weekend as a new study warned that more than 2,000 of Britain's heavy industrial firms face a near-£100m hit from the levy, which takes effect on April 1.

Corus, the Anglo-Dutch group, employs around 32,000 in Britain but has set in train 4,700 redundancies and is planning a further round of job losses and closures, possibly including Llanwern, to staunch losses on its UK carbon steel operations. These are likely to have been some £500m last year.

The Department of Trade and Industry and the national assembly are drawing up a pack age of aid to Corus, one of the groups facing the heaviest charges under the climate change levy, to alleviate its costs.

The package, worth between £10m and £20m and designed to escape European Union challenges over illegal state aid, would include grants to improve the environment around the south Wales plant which employs around 3,000 people.

Llanwern is the Corus plant most vulnerable to closure under the restructuring plan due to be announced by Sir Brian Moffat, the steel group's chairman and acting chief executive, within the next few weeks. Its closure would be damaging to Labour in the run-up to a general election in May.

Under the package being drawn up by Rhodri Morgan, first minister, and his deputy, Mike German, a Liberal Democrat, with DTI ministers, the national assembly would also buy up surplus land around the plant, ease or defer business rates, help finance research and development, and offer training grants.

Senior assembly sources accepted yesterday that the package might not be enough to deter Corus from shedding jobs at the south Wales plant but could help prevent complete closure.

Their argument has been buttressed by the recent strengthening of the euro which, Mr German estimates, has cut Corus's expected losses this year from £350m to £150m.

Last week the Engineering Employers Federation said many manufacturing firms were now increasing exports to mainland Europe despite a squeeze on prices and margins.

But the EEF warned last night that the climate change levy would cost 2,300 firms with an annual energy bill above £100,000 a net £82m even after taking into account the 0.3% cut in national insurance contributions on offer.

The EEF said the levy would damage competitiveness, prevent companies investing in energy efficiency and penalise those willing to sign challenging efficiency agreements.

The EEF, which wants the Treasury to allow more firms to sign agreements in return for a cut in the levy, said that, if only half of the 2,300 signed up, carbon dioxide emissions would be cut by 1.5m tonnes.

Martin Temple, director general, said: "We have never opposed the need for action on climate change but believe the levy to be one of the mostly badly designed economic instruments in recent times.

"We fail to understand why the Treasury, having accepted the reliability of our data, will not accept alternative proposals which would be of greater benefit to the environment while supporting the competitiveness of manufacturing companies."

webTitle: Damage delays aid as search continues

fields.headline: Damage delays aid as search continues
fields.trailText: A desperate search for survivors of the earthquake that had already taken more than 200 lives was under way in El Salvador last night.
fields.body:
A desperate search for survivors of the earthquake that had already taken more than 200 lives was under way in El Salvador last night.

It was feared that many hundreds were still buried by the rubble in a suburb of the capital, San Salvador, and in rural areas throughout the country, and that the final death toll would be well over 1,000. As the death toll rose, El Salvador's president, Francisco Flores, said he had asked Colombia for 3,000 coffins.

The earthquake, with a magnitude of 7.6, struck hardest at middle-class Las Colinas, where a landslide following the first tremors carried away whole houses, burying an estimated 400 of them.

There were more deaths elsewhere in El Salvador, and in neighbouring Guatemala as aftershocks continued throughout the day. The effects were felt in Honduras and Nicaragua and as far away as Mexico City, 600 miles from the epicentre, where buildings swayed.

President Flores immediately declared a national emergency and called for international help in the search and to assist survivors.

"We need support from experts in rescue, reopening communications, food and medicine," he said.

"I have received calls from various heads of state who are activating their assistance teams to help us in these difficult moments."

The rescue operation was complicated by the closure of the only international airport.

The entire country was without electricity for several hours and most of the telephones were out of order, making it hard to discover the extent of the damage in outlying areas, where at least 25 deaths were reported.

A dozen bus passengers were reported to have been buried in a landslide. By noon at least 234 people were known to have been killed.

Radio stations went off the air and businesses throughout the capital closed. In a bizarre touch, acrobats and other performers from a visiting circus continued to tour the city centre promoting their shows..

There are several aid organisations already in the country, some still helping the victims of Hurricane Mitch, and they were able to join in the rescue operation almost immediately.

It took time for bulldozers and tractors to reach the main site and begin the delicate work of seeking survivors.

Rescuers worked with their bare hands. Arturo Magana, 25, trying to find his 18-year-old brother Jaime, said: "I don't know where to dig because I don't know where the house is."

David Lara of the Green Cross emergency organisation said: "This is terrible. I don't think we will be able to pull out any victims. Everything has been buried."

He said that it was unlikely anyone would be found alive, but signs of life were detected in some areas, intensifying the rescue efforts.

"It was like a wave of dirt that covered us," said Emilio Renderos, a watchman employed in Las Colinas. "It was horrible."

Carmen de Marin said her son was waiting in their home for a telephone call from his father in the US when the earthquake struck. "My son is buried," she said.

The houses destroyed were mainly fairly solid two-storey structures rather than the fragile buildings in the poorer parts of the city which suffered most in the last major earthquake in the country, in 1986, when an estimated 1,400 died and 10,000 were injured in central San Salvador, which was barely affected this time.

In the south-eastern town of San Miguel a hospital wall collapsed, and 25 people were feared dead in a nearby village. In Santa Ana, about 35 miles from the capital, a church collapsed, killing at least one employee and possibly others at worship, the Rev Robert Castro said. The Red Cross reported that 13 died in nearby Sosonati.

In Guatemala the police said a man and a girl of two were killed and three other people injured when houses collapsed in the city of Jalpataua.

Aid from around the world began to arrive yesterday. Mexico sent five military aircraft, disaster experts, rescue dogs and relief supplies. The US also sent dogs along with blankets, medical kits, drinking water and makeshift shelters.

Guatemala stepped up electricity supplies to the Salvadorean grid. By last night, it was supplying 40%of El Salvador's power, up from less than 10% normally.

Britain pledged £100,000 to the Red Cross for use in El Salvador, and around £34,000 in other emergency aid.

Other help and offers of help came from France, Germany, Spain and Taiwan.

The epicentre was in the Pacific about 20 miles off the southern coast of El Salvador and 65 miles from the capital, the US Geological Survey said.

For El Salvador, the smallest country in central America with a population of 6.2m, it is the latest in a series of disasters which have included civil war and hurricanes.

webTitle: Baby Jaguar marks big leap for Halewood

fields.headline: Baby Jaguar marks big leap for Halewood
fields.standfirst: Ford plant that was byword for strife goes into luxury market
fields.trailText: Ford plant that was byword for strife goes into luxury market
fields.body:
A dot matrix sign scrolls over the head of Jimmy Rooney, protector of quality in the press shop at the Halewood car plant on Merseyside.

"25 days to X400 job 1", say the cryptic words in red and yellow dots, spelling out a message which is vital to the prosperity of the region, the British motor industry and the Ford Motor Company.

The message reminds 3,000 staff that next month the first baby Jaguar will roll off the production line and into the showrooms.

The workers who used to make the Escort, Europe's family workhorse, have moved into the luxury car business: Ford now owns Jaguar and Halewood will produce 100,000 Jaguars a year, or 10% of this lucrative sector of the market.

Behind the move is the thinking that more drivers are opting for a luxury car at what they believe to be affordable prices. That the innovation should occur at Halewood is just as revolutionary.

Halewood used to be a place where unions and management were often locked in ritualistic trials of strength. Now managers have admitted past mistakes and sought to unlock the potential of their car builders. About £300m has been poured into changing cultures and creating a factory fit for sleek little movers costing around £23,000; the Ford oval is out, the leaping Jaguar is in.

"I feel so proud to be part of Jaguar, to be building a quality vehicle," said Mr Rooney, who now wears a Jaguar T-shirt after 27 years as a Ford man. "I have already had an opportunity to drive the new X400 - 10 years ago that would have been an impossible dream."

Mr Rooney used to be a pool worker, shunted round the plant to plug gaps, unable to progress because advancement was based on seniority, not ability. Eighteen months ago he realised the significance of the Jaguar project and took the chance to spend nine months on the Jaguar line in Coventry, where the S type is being built. Eventually, 500 workers were to spend time in Coventry, learning the Jaguar way of car production.

In 1997 Halewood looked as if it would close after the announcement of the imminent end of the Escort. But the unions dug in their heels and the plant was a given the multi-activity vehicle (MAV), a people carrier version of the Focus.

Then, having examined and rejected greenfield sites and its own plants around the world, Ford decided that same year to build the new Jaguar at Halewood and embarked on the most concentrated car development plan in the company's history. Exit MAV, enter X400. The new Labour government chipped in £43m.

"We needed a quantum leap in quality and productivity," said David Perry, who moved to Merseyside to head the Ford-to-Jaguar transition team. "We also needed a major investment in infrastructure to put right the neglect of recent years and we needed to change dramatically the culture within the plant."

Negotiations with unions on changes in working practices were complete by November 1998 and recorded in the Halewood Charter, which every employee was asked to sign: 90% did. "We were delighted with that," said Mr Perry. "It covered things like smoking at work, eating in the cars, mobility of labour, promotion based on ability, and the management's right to manage in the interests of the business."

In came American consultants specialising in the culture of working relationships. Quality standards were cranked up and those who bought an Escort in the final months before the line stopped for good on July 21 last year found themselves with one of the finest popular cars ever produced in Europe.

In August, 800 workers spent 10 days at Merseyside further education colleges, brushing up on literacy, numeracy and information technology, and then took part in community projects. "They went down there with a bit of trepidation but threw themselves into learning," said Mr Perry. "IT caught their imagination. Some had never switched on a computer before. After 10 days, it was incredible to see the interest and enthusiasm."

With the launch just around the corner, pre-production X400 four door saloons are coming off the line for quality tests; the people who build them are attending quality seminars in which they examine in detail rival small Audis and BMWs. "We set out to change a culture in two years," added Mr Perry. "That is almost unprecedented. All the indicators suggest we have made dramatic progress. The jury is out on the sustainability of that. The whole culture change programme is captured by the word respect - respect upwards, downwards and sideways."

Tony Woodley, the TGWU's chief negotiator for the car industry, welcomes that respect and the investment that Jaguar has made in people and the environment in which they work. "There has been a dramatic change of culture among the management on how people are treated. That makes for a very efficient and productive plant. People are working bloody hard and producing the goods. I am absolutely delighted."

webTitle: H Bauer to publish fortnightly title

fields.headline: H Bauer to publish fortnightly title
fields.trailText: H Bauer's spring launch, Project Helena, will be a fortnightly magazine, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Women's weekly publisher H Bauer is breaking the mould by making its top-secret new magazine a fortnightly publication.

The magazine, codenamed Project Helena, will combine "the environment of a glossy monthly with the pace of a weekly" when it makes it spring debut.

"Project Helena will be everything a glossy should be - stylish, glamorous, contemporary and sophisticated - but it will also be thought-provoking, innovative, informative and witty, with a healthy dose of realism reflecting the complex labyrinth of women's lives today," said Louise Newton, publishing director at H Bauer.

H Bauer, which publishes big-hitting titles such as Bella and Take-a-Break, is hoping its move into fortnight glossy territory will allow Project Helena to survive in a saturated market.

"The fortnightly glossy concept is being extremely well received by the advertising community for three reasons," said Simon Young, managing director of H Bauer's ad sales house.

"First, their ads will be seen within the environment of a monthly; second, they achieve critical mass; and third, the fortnightly frequency enables advertisers to build cover quickly."

The company is so confident of the title's success it has set an initial print run of 900,000, though it has yet to give details of the magazine's title.

Project Helena will be edited by That's Life! editor, Janice Turner.

webTitle: The El Salvador earthquake: 'We care, but only when we know'

fields.headline: 'We care, but only when we know'
fields.standfirst: The media focus on disasters that are easy to understand, such as this weekend's earthquake in El Salvador, leaves us ignorant of more complex, politically challenging crises, writes George Monbiot
fields.trailText: The media focus on disasters that are easy to understand, such as this weekend's earthquake in El Salvador, leaves us ignorant of more complex, politically challenging crises, writes George Monbiot
fields.body:
Why is it that the better our means of communication become, the less we appear to know or to care about people on the other side of the world?

The earthquake in El Salvador is what correspondents call "sexy". There are hot pics of blasted landscapes and wailing families to broadcast, and gripping tales to tell of heroic rescue teams battling to extract people before they die. Best of all, someone might survive against all the odds.

The disaster has a simple cause and a straightforward effect. The earth quakes, the land slides and a few hundred people get crushed. It is far easier to cover than, for example, a proxy war fuelled by colonial demarcations, post-Cold War geopolitics and the global arms trade, whose accurate coverage would entail confronting powerful governments with uncomfortable truths.

In such permanent human earthquakes, many more die, but their deaths cannot be explained by pictures alone. So they are edited out of our consciousness, falling to the cutting room floor of our minds.

But even the sexy stories touch us for four or five days at most, after which they are abandoned as if they were no more than thrilling tales concocted for our amusement. So what's going on? Is this a result of compassion fatigue? I don't think so.

Scarcely a week goes by in which the tabloids or the TV stations don't launch an appeal to buy baby X a new liver or rescue the doomed donkeys of Spain or the benighted bears of Pakistan. And these appeals elicit a huge response and are remembered.

The problem, I feel, is that the news has become an exercise in transmitting information without understanding. Because we hear only about those catastrophes - such as earthquakes and air disasters - which the world can do little to prevent, and almost nothing about the man-made crises which are susceptible to mediation, we are left feeling helpless and this encourages us to switch off. We care, but only when we know.

• George Monbiot's latest book Captive State: the Corporate Takeover of Britain, is published by Macmillan.

Is this a result of compassion fatigue? I don't think so. Scarcely a week goes by in which the tabloids or the TV stations don't launch an appeal to buy baby X a new liver or rescue the doomed donkeys of Spain or the benighted bears of Pakistan. And these appeals elicit a huge response and are remembered. The problem, I feel, is that the news has become an exercise in transmitting information without understanding. Because we hear only about those catastrophes - such as earthquakes and air disasters - which the world can do little to prevent, and almost nothing about the man-made crises which are susceptible to mediation, we are left feeling helpless and this encourages us to switch off. We care, but only when we know. • George Monbiot's latest book Captive State: the Corporate Takeover of Britain, is published by Macmillan. webTitle: IT 'glasnost' allows health staff web access

fields.headline: IT 'glasnost' allows health staff web access
fields.trailText: Department of Health staff will be able to read these words without fear of the sack - because technology "glasnost" in their section of the notoriously stuffy civil service now permits "free" use of the internet at work.
fields.body:
Department of Health staff will be able to read these words without fear of the sack - because technology "glasnost" in their section of the notoriously stuffy civil service now permits "free" use of the internet at work.

An internal review has concluded that for the first time staff should be allowed to log on to the internet for personal use, such as on-line banking, or, for that matter, reading SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

As health secretary Alan Milburn launches his £500m IT strategy for the NHS, DoH civil servants have been told that the existing prohibition on personal use of internet use has been eased.

A memo sent out last week says: "We have relaxed the current rules to allow reasonable personal use of DoH facilities, such as accessing the internet, provided they are used with discretion."

It adds: "The guidance relaxes the department's current policy which has been to prohibit any personal use of IT facilities.

"In particular it recognises that there may be times when you need to undertake personal business when in the office, for example, on-line banking."

But it warns that downloading video clips, music tracks, "offensive material" and "large quantities of personal material" is unacceptable, and warns that misuse could lead to the sack. It also says disk drives and directories on staff PCs will be routinely monitored "You should not therefore have any expectation of personal privacy when using the department's IT facilities for personal use."

The NHS IT strategy, called Building the Information Core, sets a target of giving net access to all NHS staff by April 2003, and warns that the NHS faces a "major behavioural, culture changechallenge" in becoming more e-savvy.

A recent internal review of DoH plans for electronic government found that the department was generally unprepared to exploit the electronic revolution.

It said: "The benefits of e-systems are not generally fully understood at senior management level."

webTitle: 'The earth shook and the mountain tumbled down'

fields.headline: 'The earth shook and the mountain tumbled down'
fields.trailText: With no more tears to shed, Ana Maria Juarez stood dry-eyed beside what she swore used to be her home. Covered beneath three metres of thick mud, it was hard to believe that a building had once stood there.
fields.body:
With no more tears to shed, Ana Maria Juarez stood dry-eyed beside what she swore used to be her home. Covered beneath three metres of thick mud, it was hard to believe that a building had once stood there.

With a slight wave of her hand she indicated where the back bedroom had been. That is where she believes her 15-year-old daughter was sleeping when the first waves of the earthquake were felt at 11.40 on Saturday morning.

I looked down into the mud - pretending I could imagine where the room once stood. "I don't think there can be anything left, but I just want to find her body," she said. "At least this way I can bury her with dignity."

The scene after the quake at the once lively middle class residential area of Las Colinas, on the south-western edge of the capital, San Salvador, more resembles the site of a massive aerial bombardment.

In an area of about 300 square metres, upturned trees, the odd piece of torn clothing, sheets from unread newspapers, and piles of rubble are all that remain of the 400 or so houses that were devoured by the mighty mudslide from the surrounding mountains, set off by the earthquake.

"It was like a swarm of bees flying over, when the earth shook and the mountain came tumbling down," said Ana Maria's husband Mario. He was trapped in his car when the quake struck and arrived home minutes later to begin the search for his daughter.

Yesterday the police said 234 people throughout the country had died in the quake, which registered 7.6 on the Richter scale, and 2,000 had been injured. More than 1,200 are missing; most lie under the mud at Las Colinas and in the town of Santa Tecla.

The number of homeless could run into the tens of thousands. The police said almost 5,000 homes had been destroyed and more than 16,000 damaged.

Residents in Las Colinas had long warned that construction work on the edge of the large mountain range that runs along the south-west of the city, would affect the hill's stability. But on Saturday night, as I wandered through the mud hills covering the community, it was hard to find anyone who was pleased to have been proven right.

As the night wore on, the search for survivors continued both with heavy machinery and pickaxes and shovels.

Beside such painful loss of homes and lives, my own experience pales. At home in the north of the city, I was preparing to go out as the earth began to move. My two small children were playing in the front room.

During the more than 10 years I have lived here, I have become used to the short sharp tremors that are so common to this part of the world. So at first none of us was unduly concerned. But as the movements intensified and the walls shook uncontrollably, and cupboards and tables began to shift as if they were being pushed by a hidden hand, we rushed for the front door in search of safety on the street. Dozens of our stricken-faced neighbours were already there, for in 1986 an earthquake killed more than 1,000 people and destroyed swaths of the capital.

Amid the noise from earthmovers and generators last night, the sound of hymns from a mass amid the rubble that had been the church of Our Lady of Guadalupe drifted a few hundred metres down the ravine to rescuers digging in Las Colinas.

Only three survivors had been recovered from Las Colinas, but hundreds of people worked without sleep to hunt for more, many using only shovels, even bare hands.

"It is very dangerous, but we are going to keep hunting. We are going to take them out alive or dead," said Juan Sanchez, a Green Cross rescue worker.

webTitle: £500m plan to plug NHS into internet revolution

fields.headline: £500m plan to plug NHS into internet revolution
fields.trailText: The government has launched a £500m plan to wire up the NHS to the internet revolution, with the aim of improving standards of care and speeding up access to treatment and health information.
fields.body:
The government has launched a £500m plan to wire up the NHS to the internet revolution, with the aim of improving standards of care and speeding up access to treatment and health information.

The four-year strategy promises a electronic booking system for appointments, electronic medical records, video and tele-consultations for patients, and electronically transmitted laboratory test results.

All doctors, nurses and clinical support staff will be hooked up to the net within two years, while remaining NHS staff will have workplace access to the internet and email within four years. Both professionals and patients will have access to "trustworthy and clearly (NHS) branded advice and information" on healthcare on the internet allowing staff to keep up to date with medical practice and enabling patients to be involved in their own care.

The strategy, entitled Building the Information Core - Implementing the NHS Plan, promises a "vibrant, networked" NHS by 2005.

But it warns that the NHS will have to undergo massive cultural change to the way it works if it is to take advantage of the internet.

It warns: "There is a major behavioural, cultural change and organisational development challenge in redesigning care services around the individual, and establishing a 'network NHS'. "Everyone - individuals, multi-disciplinary teams and care organisations - will need to think through the way that they work."

Ministers are convinced that increased use of electronic communications will cut out much of the delays and inefficiencies in accessing NHS care that frustrate patients.

GPs will be able to book hospital appointments for their patients directly by internet at the time of their consultation, rather than though a protracted exchange of letters through the post.

The strategy says this will give patients "more choice and convenience, with less wasted time through cancelled operations and improved management of waiting lists".

Tele-links to hospital specialists from the GP surgery will allow patients to get on the spot expert advice on their condition, rather than having to travel into hospital.

Laboratory test results will be ordered and received electronically, "giving patients less delay and worry and clinicians less bureaucracy with earlier diagnosis and treatment and improved outcomes".

Electronic patient records - possibly held on "smart cards" - will be introduced, allowing staff access to individual medical histories "to enable them to provide the highest quality care when and where it is needed".

Hospital trusts will be expected to provide varying levels of internet access to all staff, varying from desk top personal computers for medical secretaries to hand held mobile phones for community nurses.

Health secretary Alan Milburn said the strategy would make technology central to patient care, rather than "something to be left to the IT specialists".

Mr Milburn added: "Patients will see a difference. They will have access to quality and trustworthy information on personal care and local health services They will make appointments quickly and conveniently through a national booking system.

"They will have easy access to their personal medical records. They will receive reminders before appointments and proactive calls to help them manage their medicines or treatment.

"They will have the confidence and reassurance that the professionals referring, diagnosing and caring for them are working with the best quality knowledge about their condition and treatment."

webTitle: No quick fixes for NHS systems

fields.headline: No quick fixes for NHS systems
fields.trailText: Comment: Is the NHS's £500m IT strategy nothing more than a blueprint for disaster, asks Mike Cross
fields.body:
Big computer projects are risky. Studies show that anywhere between two-thirds and 90% of IT projects either fail or run late and go well over budget. Only a small minority are unqualified successes. The larger the project, the more likely the risk of failure.

Few organisations are larger than the NHS, which today unveiled a £500m strategy to modernise its IT by 2005. The strategy, snappily entitled Building the Information Core - Implementing the NHS Plan promises that by 2005 we will have "a vibrant networked NHS".

A blueprint for disaster? On the surface, the omens are not good.

Apart from the size of the NHS, not to mention its past record in IT, there are two reasons to worry.

First, unlike other big organisations such as supermarkets or banks, the NHS's head office cannot demand that every hospital or GP surgery install a uniform set of IT systems.

Every NHS organisation, even down to individual GPs, has its own IT strategy and mixture of "legacy" computers which may or may not talk to each other.

Second, healthcare everywhere is more difficult than other industries to computerise. Medical language is far more complicated and subtle to digitise than sales figures or stock inventories, and patients' bedsides are not good places to install computer terminals.

The authors of the IT strategy know the risks, which presumably explains its low-key launch. But there are reasons for optimism. By the standards of Labour's grandiose scheme's to deliver e-public services, the strategy has been carefully thought out.

It also builds on, rather than overturning, previous initiatives. For example, the target of all acute hospitals having electronic patient records by 2005 was set in the previous strategy, Information for Health, published in 1998.

Some targets have even been scaled back: in 1998, ministers were talking confidently of connecting all GPs to NHSnet by March 2000: that date has since slipped to 2002.

Technically, the strategy does not look particularly ambitious. One headline target, 2005 for electronically booked appointments, would appear painfully slow in other industries.

Patients might wonder why the wait - after all, this is what happens every time a travel agency makes an airline reservation.

In practice, it's all a bit more difficult. Even when the technology is sorted out, there are complex political questions. GPs are supposed to "request" appointments from specialists, who decide to allocate them according to available resources, not order them like cans of beans.

There are also uncertainties surrounding the two tiers of electronic records envisaged in the strategy.

By 2005, all acute trusts to hold electronic patient-records (EPR). Such "organisational" records are difficult enough to create - only a handful of hospitals in the world have them, and about one-tenth of NHS trusts have moved significantly down this path. (Their use by GPs became legal only in October last year.)

However by 2005, the strategy envisages the NHS piloting a second tier electronic health record (EHR), a cradle-to-grave dossier of essential information available seamlessly to health professionals, the patients themselves, but not to insurance companies, police officers or journalists.

Arguments about the security of electronic records have hamstrung healthcare IT for a decade, and are not about to go away. The strategy revives one possible solution, the idea of issuing patients "smart cards" as keys to their records.

But here the strategy hedges its bets, saying that it awaits the outcome of two separate studies due to report by March.

There are other reasons for caution. While the new money for IT is welcome, it will do no good if NHS organisations are not allowed to spend it.

Today, procurements usually take two years or more, to the despair of IT companies, many of whom have left the market. The strategy's solution is to draw up national lists of approved systems, from which hospitals can pick without unnecessary bureaucracy.

The snag is that such lists take years to draw up, with IT firms fighting like ferrets in a sack to get onto them.

In the meantime, technology moves on and the targets loom closer. There are no quick fixes.

webTitle: Tesco.com boasts bumper Christmas sales

fields.headline: Tesco.com boasts bumper Christmas sales
fields.trailText: 5pm: Tesco.com, the e-commerce division of Tesco, is claiming spectacular sales over Christmas, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Tesco.com, the e-commerce division of Tesco, is claiming spectacular sales over Christmas.

In a trading statement published today, the grocery retail giant said sales over the seven weeks to January 6 were up 400% with some 30m products being delivered.

Demand over Christmas led to Tesco.com recruiting 400 new staff and allocating 10,000 additional delivery slots.

Tesco.com now claims it can cover 90% of the UK population for home deliveries.

The strong performance contrasts with poor results from other retailers in the pre-Christmas trading period, particularly from discount and speciality clothing retailers who are now having to compete with supermarkets that offer cheap clothes online.

webTitle: Plates, Spoons, and Cups

fields.headline: Plates, Spoons, and Cups
fields.trailText: ON-OFF-ON-OFF-ON-OFF-ON-OH FOR GOODNESS SAKE
fields.body:
ON-OFF-ON-OFF-ON-OFF-ON-OH FOR GOODNESS SAKE

Like any resident of the big black smoke, Appy Arry Redknapp loves striking a deal. In fact, he loves striking them so much that he tries not to complete any at all, thus enabling him to go back and start negotiations again from scratch. You can't get away with this all the time. Um and ah when English Len is giving you first option on good-quality registration plates, for example, and you'll soon know the medical definition of procrastination. But if you're brokering a £3m deal with Rangers for defender Lorenzo Amoruso, it's probably safe to stretch things out for as long as you wish.

"We will not be attempting any further negotiations," one of Arry's boys snarled this morning, after Amoruso failed to agree personal terms with the Ammers. And before long, Arry 'imself was giving it the big one about how the deal was definitely dead, well true and proper, and no mistake: "I really believed we could do business, but our chairman doesn't want to spend that sort of money on wages and a fee until the transfer system is resolved. I'm disappointed because we were keen to sign Lorenzo. I even went to Florence last week to see him but at this moment we can't come up with the money."

That'll be an end to it, your normal observer would think. But we know better, don't we? And sure enough, events in the East End soon took an abaht turn. "It is up to the player whether a deal can be reached," club managing director Paul Aldridge insisted on the Ammers website (www.comeandhavealookatmylockup.co.uk) this afternoon. "We would still hope a sensible solution could be arrived at, but we will have to wait and see." So, only six more announcements of "it's off" and seven more of "it's on" before Amoruso's in the bag. Gertcha!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NOBODY KNOWS HOW I'M FILLING

You can be a £30m-valued striker, considered by some to be the most lethal marksman in the world (after Roger 'The Stoat' Blazevijicik, but that's a different kind of marksman). You can earn unheard of amounts of cash every week, and have a very nice suit or thirteen, just for playing football. But that doesn't have to stop you from throwing a strop when nobody sympathises with your toothache.

Christian Vieri, who was nearly as good as West Ham substitute Davor Suker during France 98, scored a late equaliser for Internazionale against Parma in Serie A yesterday. But the lolloping Italian international refused to celebrate his strike because Inter fans had booed him for spooning two earlier chances. "Today I didn't like how the fans treated me," he said after the game. "People seem to forget all too quickly that I was out through injury for ten months and that this week I had a terrible toothache."

Vieri promised that the celebration strike will continue, even if the fans take his dental difficulties into account. And quite right, too. But what's to stop this principled stand from being corrupted by lesser players? What if John Hartson refuses to run because he got sold an underweight bag of chips? Or Sergei Rebrov puts his goal drought down to a lack of decent CB radio parts? About the only player who's got a few cast-iron excuses is Mr Robbie Fowler. But let's face it, he's not about to get a chance to use them.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"At Villa we tend to get world-class goals. Very rarely do we get scrappy ones or tap-ins off the keeper's backside or from three yards out. A lot of Angel's goals have been like that. They are horrible goals, the sort where he's gone to volley it and the ball will roll half-way down his shin and bobble into the opposite corner of the net" - Man-management guru John Gregory talks up his new £9.5m striker Juan Pablo Angel.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TO BE FRANK

So farewell then, Frank Leboeuf. Actually, not quite, but the Fiver couldn't wait till the end of the week, when Leboeuf is expected to complete a £3m move to Monaco, to wave cheerio to the oft-floundering centre-half. After all, the French international substitute has put his size 24s in it so often that he could be in danger of giving the tabloids a handy brush with which to tar their least favourite nation (we're only speculating here).

Anyway, this morning Mr Leboeuf signalled his intention to jet off to sunnier climes than the solarium in West London's most fashionable boutique. And he did it in typical fashion. "There are times when you have to make a choice and Monaco can bring me more trophies," said the man who is in no way connected with Chelsea's limited silverware options.

Leboeuf wants out of the trophy-free Bridge only a few months after helping get rid of the most successful manager in the club's history. It was Frank who went on record to declare that Gianluca Vialli had "a problem with everybody". "It's normal for a coach to get along with his lads," he said at the time without a hint of bitchiness, "but not him." Now, after blowing kisses at supporters after the weekend's 1-1 draw with Arsenal, Frank wants to be off. Except that the one remaining stumbling block is believed to be his £25,000-a-week wage demands. Trouble in a gleaming skull-sack, that's what we say.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Fulham striker Luís Boa Morte is a £2m target for Benfica, according to reports.

Middlesbrough's bid for Bradford striker Dean Windass looks dead in the water after Bryan Robson refused to up his £1m offer. "We offered what we thought was a fair price and we won't be going back in for him," said Robson.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Uefa have threatened to break off negotiations with Fifa over changes to the international transfer system. Uefa said it would deal directly with the European Commission and hold "no further meetings with Fifa" unless the game's world governing body agreed "certain principles". These were not spelt out in the statement but referred to the fact that Fifa did not consult Uefa before making their own proposals to the EC last week.

IFK Gothenburg are interested in signing Manchester United winger Jesper Blomqvist. "We are very interested, as Blomqvist's future at Manchester United is in doubt," coach Roger Gustafsson told Swedish daily newspaper Aftonbladet. "If he can't play before his contract expires then Manchester United will probably not extend it. I think we're a very good alternative for him." Blomqvist's contract with United expires at the end of June.

Gareth Barry has started contract talks with Aston Villa over a new deal that would keep him at the club until 2006. "I love it at Villa. It is a great place for me to learn my football," said Barry. "The process is still going on and there is nowhere I would rather do it."

Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri has announced that he will not speak to the media again unless his team lose. "I've decided not to speak if we have won or drawn and will send a players' representative to speak instead because the results are to their merit. I will continue to speak after matches, however, when we have lost."

The final game ever at the Dell will feature Robbie Williams and Craig David. Both have been lined up to appear in Southampton defender Jason Dodd's testimonial at the end of the season.

Republic of Ireland international Jeff Kenna has handed Blackburn a transfer request.

St Johnstone defender Alan Kernaghan will retire at the end of next season. The 33-year-old former Republic of Ireland international has suffered with a pelvic problem - which has needed three operations - for the last four years.

Barcelona president Joan Gaspart has promised the post of technical director to coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer for at least four years. But Gaspart said no decision would be made on the position of first team coach until the end of the season.

webTitle: European grant for new net research

fields.headline: European grant for new net research
fields.trailText: The research effort to develop the next generation of the net received a boost last week, when the European commission confirmed that it is injecting 9.8m euros (£6.2m) over three years into a project which could revolutionise our ability to access and manipulate vast amounts of information and data.
fields.body:
The research effort to develop the next generation of the net received a boost last week, when the European commission confirmed that it is injecting 9.8m euros (£6.2m) over three years into a project which could revolutionise our ability to access and manipulate vast amounts of information and data.

Academics believe that the creation of a computing network designed to analyse, process and distribute masses of data will mark the beginning of the world wide grid, a computing system incomparably more powerful than the existing internet.

Professor Ian Halliday, chief executive of the UK's Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council said: "The Datagrid will be a watershed in information technology which will revolutionise scientific research, e-commerce, and our society. Just like the world wide web before, which was also invented by a British particle physicist, UK scientists are right at the heart of this technology".

PPARC, which last year received £26m over three years from the government to develop the grid technology for particle physics experiments and astronomical observation, will spearhead British input into the project.

The funding from the European commission's information society programme paves the way for a European-wide research effort to produce a computing grid, similar to the electrical grid first developed 100 years ago. Like electrical power, the grid's end-users will have access to vast computer processing and distributed power without any regard as to who, how, or from where the power and information is coming from. The EU project is being co-ordinated through CERN, the European Laboratory for particle physics.

A key aspect of the grid is the development of 'middleware' - the software 'glue', which connects the computing operating systems.

PPARC is using the grid technology to produce a virtual astronomical observatory, combining vast amounts of astronomical data and images from a range of ground and space based telescopes and instruments, and distributing the data to a network of scientists.

The six main partners in the European project are: CERN, based in Geneva; CNRS, in France - Le Comit National de la Recherche Scientifique; ESRIN - The European Space Agency's Centre in Frascati (near Rome); INFN, in Italy - Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare; NIKHEF - The Dutch National Institute for Nuclear Physics and High Energy Physics, in Amsterdam, and PPARC.

webTitle: Conventional wisdom may change face of regional politics

fields.headline: Conventional wisdom may change face of regional politics
fields.standfirst: Wales and Scotland both have regional government, and some activists want the south-west to be next. The Right Rev Michael Langrish, Bishop of Exeter, explains why he decided to chair a constitutional convention steering group looking into how it might work
fields.trailText: Wales and Scotland both have regional government, and some activists want the south-west to be next. The Right Rev Michael Langrish, Bishop of Exeter, explains why he decided to chair a constitutional convention steering group looking into how it might work
fields.body:
I have been in south-west England for nearly a year and have tremendously enjoyed getting to know a diocese in a new area. During the previous seven years as Bishop of Birkenhead I saw how important it was for the challenges that faced Merseyside to be tackled within a north-western perspective. I had also been concerned to see that the churches responded properly to emerging regional structures.

It was partly because of this background, and partly because Exeter is the geographical centre of the area covered by the government office for the south-west, the regional development agency and the south west assembly, that I was approached to chair the constitutional convention in the region.

The south-west constitutional convention has been established to examine the case for the devolution of power from Whitehall. Its aim is to be consultative and inclusive, seeking the views of the wider public on the kind of structures they would find most suitable, and which would enhance participation in the electoral process.

My own involvement also reflects the importance of the contributions of faith communities in general, and Christian churches in particular, to the life of the area. We all share a desire to improve the region's civic, public and economic life, and to develop a more inclusive political culture.

Within the seven counties - Cornwall, Devon, Dorset, Somerset, Wiltshire, Gloucestershire and the area that was known as Avon - we have an exciting mixture of tourist attractions, as well as agriculture, local and regional industry, and business enterprise. We also have proud traditions that establish our local identities.

Across the region we are also responding to the challenge of a decline in many of our traditional economic activities such as farming and fishing. We need a forum to bring together the councils, social partners, business and trade unions, statutory and voluntary organisations, people from different traditions, as well as young people, to ensure that the forces which will shape the region's future are coherent, democratic and fully representative.

The convention's work springs out of a desire to engage with the widespread feeling that we increasingly enjoy less and less democratic control and accountability over so many areas that shape our daily lives. Local government has lost significant functions over the past 20 years. Many formerly accountable bodies have been abolished and non-elected quangos, answerable only to central government, have filled the void.

There is a sense also that power is increasingly exercised by national or trans-national companies, and there is weariness with forms of politics dominated by politicians alone. What is not wanted is the creation of yet more government, still less more bureaucracy. Rather, the aim must be better government with more local accountability. And, with such a worryingly low turnout for local and national elections alike, more people must be drawn into the democratic process. It is by such criteria that any new regional structures must be judged.

Local accountability also means the recognition of local diversity. I have learned, not just through the work of the convention, but also through meeting people in all sectors of the community, that there are very real cultural and socio-economic differences within the region. These are to be valued and respected.

So, for example, we are trying to incorporate the aspirations of Cornish people, some of whom seek further devolution, within a framework which addresses those concerns which are common to the region's life. Just as the EU has been described as a community of regions, so the south-west is truly a region of communities.

The convention's work is not seen as an answer to the so-called "English question" although we recognise the importance of regions to England, especially after the developments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does stem from a widespread local feeling that there needs to be a strong voice in Westminster and Whitehall for the south-west. That voice needs not only to reflect the different needs and aspirations of all the people who live here, but to be accountable to them as well.

As a Bishop, I have responsibility for a large geographical area, and also hold an office which, by its very nature, is apolitical. In that capacity I am pleased to chair a process which is intended to ensure that people representing all sectors of the regional community, and of all political persuasions or none, share in the ownership of the process of transforming a regional bureaucracy into flexible, effective and democratic bodies with sufficient autonomy to respond to our own local needs.

The underlying concept is that of "subsidiarity", to which the present government is so firmly committed. It is a principle which recognises that the function of any tier of government is to energise, rather than enervate, other parts of the body politic.

The next stage of the process will be the formal launch of the south-west constitutional convention on May 19, leading ultimately to a referendum in which the people of the south-west may speak for themselves about the shape and nature of the governance they want and need.

webTitle: Roma finally falter while Fiorentina run riot

fields.headline: Roma finally falter while Fiorentina run riot
fields.trailText: Even Italy's notoriously fickle press have been mightily excited by runaway Serie A leaders Roma this season. But after such an impressive start it was inevitable that Fabio Capello's men would eventually stutter somewhere. It's just that nobody expected they would do it at home against bottom placed Bari.
fields.body:
Even Italy's notoriously fickle press have been mightily excited by runaway Serie A leaders Roma this season. But after such an impressive start it was inevitable that Fabio Capello's men would eventually stutter somewhere. It's just that nobody expected they would do it at home against bottom placed Bari.

Roma eventually escaped with a 1-1 draw - with Francesco Totti's 74th-minute penalty cancelling out Giuseppe Mazzarelli's viciously spiralling free-kick five minutes earlier - but that didn't stop the more excitable members of the pressbox speculating about Roma's future. For months they had come to praise the Giallorossi. Now they were trying to bury them.

"Please don't exaggerate," Fabello urged them. "It's too early to say that we're finished. We had too many players out in midfield and, of course, the team was affected by the absences particularly of Cristiano Zanetti and Gabriel Batistuta."

"I think that we got a good point in the end," he added. "Bari played better than us and had the best chances of the match. We couldn't find the way to play our football and in such conditions I think that we really won a good point."

And the always-honest Capello admitted he was partly to blame for his team's limp performance. "During the whole week, I have been doing my best to convince my players that they must keep their concentration," he agreed. "But I saw that they were too relaxed and self-confident. Clearly, I didn't manage to make myself understood. That's my fault."

Juventus took advantage of Roma's mini-slip with a turgid 1-0 victory at home to Bologna, which reduces the gap at the top of Serie A to six points.

Without the suspended Alessio Tacchinardi and the injured Antonio Conte and Edgar Davids, the bianconeri wheezed rather than wowed on a heavy Stadio delle Alpi pitch. But an early David Trezequet goal proved just about enough - although Bologna blew a perfect chance to equalise when Cruz Jaap Stam-ed his penalty high over Edwin Van der Saar's bar ten minutes from time.

Fiorentina go third

Fatih Terim's Fiorentina are the sleeper hit of Serie A. For most of the season they have looked nothing more than a mid-table side. But then - suddenly, strangely - a run 14 points from their last six games has thrust them into third, leaving Florentine mouths uttering the words "Champions League" and even "Scudetto" for the first time since their beloved Batigol departed.

Milan were the hapless victims this weekend, receiving a good old-fashioned 4-0 shellacking - as Fiorentina knocked up their biggest league win over Milan since 1932/3. As per usual, Rui Costa was the Viola's inspiration, playing the Good Samaritan to set up goals for Nuno Gomes, Sandro Cois and Enrico Chiesa - before deservedly scoring himself three minutes from time.

Lazio hang on, Udinese president calls for foreign refs

What price David Elleray refereeing in Serie A? That's what Udinese president Giampaolo Pozzo is demanding after seeing his 10-men side lose a seven-goal thriller to Lazio. "I have had enough. They're psychologically compromised - they're not free," he blasted. They are so biased towards certain clubs. Why not have foreign referees? It would be the only way to be sure of their behaviour."

With the luxury of an extra man, Lazio cruised to a 4-1 lead shortly after half time. But after goals from Massimo Margiotta and Roberto Sosa, their old defensive uncertainties returned, ensuring an uncomfortable last few minutes for new manager Dino Zoff.

"It reminded me of the France-Italy final when late goals destroyed us," a relieved Zoff admitted. "I'm pleased to win but it got far too close for comfort at the end. This sort of struggle is to be avoided at all costs. But we needed a victory to start a new era and that's what we got."

But the gruff Zoff refused to speculate on Lazio's chances of catching their rivals at the top of Serie A. "I don't want to look at the table," he claimed. "I don't care about Roma. But as far as fans in the San Siro were concerned, Bobo was playing like a bozo during Internazionale's match against Parma - and their booing and catcalling certainly let Vieri know how they felt.

So when he equalised 21 minutes from time to earn Inter a 1-1 draw, it was perhaps not surprising that Bobo refused to coco, and instead returned silently back to his own half. "When I scored that goal I felt anger more than anything else," he said afterwards. "I was furious with the fans."

webTitle: Not so happy Christmas for online retailers

fields.headline: Not so happy Christmas for online retailers
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Christmas shoppers stayed away from the internet in droves, according to a survey from NOP, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Christmas shoppers stayed away from the internet in droves, according to a survey from NOP.

Despite reports of successful e-Xmases for the likes of Dixons, Amazon and GUS, NOP's research shows only 9% consumers did their Christmas shopping online.

Consumers said they were reluctant to shop online because it was just too confusing.

Almost a third claimed that they found the choice of information on the internet overwhelming, while a quarter said it took too long to find what they were looking for.

Adding to the feeling of being 'overwhelmed' by the web, 13% of those questioned said another reason for not shopping online was the fear of their presents not turning up on time.

Indeed, 12% of those who did buy online said they didn't receive their gifts in time for Christmas.

The survey, of 1,000 adults from around the country, was commissioned by Connextra, creator of browser companion Sidewize

"As well as surmounting the well-known problems of fear of fraud and poor fulfilment, websites must now also contend with the need to help users cut through the clutter on the web," said David King Lassman, Connextra chief executive.

Separately, research from retail analysts Verdict also out today, said that the value of home shopping in the UK will almost double to £34.5bn by 2005.

However, the big hurdle for online retailers to overcome in the coming years is the problem with fulfilment and delivery.

webTitle: Government announces court internet overhaul

fields.headline: Government announces court internet overhaul
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Britain's county courts face an overhaul, under government plans announced today to cut costs and modernise the court system by allowing litigants to settle civil lawsuits over the internet.
fields.body:
Britain's county courts face an overhaul, under government plans announced today to cut costs and modernise the court system by allowing litigants to settle civil lawsuits over the internet.

The court service aims to "rationalise" its 222 county courts and replace some of their services with a new website to administer civil claims normally made in person or by post.

The plans, unveiled today by the Lord Chancellor's department, will update a court system that has hardly changed since the 1840s. A consultation paper, Modernising the Civil Courts, proposes a future of "paperless court rooms", where evidence is submitted electronically and writs settled entirely online.

Annoucing the plans, David Lock, a minister in the Lord Chancellor's department, said that the courts are "scattered through the country in a way which owes more to history than to logic or customers' needs today."

Mr Lock said that the online system should result in cheaper and faster settlement of claims for litigants.

"We want internet technology to provide round the clock access," he said. "It's very important that we receive the best elements of traditional and face-to-face justice in our courts while, at the same time, accessing the benefits of new technology."

Preston county court will be the first to handle claims online. From 5 February, litigants will be able to use the internet to file an initial application to the court.

The Lord Chancellor's office plans to introduce further elements of the claims process, such as straightforward money claims, at a later date.

In addition, two pilot schemes of electronic centres offering advice on the court system are being set up in Shropshire.

Some county courts in towns and cities could be closed to make sure centres for legal hearing are better spread through England and Wales - for example, two of London's 16 country courts are just one mile apart.

Meanwhile, courts backroom workers could be centralised to cut costs, says the report, meaning that fewer staff will be needed.

People who do not have access to a computer could still use the internet system through the Citizens' Advice Bureau, libraries and digital television, or use the traditional application methods in person at new legal hearing centres in existing buildings such as magistrates or
coroners courts.

webTitle: DMA attacks Hollick's kids' website

fields.headline: DMA attacks Hollick's kids' website
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The Direct Marketing Association has attacked Sub.Club.com for breaching its guidelines on children's websites, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
A new website backed by Labour peer Lord Hollick has been attacked by the Direct Marketing Association for breaching its guidelines on marketing to kids via the net.

The DMA said Sub-Club.com - the newly launched kids portal backed by Lord Hollick's United Business Media - was wrong to target kids without having a foolproof way of obtaining parents' consent.

Marketing to children is a particularly sensitive issue at a time when the new Swedish presidency of the EU is urging a pan-European ban on advertising aimed at children.

Sub-Club.com is attempting to combine the e-commerce potential of a shopping mall with the interactivity of a chat room.

It has teamed up with brands including Woolworths and Micro Skate Scooter to target seven to 18-year-olds.

Chief executive Naomi Gibney said the site was fully compliant with the Data Protection Act and stressed that children were unable to stray into other sites.

She claimed it e-mails parents to obtain permission before children complete transactions.

However, Jo White, director of legal and public affairs at the DMA, said this was generally insufficient.

"I'm sure Sub-Club is a responsible company but our guidelines are clear on the issue," she said.

"If you're taking data from a child you must have explicit consent from a parent or guardian and at present this must be obtained offline to ensure it is genuine."

Ms White said these guidelines were also the benchmark of TrustUK, the online marketing sector's self-regulatory body.

Because Sub-Club is not a DMA member, it admits it can take no action other than express its disapproval.

webTitle: Mytaxi.com considers online retailing

fields.headline: Mytaxi.com considers online retailing
fields.trailText: Online shopping portal mytaxi.com is considering a move into online retailing, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online shopping portal mytaxi.com is considering a move into online retailing by taking a ride with cash-strapped start-ups.

Chief executive Titus Adam said mytaxi might take advantage of the rapidly consolidating e-commerce scene, using its knowledge of the sector to put companies back on the right track.

"We are approached all the time by e-tailers, who are exhausted and need a partner. We could set up taxi shops and go into e-tailing ourselves, like having your own brand goods in a supermarket," he added.

However, Mr Adam said the main priority for the company, which provides consumers with information on the best products and prices, was to launch a new personalised service and expand abroad.

"Moving into e-tailing goes against what we have done in the past," he said. "As soon as you start taking cash you have to deal with the liability. It complicates the business model."

If the company makes the shock move into e-retailing, it will have no shortage of potential partners in a market where sales are low and investment funds have dried up.

Mytaxi has teamed up with technology firm Applied Psychology Research to set up a system that will allow its corporate clients to build up detailed profiles of online shoppers. In turn, consumers can be targeted with specific offers on certain items.

"About 20% of people personalise on mytaxi. The more people personalise, the better," said Mr Adam.

Despite the guiding hand it is offering to retailers and consumers, mytaxi believes e-commerce will not truly take off until companies agree on a standard method for paying over the net with mobile phones and other wireless technologies.

"We want to help push an industry standard. We hope it is resolved this year, and someone has to push it," added Mr Adam.

He said most e-commerce companies were waiting for high street banks to make the first move in designing an "e-wallet".

webTitle: EastEnders to run four times a week

fields.headline: EastEnders to run four times a week
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: The BBC is to up the ante in its ratings war with ITV by introducing a fourth weekly episode of EastEnders, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC is to up the ante in its ratings war with ITV by introducing a fourth weekly episode of flagship BBC1 soap EastEnders.

After almost a year of speculation it finally announced it was extending the soap's presence - four years after arch-rival Coronation Street introduced its Sunday night episode.

The extra episode of EastEnders will be introduced later this year.

The BBC would not say exactly when, or on which night, the fourth episode will be introduced. EastEnders currently goes out at 8pm on Monday and 7.30pm on Tuesday and Thursday.

Wednesday is the station's weakest night in the ratings, followed by Friday and Sunday.

The fourth weekly episode of EastEnders will be paid for out of the extra £120m investment in new original drama earmarked for BBC1 over the next two years.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey said: "Viewers love EastEnders and this is part of our commitment to the loyalty of our audience, investing in the future of the programme and capitalising on its success."

ITV soap Emmerdale went to five nights a week in September. Coronation Street added a Sunday night episode, taking it to four nights a week, in November 1996.

The soap initially struggled in the ratings but is now a bedrock of the weekend schedule and Sunday is occasionally is the highest rated episode of the week.

webTitle: The science of sex appeal

fields.headline: The science of sex appeal
fields.standfirst: A range of studies brings us closer to finally understanding the mysteries of sexual attraction
fields.trailText: A range of studies brings us closer to finally understanding the mysteries of sexual attraction.
fields.body:
How can men make themselves irresistible to women? Put on a deep booming voice, mention that you are already hitched, and slip into the conversation that you have recently been down to the gym. Oh yes, and try and look rugged and masculine, in a kind of Russell Crowe way. In short, be a real man. But even then your mix of pheromones might be the chemical cocktail that repels rather than attracts a woman.

These are the latest research results from the scientists and academics on the scent of sexual attraction. Experiments are honing in on the secret factors behind sex appeal as researchers across the globe work to demystify the human mating game.

Women perceive men with deep voices as being more attractive, stronger and taller than men who speak in high-pitched tones, Nottingham UniversityÍs behavioural ecology research group revealed last week. After hearing recordings of 34 men aged between 18 and 30 uttering five vowel sounds, 54 women rated the men's attractiveness.

Men speaking in ïlow frequency harmonicsÍ were judged to be more attractive, older and heavier, more likely to have a hairy chest and be more muscular. In reality, there was no connection between the deepness of a man's voice and his chest hair, muscles or height.

Simply mentioning that you have been working on your muscles down the gym though helps to impress others - irrespective of whether this is actually true or not, Canadian researchers revealed earlier this month.

Mentioning that you exercise regularly when first meeting someone creates a positive perception of your personality and physical condition, says the paper published in the Journal of Sport and Exercise Psychology.

Academics at McMaster University in Ontario asked 627 Canadian men and women to rate an individual's personality and physical attributes based on a brief description that included the person's gender and information on whether they exercised.

Non-exercisers were considered to have fewer friends, and to be less brave, smart, neat, happy, sociable and friendly. They were more often perceived as sickly, scrawny and sexually unattractive in comparison to their supposedly healthy, muscular, and sexually attractive counterparts who exercised regularly.

Meanwhile, females find males more attractive if other females also show interest, concluded a study at University of Louisville, Kentucky, last month. Women thought that wealth, rather than a sense of humour or social skills, was the reason why the man was attractive to other women.

The finding that women, like all female members of the animal kingdom, engage in "mate copying" explains a number of social phenomena: why women are attracted more to married men than single men; and why ugly pop stars have so many women swooning at their feet.

The researchers presented 166 female undergraduates with a report in which five (fictitious) women rated the physical attractiveness of a man, and indicated whether they were interested in dating him. The female students were more likely to express interest in the man if more of the women in report had also done so.

A study at St Andrews University, meanwhile this month reported that beautiful women go for more masculine men. A woman's taste depends on how attractive she thinks she is. The academics reckon that beautiful women go for masculine men because they are driven by the urge to have beautiful children while less attractive women find a partner who is least likely to desert them.

But Australian academics at Southern Cross University have found that particular pheromones can produce very different reactions among women. In one test, nursing students were put in a room and asked to choose between two T-shirts, one of which was laced with a pheromone. The study found that some were strongly attracted to the pheromone T-shirt, but others were put off by it. The researchers are still convinced that pheromone sprays in shops could directly and subconsciously affect the purchasing decisions of females.

Tests carried out at the University of Northumbria last year showed that women found ugly men more attractive when they were secretly exposed to the chemicals found in their armpits.

Finally, scientists think they have got to the bottom of the major question in all sex surveys: why men report higher numbers of partners than women. Academics at the University of Washington found that studies about human sexual activity leave out one crucial factor: prostitutes. The researchers conclude that women working as prostitutes are under-represented in the surveys.

webTitle: Obituary: Michael Williams

fields.headline: Michael Williams
fields.standfirst: Actor whose light television roles belied a substantial talent
fields.trailText: The actor Michael Williams, who has died aged 65, may have lacked what a critic once called "a streak of chilled steel", but that is not surprising for a man who sent his wife, Dame Judi Dench, a single red rose every Friday.
fields.body:
The actor Michael Williams, who has died aged 65, may have lacked what a critic once called "a streak of chilled steel", but that is not surprising for a man who sent his wife, Dame Judi Dench, a single red rose every Friday.

Williams was a gentle man long cherished as Dench's partner; Pooter, the social climber in Mr and Mrs Nobody (1986); Bob, the quietly perplexed suburban husband in Pack of Lies (1983); and the innocent, charming school- teacher in Quartermaine's Terms, which he toured in 1982. On television, the comedy series A Fine Romance was the best known of their joint appearances.

Yet in the early 1960s, he chilled at the Ashcroft theatre, Croydon, wielding a murderous knife in Cry For Love. And in the heyday of Peter Hall's Royal Shakespeare Company, a year or two later, he angered enough theatre-goers as Adolf Eichmann, in The Representative, to need police protection.

By 1971, Williams had settled for a more genial and comic persona. His studies of ordinary men in extraordinary situations could be as beguiling as his farcical frenzies - when his face would redden, his posture tremble and his person appear to be on the point of seizure.

It was his appearances in Ray Cooney's plays, farces which produced sublime acting, that were to lift his talent to stardom. There was his achievement as George, the PPS to Donald Sinden's adulterous cabinet minister in Two Into One (1984) and Out of Order (1990). "Donald and I," Williams said, "are both agreed; compared to this, King Lear is a piece of cake."

After l4 years at the RSC, Dench and Williams were amused to find fame as an unmarried couple trying to resist all temptation to marry in A Fine Romance (1980-82). In Can You Hear Me Thinking? (1990), they were the anxious parents of a schizophrenic adolescent. Other series included September Song, Conjugal Rites and A Dance to the Music of Time (1997).

But Williams worried about his theatrical technique growing rusty if he spent too long in front of the cameras, and he knew the pleasure of laughter from an audience. When he returned to the stage, it was as John Aubrey, the 17th-century antiquary and gossip, in Brief Lives (1998), an exquisite portrait of thoughtful old age.

An insurance man's son, Williams was born in Manchester and educated at St Edward's College, Liverpool, where his English teacher inspired a love of Shakespeare. At 16, he asked his father about drama school. He was told to ask again at 21 and, meanwhile, went into insurance. After national service, he won a scholarship to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, graduating in 1959 and joining the Nottingham Playhouse.

Behind his often flippant, physically agile exterior was an imagination which was to turn the lightest parts into characters of consequence. A devout Catholic, he was appointed a Knight of St Gregory, one of the highest honours in the Catholic church, last November. He married Judi Dench, a Quaker, in 1971. She and their daughter, Finty, also an actress, survive him.

 Michael Leonard Williams, actor, born July 19 1935; died January 11 2001

webTitle: Tesco takes brand dispute to European court

fields.headline: Tesco takes brand dispute to European court
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Tesco will take its fight to sell brands obtained via the 'grey market' to the European Court, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Tesco will fight for its right to sell brands obtained via the 'grey market' at rock bottom prices when it appears before the European Court of Justice tomorrow.

The UK's biggest supermarket will appear before 15 European judges in a landmark legal battle with jean-maker Levi Strauss.

Levi's is trying to control the distribution, and ultimately the premium status, of its jeans brand, which Tesco has been importing from cheaper countries outside the EU and selling at a discount to British shoppers.

Brands such as Levi's believe they are protected by a 1998 case - known as the Silhouette judgement - which allows the brand owner to tell importers where, and to whom its products can be sold.

But Tesco will argue that once a product has been bought, the new owner has every right to decide what to do with it.

It claims brand owners are hampering free trade and deliberately keeping prices artificially high for EU consumers.

Just before Christmas, Tesco smuggled in 2,500 Sony Playstation 2 consoles - the next consignment of which has been delayed by Sony - and put them on sale at the recommended retail price in its stores.

It criticised Sony for deliberately restricting the popular toy from consumers.
