webTitle: Your Christmas turkeys

fields.headline: Your Christmas turkeys
fields.standfirst:
We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here are some of your entries

If yours was worse than these, enter our competition to win a palmtop computer here
Read more Christmas turkey stories
fields.trailText: We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here are some of your entries
fields.body:
My worst present has to be bubble bath, which I often receive from several people, including my mother. What's wrong with that? Well for the last ten years I have lived in this house and we only have a shower!
Lynn Mercer

A few years ago air plants were all the rage. My sister decided to buy me one, so she chose a very attractive plant, growing on a branch, which she lovingly and carefully wrapped up with a nice ribbon. A month later Xmas arrived, I opened up my beautifully wrapped present and was presented with a completely dead bit of mould on a dry twig. Air plants might not need food but they do need light apparently.
Steve Palmer

My worst Xmas present was from a young man that I was seeing three years ago. We had been together for several months and the relationship was getting quite serious. I was hoping for anything that spelt romance - a ring or bracelet - to give me some clue as to how he really felt about me. I was therefore shocked and disappointed when the package he gave me, when unwrapped, revealed a frying pan. As an independent woman who does not picture herself as becoming a housewife, this was devastating as it showed me exactly how he perceived my future role. I had to dump him!
Madeline Lewis

I got a month's supply of X-Fat - need I say more!
Jackie Brennan

My two children (aged eight and eleven) spent their first Christmas with me since I separated from their mum three years ago. Christmas morning saw much giggling as I opened their present to me which was an inflatable head support for the bath - in the form of a pair of black lace clad boobs. They hadn't realised what they were for and thought I would wear them!
Simon Wood

Upon grabbing a strange shaped squidgy package from my stocking, imagine my surprise and amusement as I eagerly ripped the paper off a pair of inflatable doggy slippers, that's right - blow-up slippers! As we rarely hoover the floor in our house I wonder how long it will be before I burst the puppies attached to my cold feet.
Chris Hutcheon

My worst present was a broken picture. A friend sent a very cheap (pink plastic framed) landscape picture (he was unemployed at the time). Unfortunately the postman left the package in the garage as there was nobody at home. Unknown to me, my wife had found the package after driving over it with the car - she did not know she had done this. It had been bubble wrapped and taped up, wrapped in Xmas paper then packaged in brown paper so the effect of a large car driving over it was masked until I opened it on Xmas day! I must admit I felt sorry for our friend who had wasted his money to buy something. The picture was awful even if it had been undamaged. It got dumped rather rapidly in the bin. My friend was duly thanked for his generosity. I am always very careful now when driving into the garage especially in the dark during winter one never knows what might have been sent!
John Lasocki

A couple of years ago whilst a student, I unwrapped at least five bad presents including floor cleaner, scouring pads, furniture polish, bleach and drain cleaner....nice. I think my mum was trying to tell me something. They made a significant pile under the tree and to say I was disappointed would be no lie.
Dan Wright

I once received a garden spade from my husband, cunningly wrapped to look like... a spade, that was a real surprise!! That was only surpassed by the gift of a trowel the following year. Now I do like gardening, but I wasn't going to dig the flower beds in December. I think I would have preferred slippers, come to think of it, I think I got those a year later together with a natty pair of gardening gloves!
Sally Rose

I have to say my worst Xmas present of all time was given to me this year. My aunty Sue sent me a pack of three men's briefs all in a highly attractive fleshy colour - considering the fact that I am of the fairer sex these are the most useless Xmas present ever. I can't even wrap them up again and send them to someone else as I don't know anyone who would even consider wearing a pair of fleshy pants - a real passion killer!!!!! I don't know how to thank her for this attractive gift either - I've been putting off writing a 'thank you' letter - any ideas??!!
Jennie Agarwala

I mentioned that as a new year's resolution I'd try to lose some weight and wouldn't mind something at Christmas to help me in my quest. I open my present on Christmas Day expecting some weights or running shoes, but oh no... My wife had bought me a Rosemary Conley keep fit video!
David Hopwood

I got my worst ever Christmas present this year - a pair of old fashion pyjamas four sizes too big.
Madelaine Merriman

The worse Christmas present I got was a parcel from my family containing food and goodies from Norway, home made cookies, etc.. ( I was backpacking in Australia at the time). The parcel got delayed and forced me to stay in Cairns for an extra week (wrecking my budget in the process). I was charged a fortune to clear it through customs, who confiscated half of the food inside because it is was not allowed to be imported in to Oz, and the remaining food was inedible - the cookies were smashed to bits, a glass pot of herrings had leaked and I had to throw the whole lot in the bin! It was a total disaster, but I did not say anything to my folks, just thank you!!
Frederic Degeilh

Having expensive taste and maxing out my credit cards, my friends joke that I'm the girl who has everything (even if I can't afford it all!) and they got together and bought me a belly-button brush for Christmas (to remove belly-button fluff, I presume). It was quickly discarded!
Tracy Johnson

My worst and most least thought out present was from my father. He wrapped up a second hand Philips School Atlas as my Christmas present. I am 41 years old and have teenage sons (I am not a school teacher). He then had the audacity to write on it "I thought the boys might get some use out of this"! Up to that point we had not even fallen out! I think he has decided to take over from where his own mother left as she used to give out whatever she had in the house at the time. One year my whole family were the happy recipients of a tin of rice pudding: that is apart from my father who received a bowl of Kellogs Cornflakes - but then he was always her favourite.
Phil Shelton

The worst present was this Christmas. I got a minidisc carrier. Sounds good, but I don't have a minidisc, my mother mistook it for something else and bought the wrong thing. The worst thing about it was that it was the first present I opened so until my mum explained I though I was actually getting a minidisc. Gutted. A Handspring Palm Top would ease the pain and torture though.
Steve Hornby

The worst Christmas present I ever received was from a girl I was seeing around three years ago. I agonised over what would be a suitable present for her, as we hadn't been seeing each other that long and to be honest, I wasn't sure how much longer the relationship was going to last anyway. I finally settled on a rather sweet glass bowl, some of those floating candles and a copy of 'It's a Wonderful Life' on video. Nice. Anyway, I was out at a Christmas do and came back home to see that she had let herself into my flat (she had a key and everything...). She was sitting on the couch, wine in hand, presents in her lap and after a while we got round to opening the gifts. She seemed very happy with hers so I was made up. Then it came to opening mine. I suppose that I should've suspected something was amiss when she said "I just know that you're going to hate this..." I opened it up and looked at what it was. A metal atomiser was sitting in my hand with a star embossed on the front. It was a fragrance that I had never heard of before but I thought, I'm game, I'll see what it's like. The smell was so over-powering! There was an expectant look on her face. The only way I could play it was with pure honesty. I did not like it. "Oh" she said, "well you're not going to like the other gift I've bought you then..." It was the deodorant in the same brand. I felt like a right scrooge. Until... She went on to tell me how it was her favourite smelly stuff (God how it smelt) and if I didn't like it she would gladly take it off my hands as she loved it so. So technically I suppose this has to be the worst Christmas present I ever got, and then had taken back. Does that count?...
John Sandy

An elderly aunt asked what I wanted for Christmas and knowing she wasn't particularly well off, I said 'just get me the Weekend Guardian'. She must have thought I had Val Doonican tendencies because lo and behold on Christmas Day I opened a lovely blue 'weekend' cardigan.
Phil Sutcliffe

When I first married my husband 13 years ago, I was in dire need of a car to get to work. Christmas morning he said my chrissie present was in the garage, I just couldn't believe it I ran out to the garage to find.. a set of loft ladders wrapped with ribbon and bows!! Hubby said they would be really useful and I must say, HE has found them useful, but it really wasn't the present my heart desired.
Sue Daniels

This year my teenage son (bless him) thought he'd really got me the ideal present. My husband wouldn't tell me what it was, even though I pestered before Christmas day. Imagine my surprise (!) when I opened this long awaited present. It was a cover that wrapped round my computer screen. Doesn't sound too bad does it? Until I tell you that it was black and white and in the shape of a cow. Yes, two big floppy ears hung down the sides and the most monstrous pair of horns sat perched on the top of the computer like a big game trophy. Wouldn't have been so bad if the computer was hidden away in an office or spare room. But, no. Not in our house. It sits loud and proud in the kitchen where everyone sits when they visit. I have now very quietly taken it back to the shop and exchanged it for something a little less 'glaring'!!
Mrs Howson

What did Santa put in my stocking this year? Socks! Not just any new socks, but as an occasional golfer - golfing socks. Why do people insist on buying the latest, most tasteless or useless gifts for golfers? It wasn't the socks by themselves - there were 14 pairs all exactly the same! Black of foot with a brown, green and red pattern top. 14 pairs, that's more than I manage rounds of golf in a year. How could I possibly use them all? I suppose I could use them as club covers, maximum number of clubs 14, so that's one lot on the clubs and another set in the wash.. No chance of a penalty for the incorrect number of clubs in future!
David Pollitt

My mother gave me a pair of heavy duty black rubber gloves with a clump of cloth- made flowers at the elbow end. Not sure what she was trying to tell me!
Alison New

My sister Sue really excelled herself this year. Usually we exchange gifts of perfume or jewellery, but out shopping with her before Christmas I happend to say I could do with a metal ice cream scoop as the plastic one I had wasn't very strong. I thought nothing more of it until Christmas morning that is.. I got to Sue's prezzie which was in a box marked fragile - a delicate china ornament perhaps? I carefully opened the packaging and yes you guessed it, there, staring me in the face was a metal ice cream scoop. She'll be sorry this year you wait and see.
Sheila Titley

Imagine, I was 11 years old and my friends and I were talking about what games we would get for our spanking new Sega megadrives. I really wanted sonic the hedgehog, as I had been down the local shops and played on it in a store. Others wanted football games, tennis games and fighting games, but all I wanted was sonic the hedgehog. So Christmas Day came and when I went downstairs I saw it, a box about the same size as a Sega megadrive, I couldn't wait to rip it open. I had to open it last as that was the rule, open the best Christmas present last.

I picked it up and thought to myself 'this is a bit heavy? They must have filled it with lots of games' I thought, so I ripped open the present with delight to reveal a shiny new...toolbox? "Suprise!" dad said, "I thought you could make a kennel for the dog, he gets a bit cold in the winter". Because I had great respect for my dad I didn't dare say how I really felt as I didn't want to hurt his feelings. So with tear filled eyes I said "thanks dad, just what I wanted". So for the remainder of Christmas I was outside, freezing, making this kennel for the dog while all my other friends were playing with their spanking new playstations.
Jason Curzon

My Husband's grandmother is notorious for giving the tat she wins in the bingo as Christmas gifts. It's always a big laugh in our house during the holiday season. This year, however, she has really outdone herself. Under our tree were two giant Teletubbies Easter eggs, unwrapped, sitting in carrier bags. Next to those little gems was a set of really tacky ceramic cute-kitten-shaped salt and pepper shakers. Again, unwrapped. As if the gifts weren't bad enough, they absolutely stunk of fags. She is a heavy smoker and we know for a fact there is a room in the house where she leaves her bingo booty to fester throughout the year. Bless!
Julie Wilson

A nasty dose of glandular fever - caught from someone I'd kissed under the mistletoe at the office Christmas party. Spending the whole of Christmas in a darkened room with lumps the size of tennis balls in my neck, and unable to eat, was not the sort of Christmas Present I'd had in mind!!!
Sharon Clarke

My worst Christmas present was discovering my husband had a lover. She rang him on Christmas Day, I was eight months pregnant with twins!
Anonymous

My turkey gift? Shania Twain (the platinum collection) video. I'm 54 with four adult kids and 3 granddaughters, but I love Freddie Mercury and Queen!! I'm open to offers for the unplayed vid, otherwise it goes to the charity shop!
Karawl Dowds

The worst gift I have ever had has got to be from the firm I worked for. A couple of days before Christmas instead of getting our usual bottle of wine they gave us all our notice and told us that they were not paying us that month.
Heather Tamworth

Here's my story about a particularly 'weird' Christmas gift... My nan, like a lot of women her age was an incredibly innocent and sheltered woman. So much so, my mum used to tell us not to swear in front of her or go out wearing short skirts when she came down to visit. So imagine our surprise a couple of years ago when she gave my dad some sort of 'caring for your horse' magazine (not that much of a strange gift, but he doesn't actually own a horse or have any interest in them) and I, who was only 14 at the time, received a 'Penis Grooming Kit' - complete with illustrations of the organ in question, modelling different..erm....'hair' styles. I didn't exactly know how to react when I opened my present on Christmas morning, but it was certainly one of my most interesting gifts!
Laura Jones

My worst and most mind boggling Christmas present was from my boyfriend of two months. He bought me a giant catering size jar of pickled onions! Not exactly the romantic present I was expecting! To this day I'm still not entirely sure why?! But it took two years to get through them and he's now my husband so I can't have minded that much !
Sarah Ockwell-Smith

I once told my nan that I liked Robbie Williams. What a mistake that was! The following Christmas I got the video "Mrs Doubtfire". Then, on my birthday, the video "Flubber". On my graduation I got the video "Patch Adams". These films all starred ROBIN Williams, who I can't stand. No doubt I'll get a Mork and Mindy pencil case for Easter. In return, I'll be buying my Nan a new hearing aid.
Emma Clarke

I received a potato peeler from my husband, yes I am not joking I only wish I was. He was beaming when I opened it as he thought it would be a great idea, as I was having a lot of visitors for Christmas dinner and my old peeler had seen better days. Luckily I managed to turn the whole situation around by getting him to help me peel the vegetables as we now had two peelers. How fortunate after all!
Karen Wilson

I had a grapefruit knife (I have always hated grapefruit) from my mother-in-law (who likes to eat grapefruit whenever she comes round) and a plastic toilet-roll holder for the outside toilet fom my wife!
Phil Nevard

The worst or most unusual present ever has to be the one received by my dad from his brother. We were all intrigued beforehand as it was small, round and rattled. You can imagine our surprise when we opened it and found a box of car travel sweets.
Simon Penfold

As a Leeds United fan, I think my worst present must have been a pair of Everton boxer shorts which I received as a stocking filler from my own mother some years ago. When I chided her with regard to both her taste and knowledge of her only child she archly replied: "Don't worry - no-one will ever see them!"
Lou George

I was 16 years old. Music, clothes and possibly something smelly might have gone down well for Christmas but my poor well meaning parents had never managed to master the art of giving. To be fair, we were living in Africa at the time and the selection of gifts to be had was pretty limited. Even so, not much could have prepared me for the gift my parents had selected. It was a rain gauge - one of those nasty plastic funnels you use to measure rainfall. Wow, all for me? My father was especially exited about the customised frame that held it in the garden and was just gagging to get out there and set it up. I have never prayed so hard for a drought in my life before.
Gary Burgoyne

My wife bought me a do it yourself will kit for Christmas.We only got married this year. I thought she was after my good looks.
James Routley

Phil Shelton The worst present was this Christmas. I got a minidisc carrier. Sounds good, but I don't have a minidisc, my mother mistook it for something else and bought the wrong thing. The worst thing about it was that it was the first present I opened so until my mum explained I though I was actually getting a minidisc. Gutted. A Handspring Palm Top would ease the pain and torture though. Steve Hornby The worst Christmas present I ever received was from a girl I was seeing around three years ago. I agonised over what would be a suitable present for her, as we hadn't been seeing each other that long and to be honest, I wasn't sure how much longer the relationship was going to last anyway. I finally settled on a rather sweet glass bowl, some of those floating candles and a copy of 'It's a Wonderful Life' on video. Nice. Anyway, I was out at a Christmas do and came back home to see that she had let herself into my flat (she had a key and everything...). She was sitting on the couch, wine in hand, presents in her lap and after a while we got round to opening the gifts. She seemed very happy with hers so I was made up. Then it came to opening mine. I suppose that I should've suspected something was amiss when she said "I just know that you're going to hate this..." I opened it up and looked at what it was. A metal atomiser was sitting in my hand with a star embossed on the front. It was a fragrance that I had never heard of before but I thought, I'm game, I'll see what it's like. The smell was so over-powering! There was an expectant look on her face. The only way I could play it was with pure honesty. I did not like it. "Oh" she said, "well you're not going to like the other gift I've bought you then..." It was the deodorant in the same brand. I felt like a right scrooge. Until... She went on to tell me how it was her favourite smelly stuff (God how it smelt) and if I didn't like it she would gladly take it off my hands as she loved it so. So technically I suppose this has to be the worst Christmas present I ever got, and then had taken back. Does that count?... John Sandy An elderly aunt asked what I wanted for Christmas and knowing she wasn't particularly well off, I said 'just get me the Weekend Guardian'. She must have thought I had Val Doonican tendencies because lo and behold on Christmas Day I opened a lovely blue 'weekend' cardigan. Phil Sutcliffe When I first married my husband 13 years ago, I was in dire need of a car to get to work. Christmas morning he said my chrissie present was in the garage, I just couldn't believe it I ran out to the garage to find.. a set of loft ladders wrapped with ribbon and bows!! Hubby said they would be really useful and I must say, HE has found them useful, but it really wasn't the present my heart desired. Sue Daniels This year my teenage son (bless him) thought he'd really got me the ideal present. My husband wouldn't tell me what it was, even though I pestered before Christmas day. Imagine my surprise (!) when I opened this long awaited present. It was a cover that wrapped round my computer screen. Doesn't sound too bad does it? Until I tell you that it was black and white and in the shape of a cow. Yes, two big floppy ears hung down the sides and the most monstrous pair of horns sat perched on the top of the computer like a big game trophy. Wouldn't have been so bad if the computer was hidden away in an office or spare room. But, no. Not in our house. It sits loud and proud in the kitchen where everyone sits when they visit. I have now very quietly taken it back to the shop and exchanged it for something a little less 'glaring'!! Mrs Howson What did Santa put in my stocking this year? Socks! Not just any new socks, but as an occasional golfer - golfing socks. Why do people insist on buying the latest, most tasteless or useless gifts for golfers? It wasn't the socks by themselves - there were 14 pairs all exactly the same! Black of foot with a brown, green and red pattern top. 14 pairs, that's more than I manage rounds of golf in a year. How could I possibly use them all? I suppose I could use them as club covers, maximum number of clubs 14, so that's one lot on the clubs and another set in the wash.. No chance of a penalty for the incorrect number of clubs in future! David Pollitt My mother gave me a pair of heavy duty black rubber gloves with a clump of cloth- made flowers at the elbow end. Not sure what she was trying to tell me! Alison New My sister Sue really excelled herself this year. Usually we exchange gifts of perfume or jewellery, but out shopping with her before Christmas I happend to say I could do with a metal ice cream scoop as the plastic one I had wasn't very strong. I thought nothing more of it until Christmas morning that is.. I got to Sue's prezzie which was in a box marked fragile - a delicate china ornament perhaps? I carefully opened the packaging and yes you guessed it, there, staring me in the face was a metal ice cream scoop. She'll be sorry this year you wait and see. Sheila Titley Imagine, I was 11 years old and my friends and I were talking about what games we would get for our spanking new Sega megadrives. I really wanted sonic the hedgehog, as I had been down the local shops and played on it in a store. Others wanted football games, tennis games and fighting games, but all I wanted was sonic the hedgehog. So Christmas Day came and when I went downstairs I saw it, a box about the same size as a Sega megadrive, I couldn't wait to rip it open. I had to open it last as that was the rule, open the best Christmas present last. I picked it up and thought to myself 'this is a bit heavy? They must have filled it with lots of games' I thought, so I ripped open the present with delight to reveal a shiny new...toolbox? "Suprise!" dad said, "I thought you could make a kennel for the dog, he gets a bit cold in the winter". Because I had great respect for my dad I didn't dare say how I really felt as I didn't want to hurt his feelings. So with tear filled eyes I said "thanks dad, just what I wanted". So for the remainder of Christmas I was outside, freezing, making this kennel for the dog while all my other friends were playing with their spanking new playstations. Jason Curzon My Husband's grandmother is notorious for giving the tat she wins in the bingo as Christmas gifts. It's always a big laugh in our house during the holiday season. This year, however, she has really outdone herself. Under our tree were two giant Teletubbies Easter eggs, unwrapped, sitting in carrier bags. Next to those little gems was a set of really tacky ceramic cute-kitten-shaped salt and pepper shakers. Again, unwrapped. As if the gifts weren't bad enough, they absolutely stunk of fags. She is a heavy smoker and we know for a fact there is a room in the house where she leaves her bingo booty to fester throughout the year. Bless! Julie Wilson A nasty dose of glandular fever - caught from someone I'd kissed under the mistletoe at the office Christmas party. Spending the whole of Christmas in a darkened room with lumps the size of tennis balls in my neck, and unable to eat, was not the sort of Christmas Present I'd had in mind!!! Sharon Clarke My worst Christmas present was discovering my husband had a lover. She rang him on Christmas Day, I was eight months pregnant with twins! Anonymous My turkey gift? Shania Twain (the platinum collection) video. I'm 54 with four adult kids and 3 granddaughters, but I love Freddie Mercury and Queen!! I'm open to offers for the unplayed vid, otherwise it goes to the charity shop! Karawl Dowds The worst gift I have ever had has got to be from the firm I worked for. A couple of days before Christmas instead of getting our usual bottle of wine they gave us all our notice and told us that they were not paying us that month. Heather Tamworth Here's my story about a particularly 'weird' Christmas gift... My nan, like a lot of women her age was an incredibly innocent and sheltered woman. So much so, my mum used to tell us not to swear in front of her or go out wearing short skirts when she came down to visit. So imagine our surprise a couple of years ago when she gave my dad some sort of 'caring for your horse' magazine (not that much of a strange gift, but he doesn't actually own a horse or have any interest in them) and I, who was only 14 at the time, received a 'Penis Grooming Kit' - complete with illustrations of the organ in question, modelling different..erm....'hair' styles. I didn't exactly know how to react when I opened my present on Christmas morning, but it was certainly one of my most interesting gifts! Laura Jones My worst and most mind boggling Christmas present was from my boyfriend of two months. He bought me a giant catering size jar of pickled onions! Not exactly the romantic present I was expecting! To this day I'm still not entirely sure why?! But it took two years to get through them and he's now my husband so I can't have minded that much ! Sarah Ockwell-Smith I once told my nan that I liked Robbie Williams. What a mistake that was! The following Christmas I got the video "Mrs Doubtfire". Then, on my birthday, the video "Flubber". On my graduation I got the video "Patch Adams". These films all starred ROBIN Williams, who I can't stand. No doubt I'll get a Mork and Mindy pencil case for Easter. In return, I'll be buying my Nan a new hearing aid. Emma Clarke I received a potato peeler from my husband, yes I am not joking I only wish I was. He was beaming when I opened it as he thought it would be a great idea, as I was having a lot of visitors for Christmas dinner and my old peeler had seen better days. Luckily I managed to turn the whole situation around by getting him to help me peel the vegetables as we now had two peelers. How fortunate after all! Karen Wilson I had a grapefruit knife (I have always hated grapefruit) from my mother-in-law (who likes to eat grapefruit whenever she comes round) and a plastic toilet-roll holder for the outside toilet fom my wife! Phil Nevard The worst or most unusual present ever has to be the one received by my dad from his brother. We were all intrigued beforehand as it was small, round and rattled. You can imagine our surprise when we opened it and found a box of car travel sweets. Simon Penfold As a Leeds United fan, I think my worst present must have been a pair of Everton boxer shorts which I received as a stocking filler from my own mother some years ago. When I chided her with regard to both her taste and knowledge of her only child she archly replied: "Don't worry - no-one will ever see them!" Lou George I was 16 years old. Music, clothes and possibly something smelly might have gone down well for Christmas but my poor well meaning parents had never managed to master the art of giving. To be fair, we were living in Africa at the time and the selection of gifts to be had was pretty limited. Even so, not much could have prepared me for the gift my parents had selected. It was a rain gauge - one of those nasty plastic funnels you use to measure rainfall. Wow, all for me? My father was especially exited about the customised frame that held it in the garden and was just gagging to get out there and set it up. I have never prayed so hard for a drought in my life before. Gary Burgoyne My wife bought me a do it yourself will kit for Christmas.We only got married this year. I thought she was after my good looks. James Routley Read more entries

webTitle: New Media Markets round-up

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 12.
fields.trailText: January 12: A report on BSkyB from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter shows that the satellite firm makes the bulk of its earnings from its channel business.
fields.body:
A report on BSkyB from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter shows that the satellite firm makes the bulk of its earnings from its channel business (selling channels to cable operators and ONdigital) rather than its direct-to-home satellite operation.

Canal Plus faces a busy year ahead, with major changes likely to be introduced following the group's absorption in the new Vivendi Universal media giant. First up is to be the company's "rather messy assortment of interests in thematic channels".

ONdigital's offices in south London are starting to resemble the Ministry of Truth in George Orwell's 1984, where history was revised to suit current political needs. NMM looks back at press release targets and revised amendments to these.

Between 2,000 and 3,000 Telewest digital subscribers have been unable to access the company's interactive services for more than a month, owing to faults in set-top boxes.

webTitle: TV ratings Jan 15 update

fields.headline: Big Breakfast duo depart on a high
fields.standfirst: Weekend ratings
fields.trailText:
2pm: Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen ended their Big Breakfast careers on a ratings high, writes Jason Deans.
Weekend ratings
fields.body:
Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen ended their Big Breakfast presenting careers on a ratings high on Friday morning.

The dynamic Big Breakfast duo attracted the show's best ratings since before they were reunited in September for their swansong.

The Channel 4 morning show had 0.7m and a 17% share of breakfast viewing on Friday from 7-9am.

Last week overall the Big Breakfast took 0.5m and 13% of viewing, which compares favourably with the show's weekly average ratings for the previous month.

A new five-strong Big Breakfast presenting team - Melanie Sykes, Paul Tonkinson, Amanda Byram, Donna Air and Richard Bacon - is due to take over later this month.

webTitle: TV ratings Jan 13-14

fields.headline: ITV's Popstars beaten by old Fools
fields.trailText: 1.15pm TV overnights: ITV's new entertainment show Popstars was beaten by a repeat of Only Fools and Horses on Saturday night. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's heavily promoted new entertainment show, Popstars, was beaten by a repeat of Only Fools and Horses on BBC1 on its first Saturday night outing.

Popstars, which moved to its regular early Saturday evening slot after debuting last Wednesday, had 6.7m and a 31% share from 5.55-6.55pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Only Fools and Horses attracted 6.9m and a 32% share from 6-6.50pm.

Popstars was also slightly below the average, of 6.8m and a 34% share, for the pre-Blind Date slot over the preceding four weeks.

But among its target audience of 16-34 year olds, the show attracted a healthy 39% share.

Channel 5's new reality entertainment format, The Mole, fared better on its Friday night debut, relatively speaking.

The show, in which 10 contestants try to complete physical and psychological tests while working out who the mole in their midst is, took 1.4m and a 6% share, 8-9pm.

In the past four weeks Channel 5 shows have averaged 1.1m and a 5% share in that Friday night slot.

Channel 5 insiders were also pleased with The Mole's demographic profile. The show posted a 79% increase in 16-34 viewers compared with the average for its slot.

It also doubled its percentage of ABC1s, which made up 46% of The Mole's total audience.

BBC2's I Love the 80s series launched successfully on Saturday, suggesting that viewers' appetite for relatively cheap, archive-driven shows about recent pop culture history is far from exhausted.

I Love the 80s, which opened with Larry Hagman - JR from Dallas - looking back at 1980, had a perky 3.5m and 15% share from 9-10.30pm.

On Sunday night BBC2 dusted off factual dinosaur the World At War for yet another outing.

The landmark 1970s history of the second world war, produced by Jeremy Isaacs and voiced by Laurence Olivier, drew a respectable 2.1m and 8% share from 8.10-9pm.

It thrashed Channel 4 opposition Year One: a Snapshot of Britain in the 21st Century, which had just 0.8m.

Proving the enduring appeal of grumpy northern blokes in anoraks, David Jason returned to ITV on Sunday night in a new Touch of Frost. The detective drama drew a majestic 14.2m and 57%, 9.10-10.40pm.

BBC1 opposition Rebel Heart managed just 2.7m and a 10% share from 9-9.50pm.

A Touch of Frost also gave a leg-up to the returning Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned. The live comedy-show-without-a-safety-net had 6.1m and an impressive 38% share from 10.40-11.10pm.

webTitle: Cosmo ads target women train drivers

fields.headline: Cosmo ads target women train drivers
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: London Underground is running ads for women train drivers in women's glossy Cosmopolitan, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Driving a tube train might not seem the obvious career choice for the average Cosmopolitan reader, but all that could change if London Underground's latest ad campaign proves a success.

Tube managers have taken the unusual step of placing an ad in Cosmopolitan magazine in a bid to attract more women tube drivers.

A half-page colour ad that appears in the latest issue of Cosmopolitan magazine appeals to young women with the line, "We believe in modern values ... like opening doors for women."

The ad promises a starting salary of more than £27,000, "free travel for you and your partner" and an "attractive uniform".

"We want to reach people who wouldn't automatically think of this for a career," said a spokeswoman for London Underground. "We are trying to say that this is a job women can do just as well as men."

At the moment only 100 of London's 3,000 tube drivers are women, but tube managers are keen to redress the balance.

webTitle: Gainsborough Studios are to become luxury flats

fields.headline: Where the lady vanished
fields.standfirst: Hitchcock made his first films here, Boris Karloff was a regular. Now Gainsborough Studios are to become luxury flats.  Steve Rose  reports
fields.trailText: Hitchcock made his first films here, Boris Karloff was a regular. Now Gainsborough Studios are to become luxury flats. Steve Rose reports.
fields.body:
Film studios are, of necessity, adaptable buildings but the Gainsborough Studios, in Hoxton, London, have proved more versatile than most. In their film-production heyday, when Hitchcock made movies here, they served as everything from mad professor's laboratory to railway station, to 19th-century manor house to mermaid's lair. At various other times the building has also been a power station, avant-garde theatre and whisky store. But now it is preparing for another incarnation: a luxury residential development.

At the start of its life, this enormous canalside brick construction wasn't a film studio, but an electrical power station for the East London railway line, built in about 1900. It entered the movie business after the first world war, when American studios were taking over impoverished London facilities to expand their empires. The property caught the eye of Jesse Lasky, head of Famous Players, who noted it was "a location where heavy fog would collect even when the rest of London was in bright sunshine". It was swiftly converted into a two-stage studio with workshops and offices, and began turning out films in 1920. Among the studio's first employees was a sign painter named Alfred Hitchcock. Four years later it was sold to Michael Balcon, who formed Gainsborough Pictures, using the building as one of his two London studios (in those days it was known as Islington Studios).

Under Balcon's guidance, Hitchcock shot his first suspense thriller, The Lodger, there, as well as his 1926 masterpiece, The Lady Vanishes (using one train coach and plenty of back projections). Also to be found passing through the Islington compound over the next two decades were former music hall stars such as Will Hay, Gracie Fields and the Crazy Gang, horror veteran Boris Karloff, Third Man director Carol Reed and, later, James Mason, Phyllis Calvert and Stewart Granger, for the shooting of Anthony Asquith's Fanny By Gaslight. At the start of the second world war, however, the building's huge chimney was judged a liability in the event of an air raid, and production began to wind down, finally grinding to a halt when the studio was sold in 1949.

For the next 50 years the building languished in obscurity but, as Hoxton's fortunes have risen, so it has become a hot property once more. Its combination of post-industrial urban chic, vogue-ish location ("the birthplace of BritArt" as the sales brochure puts it) and rich cultural history has proved highly marketable. Indeed, for a derelict building it has been remarkably busy of late. Last summer, to both theatrical and architectural acclaim, the main turbine hall was transformed into a temporary extension of the Almeida Theatre, where Ralph Fiennes led productions of Shakespeare's Richard II and Coriolanus. The architects knocked through a floor that had been added in the 1960s (when the space was a whisky store), to restore the hall's original triple-height volume, and put a massive raked concrete stage in the centre, surrounded by scaffold seating. Otherwise, the scarred interior was unchanged. "At one time, we had to work around a film crew who had turned part of it into a boxing arena for Guy Ritchie's film Snatch," recalls architect Roger Watts of Haworth Tompkins. "There was also a fashion show by Alexander McQueen just before we went in." It has hosted music awards ceremonies, cinema nights and contemporary music performances. On New Year's Eve it was the venue for a party for 3,000 people, featuring four Hitchcock-themed rooms.

Under the new scheme, parts of the studios, including the large turbine hall, will be demolished later this month, though the main studio building will be retained. Around it will snake clean, elegant residential and office blocks, including a 12-storey tower sliced vertically by aluminium fins - an echo of the power station's original chimney, which is likely to become a conspicuous feature of the area. Buildings are mostly brick and steel, with plenty of glass and large X-beams supporting the lower floors - in other words, a rectilinear ultra-modern style which is sure to attract smart young punters. There will also be a nine-story wooden building facing the canal, a tribute to the original wharfside architecture.

"It's like taking a bit of Covent Garden, and putting it up in a brand-new environment," says Steve Marshall, of architects Munkenbeck + Marshall. (Marshall also worked on the restoration of the late Denys Lasdun's nearby Bethnal Green tower block Keeley House.) "The planners were keen to put a very strong landmark here, so it makes sense to have a building that says goodbye to you as you leave Hackney and says hello to you as you come from the north."

For those who resent the rampant gentrification of this part of London, the project is likely to become a prime target for scorn, though there are several other similar conversion schemes under way in the area. As fashionable as the area has become, complaining about its fashionability is even more fashionable. The critics' only consolation is that it could have been much worse. About five years ago, planning permission was granted to turn the site into a bingo hall, surrounded by car parking. That was replaced by another scheme for 100 luxury flats arranged around a private courtyard, which was also abandoned. This project will achieve a much higher density - about 300 flats - but makes several concessions to the public

"The way the planners worked was exceptional," Marshall explains. "They said: 'If you keep the film use and you really promote this part of London as a media focus, we will allow you to build to a higher density, in line with the recommendations of Lord Rogers's Urban Task Force.' Unlike most planners, who would say six storeys was too high, they were saying, 'Go up to 12 storeys but give us a lot more that can be shared by the community'".

There will be the proportion of affordable housing (44 units) now required in new housing developments and a public walkway along the canal but, most importantly, the ground floor is given over to commercial space, which it is hoped will be occupied by film and media companies, most likely pre- and post-production companies - and a link with the site's heritage. A more explicit link is the 6.5 metre-high public sculpture planned for the central courtyard: a semi-abstract bust of Hitchcock's head rising from the ground. Whether it turns out to be a symbol of future cinematic regeneration or a kitsch finale for a development that knows its selling points remains to be seen.

There will also be a nine-story wooden building facing the canal, a tribute to the original wharfside architecture. "It's like taking a bit of Covent Garden, and putting it up in a brand-new environment," says Steve Marshall, of architects Munkenbeck + Marshall. (Marshall also worked on the restoration of the late Denys Lasdun's nearby Bethnal Green tower block Keeley House.) "The planners were keen to put a very strong landmark here, so it makes sense to have a building that says goodbye to you as you leave Hackney and says hello to you as you come from the north." For those who resent the rampant gentrification of this part of London, the project is likely to become a prime target for scorn, though there are several other similar conversion schemes under way in the area. As fashionable as the area has become, complaining about its fashionability is even more fashionable. The critics' only consolation is that it could have been much worse. About five years ago, planning permission was granted to turn the site into a bingo hall, surrounded by car parking. That was replaced by another scheme for 100 luxury flats arranged around a private courtyard, which was also abandoned. This project will achieve a much higher density - about 300 flats - but makes several concessions to the public "The way the planners worked was exceptional," Marshall explains. "They said: 'If you keep the film use and you really promote this part of London as a media focus, we will allow you to build to a higher density, in line with the recommendations of Lord Rogers's Urban Task Force.' Unlike most planners, who would say six storeys was too high, they were saying, 'Go up to 12 storeys but give us a lot more that can be shared by the community'". There will be the proportion of affordable housing (44 units) now required in new housing developments and a public walkway along the canal but, most importantly, the ground floor is given over to commercial space, which it is hoped will be occupied by film and media companies, most likely pre- and post-production companies - and a link with the site's heritage. A more explicit link is the 6.5 metre-high public sculpture planned for the central courtyard: a semi-abstract bust of Hitchcock's head rising from the ground. Whether it turns out to be a symbol of future cinematic regeneration or a kitsch finale for a development that knows its selling points remains to be seen.

webTitle: How to make the leap from business to fundraising

fields.headline: How to make the leap from business to fundraising
fields.standfirst: If you want new year to mean a new job, and you have experience in business, take a look at charity fundraising, says  Nicola Hill
fields.trailText: If you want new year to mean a new job, and you have experience in business, take a look at charity fundraising, says Nicola Hill
fields.body:
Now you have joined the gym and started the diet, it is time to tart up the CV and find a new job. So how about working for a charity? They are in desperate need of fundraisers, according to an annual recruitment survey. "It is certainly a fundraisers' market, and those with the necessary skills should be able to use this to their advantage in choosing the job they want," says Jennie Saunders, research manager at Charity Recruitment.

Of the 100 charities surveyed, a third reported problems recruiting fundraisers, with 45% blaming the low pay on offer. However, a director of fundraising in a charity with a turnover of over £25m can expect to earn an average of £52,571.

Stephen Perrett, chief executive of recruitment agency Execucare, said people in the commercial sector with PR, event management or communications skills can move across easily to the voluntary sector. "People who understand what makes business tick and can manage corporate relationships will walk into a fundraising role."

However, he advises that it is probably easier to move into a larger charity where "a fundraising department will be big enough to take the risk of an employee struggling to adapt to voluntary sector culture".

Before taking the plunge to apply for a job, Susan Holliday, senior consultant at Charity Recruitment, recommends thinking hard about the type of fundraising you want to do - for example, corporate, trust or event fundraising - and then identify the charities that are growing and might need your skills. "It is critical to research the organisation you are applying to and tailor your approach accordingly."

Whether you are already in the charity sector or struggling to break in, there are a number of courses run by the Open University, Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, the Directory of Social Change, the South Bank University and an organisation called Working for a Charity. These can give a good insight and signing up shows commitment. There is also a selection of recruitment agencies specialising in the charity sector. Christian Aid and Imperial Cancer Research Fund are among the few charities that offer graduate training opportunities. Oxfam has a trainee programme but only pays expenses.

Sara Naylor, 25, who graduated in 1999, is now employed as a fundraiser for Raleigh International's Youth Development Programme. Her advice to someone starting out is: "Be prepared to work voluntarily or to take low-paid positions to gain the initial experience that employers are looking for.

"I found it useful to volunteer as a campaigns assistant for Oxfam to get extra experience while applying for jobs. Doing voluntary work also goes a long way toward showing genuine commitment to working within the sector. Competition for jobs is quite high and it helps just to 'get your foot in the door'."

Sophie Morris, 27, warns that jobs in events can be short-lived. "My last job at CSV started on July 31st, the event was on October 28th and my contract ended on that day. Many of the jobs in events are contract based, so an employer who is sceptical of someone who chops and changes can be put off when they see your CV."

Yet Andrew Watt, spokesman for the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, said: "Fundraisers are the most fluid employees in the voluntary sector. The average time a fundraiser stays in a job is two years. There is a huge degree of sideways movement."

This movement illustrates the flip side of job opportunities - the fact that charities are finding it hard to retain fundraisers. Ms Saunders, of Charity Recruitment, found in her research that 20% reported difficulties retaining staff. Respondents cited lack of career development and competition from other organisations. She warned: "Charities will need to address the issues of salary levels and the provision of personal development opportunities for fundraisers if they are to strike gold."

webTitle: Leeds station plans run off the rails

fields.headline: Leeds station plans run off the rails
fields.standfirst:
It's grim up north - or at least it is if you're trying to travel by train to and from Leeds, as Martin Wainwright discovers

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: It's grim up north - or at least it is if you're trying to travel by train to and from Leeds, as Martin Wainwright discovers.
fields.body:
Considering that the world's first colliery railway still runs in Leeds, merrily ferrying tourists rather than coal to the greened-over site of Middleton pit, the state of the city's "real" train station these last four weeks defies belief.

Barred entirely to trains, apart from occasional diesels sneaking off to Skipton or Ilkley from a distant side platform, the place has been ringed instead by "rail support coaches", hired from places as far away as Sunderland and Carlisle.

Puffing exhaust fumes into basement offices along Leeds' "lawyer streets" of Park Place, St Paul's Street and East Parade, these have become the accepted way of getting to England's biggest financial and legal centre outside London.

Hunched in their cabs, the drivers pore over A-Z guides of how to get commuters to connecting stations at Wakefield, Garforth, Castleford and Huddersfield - since December 18, the nearest that trains have been able to get to Yorkshire's unofficial capital.

Today, the grand rebuilding of the station was due to be finished at last, but the prudence of local newspapers turned out to be more than justified.

"Leeds City Station will open on Monday ... maybe", said one prophetic headline. By 8am this morning, "maybe" was the operative word.

Electrical faults, signal glitches and the all too predictable birth pains of a new £165m station meant that travellers' misery continued.

"It's incredible, incredible, incredible," said Linda Fellowes from Harrogate, shuffled to a bus for Wakefield after wasting over half-an-hour on a platform to which the grand re-opening train never came.

"At least they could have changed the signboards - they're all up the creek," commented a colleague of hers from Pudsey, who had been given three different messages by the rail phoneline, local news and the regional director of Railtrack, who gave a strangely buoyant interview on BBC Radio Leeds.

The long siege will gradually end this week, he promised, between gulps at the mounting post-Hatfield bill for his company, whose details were coming out in bulletins before and after his slot.

Too late, though, for city centre shops whose Christmas and new year sales have been the quietest for years, and for the organisers of scores of ill-attended seasonal events.

There are always silver linings; and, on daily flights to London from Leeds/Bradford airport, the curtain dividing business from ordinary passengers has steadily moved down the plane, finally coralling only a handful of long pre-booked ordinaries in the last few seats.

Last month's 14% rise in domestic air travel, announced yesterday, owes a lot to the 45-minute Leeds-London hop.

Back at the station, the Railtrack signs still promote "Leeds first", the name of the rebuilding project which was meant to take only a fortnight over Christmas - the network's least busy time - to carry out the signal, track and platform work.

"If Leeds is first", runs the local mordant query, pray devoutly that it isn't "you next".

webTitle: Madrid go top as Macca whacks Oviedo

fields.headline: Madrid go top as Macca whacks Oviedo
fields.trailText: Sir Bobby Charlton is football's premier junket junkie, travelling the world rubbing shoulders with the good and the great. And Sepp Blatter. This Sunday the comb-over king was in Madrid with Di Stéfano, Kopa and Eusebio for the presentation of the European Footballer of the Year award to Luis Figo.
fields.body:
Sir Bobby Charlton is football's premier junket junkie, travelling the world rubbing shoulders with the good and the great. And Sepp Blatter. This Sunday the comb-over king was in Madrid with Di Stéfano, Kopa and Eusebio for the presentation of the European Footballer of the Year award to Luis Figo.

The Bernabéu crowd, without a hint of irony, gave a rapturous reception to the Portuguese superstar who won the award for his performances as a Barcelona player. Mind you, Figo certainly turned it on for the meringues as they ran out 4-0 winners against Real Oviedo.

Madrid were far from impressive in the first half, but still went in 1-0 up through Figo's fifth goal of the season. The second half was a different story, however: Morientes scored a neat second and then things got even better - McManaman and Munitis were given a run-out.

The Bernabéu loved it, the Oviedo boss, on the other hand, couldn't bear to watch. Antic described their appearance as "a nightmare that we just couldn't stop". Madrid began to turn on the style. First, Munitis - superbly set up by Raúl - scored a third and then, in the dying minutes, came the crowning glory. Roberto Carlos's deep cross was smashed home by a scissors volley from the shaggy-haired scouser.

The madridistas, who hold Macca dear, went absolutely mental - and so did Norma Charlton. Spain's football dailies have gone to town, too. McManaman, said AS, "leapt like a gazelle, connected with Roberto Carlos's cross and the ball flew into the top corner. Brilliant!". Marca has got in on the act, too - its website offers an animated cartoon of "Macca's golazo".

Valencia slip up late

Madrid's win took them three points clear on Sunday night, but they had actually gone top on goal difference on Saturday after Valencia were beaten 2-0 by Deportivo La Coruña. A disappointing match was finally settled in the 88th minute when Pandiani dived to head home Valerón's cross. To add insult to injury, Depor managed to get another one a minute later, Roy Makaay taking advantage of Pelegrino's error.

Valencia, who had held out with ten men after Adrian Ilie was sent off early in the second half, looked devastated and Santiago Cañizares looked ready to kill someone. He wasn't alone - at the final whistle Valencia midfielder David Albelda had to be held back in true Scrappy Doo fashion ("lemme at him, lemme at him") to stop him attacking Djalminha, with whom he'd been "involved" throughout the match. Albelda has let Djalminha off, though, insisting that "what went on was just the product of a tense football match. Anyway, complaining won't change anything now."

Barcelona close the gap - Petit talks about shooting the rest of the squad

Barcelona have closed in on the leading pack after late goals from Pep Guardiola and Rivaldo (on 92 and 93 minutes) secured a 3-1 home win against Valladolid. That was Barça's eleventh win on the trot (including the Copa del Rey, which the Catalans are taking more seriously than most), but all is not well with Serra Ferrer's side. Manu Petit admitted this week that he's unhappy at his lack of minutes at the Nou Camp and might leave at the end of the season. "I can't understand what's going on", said the pony-tailed one, "But what can I do - get a gun and shoot the rest of the squad?"

Well, no Manu, not the rest of the squad, but you could start with comedy keeper Richard Dutruel. The (other) Frenchman with the crap hair complained this week that since coming back from injury he's been unable to regain his place in the side. Oh, and the "míster" is ignoring him, too - "I lost my place due to injury and I hoped to have a new chance after my recovery," he whined. "But that wasn't the case and I'd expect the coach to give me his point of view."

Given his shocking performances so far this year, the Comedy Keeper should count himself lucky that all Lorenzo Serra Ferrer has done is ignore him. The "míster" has responded with that old favourite "if it ain't broke, don't fix it". And since Dutruel left the side it ain't been broke (funny that). Dutruel's replacement, teenage keeper José Reina, has had his worth underlined this week by Barça's decision to up his buy-out clause to 3000 million pesetas (about £11.5m).

John Benjamin Toshack: what an idiot

Over in the Basque country it was derbi day. Real Sociedad had been unbeaten in eight years against Athletic Bilbao, and new boss John Benjamin made the hideous mistake of declaring: "I don't want to be the idiot that loses after fifteen derbis".

Ooops. A typical derbi - lots of passion, virtually no quality - ended with Txetxu Rojo's side winning 2-0. And surprise, surprise it was ex-Real player Joseba Exteberria - a man who spent much of the match dodging flying bottles - who scored both goals.

John Benjamin's side remain bottom, below Racing Santander, Numancia and Osasuna, who lost to Málaga (1-0), Rayo Vallecano (2-0) and Zaragoza (4-2) respectively. Victor Fernández's Celta de Vigo continued their dreadful run of form with a 2-0 defeat at Villarreal, who this week amazingly signed Martín Palermo from Boca Juniors. Up at the other end, Las Palmas beat Espanyol 1-0 with a goal from Eloy.

The rain in Spain falls mainly on Mallorca

More evidence that the rain in Spain does not fall mainly on the plain - just ask Luis Aragonés. His Mallorca side beat Alavés 4-3 on Sunday with two goals from Ariel Ibagaza, but Aragonés seemed more concerned about the empty seats at the San Moix. "When it rains in Mallorca", he moaned "no-one leaves the house. We've got to change all that." Can't help thinking that 4-3 thrillers, fifth spot in the league, and victories over Real Madrid and Barcelona should be enough already. Perhaps it's time to put a roof on the San Moix.

Remembering Dubovsky

Figo wasn't the only footballer saluted at the Bernabéu this weekend. Sunday was the first time that Oviedo and Madrid had met since the tragic death of Slovakian Petr Dubovsky. The Oviedo and ex-Real Madrid player slipped and fell to his death while visiting waterfalls on the Thai island of Koh Samui this summer.

Both clubs mourned the passing of a "genuine friend" and, if you'll allow your correspondent a moment of personal reflection, a fine footballer. As a regular at Oviedo's Carlos Tartiere staduim a few years back, Dubo was my first Spanish football hero - he also scored the first goal I ever saw in Spain, a great strike for Real Madrid against Zaragoza. He will be missed.

webTitle: Swizzle.com axed

fields.headline: Procter & Gamble axes teen girl website
fields.trailText: 1pm: Consumer goods giant Procter & Gamble has scrapped its teen girl web portal Swizzle.com, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Consumer goods giant Procter & Gamble has followed the lead set by arch-rival Unilever by scrapping its teen girl web portal.

The multi-million pound investment in seven-month old website Swizzle.com has been written off with P&G explaining that the site was no longer part of its strategy.

P&G's reasons for ditching the teen portal have not been made clear, although observers of the online teen sector are not surprised by the closure.

Since Wowgo, the Unilever-backed teen portal, went into liquidation at the end of last year, the viability of niche sites aimed at a market that doesn't have the means - a credit card - to shop online has been called into question.

Swizzle.com was a joint venture with Excite announced at the start of 2000.

The plan was to use the site to showcase P&G's brands, including Tampax, Clearasil, Max Factor and Cover Girl to the fickle teen market.

P&G said it would continue to run brand-oriented websites for companies including Pampers, Pantene and Olay.

BSkyB and Freeserve-backed teen girl website mykindaplace.com, which is rumoured to have sold a stake to Unilever, is the only remaining ambitious UK website in this sector.

webTitle: Veteran actor marries at 92

fields.headline: Sir John Mills and wife go down the aisle 60 years on
fields.standfirst: Couple will finally achieve the church ceremony denied to them by Hitler
fields.trailText: Sir John Mills, the veteran actor, is to walk down the aisle tomorrow for the first time at the age of 92, six decades after he and his 89 year old wife had their plans for a church wedding scuppered by the second world war.
fields.body:
Sir John Mills, the veteran actor, is to walk down the aisle tomorrow for the first time at the age of 92, six decades after he and his 89 year old wife had their plans for a church wedding scuppered by the second world war.

Mary Hayley Bell and John Mills were married at Marylebone register office in central London in 1941 while he was on leave from his sergeant's post in the army. They always regretted forfeiting a traditional service.

To celebrate the couple's diamond wedding anniversary, 50 guests including their daughter the actress Hayley Mills and the actor Stephen Fry, will congregate at St Mary's Church in Denham, Buckinghamshire, to witness their renewing of vows.

Sir John said from his Tudor home in Denham yesterday: "I've been thinking for a couple of months now that I'd done her out of a church wedding. It wasn't my fault, of course, it was Hitler's, but I approached the rector of St Mary's and he thought it would be a good idea to have another go. Mary and I are both very romantic and the first wedding was quite a low-key affair."

The Oscar winning actor, beloved for his roles in Hobson's Choice and Great Expectations, met his wife in Shanghai in 1929 when he was on tour with a theatre group, and Mary's father, a colonel, took her to see one of his productions. "I thought she was terribly pretty," said Sir John. "She was very young - only 15. Her father mixed me a couple of startling gin slings and suggested that I play tennis with his daughter. I lost six love, six love."

Twelve years later they met again in London and the relationship blossomed. "I'm not a very clever man," said Sir John. "But I had sense enough to marry the colonel's daughter. She has given me three first class productions: our children Juliet, Jonathan and Hayley."

The wedding in Marylebone was attended by eight of the couple's closest friends and family, after which Sir John returned straight to the war. "We were just so thrilled to get married that we didn't much mind it was in a register office," he said. "But I have been meaning to put it right for a long time."

Mary gave up her acting career and began writing novels and screenplays, several of which were made into films in which her husband starred. The secret of their marriage, one of the entertainment industry's most enduring, was, said Sir John, never being apart. Mary would always accompany her husband when he was on location and on a recent trip to Spain, Sir John observed with a jolt that it was the first time he and Mary had been apart in 55 years.

The service, to be held at 4pm, will be an informal affair, with music to include the hymn All Things Bright and Beautiful and the Jerome Kern love song, All the Things You Are.

"I won't be nervous before the ceremony," said Sir John last night, "because for once I don't have any lines to remember."

webTitle: China tries to snare Tibet's web visitors

fields.headline: China tries to snare Tibet's web visitors
fields.standfirst: NetNews
fields.trailText: China has opened an English-language website on Tibet to reinforce its effort to counter unfavourable publicity abroad. It offers 220 megabytes of information about religion, culture, tourism, business - and the blessings of being part of China.
fields.body:
China has opened an English-language website on Tibet to reinforce its effort to counter unfavourable publicity abroad. It offers 220 megabytes of information about religion, culture, tourism, business - and the blessings of being part of China.

The Tibetan Buddhist priests it quotes have no truck with the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, the Dalai Lama. A "patriotic lama" called Nyima Cering says that he seeks to abide strictly by Chinese law, and that he accepts "the teachings of President Jiang Zemin".

The site on is described as "non-governmental", and while it follows the official Beijing line faithfully it tries to convey a more human touch.

"For fifteen Tibetan girls," it reports in its opening menu this week, "January 1 may never be forgotten as they realise their long-cherished dream of flying as stewardesses."

They are delighted, in other words, to have become the first Tibetans to work as cabin crew on the Chinese airline which has been flying to Lhasa for more than 40 years.

Tibet's entry into the internet world is also hailed.

"If you ramble about the street in Lhasa," begins another item, "you will find many Netbars. It is said that Netfans can ... fast gain the latest informations and be in touch with [the] outside betimes."

The site is run by the China Tibet Information Centre. Whether or not by coincidence, its name -tibetinfor.com - is similar to that of the London-based Tibet Information Network - tibetinfo.net - a much-quoted critic of Chinese policy.

"I suppose it is very flattering", the Tibet Information Network director, Richard Oppenheimer, said. "They [the Chinese] are entirely selective in what they have chosen, but it does appear to contain some new material."

Politics, though not listed on the Chinese site's homepage, surfaces unexpectedly under "travel" in an advertisement from the Lhasa Travel Agency.

The agency warns that no refunds will be made because of circumstances outside its control. These include not only "natural disasters" - common in the land of the snows - but "political disturbances".

The site counters the arguments of foreign critics by quoting a select number of "foreign friends".

It reprints a long article by an Indian journalist, N. Ram, beginning with a short poem adapted by him from an old Tibetan song:

"The sky is turquoise, the sun is golden. The Dalai Lama is away from the Potala, making trouble in the west. Yet Tibet's on the move."

The Tibet Information Network website sets the changes under way in Tibet in a rather different context.

It calls Lhasa "a city where corruption co-exists with hard-nosed commercialism, where prostitution thrives in areas previously better known as places of spiritual pilgrimage, and where citizens may own computers and widescreen televisions but not necessarily toilets or running water".


www.tibetinfor.com Beijing-backed China Tibet Information Centre site.
www.tibetinfo.net London-based Tibet Information Network site.

webTitle: London boroughs clash with Livingstone over police spending

fields.headline: London boroughs clash with Livingstone over police spending
fields.trailText: London boroughs today put themselves on a collision course with mayor Ken Livingstone by calling on him to cut £84m from his proposed budget for the next financial year.
fields.body:
London boroughs today put themselves on a collision course with mayor Ken Livingstone by calling on him to cut £84m from his proposed budget for the next financial year.

The mayor's increases, aimed partly at recruiting 1,050 extra police officers, would see the Greater London Authority's (GLA) precept on local authorities rise by a third, and add around £40 to the average annual council tax bill. Increases to pay for local authority services would be added on top of this.

The Association of London Government (ALG) believes its package of cuts, set out in a submission to the mayor, will still pay for the extra police, while saving band D council tax payers more than £35 a year.

Although Mr Livingstone has clashed with individual boroughs in the past, particularly over planning and congestion charging, this is the first time he has faced a confrontation with the ALG, which represents all 33 London authorities.

Mr Livingstone is himself a member of the association, making the possibility of a standoff doubly embarrassing.

ALG chairman Sir Robin Wales said: "The bulk of the tax increase being proposed by the mayor is not aimed at providing these additional officers. The proposed increase is far too high and could seriously undermine the work of London boroughs."

The association's plans include cutting £60m from the £166m increase for the metropolitan police budget. Around half of the cut would come from efficiency savings. The boroughs believe these can be achieved without hitting frontline policing services.

Councils are under a duty to slice 2% off their budget every year through savings of this kind, and believe the Metropolitan police should do the same, cutting over £25m.

The London assembly's budget committee has backed this call, with committee chairwoman Sally Hamwee accusing the Met of using "archaic accounting practices" and calling on the force to be ambitious about making savings.

The ALG is also calling on the government to offset the costs of expanding the capital's police force by releasing an extra £17m to the GLA and providing extra money to pay for royal protection and anti-terrorism work.

Mr Livingstone has come under further fire from the ALG, which is calling on the mayor to rein in increases for transport for London and to halve his budget for cultural initiatives.

webTitle: West Ham fail in Amoruso bid

fields.headline: West Ham fail in Amoruso bid
fields.trailText: West Ham will not be signing Lorenzo Amoruso from Rangers after a proposed £3m-plus transfer fell through over personal terms.
fields.body:
West Ham will not be signing Lorenzo Amoruso from Rangers after a proposed £3m-plus transfer fell through over personal terms.

Rangers and West Ham had agreed a fee for the 29-year-old, who has been in and out of the Rangers side this season, losing the club captaincy to Barry Ferguson. But the Hammers were unable to agree personal terms with Amoruso and today conceded that they will not be making any further moves for the player.

"We met the player and could not agree personal terms," said a West Ham spokesman. "It is as simple as that. We will not be attempting any further negotiations."

A similar attempt by Sunderland to sign Amoruso failed in the summer, again over personal terms.

Amoruso could now find himself in a difficult position at Ibrox, after he claimed last weekend that he wanted to play at a higher level than the Scottish Premier League.

"I just want the opportunity to become a better player and play at a much higher level than the Premier League," Amoruso said at the weekend.

"It will be good for me to join a new club as I need new motivations, new team-mates and a new manager.

"I have no preferences on which club to sign for, although contrary to what has been said, I wasn't holding out for a move back to Italy.

"It could be the Premiership, Serie A or any other league in Europe, it doesn't matter."

webTitle: Israel seals off Gaza and halts peace talks

fields.headline: Israel seals off Gaza and halts peace talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel sealed off the Gaza Strip and cancelled peace negotiations with the Palestinian leadership today, after the body of a Jewish settler who had been missing since yesterday was found in an onion field in Gaza this morning.
fields.body:
Israel sealed off the Gaza Strip and cancelled peace negotiations with the Palestinian leadership today, after the body of a Jewish settler who had been missing since yesterday was found in an onion field in Gaza this morning.

Israeli soldiers blocked roads into Gaza and shut the airport, preventing Palestinians from arriving at workplaces in Israel.

The body of Roni Tsalah, a Jewish settler, was found in the Kfar Yam settlement in Gaza. His car, carrying a locating transmitter, was tracked to the Palestinian city of Khan Yunis where it was set on fire.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the killing, but Ben-Ami said that the assailants apparently were members of the Islamic militant group Hamas.

Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak said that the killing was despicable and dealt a tough blow to the peace process. In response, a meeting between Israeli foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami and Palestinian parliament speaker Ahmed Qureia was called off, officials from both sides said.

Mr Barak, speaking in an interview with the Qatar-based TV station Al Jazeera, urged Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to do more to stop acts of violence.

After Mr Tsalah first went missing late on Sunday, Israel sent tanks toward Palestinian-controlled areas and cut the Gaza Strip into three isolated sections. The tanks fired shells - one landing a mile from Mr Arafat's seaside office - as military search parties lit up the sky with illumination shells, looking for the missing man.

Palestinian police were put on alert after the shelling, Palestinian security officials said, as Israeli navy vessels circled off the Gaza coastline, in clear view of Mr Arafat's office.

Israel has tightened restrictions on access to the West Bank and Gaza Strip since a Palestinian uprising erupted in September, allowing only essential supplies into Palestinian self-rule areas.

Around 308 Palestinians, 44 Israelis and 13 Israeli Arabs have been killed since the uprising began.

Today's cancelled negotiations are part of an attempt by Israel and the Palestinians to draft a document that would sum up agreements and differences, with US president Bill Clinton's peace proposals serving as a guide.

The Palestinians are waiting for maps showing Israel's interpretation of Mr Clinton's plan, under which the Palestinians would establish a state in all of Gaza, 95% of the West Bank and Arab neighbourhoods of contested Jerusalem.

In the West Bank, a 10-year-old Palestinian boy, who was critically wounded by Israeli army fire earlier this month, died yesterday of his injuries.

He was shot by Israeli soldiers 10 days ago, during a clash near the West Bank town of El-Bireh

The European Union expressed "deep regret" at Saturday's executions by the Palestinian authority of two Palestinians accused of collaborating with Israel, and called on Mr Arafat to consider a moratorium on the death penalty.

Palestinian authorities said that more trials - and harsher punishment - were ahead for Palestinians accused of collaborating with Israel. Two other men are are also facing execution after trials on Saturday.

"I also appeal to president Arafat to commute the death sentences handed down on Saturday against two persons in Bethlehem", Swedish foreign minister Anna Lindh said in a statement issued late yesterday on behalf of the 15-nation EU.

Sweden currently holds the EU's six-month rotating presidency. "I encourage President Arafat to consider, as a first step, the introduction of a moratorium on the death penalty," she said.

The executions in Nablus and Gaza City were only the fourth and fifth death penalties carried out in the more than six years of the Palestinian authority - and a dramatic bid to stop cooperation in weeks of Israeli killings of Palestinian militiamen.

The two Palestinians executed - Alam Bani Odeh, 25, and Majdi Makawi, 28, - admitted aiding Israel in a car bombing and a checkpoint shooting in November that killed a Palestinian bombmaker and a leader of Mr Arafat's Fatah group.

Palestinian attorney general Khaled Qidreh defended the trials, saying, "We, as the Palestinian authority, implement the law, and we gave them the opportunity to have legal representation and an open trial."

In the Palestinian West Bank village of Kfar Salem, troops surrounded a house from which shots were fired at a convoy of cars from the nearby Jewish settlement of Elon Moreh. One settler was wounded in the attack.

webTitle: CIA lands Pentland business

fields.headline: CIA lands Pentland business
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Ad agency CIA has picked up the bulk of sportswear firm Pentland's planning and buying business, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Sportswear specialist Pentland Group has handed the bulk of its media business, including the Ellesse brand, to CIA International.

The appointment follows a competitive pitch prompted when MindShare, the incumbent agency, snapped up the £60m European account for rival Nike in December.

Work on a £3m Ellesse campaign will begin immediately. Activity for Pentland's other brands may follow later in the year.

The £800,000 media buying for Kickers remains with Rocket, while Bygraves Bushell Valladares & Sheldon will continue to buy for the Lacoste fashion range.

"The sports lifestyle arena is expansive and changing constantly," said Ron de Pear, CIA International chairman. "This gives us a huge opportunity to develop the Ellesse brand in an innovative way."

Pentland, whose global headquarters are in the UK, also owns the Speedo, Berghaus and Red or Dead brands but has not advertised these in the UK in the past year, according to ACNielsen MMS.
