Work on a £3m Ellesse campaign will begin immediately. Activity for Pentland's other brands may follow later in the year. The £800,000 media buying for Kickers remains with Rocket, while Bygraves Bushell Valladares & Sheldon will continue to buy for the Lacoste fashion range. "The sports lifestyle arena is expansive and changing constantly," said Ron de Pear, CIA International chairman. "This gives us a huge opportunity to develop the Ellesse brand in an innovative way." Pentland, whose global headquarters are in the UK, also owns the Speedo, Berghaus and Red or Dead brands but has not advertised these in the UK in the past year, according to ACNielsen MMS.

webTitle: South's rich areas get richer

fields.headline: South's rich areas get richer
fields.trailText: People in Britain's richest areas have gained most from the strong economy since Labour came to power, with areas reliant on farming and manufacturing gaining least, according to a survey released today. Vikram Dodd reports
fields.body:
People in Britain's richest areas have gained most from the strong economy since Labour came to power, with areas reliant on farming and manufacturing gaining least, according to a survey released today.

Household income in Surrey rose by 12% over the past two years, well above inflation, while Cornwall's grew by 1.7%, well below inflation, now at 3.2%, meaning that its economy is, in effect, in recession.

The fabled north-south divide is too simplistic to describe differing income levels, with the poorest regions being the south-west, East Anglia and Wales as well as the north.

Overall incomes have risen, with the average household earning £23,200 a year, a growth of 8.6% since the last survey two years ago by the market analysts CACI, and a rise of 19.6% since 1996.

Comparing counties, household income in Surrey is 88% higher than the level in Cornwall, and 80% higher than Tyne and Wear.

In Surrey, the richest county, the average income was £33,400 followed by Berkshire with £31,700, with the rest of the top 10 comprising London and the home counties. Bottom of the county list was Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly where average household income is £17,700.

But even within counties there are huge disparities which the study can highlight by providing a breakdown of income by postcode. Merseyside, one of the poorest, contains the seventh richest neighbourhood in the UK, which is Heswall, Wirral, where the average household income is £46,600.

But nearby Liverpool contains four of the 10 poorest postcode sectors. The Vauxhall, central, Seaforth and Kirby areas of the city have an average income as low as £9,100.

The survey also highlights deprived areas enjoying a boom. One of Britain's poorest boroughs, Hackney, north-east London, experienced a 22.5% income growth in two years taking its average to £26,000. This is believed to be due to the "gentrification" of the area with professional and middle-class people moving in after finding property prices in neighbouring Islington too high. But even in Islington, affluence and poverty sit side by side. One postcode in the Highbury area enjoys an average household income twice as high as one less than 100 metres away.

The highest earning postcode is west London, with an average income of £34,200, up 13.4% since 1998. The lowest is Sunderland, with an average income of £17,000 per household, an increase over two years of 5.8%.

The highest earning postal code areas are in London and the south-east, and this is where the biggest rise in incomes over the past two years is concentrated.

The survey does not detail the causes behind why those areas that have the most wealth are doing best. But London and the south-east are where more people work in sectors such as IT, financial services, consulting, higher skilled service sector jobs, and non-public sector professions.

Highest earning area by postcode sector: South Kensington, London, average household income £47,700. Poorest: Vauxhall, Liverpool, £9,100.

Ave household income in the constituencies of Tony Blair (Sedgefield) £18,700; William Hague (Richmond) £22,200; Charles Kennedy (Ross, Skye and Inverness) £20,800.

webTitle: The Edge

fields.headline: The Edge
fields.standfirst: The stats that matter, from IQ Sports
fields.trailText: ARSENAL 1 - 1 CHELSEA
fields.body:
ARSENAL 1 - 1 CHELSEA

Key man: John Terry won 5 of 7 tackles, made 5 good clearances and was rewarded by scoring the equaliser.
Weak link: Arsenal created little. The Gunners were accurate on only 11 of 17 crosses, and did not play a single good through ball.
The Edge: Chelsea were the keener chasers, attempting 96 challenges to Arsenal's 57.

ASTON VILLA 0 - 3 LIVERPOOL

Key man: Danny Murphy won 11 of 13 tackles, completed 44 of 56 passes and scored twice from three attempts.
Weak link: Villa's forwards did not have a shot on target all day.
The Edge: Villa had more attacking time (16 minutes in the front third to Liverpool's 11), but their crossing failed them - they only connected on 4 of 17. Meanwhile, Liverpool completed 101 of 130 passes in the attacking third. They also created the game's first 8 attempts to settle things early.

BRADFORD 0 - 3 MANCHESTER UNITED

Key man: Ryan Giggs had 5 scoring attempts, of which 2 were on target. He beat 14 of the 22 defenders he took on and completed 21 of 25 passes.
Weak link: Bradford chased, attempting 127 challenges ... but won less than half of them.
The Edge: United spent 21 minutes in Bradford's third and had almost 60% of live possession. Roy Keane commanded in midfield, completing 84 of 90 passes. Jaap Stam's return was quiet: he completed 34 of 38 passes, but only had to make one tackle.

EVERTON 0 - 0 TOTTENHAM

Key man: Neil Sullivan salvaged a point for Spurs with 6 saves and 9 good claims.
Weak link: Tottenham completed only 1 cross, and played no good through balls all afternoon.
The Edge: Everton should have probably won a match marred by technically inferior passing. The home team had 17 minutes of live possession in Tottenham's third and 57% of live possession overall.

MANCHESTER CITY 0 - 4 LEEDS

Key man: Lucas Radebe won 16 of 20 challenges, made 8 clearances and completed 19 of 26 passes.
Weak link: City did not have a first-half attempt, and had only 33% of live possession.
The Edge: Robbie Keane only played 18 minutes but scored 2 goals, hit the post, won 2 tackles, and completed all of his 3 passes in the forward third.

MIDDLESBROUGH 4 - 0 DERBY

Key man: Paul Ince was accurate in 40 of 47 passes (13 of 16 in forward third), and hit the target twice with 2 of 3 goalscoring attempts. He also won 5 of 7 challenges.
Weak link: Derby were only accurate with 2 of their 19 crosses.
The Edge: Derby played with little urgency, attempting only 40 challenges. Boro's back four of Gianluca Festa, Curtis Fleming, Steve Vickers and Ugo Ehiogu won 21 of 29 tackles, and made 14 good clearances.

NEWCASTLE 3 - 1 COVENTRY

Key man: Kieron Dyer scored a superb solo goal, had an assist and completed 28 of 29 passes.
Weak link: Craig Bellamy will want to forget this one. He lost 5 of 6 tackles and lost possession 16 times to Newcastle's defence.
The Edge: Coventry had twice as many successful passes in the forward third (104 to Newcastle's 52), but Newcastle created more chances. They completed 11 of 19 crosses, 6 of those from the foot of Norberto Solano.

SOUTHAMPTON 0 - 0 CHARLTON

Key man: Mark Fish, Richard Rufus and Andy Todd won 13 tackles and made 38 clearances for Charlton.
Weak link: Kevin Davies completed only 13 of 30 passes and had only 1 attempt at goal in 75 minutes of play.
The Edge: The game finished scoreless despite the ball being in play for 85% of the match. Southampton had 56% of possession and bombarded the box with 32 crosses (15 by Hassan Kachloul). Dean Kiely made 7 good claims in the Charlton box.

WEST HAM 0 - 2 SUNDERLAND

Key man: Thomas Sorensen made 8 saves and 5 claims, helping his team keep possession by completing 39 of 43 passes.
Weak link: Terrible passing accuracy all round could not have impressed the watching new England coach.
The Edge: Another professional away performance from Sunderland in defence, winning 74 of 89 challenges. Time-wasting had something to with it - only 66% of Sunderland's possession time was in play.

webTitle: New editorial director at Trinity Mirror

fields.headline: New editorial director at Trinity Mirror
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Trinity Mirror Regional Newspapers has hired Neil Benson, former editor of the Newcastle Evening Chronicle, as editorial director. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Neil Benson, former editor of the Newcastle Evening Chronicle, has been appointed editorial director of Trinity Mirror Regional Newspapers.

Mr Benson will oversee the appointment of editorial staff and implement a "best practice" scheme for the group.

"This new appointment highlights the importance the group attaches to the continuous development of editorial quality at our growing portfolio of regional newspapers," said Stephen Parker, managing director of Trinity Mirror Regional Newspapers.

A spokesman for the group, whose publications include the Liverpool Echo, could not confirm if the scheme would result in cost-cutting measures at Trinity Mirror.

The group warned last week of a slump in advertising and circulation revenues at its national newspapers, which include the Mirror and the Daily Record.

Mr Benson will also take charge of Trinity Mirror's training centre in Newcastle. He is currently managing director of Gazette Media Company in Teesside, whose parent company is Trinity Mirror.

webTitle: London borough sacks ITNet

fields.headline: London borough sacks ITNet
fields.trailText: 11.30am: IT company ITNet has lost its £70m contract with the London borough of Hackney, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Information technology company ITNet has been sacked by the cash-strapped London borough of Hackney from a £70m contract.

The protracted dispute, which began in October, could wind up in the courts, as the midlands-based firm confirmed its legal advisers were negotiating the termination of the 10-year revenues and benefits contract.

"It is a long and complicated contract and they have had problems on both sides. It was very difficult to see a way forward," said a spokeswoman for ITNet.

Hackney council was unavailable for comment, but councillors threatened to dump ITNet last year, citing "significant failures by the company to deliver effective service performance".

Analysts breathed a sigh of relief at the news, as it signalled the end of a dispute that has wiped up to £11m from ITNet's balance sheet and slashed its share price.

"It is good that the situation has been resolved. Now the company can look forward to getting deals that are less politically tempestuous. There were real internal problems at Hackney," said Ian Mitchell, analyst at Beeson Gregory.

In December last year, Hackney said it had a housing benefit applications backlog of 24,000 claims. ITNet had similar problems in the nearby borough of Islington, and was fined £30,000 before the two parties managed to reach a compromise.

webTitle: NBC to cut 600 jobs

fields.headline: NBC to cut 600 jobs
fields.trailText: 11.45am: NBC president Bob Wright is embarking on a cost-cutting drive, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
NBC president Bob Wright has confirmed he is planning to cut up to 600 jobs at the leading US TV network.

Mr Wright revealed the cost-cutting drive, which will hit between 5-10% of NBC's 6,000 employees across all divisions, in a memo to staff on Friday.

"It is no secret the current economic climate is affecting our business," Mr Wright said.

"It is now clear we must go beyond belt-tightening and take the additional step of reducing the size of our workforce."

The boss of the US network said that some of the job cuts would be achieved through "attrition" but added that redundancy notices would be issued within the next few weeks.

The cutbacks are being made in response to the downturn in advertising.

Staff at CNN are also bracing themselves for news of job cuts this week. Up to 1,000 posts are at risk.

webTitle: Biopic about Damien Hirst and the YBAs planned

fields.headline: Biopic about Damien Hirst and the YBAs planned
fields.trailText: Biopic will chart the rise of the current crop of young British artists and the truth about their intertwining private lives and experimentation with drugs
fields.body:
A warts-and-all biopic of the current generation of controversial young British artists will reveal their lives before they became famous, the incestuous relationships within the group and their excessive drink and drug consumption.

According to entertainment site PeopleNews, the film will focus on artists such as Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin during their rise to fame during the 90s. The producers are hoping that the project will be directed by John Maybury whose 1998 biopic of Frances Bacon, Love is the Devil, which starred Derek Jacobi, received critical acclaim. The 43-year-old director is currently working on a biopic of Christopher Marlowe, with Johnny Depp.

It is thought the film will take its starting point from the Damien Hirst-curated 1988 show Freeze. "It's in it's early stages," a 'source' close to the project told the site, "but will home in on the time before their success when most of them were on the dole."

Apparently a number of the artists have already been asked to jot down their recollections of the period as well as revealing the truth about the excesses which their fame brought. "The film will also look at the corrupting influence of fame; the bust-ups - so many of them slept with each other in the early days, as well as the boozing and the drugs," the 'source' adds.

webTitle: Kidman courts controversy as Mrs Satan

fields.headline: Kidman courts controversy as Mrs Satan
fields.trailText: Nicole Kidman is to star in a biopic of Victoria Woodhull-Martin, a woman who shocked America with her sensational lifestyle, before she moved to Britain and became a philanthropist
fields.body:
A transatlantic row has erupted over the portrayal of the life and works of an American woman who became a Cotswold heroine in a new film which will star Nicole Kidman and may be directed by Paul Verhoeven, who is best known for such controversial blockbusters as Basic Instinct and Showgirls,

According to The Daily Express today, opinions about Victoria Woodhull-Martin on either side of the Atlantic could not be more divided. The Brits see her as a "sainted philanthropist" who tirelessly worked for the under privileged whereas the Americans remember her as a former prostitute whose views on free love earned her the nickname "Mrs Satan."

Villagers in the Cotswold village of Bredon's Norton where Woodhull-Martin eventually settled are concerned that the new £50m Hollywood film, which will be produced by Kidman's husband, Tom Cruise, will only focus on her early days.

Woodhull-Martin caused much consternation in the United States by marrying at 15 before making her fortune as a stockbroker who dressed as a man and she eventually incurred the wrath of her fellow countrymen by running for the presidency.

The film is less likely to focus on her time in Britain where her life was considerably less sensational. She married a local banker, set up a village school and women's agricultural college and worked tirelessly during the First World War. She died in 1927 at the age of 89.

Anxious villager Owen Stinchcombe summed up local opinion in Bredon's Norton by saying: "I am sure it will make for a saucy and exciting film but it is not going to be good history."

webTitle: Child protection training is 'inadequate' warn social workers

fields.headline: Child protection training is 'inadequate' warn social workers
fields.trailText: Social workers have warned that current training does not guarantee adequate experience of child protection.
fields.body:
Social workers have warned that current training does not guarantee adequate experience of child protection.

The warning comes after the colleague involved in the tragic case of Anna Climbié, the eight-year-old girl murdered after a year of "truly unimaginable abuse", was criticised as "blindingly incompetent".

Rob Hutchinson, chairman of the Association of Directors of Social Services' children's and families committee, warned it was currently "hit or miss" whether trainees participated in child protection placements under intense supervision.

His comments came as the Department of Health confirmed it was considering extending social work training from two to three years. The proposal will be discussed at a workforce summit in February aimed at addressing current recruitment and retention problems, as well as the poor image of social care.

The national vacancy rate for social workers now stands at 16%, with one in five posts in the south-east unfilled last year.

Mr Hutchinson said: "The recruitment and retention of nurses, teachers and police officers has been given great recognition and now it is time for the terms and conditions of service, recruitment and reputation of social workers to be given equal priority.

"Three years should allow trainee social workers to participate in child care placement settings with intensive supervision. At present it can be hit or miss whether a placement is experienced by the student."

Training should also address interagency working and promote more evidence-based practice, he added.

However, Mr Hutchinson was cautious about calls by Louis Blom-Cooper, QC, who chaired the Jasmine Beckford and Kimberley Carlile abuse inquiries, for the creation of a nationwide specialist child protection service.

"The vast majority of social workers are concerned with child protection," he said. "Piloting specific teams could be worth pursuing but the key to child protection is ensuring that all professionals in the system - teachers, health visitors and GPs, as well as police and social workers - are able to recognise and report suspected child abuse."

The health and social services departments of Bristol, south Gloucester, north Somerset and Bath and north-east Somerset, have drawn up guidance to put effective inter-agency working into practice, which will come into force in April.

The scheme involves local social services, police, probation services, charities including the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children and health authorities and trusts.

A Bristol city council spokeswoman said: "Previously a social worker would come in on one angle and a teacher on another. This coordinated strategy should enable agencies to spot abuse more quickly as they will be looking for the same signs and be kept informed about each other's work."

webTitle: Larry Elliott: Artists' wariness of capitalism may not be a bad thing

fields.headline: Novelists tell fact from fiction
fields.trailText: Authors and film-makers are more in touch with the public mood than the politicians, which is why the message given by mass culture is that there is no such thing as a free lunch, no such thing as a "free" new laboratory supplied by a pharmaceutical company, and no such thing as a political donation given without strings - albeit invisible strings - attached.
fields.body:
Life was never quite the same for John le Carré after the Berlin Wall came down. Without the great symbolic barrier, the world of Smiley, Karla and the Circus disappeared as the certainties of the cold war were replaced by the triumph of liberal capitalism and the end of history. It has not really worked out that way in practice, but for le Carré it meant the start of a search for some new enemies. Now he has found some.

The villains of his latest book, The Constant Gardener, are not KGB spymasters but the bosses of a multi-national pharmaceutical company who use Africans as guinea pigs for a new anti-TB drug and suppress evidence of its lethal side-effects in the pursuit of profit. The company falsifies tests, ensures that only puffs by tame scientists appear in the prestigious medical journals and organises a contract killing to ensure that critics of the drug are silenced.

The author's note from le Carré contains the usual disclaimers about there being no drug called Dypraxa and no pharmaceutical company called KVH, but makes his own views abundantly clear. "As my journey through the pharmaceutical jungle progressed, I came to realise that, by comparison with the reality, my story was as tame as a holiday postcard." Scion of the establishment he may be, but le Carré is as convinced as any Seattle protester that there is a dark side to multi-national capitalism.

With good reason. Poor African countries that explore the possibilities of importing cheap generic drugs to make their pitifully small health budgets stretch a little further are left in no doubt that they might see aid budgets cut and trade sanctions imposed if they prevent the big western drugs companies from exploiting their patents.

For patent read profit

The explanation wheeled out by the pharmaceutical industry for taking South Africa to court over its plans to find a low-cost drug to combat Aids is that there would be no incentive to develop new cures without strong protection. For patent read profit. As one of the characters in le Carré's book says: "Don't talk to me about research and development costs. The pharmaceutical boys wrote them off 10 years ago and a lot of their money comes from governments in the first place, so they're talking crap. What we've got here is an amoral monopoly that costs human lives every day, OK."

As far as the Institute for Economic Affairs is concerned, this is par for the course. The free-market think-tank is concerned at the way in which business - and especially big business - is portrayed in literature, fearing that the cumulative effect of three centuries in which readers have been told that "making money is a dirty game" has been to stifle enterprise.

The first part of the IEA's thesis is undoubtedly true. Writers do not like businessmen, and sympathetic portrayals are hard to find. Try it for yourself. At a recent party, the invitation to come up with a few names led to a lot of head-scratching before an English teacher produced a solitary offering: Willy Wonka. An example of a good-hearted philanthropist certainly, but somewhat outgunned by the works of Dickens, Lawrence, Galsworthy, Priestley, Martin Amis and countless others.

John Blundell, director of the IEA, finds this all depressing, noting in the foreword to his organisation's book on the subject (The Representation Of Business In English Literature) that "one is faced with a rather damning picture of prodigiously wasteful yet Scrooge-like businessmen who are abnormal and antagonistic; corrupt, cunning and cynical; dishonest, disorderly, doltish, dumb and duplicitous; inhumane, insensitive and irresponsible; ruthless, unethical and unprincipled; and villainous to boot."

Nor is this a peculiarly British trait. American culture, too, is dominated by images of grasping, greedy, mendacious big business, all the way from the westerns that have the lantern-jawed homesteader pitted against the ruthless rancher to the unpicking of 80s Wall Street in Tom Wolfe's Bonfire of the Vanities. According to US research quoted by the IEA, more than half of all corporate chiefs depicted on TV commit illegal acts ranging from fraud to murder; 45% of all business activities are portrayed on TV as illegal; only 3% of TV businessmen engage in socially or economically productive behaviour; and hard work is usually ridiculed on TV as "workaholism" that inevitably leads to strained personal relationships.

Like the IEA, the government sees these sort of attitudes as unhelpful. Tony Blair says he is proud that businessmen want to donate a couple of million pounds to Labour party coffers, but the mood music that accompanied the recent brouhaha over who gave what suggested that Labour knows it is swimming against the tide.

Authors and film-makers are more in touch with the public mood than the politicians, which is why the message given by mass culture is that there is no such thing as a free lunch, no such thing as a "free" new laboratory supplied by a pharmaceutical company, and no such thing as a political donation given without strings - albeit invisible strings - attached.

In reality, of course, things are rather less bleak for business than the IEA and its sympathisers in government make out. Despite the best efforts of Dickens et al, the wheels of industry turn faster than ever. Of the 100 biggest economic entities in the world, 48 are countries and 52 are multi-national corporations, so there is very little evidence that corporate capitalism is being brought to its knees by the regular rubbishing it gets from the men and women of letters. Hollywood is willing to make a film like Erin Brockovich - one woman's fight against corporate malfeasance - precisely because the studios have big marketing budgets and know what the punters want. In other words, a film about the cynicism of modern capitalism becomes yet another product of modern capitalism.

According to the Economist magazine, the IEA is getting worked up about nothing. It argues that the moral of the story is that capitalist societies "consume literature and film to let off steam rather than to change the world". There is something in this. For a start, some of the criticisms - particularly of big business - are naive. There is no evidence that large firms pay less than small firms, nor that they have worse health and safety records. Quite the reverse. Multi-national companies operating in developing countries often pay higher wages than indigenous firms.

Even so, it is somewhat strange that an economic system which has produced a phenomenal rise in western living standards over the past two centuries is so routinely trashed by our great creative minds. Or perhaps not so strange. We do not especially like some of the things business gets up to in the pursuit of profit, and look to our intellectuals both to articulate that unease and adumbrate alternatives.

But it is wrong to assume that business is being singled out. Writers do not much care for politicians either, portraying them as weak, power-hungry and corrupt. It would be quite easy to construct a thesis - illustrated let us say by the works of Orwell and Solzhenitsyn - that the impression given of government is invariably negative. The fact is that our culture reflects back at us our deep-seated suspicion that power tends to be abused. Be thankful that it does.

A better employer

Dickens made a difference in the mid-19th century by contributing to the sense that the poverty and the degradation associated with rapid industrialisation had to be remedied. Given the wealth and political power of corporations, it is quixotic to expect writers and film-makers to change the world. But at the margin they make a difference and, despite what the IEA might say, for the better. Hard Times did not prevent the rise of Microsoft but it may have helped ensure Bill Gates was a better employer than Thomas Gradgrind (and probably a more successful capitalist). If you were in a balloon with Dickens and Gates and had to throw one out to survive, which would you choose?

webTitle: Campaign Media Business round-up

fields.headline: Campaign Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication Date: January 15
fields.trailText: January 15: News Group Newspapers' ad chief Ian Clark has finalised a major ad sales shake-up.
fields.body:
News Group Newspapers ad chief Ian Clark has finalised a major ad sales shake-up that recognises the importance of persuading TV advertisers to switch to press.

CIA has been hired to handle the bulk of the Pentland brief, including the international media business for Ellesse.

Growth in UK ad spend slowed considerably in November, with dot.com revenues falling year-on-year for the first time.

AW Media has won the media planning and buying task for David Lloyd Leisure, the gym and health club chain.

Jonathan Bill, Real Media commercial director, is leaving the digital sales house at the end of the month to join Reuters Media.

VNU Global Media has signed a deal to sell advertising for Ziff-Davis's worldwide portfolio of magazines.

IPC Southbank is launching a handful of one-off titles - called Make It!, Your Health and Hair Ideas - as spin-offs from its Essentials brand.

DoubleClick is forecasting its worldwide advertising revenues will plummet by 30-35% in the first quarter of 2001.

Late deals with media agencies are thought to have contributed to the drop in ITV's January revenues.

webTitle: Giles Smith tests the Seat Arosa Sport

fields.headline: The edge of my Seat
fields.standfirst: Seat cars are boring, right? Not any more, says  Giles Smith , who found that the Arosa 16V Sport was a boy racer's dream
fields.trailText: Seat cars are boring, right? Not any more, says Giles Smith , who found that the Arosa 16V Sport was a boy racer's dream.
fields.body:
If you are British, there is some chance that you associate the brand name Seat with that faintly disappointing hire car you had on your last holiday on the European mainland. You know the one: Spanish-made; indeterminate-looking; smaller than you had been led to believe by the woman on the phone; air-conditioning that seemed to prefer to function as a heater, until it broke; sensationally under-powered. You had just managed to get it up to 60 miles per hour and the holiday was over.

The last time I drove a Seat, I managed to crack its oil tank on a Greek rock. I was a long way up a mountain at a time, following a disastrously ignorant map-reading incident, and would have had to sleep out in the car if I hadn't been rescued by passing fire rangers. A Seat hatchback, I discovered, isn't really your best bet for mountain-hopping. You probably wouldn't want to sleep in one, either.

You might, however, want to own one - at least if it was the new Seat Arosa Sport. Hitherto, one has been able to look at Seats and infer that the Spanish were to car building what the British are to bullfighting. But the company has shaken itself awake over the past two years, stirring its entire range (Ibiza, Cordoba, Leon) from a deep stupor, to the point where it can declare the new Arosa to be "the car that epitomises youthful vitality", and one merely smiles indulgently rather than laughing until one is sick.

The new Arosa, we should be clear, comes in three other versions that don't have the word "Sport" in them, but the Sport would seem to me to be the fun one to have, arriving, as it does, with alloy wheels, a lowered suspension and, most important of all, a centrally mounted, chromed exhaust pipe that sticks out slightly from the back of the car and is all the better to annoy people with. By this means alone, what could have been for Seat an exercise in motorising a shopping trolley ends up yielding a cheeky, road-smoking magnet for the boy racer in your family, or for the boy racer in you.

Interestingly stubby, daringly cheap and only available as a three-door, the Arosa is going to attract takers in two separate markets. There will be the families who own it as a second car and intend to nip around urban areas in it, safe in the knowledge that you could pretty much park this car in a space recently vacated by a moped. And then there will be the young buyers, perhaps first-time owners, who may have similar kinds of journeys in mind, but may additionally intend to convert the car into an enlarged boom-box by entirely filling its boot space with speakers.

Especially in its Sport form, the Arosa has enough style - or rather, enough of the right kind of style - to bring young shavers on board, in the manner of the old-style "hot hatches". Driven around London in Ebony Black, this car drew covetous looks from boys in school uniform who may not yet have passed their driving tests but who could recognise, when they saw it, the potential for a little innocent, on-road mischief making.

It's there in the Arosa's use of a strangely funky porthole motif: the rear lights are chunky and circular and their shape is mirrored in the air vents on the dashboard and the housing for the clocks. And it's there in the hip-hugging, rally-style seats with their black and red, go-faster cloth.

The interior, which features a coolly tidy CD player, favours matt black and has, overall, something of the feel of a bachelor's bathroom. This theme, too, continues on the outside of the car, where the catch for the boot is actually a large, silver Seat badge which you have to depress, like the soap dispenser in a hotel that fancies itself.

Strip these features out and you would have little more than a tame blob of bland Euro-metal. (You would have, indeed, the entry level Seat Arosa, which - hold on to your hats! - takes a sensationally meditative 17.7 seconds to crawl to 62 miles per hour.) Put those features in, though, and you have a joyrider's joy object, a dinky, head-turning piece of street culture, which was not exactly a future I readily envisaged for a Seat the last time I was up a Greek mountain with one.

It's true that, at speed, the engine hums along in an almost entirely characterless manner. It is utterly without a signature note; you could be driving anything at all. But at least, along with the visual style, you get - in a rare conjunction - economy. The Arosa sips petrol with the restraint of a lawn mower. It is also amazingly solid for a car of its size and price - weighty in the right places. One recalls the less than reassuring "poing" that accompanies the closing of a door on any Fiat. When the Arosa's doors slam, they sound like a cannon going off.

I still wouldn't fancy it at altitude. But back on earth, definitely.

The lowdown

Seat Arosa 16V Sport

Price: £9,995

Top speed: 117 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 10 seconds

Consumption: 42.2 mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Your son

On the stereo: Dr Dre

En route for: He didn't say

webTitle: Anna: radical reforms pledged

fields.headline: Anna: radical reforms pledged
fields.trailText: Sweeping changes to Britain's child protection system are being planned by ministers after the tragic case of Anna Climbié, the girl who was murdered after being failed by social workers, doctors and the police.
fields.body:
Sweeping changes to Britain's child protection system are being planned by ministers after the tragic case of Anna Climbié, the girl who was murdered after being failed by social workers, doctors and the police.

Social work training will be overhauled, and the Observer can reveal that a three-year training programme is set to replace the present two-year course.

Next month the Department of Health (DoH) will hold a summit on social work to discuss the recruitment crisis which insiders fear will be made worse by publicity over Anna's case. One in five posts in the sout- east stood empty last year, with a national vacancy rate of 16%.

Mary Marsh, director of the NSPCC, said: "The time is right to draw up a national strategy to prevent children dying from abuse and neglect, including setting national targets to reduce child killings."

Health minister John Hutton promised the government would take any steps necessary to ensure the "awful case" did not happen again.

Colleagues yesterday defended Haringey social worker Lisa Arthurworrey - widely criticised for her failure to spot signs of neglect and abuse in Anna, who died of hypothermia and neglect at the hands of her great aunt and her boyfriend. Ms Arthurworrey has been suspended, and four others in Haringey's child protection department are also under investigation over the case.

Heath secretary Alan Milburn launched an inquiry into the case after Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and Carl Manning, 28, from Tottenham, north London, were found guilty on Friday of murdering the girl in February last year. The agencies involved admitted they had failed to protect Anna from "truly unimaginable abuse".

webTitle: Jason Deans

fields.headline: Government warned over BBC digital plans
fields.standfirst: DCMS website: BBC approval guidelines
fields.trailText:
10am: The government could be on a 'collision course' with commercial broadcasters over the BBC's digital plans,, reports Jason Deans.
DCMS website: BBC approval guidelines
fields.body:
The government could be on a "collision course" with leading commercial broadcasters over the BBC's digital plans, senior figures in television have warned.

The warning comes after last week's publication of government guidelines for approving the BBC's proposed new digital TV services.

John Hambley, chief executive of pay-TV channel Artsworld, said: "There is a general feeling of disappointment that these guidelines are very, very little different to the original draft version that came out last summer."

Another senior TV executive added: "Chris Smith had six months to produce the final guidelines, but seems to have ignored virtually all the TV industry's concerns.

"I hope that we're not on a collision course with the government on this."

Seven commercial broadcasters - BSkyB, Telewest, Artsworld, MTV, Nickelodeon, Discovery and Turner Broadcasting - wrote to Mr Smith just before Christmas asking for an urgent meeting amid deep concern that the government will just rubber-stamp the BBC's plans.

Commercial rivals are worried that there will not be enough scrutiny of the potential impact of these new BBC services on their businesses before they are greenlit by the government.

The letter said: "We are extremely concerned that the BBC is behaving as if it had been given tacit consent to build their plans for new services without the proper process being adhered to."

Their anger is further fuelled by the government's declaration last year that in future the BBC would be required to get prior approval before it launched any new services.

The new rules were introduced following criticism that the BBC's former director general Lord Birt was diverting licence payers' money into an increasing number of services already provided by the market.

The BBC is planning to launch two new children's services, as well as turning BBC Choice into youth-oriented channel, BBC3 and BBC Knowledge into high-brow arts, and a current affairs service on BBC 4.

A senior TV insider said the approval guidelines published by Mr Smith has only three minor changes compared with the draft document issued last summer.

The consultation period in which submissions can be made has been extended from 15 to 20 days; the BBC is now required to publish a "description" of each new service, rather than just a "brief description"; and the BBC board of governors is now entitled to satisfy itself that "the new service represents value for money for licence fee payers".

Mr Hambley said: "When Chris Smith first announced that he was going to have this approval process he said he was going to open up the BBC to more scrutiny. We're not confident this degree of external scrutiny is going to happen."

But he added that he was hopeful the meeting with Mr Smith requested by the commercial lobbying alliance to discuss their concerns would take place.

The consultation period is expected to begin within days.

webTitle: MI6 fugitive brings book out in Russia

fields.headline: MI6 fugitive brings book out in Russia
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Richard Tomlinson, the MI6 officer on the run in Europe for the past three years, said yesterday that a book he had written about the agency's activities was to be published in Moscow.
fields.body:
Richard Tomlinson, the MI6 officer on the run in Europe for the past three years, said yesterday that a book he had written about the agency's activities was to be published in Moscow.

The book, The Big Breach: From Top Secret to Maximum Security, contained nothing damaging, he said, and he denied reports that his publisher was linked to the Russian security and intelligence services.

Speaking from Rimini in Italy where he has been working in a bar, he said: "Basically the book is about how I was fired from MI6. It is the last fling of the dice."

He said his contract allowed him to cancel publication if MI6 let him take his grievances to an industrial tribunal. "Even if the book does go ahead, I have pledged to give all the royalties to charity and come back to the UK voluntarily to face the music," he said. However, he added: "Again, only if MI6 let me take them to industrial tribunal first."

An extract from the book published in yesterday's Sunday Times dealt with his escapades in Europe after his release in 1998 following a six-month sentence for breaking the Official Secrets Act.

A Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday that Mr Tomlinson, 38, had a "fairly long record of putting out sensationalist material". He added: "The fact that he has chosen to go to the lengths of publishing in Moscow further destroys his credibility. The serious point is that he claims that the book is going to describe the inner workings of the Secret Intelligence Service. That cannot be in the national interest."

Mr Tomlinson signed an agreement in 1997 whereby he received £25,000 in return for surrendering his copyright to anything relating to MI6 activites. He now describes the deal as "absurdly one-sided".

Many of his allegations have been widely published; they include a plan to assassinate the former Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic.

Mr Tomlinson, whose training as an MI6 officer was abruptly ended in 1995, also operated in Moscow gathering information about Russian weapons systems.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours are frankly shocked at the antics of Ian Botham
fields.trailText: Manchester United are rumoured to be interested in West Ham's Frederic Kanoute. The highest quoted price we've spotted is £15m.
fields.body:
Manchester United are rumoured to be interested in West Ham's Frederic Kanoute. The highest quoted price we've spotted is £15m.

Liverpool are lining up a multi-million pound bid for Coventry reserve goalkeeper Chris Kirkland. It's an exclusive in every paper, but of course you'll want the full lowdown from the Guardian's Ian Ross.

Ipswich are looking seriously at Rangers midfielder Claudio Reyna. The 27-year-old USA international has been playing some brilliant football at Ibrox and may be interested in a move to the Premiership. Sunderland are also monitoring the situation.

Frank Leboeuf is "on the verge of signing for Monaco", according to an exclusive in the Sun. "There are times when you have to make a choice and Monaco can bring me more trophies," the defender has reportedly said. However, Chelsea are not yet prepared to sell, as the French club's offer of £2m falls at least £1m short of Claudio Ranieri's valuation.

According to Teamtalk, Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson is "taking charge of negotiations" to sign Bradford's Dean Windass for £1.5m.

John Gregory is interested in bringing another Colombian to Aston Villa. Boca Juniors midfielder Mauricio Serna could follow his compatriot Juan Pablo Angel to Villa Park, as Gregory works his way through a £10m transfer kitty.

West Ham are poised to offer Alaves £5.8m for Spain's leading goalscorer Javi Moreno.

Fulham have offered Newcastle £2m for defender Alain Goma, but Bobby Robson has told them to double their bid.

webTitle: A million children at risk over TB jabs

fields.headline: A million children at risk over TB jabs
fields.trailText: More than one million children have been denied an essential vaccination against tuberculosis because the government scheme for protecting young lives has been in disarray for nearly 18 months.
fields.body:
More than one million children have been denied an essential vaccination against tuberculosis because the government scheme for protecting young lives has been in disarray for nearly 18 months.

Ministers admitted last week they had "little idea" when new batches of the BCG vaccine would be available, despite a New Labour pledge to vaccinate 750,000 children a year against the disease.

The news comes as the government is already under fire over safety fears surrounding the MMR vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella.

New figures show that TB has increased to its highest level for 17 years. St Thomas's Hospital in London now has more referrals for TB every day than it used to have in a week only three years ago.

The government originally said it would restart the TB vaccination programme "as soon as possible" when supplies of the drug were suspended in September 1999 over a row with the manufacturer, Celltech Medeva.

But the health minister, Yvette Cooper, has now said there are still no plans to revive the scheme, which health experts say is vital if children are to avoid the potentially fatal disease.

"The Department is doing all it can to secure a robust supply of vaccine, and will announce as soon as possible when the routine schools programme can resume," Ms Cooper said. Children who had missed their vaccinations because the programme was suspended would have them later.

There are fears that the UK is on the brink of a mass epidemic similar to the one that struck New York in 1989, claiming hundreds of lives.

Dr John Moore-Gillon, TB spokesman for the British Lung Foundation, said: "It's a sign that we're losing the battle against TB.

The Department of Health (DoH) blamed "a worldwide resurgence of TB and a natural effect of more people travelling to and from areas where infection rates are very high."

webTitle: Worldpop bags new boss and £5m funding

fields.headline: Worldpop bags new boss and £5m funding
fields.trailText: 9am: Teenpop marketing firm Worldpop has hired former WEA records boss Charles Levison as its chairman, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Teenpop marketing firm Worldpop has clinched the appointment of former WEA records boss Charles Levison as its chairman.

The multimedia company, which was founded by DJ Peter Powell, will let the industry veteran take charge of corporate affairs.

Mr Levison arrives just as Worldpop has secured £5m in funding from investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, and is expected to lead future money-raising expeditions.

Liam Hamilton, managing director of Worldpop, said Mr Powell will become vice-chairman of the company, which offers music news, charts and reviews to companies who target the 12 to 17-year-old market.

"We will be looking for Charles to lead the third round of funding and we can get on with making money for the business," said Mr Hamilton.

"The corporate side has been getting more and more time-consuming and Peter would not claim that corporate financing is his bag."

Mr Levison once headed up Virgin's TV interest and had a leading role in the ultimately ill-fated Super Channel - a "best of British" service set up by ITV companies in the 1980s.

He is currently vice-chairman of the Chrysalis group and chairman of the SCI Entertainment group.

Mr Hamilton added that the latest cash boost will be invested in a joint venture with direct mail company Trinity Street Direct, which has a 6m-strong database of pop fans.

"We will be using their data and consumer base to sell our services, and in turn we will push their services onto email and mobile phones," he said.

Last summer, Worldpop ran an attention-grabbing text message service in Ibiza, offering thousands of clubbers free entry into nightspots. It has also teamed up with financial news service Reuters to run a pop news operation.

Today's fundraising announcement comes at a time when new media companies are finding it increasingly difficult to prise money out of sceptical investors, although Worldpop's optimism is unlikely to spark immediate plans for a flotation.

"We are particularly pleased to get the money in an environment where companies are dropping like flies. If and when the market changes, and looks like it has changed permanently, then a flotation is definitely on the agenda," said Mr Hamilton.

webTitle: Bollywood spins its own mobster yarn

fields.headline: Bollywood spins its own mobster yarn
fields.standfirst: The Indian film industry can tell a story or two, but, as Luke Harding explains, reality can be stranger than fiction
fields.trailText: The Indian film industry can tell a story or two, but, as Luke Harding explains, reality can be stranger than fiction.
fields.body:
The most pressing question that Bharat Shah, Bollywood's leading financier, used to face each morning, was which one of his trendy BMWs should he drive?

As he strolled out of his palatial Bombay apartment, complete with tennis court and swimming pool, and glanced at his diamond-studded Piaget watch, Mr Shah could have been forgiven for thinking himself above the law.

But Mr Shah was to underestimate Bombay police's tenacious crime branch. Detectives who summoned him last week wanted to know about Mr Shah's links with Chhota Shakeel, Bombay's leading mafia don.

They had already arrested Nazeem Rizvi, a previously obscure Bollywood director, whose latest film Chori Chori Chupke Chupke (Steal Steal Stealthily Stealthily) was backed by Shah's large pockets.

After two previous interrogations, Mr Shah was in a confident mood. The five investigating officers started off gently. Then they pulled out their trump card. They played a tape in which Mr Shah could be heard discussing business with Shakeel, the right-hand man of India's most feared mafia boss, Dawood Ibrahim. Shah was promptly arrested, carted off to court, and remanded in a 10ft-by-10ft cell.

The affair has convulsed Bollywood, with more celebrities shortly to face questioning over their underworld links. Shah's detention has also confirmed what many both outside and inside the industry had always suspected: that there is a deep nexus between Bollywood's leading players and the mafia.

Just how deep remains to be seen. Entertainment stocks, meanwhile, on Bombay's stock exchange have tumbled.

The crime branch has charged Shah, who is 56, with aiding and abetting Shakheel's nefarious activities. The tubby financier - who was briefly hospitalised for chest pain after his arrest - has appealed to the high court and remains in prison.

Detectives are pinning their faith in two tape recordings - both between Rizvi and Shakeel - in which Shah's name is mentioned, together with a mysterious $50,000 (£33,841) payment. They also have recordings of Shakeel and Shah chatting.

Everyone in Bollywood knows that films have been used by Bombay's mafia as a way of laundering dirty money - with the prospect of huge profits if the film is a success rather than a turkey.

According to detectives, Nazeem Rizvi used his links with Shakeel to persuade top stars to work with him. He also pressured rival directors to delay releasing their films to give Chori Chori a free run at the box office.

Just how serious such pressures are became chillingly clear three years ago when Gulshan Kumar, a Bollywood music baron, was shot dead after apparently refusing to pay protection money.

Rakesh Roshan, the director-father of India's latest male heartthrob, Hrithik Roshan, recently survived an assassination attempt. Rizvi was allegedly involved in another plot to kill Hrithik and other Bollywood stars.

Shah's detention has cast a huge shadow over the future of 11 forthcoming Bollywood films, in which he has invested £20m.

"We are still standing by our commitment, and films will be completed within the given schedule," his son Rajiv has said.

But the long-term effects on the industry of Bollywood's richest backer languishing in prison are uncertain. Chori Chori's stars - Salman Khan, Preity Zinta and Rani Mukherjee - now await plod's knock on the door.

One suspects that Shah may not remain in custody for long. He has many powerful friends among Bombay's political class. He is also popular within the industry that catapulted him to fame and fortune: diamonds.

To show solidarity, India's diamond market organised a one-day strike after his arrest. Shah, after all, has a reputation for generosity. In the end, this may prove his salvation.

webTitle: What are you like? Early adopters...

fields.headline: What are you like?
fields.standfirst: Early adopters
fields.trailText: Early adopters
fields.body:
Not a social services fast-track to fostering children, but a term used by marketers to describe the gadget-mad portion of our population. There are just under 1m of them patrolling the high street, constantly looking for the latest in techno-wizardry. Two-thirds are under 30, threequarters are male and most live in the south of England.

Typical beliefs: Early adopters like to stand out from the crowd and often spend money without thinking. They're into new bands and new drinks. This group is a marketer's wet dream, always ready to upgrade to get the smartest kit on the street. However, if a product fails to make the grade with early adopters, it will be much more difficult to sell to the rest of the population.

How do they know what's hot and what's not? This group are regular readers of PC, Hi-Fi and car magazines. FHM is popular with 22% of them, while 13% reach for Loaded.

Obviously multi-channel viewers? 80% of early adopters have satellite or cable TV and they're a key market for the new personal video recorders such as Tivo. "Tivo is going to change the way we all live. It's not about watching television, it's about a way of life," is a typically gushing reaction to this new technology. Current viewing includes Sci-Fi Channel, US sitcoms and cult animations such as South Park and King of the Hill. Sport - particularly Sky Sports - and topical comedies such as Never Mind The Buzzcocks and Have I Got News for You also rank as must-see TV.

Other media consumption: Early adopters are regular cinema-goers, 25% being classed as heavy film watchers. They're also big Radio 1 fans - a third listen to the station - and Virgin is also popular. This group is also likely to see a lot of ads on posters, buses and in the underground as 44% spend more than nine hours a week travelling.

How can you spot an early adopter? When someone says "I bought my DVD for today, I don't worry about what 's going to happen in three months' time. If there's something better then, I'll buy that," they're a fully paid-up member of the club.

 Data supplied by MediaCom

webTitle: What will lifting the injunctions on the Bulger case achieve?

fields.headline: The judge's judges
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade  asks the editors who want injunctions lifted in the James Bulger case what, exactly, they hope to achieve
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade asks the editors who want injunctions lifted in the James Bulger case what, exactly, they hope to achieve
fields.body:
The row over the high court's granting of lifetime anonymity to the killers of James Bulger shows no sign of passing. All three groups which sought to have the injunctions lifted - News International, Associated Newspapers and Trinity-Mirror - are separately considering the possibility of an appeal.

But several people appalled by the papers' obsession with the case have raised a key question: if, as editors have said, they have no intention of revealing the new identities of Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, why have they gone to such lengths to have the injunctions lifted?

So I decided to ask them. As I expected, some would not to speak to me. Again as I expected, those that did said their court action was a matter of principle. They were fighting against an intolerable inhibition of press freedom.

Times editor Peter Stothard, who had just returned to the office after many months away, was evidently unaware of his own company's leading role in the court action, so he had treated the judge's decision purely on its own merits.

After a debate at his morning leader conference, he came to the conclusion that the decision was wrong. It was an unacceptable extension of the law of confidence through the European human rights act. He could not imagine circumstances in which he would identify the youths' new identities.

But People editor Neil Wallis, who has passionately argued against the decision on television and radio programmes, could envision a context in which publication would be reasonable.

He says: "Imagine if my paper learned that one of these youths had become a care assistant in a primary school or nursery. Why shouldn't I have the right to publish that?"

Like other editors who spoke off the record (and whose anonymity I must respect), Wallis spoke of the "truly awful precedent set by this judgment". It would become possible for lawyers to argue on behalf of other notorious criminals that their lives would be in danger once released, and apply for an injunction to gag the press.

Mirror editor Piers Morgan does not appear to share his company's enthusiasm for challenging the injunctions. He thinks it is a unique case requiring a unique response and seems sympathetic to Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss's judgment. He does not see it as the thin end of the wedge, with other criminals able to take any advantage in future. Sun editor David Yelland refused to elaborate on his paper's comment which stated that his paper would "never" reveal the youths' new identities.

The News of the World's naming-and-shaming campaign was mentioned in the Butler-Sloss judgment as an example of the way in which people are liable to overreact when provided with information about released criminals. But editor Rebekah Wade maintained her usual reticence.

Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre was away on holiday, but I did gather that his newspaper "would not do a Rebekah Wade" by encouraging vigilantes to take the law into their own hands.

It had fought the injunction because editors, rather than judges, should decide what appeared in their papers. They should be allowed to employ their own discretion. Lifetime anonymity for adult criminals, even in this case, was unjust.

I got the feeling that the Mail is more ambivalent than its tub-thumping editorial criticising Butler-Sloss might have suggested. Columnist Lynda Lee-Potter's more understanding response, published the next day, illustrates that there is a great deal of heart-searching about this matter within newspaper offices.

The editors' main complaint appears to be that a judge trying to balance the principle of press freedom with the often unprincipled practices of British journalism does not view them as so high-minded as they see themselves.

webTitle: The story of E4

fields.headline: The f . . . controller
fields.standfirst: Tipped as the next Booker winner, The Secret Diary of  Kevin Lygo, aged 40-something and three-quarters, tells the true story of Channel 4's new E4. Read our exclusive extract ...
fields.trailText: Tipped as the next Booker winner, The Secret Diary of Kevin Lygo, aged 40-something and three-quarters, tells the true story of Channel 4's new E4. Read our exclusive extract ...
fields.body:
October 1999

To the National Television Awards last night. What is it with that Michael Barrymore? Are the judges fixed? Barrymore: 5 gongs (Best Entertainment Show, Best Use of Urchins and Grannies, Most Embarrassing Revelation in a Tabloid Newspaper, etc). Channel 4 comedy: 0. Comprehensively outclassed by the gangling one yet again. My humiliation is total.

Still in a bad mood the next morning, when I bump into MJ (that's Channel 4's chief executive Michael Jackson to the uninitiated) at the coffee machine. "Last chance, Lygo," he mutters darkly, slurping the froth of his latte. "Either Barrymore's on the Channel 4 talent roster by this time next Thursday, or I'll make you controller of E4." Commissioned a nice chap called Graham Norton to do a chat show - probably won't work.

November

Resign myself to exile in the Siberian backwaters of pay-TV and start asking around at Channel 4 to see if any one actually knows what E4 is. Tim Gardam (director of programmes) suggests it may be a component of Schadenfreude's Third Theorem of Mathematical Probability - which he proceeds to outline at length - but otherwise the faces are even more blank than usual. How unlike Channel 4, that no one seems to know what's going on. Commission something called Trigger Happy TV - not quite sure who's in it, but like the title.

December

E is for Ecstatic! Read in The Guardian that we've bought the pay-TV rights to Friends and ER from Sky One for peanuts (£74 trillion for the whole Warner Bros package). Both shows are going to be airing first on E4. Sounds like my kind of channel. Goodbye wet winter nights and recordings of Mark Thomas at the Hatchet and Taxman in Balham. Goodbye abusive phone calls from agents such as Jon Thoday. Hello milk and cookies with Courteney in the Winnebago and an invite to Jen 'n' Brad's wedding.

Wonderful quote from Liz Murdoch claiming Sky One is happy to have lost the rights to Friends because it will allow it to spend more on original programming. Has she seen Prickly Heat, I wonder? Commission Something for the Weekend, a sort of arts review show - at last some culture.

January 2000

New millennium, same old schtup. MJ tells me I'm to combine new duties as Controller, E4, with my day job as head of entertainment for Channel 4, so there goes my table at Spago and an office on Melrose. Worse still, they've made Andrew Newman my deputy - or head of programming, E4, as he now insists on being called - and he's started wearing a pinstripe suit and spats. Very suspicious. Must be up to something. Commission Ali G as we're woefully behind our multicultural quota.

March

Bump into David Bergg at the Baftas, looking very pleased with himself and his new job (as general manager) at Sky One. He offers to buy me a drink, but tell him I don't like Sunny Delight. Barrymore wins Bafta for Best Show Starring Michael Barrymore. Some uppity journo tells me that Graham Norton, my biggest star, is gay. Where do they find these people?

April

Flattering profile in the Daily Telegraph, which styles me Da Godfather of Ali G. Must have been the Tommy Hilfiger jeans I wore to the interview. Should be pleased I suppose, but I'd prefer to be Barrymore's second cousin once removed. Launch of E4 confirmed for January next year and those in the know tell me the Sky Digital carriage deal is close to being signed. Win two Emmys for Smack the Pony - must find out what the title means.

May

Decamp to Montreux with the rest of the British entertainment fraternity. Tedious lunch with hordes of ligging hacks including Guardian's Matt Wells who has the impertinence to ask me what programmes will be shown on E4. Fob him off with some old guff the press office gave me, while making a mental note to commission a few shows for E4. Sky Digital deal still close to being signed. Commission Black Books for Channel 4 as a literary review show is clearly needed.

June

Odious interview with some chap in Broadcast, in which he declares that the new youth-oriented BBC3 is setting out "to stuff E4". What excellent use of taxpayers' money. In the photo, said bloke is wearing a rather fetching T-shirt with "Kevin Lygo" emblazoned across his ample breast in spangled italics. Must find out where he bought it. Sky Digital deal now very close to being signed. Commission sitcom called Spaced. Apparently the young people love sci-fi.

July

Lunch with Peter Fincham of Talkback, in the Pearson canteen. Offer him a couple of commissions for E4, but he politely turns them down claiming that as managing director of a £70m company he doesn't get out of bed for less than £100k per episode these days. Sky Digital deal is now very, very close to being signed. Rumour going around that Ali G is not black. Have they not seen him?

August

While the rest of the TV industry is in Tuscany, us poor pay-TV pioneers are still hard at it. Go to a screening of two of Andrew Newman's new E4 pilots, Snuff and Booby. Think he may be taking his remit to "take risks" a little too literally. Sky Digital deal now so close to being signed it hurts. Commission a young persons' drama, As If - can't remember which channel it's for.

September

Disaster! Being controller means I have to sign the "fuck forms" and be culpable for the bad language. Does anyone realise how much swearing there is on these channels?

November

Official press launch. Bloody Matt Wells and his tiresome questions again. Review the draft E4 schedule for January and February. Looking good. Only trouble is what do we put in the other 10 months of the year? Sky Digital deal now... oh, never mind.

January 20 2001

Channel on air. Launch night (Thursday 18) a ratings triumph. Press receptive. Marketing a triumph. Launch party (Friday 19) the hottest ticket in town. MJ pleased. Lygo tired, but happy. Must go. Barrymore's on the phone. (Sky Digital deal is in the building somewhere).

 Kevin Lygo is head of entertainment for Channel 4 and controller of E4, which launches on January 18 on cable and ONdigital. Sky Digital has still to confirm whether it will carry the channel

webTitle: A new job? How about charity fundraising...

fields.headline: The breadwinners
fields.standfirst: If you want new year to mean a new job, and you have experience in business, take a look at charity fundraising, says  Nicola Hill
fields.trailText: If you want new year to mean a new job, and you have experience in business, take a look at charity fundraising, says Nicola Hill
fields.body:
Now you have joined the gym and started the diet, it is time to tart up the CV and find a new job. So how about working for a charity? They are in desperate need of fundraisers, according to an annual recruitment survey. "It is certainly a fundraisers' market, and those with the necessary skills should be able to use this to their advantage in choosing the job they want," says Jennie Saunders, research manager at Charity Recruitment.

Of the 100 charities surveyed, a third reported problems recruiting fundraisers, with 45% blaming the low pay on offer. However, a director of fundraising in a charity with a turnover of over £25m can expect to earn an average of £52,571.

Stephen Perrett, chief executive of recruitment agency, Execucare, said people in the commercial sector with PR, event management or communications skills can move across easily to the voluntary sector. "People who understand what makes business tick and can manage corporate relationships will walk into a fundraising role." However, he advises that it is probably easier to move into a larger charity where "a fundraising department will be big enough to take the risk of an employee struggling to adapt to voluntary sector culture."

Before taking the plunge to apply for a job, Susan Holliday, senior consultant at Charity Recruitment, recommends thinking hard about the type of fundraising you want to do - for example, corporate, trust or event fundraising - and then identify the charities that are growing and might need your skills. "It is critical to research the organisation you are applying to and tailor your approach accordingly."

Whether you are already in the charity sector or struggling to break in, there are a number of courses run by the Open University, Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, the Directory of Social Change, the South Bank University and an organisation called Working for a Charity. These can give a good insight and signing up shows commitment. There is also a selection of recruitment agencies specialising in the charity sector. Christian Aid and Imperial Cancer Research Fund are among the few charities that offer graduate training opportunities. Oxfam has a trainee programme but only pays expenses.

Sara Naylor, 25, who graduated in 1999, is now employed as a fundraiser for Raleigh International's Youth Development Programme. Her advice to someone starting out is: "Be prepared to work voluntarily or to take low-paid positions to gain the initial experience that employers are looking for.

"I found it useful to volunteer as a campaigns assistant for Oxfam to get extra experience while applying for jobs. Doing voluntary work also goes a long way toward showing genuine commitment to working within the sector. Competition for jobs is quite high and it helps just to 'get your foot in the door'."

Sophie Morris, 27, warns that jobs in events can be short-lived. "My last job at CSV started on July 31st, the event was on October 28th and my contract ended on that day. Many of the jobs in events are contract based, so an employer who is sceptical of someone who chops and changes can be put off when they see your CV."

Yet Andrew Watt, spokesman for the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, says: "Fundraisers are the most fluid employees in the voluntary sector. The average time a fundraiser stays in a job is two years. There is a huge degree of sideways movement."

This movement illustrates the flip side of job opportunities - the fact that charities are finding it hard to retain fundraisers. Saunders of Charity Recruitment found in her research that 20% reported difficulties retaining staff. Respondents cited lack of career development and competition from other organisations. She warns: "Charities will need to address the issues of salary levels and the provision of personal development opportunities for fundraisers if they are to strike gold."

webTitle: Nigel Lythgoe's  cult status explained

fields.headline: Stars in his sights
fields.standfirst: After a lifetime climbing up the light entertainment ladder, Nigel Lythgoe has now achieved cult status, thanks to Popstars.  Matt Wells  on TV's Mr Fixit
fields.trailText: After a lifetime climbing up the light entertainment ladder, Nigel Lythgoe has now achieved cult status, thanks to Popstars. Matt Wells on TV's Mr Fixit
fields.body:
As variety-show villains go, Nigel Lythgoe is perfect end-of-the-pier material. And with his uncanny resemblance to the late Larry Grayson, casting himself as the put-down king in ITV's new cult reality show Popstars is surely the most inspired move of his career.

With cruel jibes and withering stares, Lythgoe dispatches rows of talentless teenagers with sweet-edged sadism. The LWT entertainment chief insists that compared to most casting couches, his manner is positively cuddly - but to the kids who cower before his caustic command, he must appear the devil incarnate.

Competing with PR "guru" and power-ego Nikki Chapman, Lythgoe groans and grimaces through the thousands of self-deluding wannabes whose determination to be the "next big thing" eclipses their desperate lack of basic musical tonality.

It is a role that he has been playing for most of his professional career. From gyrating in the dance troupe Young Generation to nurturing the careers of Cilla Black and Michael Barrymore, he is Mr Light Entertainment down to the roots of his flouncy blond hair. In full Grayson mode, he even spots a draught in the room where we are talking, gets up and daintily shuts the door that his PA has left ajar. You couldn't make it up.

So it is all the more bizarre that Lythgoe has suddenly been catapulted to fame as ITV's great youth hope. One minute he was the doyen of "old ITV" (Cilla, Barrymore, Brian Conley); the next he was spearheading the network's biggest-ever drive for youth, not only entrusted with Popstars but also handed the task of developing for Britain the coast-to-coast US sensation of last year, Survivor.

In the same way that William Hague looked silly in a baseball hat, Lythgoe cuts a rather incongruous figure alongside the pop kids of Planet 24, where the Survivor project is being co-ordinated. Fortunately - like many of the 3,000 who auditioned for Popstars - he is blissfully unaware of this fact. Either that, or he just doesn't care.

And who can blame him? Now, after a career behind the cameras, he is a star in front of them. And he is not only the undisputed king of Popstars, he is also the subject of its marketing campaign too ("Nigel, pick me!" implore the billboards and TV trailers). He is the talk of taxi cabs (my driver burst into laughter when he found out I was going to interview him) and student common rooms. He has been sent up on The Big Breakfast in a feature titled "Nigel, pygmy", where "contestants" were auditioned by a rather small man. Even if the series flops (and there is not much sign of that) he will still be a household name.

Being part of the show as well as behind it is a new experience, says Lythgoe. "I'm now involved, and I have to watch the rough cuts two or three times before I can get over the emotional attachment, my ego, and the temptation to say 'My hair looks terrible' or 'I didn't know I had those spots on my face'."

Never mind that his hair looks terrible however much attention he spends on it, and that no amount of Estée Lauder is going to get rid of those wrinkles, Lythgoe is revelling in his role. It's no accident that he's good at it: he has been in rehearsal all his career. In fact, he started out on talent shows - as a contestant - at the tender age of 11.

Had it not been for a certain young woman named Melba Brunsdon, his life might have taken a different course. "I did a song, but she did a song and a tap dance." He resolved to beat her the next year, and took up tap dancing lessons. Twelve months later, his routine perfected, he returned. "I did my song and the tap dance, but Melba Brunsdon did a song, a tap dance and a ventriloquist's act. She beat me again."

Now, recounting his tale, he is still performing. With a straight face and apparently no sense of irony, he compares his adolescence to Billy Elliot: "My father was a Birkenhead docker, and I, much like Billy, had to go boxing - the Wallasey boxing club." His father only gave into the young Lythgoe's artistic leanings on the insistence of his mother. "In those days, you weren't gay, you were a fairy. And my dad said: 'Well if he's a fairy, he's a fairy.'" So, a star (if not a fairy - Lythgoe is married with kids) was born.

After a spell in performing arts school, Lythgoe joined the BBC's Young Generation. For those whose memories have faded, YG was the group of crotch-hugging kids who provided the cheesy dance routines in such televisual delights as the Rolf Harris Show and Summertime Special.

Here his production talents were spotted, and he was asked, at age 21, to be the group's choreographer. Then it was to ATV and The Muppet Show, choreographing the likes of Miss Piggy and the Swedish chef in the show's big musical numbers.

From there to here, Lythgoe's career is a rollcall of the "golden age" of ITV variety. Producing shows for Cilla Black, Morecambe and Wise, Bob Monkhouse, Lionel Blair, Joe Longthorne and Brian Conley, he has worked with just about anyone who has been anybody in TV light entertainment.

There was a wealth of talent, says Lythgoe, that simply is not around any more. "I grew up through what people now call the golden age of television - and although I'm not sure there was really a golden age, there were certainly a lot more entertainment programmes around, and a lot more performers. We were doing something like 60 TV shows, most of them live. "The performers are just not there today: the clubs have shut down, theatres are doing more musicals, whereas it used to be TV that did musical variety. Now, most of the talent is recording artists. That didn't really happen before."

Despite the death of variety, Lythgoe has kept mass-market entertainment alive. By developing new formats for stars such as Barrymore and Black and importing Gladiators from the US, he has helped keep ITV at the forefront of Saturday night family viewing.

But, in a career full of hits, there have inevitably been turkeys. There was a disastrous talent show with Lionel Blair (enough said), and he can boast that he was responsible for the only Bob Monkhouse show to bomb. (Anyone remember Bob's Your Uncle? Ouch.)

His highest-profile disaster, though, was Ice Warriors. An alarm bell should have rung when the show's host Dani Behr somewhat overstated her skating abilities to Lythgoe ("She told me that she was a great skater. She couldn't skate."). But they pressed on, believing this inexplicable piece of nonsense was great TV.

"On about show three, I realised that maybe I was deluding myself. I had been so engrossed in it that somewhere along the line we had forgotten to entertain people, to let them in on the joke." After the first series flopped, the irrepressible Lythgoe thought it could be rescued. The ITV network, fortunately, didn't give him the chance to try. "It was a complete failure," he concedes.
