From his position of strength, he can afford to be disparaging of the opposition. "I think entertainment over the past five years has been dominated by ITV. The BBC did reality documentaries very well - I think Hotel was a great programme - but a great deal of the BBC's entertainment is copied," he says.

"Star for a Night is basically Stars in Their Eyes; the Weakest Link, although I believe it is very good, is based on Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?, Stars Sing the Beatles is based on Abbamania, and Hall of Fame is a rip-off of An Audience With... They just haven't moved on."

But with Cilla Black still churning out endless series of Blind Date and Michael Barrymore still doing the same old act on My Kind of Music, Lythgoe appears to be throwing stones from the proverbial glass house.

He disagrees. "Remember, ITV has produced the biggest entertainment show, possibly in the world, with Millionaire. Michael Barrymore isn't doing the same thing as he did five years ago - I think he has moved on. Look at the Generation Game - now I think Jim Davidson is a great entertainer, but it doesn't exactly look like a lot of money has been spent on it. ITV is committed to big projects: Survivor is a big project."

And he believes that the bankers will still do the business. "Blind Date will still be on television when you and I are dead. It's the Coronation Street of entertainment, it will be there forever." Lythgoe is not a man given to understatement.

From the Lulu Show to Survivor

In much the same way as Bob Monkhouse suddenly became cool about five years ago, Nigel Lythgoe's new-found cult status has emerged after a 32-year career in the field of light entertainment. From Bobby Davro to Freddie Starr, there is virtually no star of the London Palladium with whom he has not worked:

1970s

After three years with the BBC's dance group Young Generation, he was appointed choreographer in 1971. He worked on more than 500 television shows, including the Lulu Show, Morecambe & Wise, The Two Ronnies, Vera Lynn, The Muppets and five Royal Variety Performances.

1980s

Choreographer and associate producer of Bud 'n' Ches; Tribute to Flanagan & Allen and Dizzy Feet; choreographer and director of Summertime Special for TVS; producer and director on The Bobby Davro Show, The Joe Longthorne Show, A Kind of Magic with Wayne Dobson, and the Bruce Forsyth Show.

1990s

Joined LWT as producer and director in 1992, working on Gladiators, the Brian Conley Show, and Beadle's Daredevils. In 1994, he became head of entertainment, and later controller of entertainment. Oversaw the Audience With . . . series, The Big Big Talent Show, You Bet!, Barrymore, Ice Warriors, Bruce Forsyth at the London Palladium, Royal Tournament, Record of the Year and Abbamania. Lythgoe took on the United productions entertainment and comedy departments, and oversees Michael Barrymore's My Kind of Music, Don't Try This at Home!, Friday Night's All Wright, TV Nightmares, Kids Say the Funniest Things, Hidden Talents of the Rich and Famous, and Cilla Black's Moment of Truth. His department also produces Prickly Heat for Sky, and Spaced, a co-production with Paramount, for Channel 4.

The future

Lythgoe is now on secondment to Survivor, the ITV reality show with £1m prize-money.

And with his uncanny resemblance to the late Larry Grayson, casting himself as the put-down king in ITV's new cult reality show Popstars is surely the most inspired move of his career. With cruel jibes and withering stares, Lythgoe dispatches rows of talentless teenagers with sweet-edged sadism. The LWT entertainment chief insists that compared to most casting couches, his manner is positively cuddly - but to the kids who cower before his caustic command, he must appear the devil incarnate. Competing with PR "guru" and power-ego Nikki Chapman, Lythgoe groans and grimaces through the thousands of self-deluding wannabes whose determination to be the "next big thing" eclipses their desperate lack of basic musical tonality. It is a role that he has been playing for most of his professional career. From gyrating in the dance troupe Young Generation to nurturing the careers of Cilla Black and Michael Barrymore, he is Mr Light Entertainment down to the roots of his flouncy blond hair. In full Grayson mode, he even spots a draught in the room where we are talking, gets up and daintily shuts the door that his PA has left ajar. You couldn't make it up. So it is all the more bizarre that Lythgoe has suddenly been catapulted to fame as ITV's great youth hope. One minute he was the doyen of "old ITV" (Cilla, Barrymore, Brian Conley); the next he was spearheading the network's biggest-ever drive for youth, not only entrusted with Popstars but also handed the task of developing for Britain the coast-to-coast US sensation of last year, Survivor. In the same way that William Hague looked silly in a baseball hat, Lythgoe cuts a rather incongruous figure alongside the pop kids of Planet 24, where the Survivor project is being co-ordinated. Fortunately - like many of the 3,000 who auditioned for Popstars - he is blissfully unaware of this fact. Either that, or he just doesn't care. And who can blame him? Now, after a career behind the cameras, he is a star in front of them. And he is not only the undisputed king of Popstars, he is also the subject of its marketing campaign too ("Nigel, pick me!" implore the billboards and TV trailers). He is the talk of taxi cabs (my driver burst into laughter when he found out I was going to interview him) and student common rooms. He has been sent up on The Big Breakfast in a feature titled "Nigel, pygmy", where "contestants" were auditioned by a rather small man. Even if the series flops (and there is not much sign of that) he will still be a household name. Being part of the show as well as behind it is a new experience, says Lythgoe. Never mind that his hair looks terrible however much attention he spends on it, and that no amount of Estée Lauder is going to get rid of those wrinkles, Lythgoe is revelling in his role. It's no accident that he's good at it: he has been in rehearsal all his career. In fact, he started out on talent shows - as a contestant - at the tender age of 11. webTitle: Nigel Pickard tells  Maggie Brown about his bruising start at CBBC

fields.headline: Not all fun and games
fields.standfirst: Under fire over two planned kids' channels and faced with dismal ratings for his flagship show, Nigel Pickard tells  Maggie Brown about his bruising start at CBBC
fields.trailText: Under fire over two planned kids' channels and faced with dismal ratings for his flagship show, Nigel Pickard tells Maggie Brown about his bruising start at CBBC
fields.body:
This year the BBC wants to go on a very big and very controversial adventure, by expanding into two new children's channels. But for viewers the key test of its creative powers is more immediate: whether Live & Kicking will be Dead & Buried in a couple of months.

Who else to ask but Nigel Pickard, the new head of CBBC? Last week the tabloids assured us the now low-rating three-hour show will definitely be laid to rest, poor Katy Hill eclipsed by Ant and Dec's SMTV on ITV. Pickard, 48, knows exactly what he's battling: he conjured up SMTV three years ago, revitalising children's programmes for ITV and turning the tables on BBC1. This fired up Greg Dyke to poach him.

"Clearly Saturday morning is in an interesting position," says Pickard. "For the first time in 10 years ITV is doing very well, and Live & Kicking is at a difficult stage - just when I don't want it to be!"

So is the show for the chop? "Haven't decided yet." Is it on probation? "No. Evolution."

Pickard, ever the pragmatist, believes Live & Kicking remains a strong brand. And it, or a replacement, must run 52 weeks a year on BBC1. So L&K is currently the focus of intense off-screen development, designed to change it from a staid magazine show to a fizzy compendium of fun ideas and cartoons.

L&K can't pretend to be SMTV, he says, but the revamped show won't be interviewing Mo Mowlam or the BBC1 controller like the pre-Pickard version. "We have nine months to see if can be tweaked," he reckons.

Pickard believes that CBBC programmes should aim to capture 30% of the available children's audience, and viewers had a taste of his competitiveness last week. To stop kids zapping, Newsround was moved from 5pm to 5.30pm, before Neighbours, allowing Blue Peter and dramas such as Byker Grove to start at 5pm.

Not that he's anti-Newsround: he regards it as a "a major part of our new channel line-up". He insists its agenda and target audience (11 year olds) are unchanged, though animal conservation stories seem to be crowded out by items on stress and mobile phones. But then, as he observes, children are older younger.

Pickard's biggest initiative, coming in April, will be rebranding CBBC to keep adults out. "CBBC has some fantastic programmes, but as a brand it doesn't punch its weight. CBBC should be the equivalent of a kid's bedroom, it should be exciting, a mess, somewhere you can go that's adult-free. It should feel like you're not being watched over. It should be your space. I don't think we've got that tone of voice right now, but the team are working hard towards it."

Children's viewing habits "are even more frenetic than a couple of years ago. We must be aware of the duration of programmes and links. We have to move in faster, engage them faster. We must ensure the action continues right to the end. I want them to feel they daren't leave us."

Pickard's main task since joining has been planning two children's digital channels: Playbox, aimed at 2-to-5s and due to start this summer, and a second network for 6-to-13s, launching in winter 2002. The formal application went to Chris Smith for approval last Thursday, just two days after the culture secretary published detailed guidelines for new services.

The BBC is to expand its annual spending on children from £40m to more than £90m. A quarter of the digital channel programmes will be new, but designed to be interchangeable with CBBC. The pre-school channel will have 90% British programming - Teletubbies, Tweenies, Noddy, Postman Pat - compared to 78% on the other channel.

The plans are contentious. Paul Robinson, managing director of Disney TV UK, says there are 14 commercial channels already serving UK children - so Smith must ensure that the BBC's are pure public service.

Will they be? "Public service is at the core," Pickard says. "These cannot be archive channels, they cannot be about exploiting libraries. We have got to create unique programming. As a proposition it's fantastic. That's why it is tough to argue against."

Although Robinson says the BBC channels will favour children in multi-channel homes, Pickard insists that "the product will be universally available. All these programmes will be platform-neutral. Certain programmes will premiere on the pre-school channel, but over time they will refresh CBBC1 and BBC2, which will remain our main portals."

As for the commercial networks' grouse that they have been blocked from buying BBC library programmes, Pickard says: "I don't think it's unreasonable if we are likely to launch a preschool channel. It's good business sense, and it's important that we don't dilute BBC brands."

The two new channels will occupy the lion's share of BBC3 and BBC4. Playbox, on BBC4, will run from 6am to 7pm, and stress "learning through play", with online back-up and tips for carers and parents. Pickard has inherited seven new pre-school strands, seized on by critics as evidence that the BBC is jumping the gun, expecting a friendly government rubber stamp. "This is called preparation," he retorts. "Once we're given the green light we want to get on air quickly." Why the rush? "It's important, with digital rolling out, that you need to be there. The Nickelodeons and the Disneys are way ahead, by seven or eight years."

The plans contain no promise of audience levels, and there must be concern that the BBC's channels could be so public service that children won't watch."I think they will watch. Public service doesn't mean boring. It means fulfilling commitments about a range of programming not provided elsewhere."

Bidding to bring teenagers back to CBBC, the channel for older children will run from 7am to 8pm on BBC3, later than expected, with three news shows a day. Other programme ideas include Blue Peter spin-offs and more cookery. It will profile bands but not make another chart show.

"We mustn't just perpetuate what we do. There are real opportunities for creating new programmes, not just clones," says Pickard, who is dead set against a teen soap. But a young teen comedy is in development.

The new services, he says, are driven by ideas. "This hasn't been done on the basis that we must achieve a 10% share, or a guaranteed target, that's the refreshing thing. One of the issues is that digital has become a byword for cheap and high-volume. You can't afford that with such a strong brand as CBBC."

Given the sums earned by successful children's programmes, the cynical suspect that the enthusiasm for children's networks is part-driven by BBC Worldwide's ambitious head, Rupert Gavin. "The only criteria are: are they good, do they serve children, how will they do on air?" Pickard counters. "Only a tiny proportion of any service's programmes achieve commercial success, four or five strands like Tweenies, Teletubbies.

"If there's a hidden agenda, it's hidden from me as well. Rupert Gavin as a distributor is naturally looking at what's got potential but the agenda, as to what we run, is set by me. The idea comes first."

webTitle: My media: Stephen Pollard

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Stephen Pollard
fields.trailText: Stephen Pollard
fields.body:
Newspapers: I read everything. At home I get the Independent, the Daily Telegraph and the Racing Post. Columnists-wise, I am a big fan of Jonathan Freedland, Alice Miles and Steve Richards. Overall I think Andrew Rawnsley is just about the best.

Magazines: The only two British political magazines that excite me are the New Statesman - unmissable - and Prospect. What I really adore are the American political magazines. I also get Gramophone.

Television: I despise people who despise television and label it all as rubbish. Nothing is as good as The Sopranos - ER almost, but not quite. I've also become hooked on Artsworld. I get the racing channel because I'm a bit of a horse racing nut plus I'm an unashamed Coronation Street fan.

Books: I've just finished Robert Skidelsky's biography of Keynes and I'm in the middle of Norman Podhoretz's My Love Affair with America, which is beautifully written.

Radio: My favourite programme is the Saturday morning CD review on Radio 3. I'll always listen to Alan Green's commentaries on 5 Live. The rest is predictable - Today programme, the Archers and I go to bed with 5 Live.

Adverts: I hate the Halifax Building Society advert where the supposed branch manager runs around singing about how marvellous the Halifax is. I'm also probably the only person in Britain who hasn't seen the Whassup! advert.

Films: House of Mirth and Memento were fantastic. Quite liked good rubbish films like Meet The Parents and Family Man.

New Media: The internet has made things unbelievable. The fact that every day I can look up the New York Times, Washington Post and LA Times is magnificent. I spend hours reading obscure magazines and articles. I also waste too much time looking at the Tottenham team talk page.

 Stephen Pollard was last week dismissed from his new job at the Times after including a coded message about Richard Desmond in his last column for the Express

webTitle: Media monitor: pre-election spin

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.standfirst: In the first of his pre-election columns,  John Kampfner looks at a hyperactive week for the government's spin machine
fields.trailText: In the first of his pre-election columns, John Kampfner looks at a hyperactive week for the government's spin machine
fields.body:
This is the strategy: if you can't fix things quickly, you must at least look as if you're trying. At the start of the long election campaign, this past week has been a good example of a hyperactive government media machine trying to mould news, good and bad, to its own advantage. The more troublesome the story, the more important the response.

It began with a dramatic story on January 5 in the Times. Roland Watson, the paper's astute chief political correspondent, got an early glimpse of the Department of Health report which revealed that Harold Shipman may have killed up to 265 patients. The splash came with two pages of reports and an editorial. It was followed up in the later editions of its rivals, with the Daily Telegraph, Independent and Sun (an interesting combination) changing their front pages. The report was due to be published later in the day, so was this a case of news management? Watson, who says he had been on the trail of the story for some time, is understandably coy about the source. But he wrote, not too cryptically: "Alan Milburn has been aware for a number of weeks of the likely scale of the findings."

Purely coincidentally, of course, another announcement was planned for the following Monday - the creation of a national clinical assessment authority to monitor dodgy doctors. The story was briefed to all the Sundays. But the link between a mass murderer and clinical neglect is, to say the least, tenuous - as Alice Miles of the Times pointed out later that week.

The trouble with giving a story in advance to journalists is that on the following day they tend to look for a different - and more critical - angle. On the Monday, the paper's health correspondent dwelt not on the advent of the NCAA, but of a government climbdown over so-called "boot camps for doctors". The paper also spent much of the week showing that 250 out of 700 hospital buildings are filthy.

Elsewhere in Wapping, the News of the World claimed the government had disingenuously included 20,000 people registered for care at home in figures relating to hospital beds. It also had two damaging leader articles, one on the story about the figures, the other on the Shipman case, saying ministers had until now been "fighting tooth and nail" to keep the inquiries secret. The Sunday Mirror had a commentary from a luminary of the British Medical Association on the dire state of the NHS. But worse came in Monday's Daily Mail, with doctor-in- residence Anthony Daniels saying the creation of the NCAA was part of a Labour "Leninist" plot to "turn doctors into obedient petty clerks".

On Wednesday, the Mirror announced pay rises for doctors and nurses. Alongside was another leaked piece of good news for Milburn, saying the forthcoming waiting list figures would show a sharp drop. Again, when the figures were actually published, they were drowned in Friday's tabloids by another story. The Mail and the Sun revealed that the NHS "hires African nurses with HIV".

So, the verdict on the week was: bad, but it could have been much worse. The Downing Street plan - according to officials - is to offload as much of the difficult stuff as early as possible. But what an opportunity was missed on Monday, when the best story of the week appeared in the Telegraph. "Fears of a new flu crisis at the NHS are receding," it said. The story was tucked away in the bottom righthand corner of page 6. Why did the government's spin maestros allow such a winner to be thrown away like that?

webTitle: E4 strikes Sky Digital carriage deal

fields.headline: E4 strikes Sky Digital carriage deal
fields.trailText: 10.15am: New Channel 4 entertainment service E4 has secured carriage on Sky Digital just three days before launch, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's new entertainment service, E4, has secured carriage on Sky Digital, just three days before its launch on Thursday night.

The last-minute deal means that E4 will be available in more than 7m pay-TV homes when it goes on air at 8.15pm on Thursday.

E4 will go out on Sky Digital as part of the basic tier Family Package, taking channel 205 on Sky Digital's electronic programme guide.

The service has already secured carriage on NTL's digital cable network, Telewest's digital and analogue cable services and ONdigital's digital terrestrial service.

While the negotiation with BSkyB over Sky Digital carriage has virtually gone down to the wire, Channel 4 executives were always confident a deal would be struck.

"We are pleased to have concluded negotiations with Sky Digital in time for our launch," allowing us to make British TV's most talked about shows available to the widest number of viewers," said Gerry Bastable, Channel 4 managing director of digital pay-TV.

Sky One, a BSkyB subsidiary and rival entertainment service to E4, will schedule US reality show Temptation Island against the Channel 4 service's launch night on Thursday.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: The battlelines between staff at Express New Media and its erstwhile owner are clearly drawn as workers accuse Northern & Shell of selling the Express's sites off in order to avoid redundancy payments
fields.body:
 The battlelines between staff at Express New Media and its erstwhile owner are clearly drawn as workers accuse Northern & Shell of selling the Express's sites off in order to avoid redundancy payments. However, the staff might find little comfort from some of their own content. Clearly visible on the now suspended Express.co.uk site is a link to CompanyLeader.com, an Express New Media site aimed at budding masters of the business world. An article there might make compelling reading for managers at Northern & Shell and the current owner of Express New Media, Seymour Pierce; it's called, "How to be avoid being taken to an employment tribunal".

 The Industry Standard, bible of the new economy in the United States, stayed true to its warts-and-all depiction of the increasingly bloody dot.com landscape last week. Known for its detailed portrayal of the demise of hundreds of internet firms, a popular feature on its website is its "Lay-off Tracker", a cheery record of the pink slips that keep raining down on dot.com land. This week the tracker made an interesting read - squeezed in between the job cuts at the e-commerce delivery venture Kozmo.com and the music site Launch.com was the news that Standard Media International had itself shed 36 people. The redundancies hit the marketing and sales department - a senior staffer at the Standard assured Media Guardian that no journalists were lost during the downsize.

 Silicon.com, the IT recruitment-driven technology news site, was cruelly removed from the web for three days last week. The culprits were not fiendish cyber-criminals hacking away from dank, distant bedrooms, but villains of a more traditional kind - burglars who stole crucial hardware from its London offices, starving IT managers across Europe of internet news and job vacancies. Still, with an audience of enterprising technology experts it wasn't short of offers of assistance. So much so that when editor-in-chief Jon Bernstein announced the site was back in action, he made the following impassioned plea: "Our IT director also asks that any company involved in disaster recovery does not call him to tell him about their exciting products."

 Journalists looking for a glimmer of hope among the carnage of the online news sector might have been cheered by the news this week that financial news portal EuropeanInvestor.com had landed a second round of funding, something of a feat in these more cautious times. With TheStreet.co.uk and the German edition of the Motley Fool both out of cash and off the web it was nice to see the prospect of some more venture capital-sponsored journalists. However, a closer look at the deal shows a slightly different picture - EuropeanInvestor.com has long since dispensed with the luxury of journalists. It sacked its whole team last year in a bid to smooth its path to profitability.

webTitle: The true picture of newspaper sales

fields.headline: Time to ditch the incredible bulk
fields.standfirst: ABC figures include 'multiple copy circulation' - in other words papers that are distributed free. From this month  Roy Greenslade puts the stress on paid-for sales to give a true picture of who is buying what
fields.trailText: ABC figures include 'multiple copy circulation' - in other words papers that are distributed free. From this month Roy Greenslade puts the stress on paid-for sales to give a true picture of who is buying what
fields.body:
From this month, Media Guardian is making a radical departure in the presentation of the officially audited newspaper circulation figures. It has become increasingly obvious that the totals - known as the headline figures - present a false view of the market.

So we have decided to take a dramatic step by omitting the category of sale open to the widest misuse: bulks, or "multiple copy circulation", the euphemism applied by the Audit Bureau of Circulations (ABC).

The lead statistics in the new chart therefore show sales for which individuals pay. They may pay only a proportion of the full cover price, they may pay by subscription, they may buy copies abroad. But the point is that they are genuine buyers.

Bulk sales are very different. These are the piles of papers one finds at airports, fast food outlets or betting shops. They are the papers left outside your hotel room or handed out as you get on to a plane.

As far as the receiver is concerned, they are free. But someone does pay, of course. The airline, say, or restaurant chain agrees a deal with a newspaper company in which it pays a nominal sum for each copy supplied. Sometimes this can be as little as a fraction of 1p per copy, but whatever the amount it is the reason they are referred to as "sales".

But it is clear, despite any number of safeguards agreed between newspaper companies and the ABC after years of abuses, that these giveaway papers should not be regarded as real sales and should not form part of the headline total.

There is a perfectly legitimate reason for newspapers to sell in bulk to airlines and hotels. It is a good way of promoting titles, getting them into the hands of people who might not otherwise buy them, encouraging them to change their reading habits, perhaps. In the industry, this is referred to as sampling but its effectiveness is very doubtful.

Many people get so used to being able to pick up free copies of papers that they see no reason to buy one at all. There are sampling exercises that target niche audiences which can be successful, though the results are, according to most circulation managers, marginal.

Indeed, overall declining sales and the concurrent rise in the distribution of bulks proves otherwise. Despite editors routinely telling me that their bulks are being phased out, the December 1999 bulk total of 525,867 had reached 623,599 by last month.

In most cases, the real reason papers rely on the use of multiple copy sales is to massage their headline figures, to conceal the reality of their steep circulation declines.

The Observer, published by Guardian Media Group, has increased its bulk sales from 17,000 a year ago to 30,000. The Daily Telegraph, which has hovered above a million throughout last year and sells almost a third of its total through cut-price subscriptions, relies on 47,000 bulks.

The Times has much the highest bulk total of all, at 58,000. This is 15,000 more than a year ago. But that's only one ploy used by the paper that initially depended on a price war to boost its circulation. The Times sells 77,000 through cheap subscriptions and a further 73,000 at a discount across the counter. Fewer than 500,000 copies of the Times are sold at the full cover price.

Sunday Business makes a most glaring use of bulks, giving away more than 16,000, some 30% of its headline sale. With its real sales having fallen by 28% in a year to a mere 37,824, there is every reason to question the strategy of doubling the cover price to £1.

There are papers which have largely avoided the bulks addiction, such as the Sun, the News of the World and the Daily Star. The Guardian includes 6,000, less than 2% of its total. One paper, the Sunday Mirror, has made a good stab at weaning itself off the habit, but its daily stablemate which appeared to be taking the same route has fallen back to its bad old ways.

If Trinity Mirror doesn't do something soon, it is going to find its flagship falling below 2m. Hiring the astrologer Jonathan Cainer from the Express is all very well, but he didn't take many readers with him when he left the Daily Mail for the Daily Express, so that alone isn't enough.

Which brings us back to the Express situation. One of Richard Desmond's great boasts when he took over the paper in late November was that he would increase the print run. If he did, and my researches suggest the increase was, at best, modest, it hasn't made a blind bit of difference.

Some readers may have turned their backs on the Expresses because of his pornographic interests, but the decline looks to be only a little worse than it has been for years past.

Desmond has shown not the least sign of understanding the crisis at his newspapers, offering no coherent strategy beyond cost-cutting, leaving them to drift ever downwards. When the Daily Express dips below a million, which could well happen by March, he will face the problem of falling advertising revenue alongside increasing newsprint costs. Meanwhile, many of the staff who have pledged to stay on seem to think a new editor is going to make a huge difference. With the greatest of respect to whoever does pick up the poisoned chalice, they haven't got a chance unless there is rapid and rational investment in the title.

No wonder the paper is selling only 820,000 at its full cover price. It is in limbo and readers, however unsophisticated too many journalists think them to be, understand when a paper is merely going through the motions. It isn't being promoted properly. It is failing to compete with the rest of the market, let alone the Daily Mail.

It will be interesting to see how Desmond deals with the high ratio of bulks in his papers. As newsprint gets more expensive, selling papers for 1p a copy will certainly hit the bottom line. That fact will obviously be on the minds of other owners too and it just might lead to a general decrease in numbers of bulks. Now, with our new chart, we will be able to monitor that situation closely.

Our change is not a maverick exercise. It is being done to ensure clarity. Now everyone - readers, journalists, advertisers and their agencies - will be able to get a much clearer picture of real newspaper sales.

webTitle: Blair's local bosses to lift rundown areas

fields.headline: Blair's local bosses to lift rundown areas
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today unveil ambitious plans to appoint "neighbourhood managers" to run some of the most deprived estates and old industrial communities as part of his drive to end poverty and social exclusion.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today unveil ambitious plans to appoint "neighbourhood managers" to run some of the most deprived estates and old industrial communities as part of his drive to end poverty and social exclusion.

The managers, paid from central government funds, will have enough local knowledge, empathy and clout to tackle failing services, from crime and health to education and housing, by banging official heads together if necessary.

Ministers hope to see councils and local businesses join in partnerships and believe that deprived communities have been seen for too long as part of the problem, not part of the solution, and that their priorities have often been ignored.

The neighbourhood managers' tasks will vary according to circumstance. Some may come from local authorities, but have a remit that also includes the NHS and police. Many will live locally, it is predicted.

They could be responsible for managing services covering 4,000 households, a large inner city estate or several former pit villages.

Some 900 wards in the 88 most deprived areas of England are being targeted, but successful techniques are expected to spin over into the devolved governments in Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast.

But in line with Labour's "tough love" approach, the scheme will expect residents to give "something for something" by taking on more responsibility and working with the neighbourhood manager. "Communities must fight for themselves," said one senior official.

This morning the prime minister will lead a ministerial team to Tower Hamlets, east London, to implement plans to revitalise struggling communities by encouraging leadership at the grassroots.

To underpin the new drive, "floor targets" will be set to require improvements such as every school getting at least a quarter of its pupils five "good" GCSE results by 2004 and ensuring that the burglary rate by 2005 is nowhere more than three times the national average. With more than £100m being released by the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, to support the initiative - initially in 30 pilot schemes from among the 900 targeted wards - Mr Blair will admit that governments got it wrong in the past.

"The approach on the left for too long was too top down and believed that every problem could be solved by promising more money. The chief failure on the right was indifference to social exclusion, a massive mistake for which we are still paying," he will say.

Ministers have been encouraged by the sharp rise in standards of literacy and numeracy and falls in unemployment in some of the most deprived areas since 1997. A scheme in Sunderland halved burglary on one difficult estate.

Community-led anti-drug projects and schemes to improve health have also produced good progress, on which Mr Blair hopes to build with the help of a 50-strong neighbourhood renewal unit.

webTitle: Media monkey

fields.headline: Media monkey
fields.trailText: If you noticed that the much-parodied BBC newsreader Huw Edwards was looking even more cheesed-off than usual last week, there's a simple explanation: "Huw Who" has yet to make Who's Who
fields.body:
 If you noticed that the much-parodied BBC newsreader Huw Edwards was looking even more cheesed-off than usual last week, there's a simple explanation: "Huw Who" has yet to make Who's Who. Worse, his stand-in, Fiona Bruce, is among the new entrants in the just- published 2001 edition. Please don't send him a video of All About Eve to try to cheer him up.

 Commiserations to young Mirror reporter Tom Newton Dunn, who last week learned the hard way how to get on in journalism when he was sent by Piers Morgan to interview the nudist Vincent Bethell stark-naked (the reporter, as well as Bethell). Despite telling Tom that he would protect his modesty, the photographer, John Ferguson, gave a full-frontal shot of Newton Dunn to the newsdesk, and it has been emailed all over the building.

 A letter in this week's BBC staff newsletter, Ariel, raises the horrifying possibility that the new series of Bill and Ben has mixed up the flowerpot men. Apparently, the high voice used to belong to Bill and the low one to Ben, and the new series has swapped them. Monkey is, of course, too young to remember.

 Express diary story of the week comes from under an avalanche of paper. Monkey has been inundated with copies of a letter sent to thousands of Express suppliers last week. From Group joint managing director Martin Ellice, it states that "Under no circumstances are you to supply goods or services to our company unless you receive an Official Express Newspapers Purchase Order". Otherwise, it continues, the supplier will not be paid. And, guess what, it seems no one has seen a purchase order.

 Channel 4's political strand, Powerhouse, marked the start of a new series last week with a champagne party in Westminster. In a rare glimpse of brotherly solidarity, editor Andrew Brown played host to his older brother, Gordon, who popped by for a cheery mingle. Alas, the programme, which uses a variety of politicians as presenters, has been unable to test Gordon's journalistic skills. "It's a bit awkward for us to use government ministers, when inevitably the programmes are criticising official policy," explains Andrew.

webTitle: Facts behind the figures that damn Walsall

fields.headline: Facts behind the figures that damn Walsall
fields.trailText: The Walsall NHS trust points to local lifestyles and deprivation as reason for highest hospital death rate in England. Jeevan Vasagar reports
fields.body:
Walsall was once famous for its leather industry - hence Walsall Football Club's nickname, the Saddlers.

These days only a museum preserves the memory of the industry. Unemployment is high and low wages are rife.

The West Midlands town, in the industrial Black Country, retains a tough working men's club culture, fuelled by bitters and baltis, in which too much attention to health can be seen as effete.

It also has a large Asian population, with higher than average rates of heart disease.

These factors may go some way to explain why the Walsall NHS trust has the highest death rates in the country, as found in the study by Sir Brian Jarman of Imperial College, London, published yesterday.

But Sam Ramaiah, the trust's public health director, who has earned local notoriety for his vigorous assault on Walsall's "curry and couch potato" lifestyle, expressed astonishment that death rates were not weighted by social factors: "I've been saying for a long time that deprivation has a major impact on health, and it certainly has on mortality rates."

Nevertheless, the finding of a link between staff levels and patient deaths has alarmed the trust, which runs Walsall Manor hospital.

Trust sources indicated that the report could be used to put pressure on the government to provide more cash for recruitment. The hospital has 23 doctors per 100 beds, compared with an average of 35 per 100 beds in England.

After a board meeting yesterday morning, the chief executive, John Rostill, acknowledged "the broad suggestion that the number of doctors we employ has a direct bearing on mortality. Of course it's got to be a contributing factor, but I can't believe it's so strong.

"That's the sort of thing we've got to look at."

He denied there were recruitment problems because of the town's unglamorous image. "Clearly there are people who like to go to places that have a slightly different background. But it is quite offensive to our staff to say that nobody of calibre would want to work in Walsall.

"It's not a question of us having recruitment difficulty. It's a question of us identifying the funding to take on more staff."

Mr Rostill stressed that on many other measures Manor hospital performed well, "such as waiting lists, how quickly we deal with complaints and breast cancer care".

The trust and Walsall health authority are expected to announce a joint inquiry, looking at Sir Brian's methodology and identifying problems with local healthcare.

Local people yesterday said they were proud of the hospital and had confidence in its doctors and nurses.

Paul Woolley, 50, who was admitted 2 years ago after a stroke and was visiting the hospital's social club, said: "I was as close to death as you will ever be. When I needed them, they were there. My mother-in-law had surgery for breast cancer here. Both my kids were born here, and the aftercare was absolutely brilliant. Out of 100 I would give them 95.

"Like everywhere else in the country, I think nurses have a raw deal for what they do and should be paid more."

Benjamin Edwards, 72, was also treated for a stroke in 1998 and regularly returns to catch up with other former patients at the social club.

"It's a good hospital," he said. "After my stroke they did a lot of therapy for me, and I'm much better now. I can stand up and get in the bath.

"I come down to the social club and have a couple of orange juices because it gets me out of the house."

Dr Ramaiah said health education was slowly eroding traditional attitudes and improving lifestyles.

"Fewer people are dying from heart disease," he said. "We are making improvements, but the improvements are slow to be recognised because we are starting off from a much lower level."

webTitle: My new media: Maria Trkulja

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Maria Trkulja
fields.trailText: Maria Trkulja
fields.body:
Favourite sites? The Drudge Report.com is great for celebrity exclusives and the latest gossip. Beauty site Sephora.com is very rare because it's better than the shop it's based on. As well as selling products it has a great magazine and interactive tools such as a fragrance finder. You can also post questions to the site's beauty adviser.

Last online purchase?

I bought vitamins from health website gnc.co.uk. as part of my half-hearted attempt to be healthier this year. I forget to buy things if I'm busy, whereas this way I can do it the moment I think of it. The instant availability is appealing.

Most recent technological faux pas?

My five-year-old nephew having to show me how to get my new laptop to work. I was having problems getting through a security shield and he got me in within seconds.

Main news source on the web?

It used to be BBC Online. Up-to-the- minute news is a priority.

Most persistent spam emailer?

I'm lucky. I don't get many.

Time spent on the web?

I'm online virtually all day editing which unfortunately means I don't get much time for surfing.

Next boo.com?

Anyone who believes in style over substance. I wouldn't wish it on anyone but the industry does seem to be more cautious now. Identifying and targeting a market has to be the first step and not an afterthought. I don't think boo really had a market. No matter how much confidence you have in an idea, the figures have got to add up.

Least useful site on the web?

Any that don't work and there are too many to mention.

Most useful site?

Scoot for cinema listings and Streetmap.co.uk which means never having to carry around an A-Z again.

Which screensaver do you use?

I don't. I find them too distracting.

Most irritating thing about the web?

When it won't let you access a site. You have to be very persistent to keep going back and most people give up. That's the worst thing about the internet and it's holding back progress. This problem really needs to be sorted out.

Do you bother with old media?

My background is in newspaper and magazines. The web won't ever replace them but you can have the best of both worlds.

 Maria Trkulja is editor of femail.co.uk which was relaunched this month

webTitle: Mortality lottery in NHS

fields.headline: Mortality lottery in NHS
fields.trailText: The government last night renewed its pledge to increase the number of doctors and promised a simple annual report card on every hospital in England after the publication of death rates showed that mortality among patients varies significantly. James Meikle reports
fields.body:
The government last night renewed its pledge to increase the number of doctors and promised a simple annual report card on every hospital in England after the publication of death rates showed that mortality among patients varies significantly.

The research suggests that 17 people are likely to die in the country's worst performing hospital for every 10 who die in the best, even after adjusting the figures to take account of the patients' ages, sex, diagnoses and length of stay.

The availability of doctors, and whether or not patients were admitted as emergency cases, were far more important than factors such as social background, the study showed. It used NHS data for five years up to last March to assess performance.

Walsall NHS trust was revealed as having the worst mortality rate, while University College London Hospitals NHS trust had the best, the research for Dr Foster Ltd, publisher of healthcare information, showed.

The British Medical Association jumped on the general link between staffing and death rates to strengthen its campaign for more doctors, although some hospitals with comparatively low numbers of doctors also had low patient mortality.

Liam Fox, the Tories' health spokesman, claimed the variations revealed a "permanent structural crisis in the NHS".

The assessments, which will fuel debate about the "postcode lottery" in NHS care, were made by Sir Brian Jarman, emeritus professor of primary health care at Imperial College, London. He used official NHS data, but went far further than the government has in turning performance indicators into stark overall death rates.

Sir Brian insisted that his team had tried to be "as fair as we can". During the period surveyed, each hospital trust would have seen on average 59,000 admissions and 4,700 deaths. One thing was clear: "We need more doctors."

His team calculated a mortality index for each hospital so one that had exactly the national average of deaths, after taking into account other factors, would score 100. Those that had more deaths would score above 100; those with fewer would score below. Hospitals in Walsall scored 119, compared with 68 for the UCH trust, but Walsall also had a far lower ratio of doctors per 100 beds (23 against 63). Of 174 trusts surveyed, death rates in 17 were at least 10.5% above average, while in 22 others they were 10.5% lower.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, gave a bullish welcome to Sir Brian's work. "In the past governments refused to publish this sort of information. That was wrong," he said.

He said more information and tough inspections would improve standards. The government, already published in non-league-table form the death rate per hospital, and within a year would give information on waiting times, cancelled operations, cleanliness, length of hospital stay and delayed discharges.

The government had already promised 7,500 more consultants by 2004, and more beds.

webTitle: How not to run an internet video site

fields.headline: I left my art in San Francisco
fields.standfirst: When  Jason Thompson arrived in California to join an internet video site he was an excited player in a brave new world, full of idealism and optimism. Then it all started to go horribly wrong...
fields.trailText: When Jason Thompson arrived in California to join an internet video site he was an excited player in a brave new world, full of idealism and optimism. Then it all started to go horribly wrong...
fields.body:
There were long queues at the immigration desk when I arrived at San Francisco's international airport on December 18 1999. Like thousands of other foreign workers converging on the city at the dawn of the third millennium I was about to join the internet industry. After working in British television documentaries for five years I was thrilled to imagine myself as a pioneer in a new medium, and I soon stumbled into a job at "user-generated" video site Eveo.com.

He spoke in charismatic terms about his desire to empower ordinary people to tell their own stories. Above all, as he said in an interview with film-maker community site IndieWire, "the internet is about people". I was seduced by the rhetoric.

The Chocolate Building in San Francisco's Ghirardelli Square, an area thronged with seagulls and tourists, seemed an odd choice for the headquarters of an internet entertainment company. This feeling of oddity stayed with me as I walked into the Eveo office early last year, to face bare white walls and boxes of self-assembly desks. But as a newcomer to the brash culture of California start-ups, it was difficult to tell for sure that anything was wrong. I built my desk, plugged in my phone, and got to work.

Critics of the internet gold rush have rightly assumed that one motive for dot.com employees was greed. But in late 1999 and early 2000, there was also a millennialist optimism sustaining the fervour of those who embraced the new technology. The promise of new technology is that it will improve the spiritual, as well as the material lot of humanity, and I am quite sure that, however naively, I invested Eveo with this world-improving faith. Along with the idea of working in a new medium, in a new century, came the thought that this was perhaps a new world. I was not alone in my optimism. At a company meeting, marketing manager Tammy Karpanko, described Eveo as "video by the people, for the people". Linda Olszewski, a Dreamworks executive hired as fiction and comedy channel manager, suggested that kids in the ghetto might stop shooting bullets, and start shooting films.

As documentary channel manager my job was to get hold of as many short videos as possible before the site launched on February 20. Zitoun gave me a small budget for commissions, and I made some films myself, but my main task was to encourage submissions from aspiring video-makers. The company promised to pay $100 for every video received before the launch date, regardless of quality, in the hope that they could sell some of these films to other websites, or even to television. It seemed unlikely, but I reminded myself that I was part of a revolution, and kept my doubts to myself. "You don't need to worry about that," the vice-president Marc Ruxin reassured me, when I asked him how the company intended to make money. So, like all the other workers joining start-ups without clear revenue models, and the investors who gambled on them, I allowed myself to believe that the traditional laws of economics had been miraculously suspended.

The oddities multiplied. I tried not to worry, as Ruxin suggested, but it was difficult. In February I attended the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. The company had spent several thousand dollars on an advert in one of the festival catalogues. "A truly inspirational thought for genuine artists," the copy declared, "sub-five-minute shorts can now make you serious bucks." A company flyer depicted an Eveo logo in the style of the giant Hollywood sign in the hills above Los Angeles, a tactic so self-important that some people took it as irony.

On my return to Ghirardelli Square, I expressed my concerns about the company's public relations strategy to Zitoun. He reassured me that it was early days. We soon began receiving videos in the post. The films ranged from excellent 16mm shorts by young directors to amateur footage of students being sick. Many people in the company began to suggest it should encourage the good material, and reject the bad. Zitoun disagreed. Shortly after the site's launch in March, venture capitalists gave the company $15m. I started getting phone calls from angry film-makers who had not received their $100.

Later that month, Zitoun rewarded our hard work with a company boat trip to Angel Island. It was during our games there that I had an epiphany about the way Eveo worked and why I had been feeling so strange. The games were random. People divided into small groups, which then divided into still smaller groups, before re-forming in new allegiances, with footballs and frisbees flying back and forth arbitrarily. It struck me that life in the office was scarcely different: emails flew back and forth, projects emerged and then vanished, people came and went without explanation or consequence. It was chaos.

In April I helped to produce a DVD, featuring the best work on the site, which the company gave away as a promotional tool at the Cannes Film Festival. A few days after packing the discs into boxes and sending them out into the world, Karpanko received an anxious phone call from Max Frankston, a New York film-maker and winner of an Eveo contest for a short documentary he directed about his son, which was meant to feature on the disc. Frankston had invited relatives to watch the film at his home, and was calling Karpanko to say that he had received the "wrong" DVD.

The disc had an Eveo label, and was packed in an Eveo box, but did not feature Eveo material. Instead, the DVD contained a hardcore porn film called Blackballers II, about a gang of black men who abduct and rape young white boys. Frankston was not alone in receiving Blackballers II, and Eveo film editor Marcy Charap spent several painful hours calling bewildered film-makers to apologise for the mysterious mix-up in the DVD pressing plant, which was never explained.

I might have seen the funny side, but I'd started making promises I could not keep, to people I respected. The angry phone calls from unpaid film-makers got angrier. The oddities multiplied to a surreal level, and I sank into depression. In February, I began talks with Colin Luke and Adam Alexander of the UK indepen dent production company Mosaic Films. The talks were still continuing when I left the company almost five months later.

In April I went to a film festival in Taos, New Mexico, and met Haskell Wexler, the Oscar-winning cinematographer of Days of Heaven. Listening to my pitch about global democracy, he agreed to give the company his video about Gladys Knight and Burt Bacharach in Cuba. But I no longer believed what I was saying, and Wexler's generosity shamed me.

Later that month, the Nasdaq slumped, and a string of internet companies went bust. But it was the end of the millennial optimism, not the stock market downturn, which led to my resignation on June 30. Like the investors who lost their shirts on overvalued stocks in April, I lost my innocence about the corporate world, and my naive faith in the internet.

Eveo survives today with a new business plan, based on licensing its services to other companies. But, for me at least, the idealism is over.

webTitle: Michael Streeter on the demise of the Daily Express' website

fields.headline: We may be down but we're not out
fields.trailText: Michael Streeter tells the story of the demise of the Daily Express' website
fields.body:
It had all started so optimistically, as cautionary tales usually do. I was called down from Glasgow, where I'd been editing the Scottish Daily Express, to become the first editor of the Daily Express website. My only instruction was to make it the best newspaper site in Britain - and money, it was implied, would not be an obstacle.

Meanwhile in the London office, ambitious plans were taking shape for the new Express Digital Media division of United News & Media, boosted by the promise of millions of pounds of funding within UN&M's new new media arm, Xilerate.

That was last summer. Last week, in the middle of winter, the tale came to its gory conclusion. Express Digital Media was closed down, leaving all 46 staff redundant and scrabbling for new jobs.

So far, you may say, nothing terribly surprising in that. The world of web hasn't exactly had a great six months.

But this tale had an extra twist. EDM and its constituent companies (Express.co.uk Publishing, Sportlive.co.uk, Allaboutparents and Companyleader) were sold by the new Express Newspapers owner, Richard Desmond, to a company controlled by his financial advisers, Seymour Pierce. For £1. Finally, the liquidators were called in on Tuesday.

This left all of us not just without work, but without redundancy, without our notice pay and without part of our salaries. Financial insult was piled on top of injury.

The circumstances of this mess raise some important questions. The liquidation of the sites with few assets means, on the face of it, that neither Seymour Pierce, Express Newspapers nor indeed UN&M (now United Business Media) has to pick up the redundancy tab. Instead the taxpayer, in the form of the admittedly tiny statutory redundancy from the Department of Trade and Industry, is having to pick up that bill. Is that really what the law intends to happen?

The riddle doesn't end there. Just why did Desmond's Northern & Shell buy us in the first place when he acquired Express Newspapers from Clive Hollick's UN&M for £125m in November? The websites only became part of the sale right at the end of lengthy negotiations over the newspapers.

It's hard to escape the conclusion that this was simply a smart move by the wily Hollick to offload the sites as his own company moved away from digital media - and one that perhaps caught Northern & Shell flat-footed.

That may explain why, within days of buying us, the new Express owners told us bluntly they wanted to close us down. Deeply disappointing though this was, we were at least promised redundancy and the honouring of our contracts.

Such solace was short-lived. Two weeks later came the most baffling development of all. Late on December 13, we were informed that we had been sold yet again, this time to Seymour Pierce. To those of us who came into the media to work for, well, media companies, this was indeed odd. Even odder was that the name of our new company was SP Investments, registered in that well-known media heartland, Guernsey.

The stated plan was that Seymour Pierce would find buyers for the sites, or pay us our redundancy. The process dragged on, Christmas and the New Year came and went, but still no news.

Then, on January 5, a Seymour Pierce spokesman was quoted as saying that rumours we would go into liquidation were "bollocks".

Unfortunate timing, perhaps, as later that same day, Seymour Pierce applied to put the websites into liquidation.

So, here is another puzzle. Why did Seymour Pierce want to take on Express Digital Media? To sell the websites as going concerns, as they say? But why then did it not buy all our computers and servers, which Northern & Shell insist are still theirs?

S eymour Pierce has since said the whole EDM deal was a "gamble" which didn't come off. Thanks, guys, but in future we would rather you didn't gamble with other people's livelihoods.

In the circumstances, it is perhaps not surprising that we have been tempted to describe what has happened to us as immoral, if not illegal. We are now talking to lawyers to see if we can challenge the deal which led to the liquidation of our websites.

Our suspicion - denied by Northern & Shell and Seymour Pierce - is that it was a cynical ploy to avoid paying redundancies. Sharp practice, as the senior Labour MP Robin Corbett has already described it.

Battered we may be, but we certainly don't intend to walk away from this situation without a fight. We will be writing to the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and are busy contacting dozens of MPs. We also want to talk to financial regulators and key opinion formers in this area.

No one should be put in this position again. If this can happen to us, it could happen to others. A cautionary tale indeed.

 Michael Streeter is the former editor of the Daily Express website

webTitle: Comment: Labour should confer charitable status on amateur clubs

fields.headline: Moving the goalposts
fields.standfirst: Blair professes to be a keen friend of sport, so he should confer charitable status on amateur clubs
fields.trailText: Blair professes to be a keen friend of sport, so he should confer charitable status on amateur clubs
fields.body:
Last Thursday Tony Blair unveiled major new resources for school sports, and Gordon Brown announced that his next Budget will invest £100m a year in local and voluntary action.

Both could do no better than focus on the Cinderellas of Britain's embattled communities, our 150,000 amateur sports clubs. Remarkably, some think, they enjoy none of the tax exemptions available to charities, apart from limited, discretionary rate relief.

Take, for example, the village football club in Long Melford, Suffolk. It runs 10 junior sides, along with several senior ones, for youngsters of all abilities and backgrounds. They get no public funding and have no employees. Many plush professional clubs contribute far less to community football.

Such amateur sports clubs are at the heart of their local communities, run on a shoestring by squads of volunteers (around 1.25m) who tend the grounds, wash the shirts, make the teas, organise the juniors and do 101 other things. They link schools and the world beyond and cross age, class, race and occupational boundaries. In short, they reach the parts that the others do not reach. Government largely takes them for granted. Since team sports are often no longer available in state schools, local clubs provide an invaluable experience of self-discipline, self-motivation and teamwork. They are irreplaceable "socialisers" in a society desperately in need of just that.

Kate Hoey, the sports minister, well understands all this, but so far there is no sign that the Blair/Brown initiatives will help the clubs. Yet the report on community self-help that came out of No 10 Downing Street earlier this year concluded - rightly - that "without effective self-help it is unlikely that any other measures of community regeneration, however well resourced, will provide long term solutions to long term problems". As it also remarked, the crying need is for citizens to be "doing, not to be done to".

Against this background a campaign is now under way to try to persuade the government to give community amateur sports clubs the same tax exemptions as charities - such as are enjoyed, for example, by amateur dramatic, horticultural or history societies. The campaign has received unanimous support from the sports fraternity, including Sport England, the FA, the RFU and the MCC, as it did in the recent 10-minute bill debate in the Commons, introduced by Andy Reed MP.

The roadblock to charitable status for clubs is the 100-year-old House of Lords case of Re:Nottage where, unsurprisingly, the judges rejected an attempt by the ocean-going yacht club of late Victorian England to establish a charity for the award of silver cups to the tycoon winners of its races. The judges described it all as "mere sport", and that label has stuck.

Given the cost of taking cases to the House of Lords, it has never been challenged, though most charity lawyers think it might well be overruled if a suitable case was brought. Times have, after all, changed. Popular sport occupies a place in the de-communalised modern world undreamt-of in 1895.

One answer would be to extend charitable status to community amateur sports clubs by legislation. But the definition of charity has always been left fluid, to be evolved by judges, not fixed by parliament. Any such attempt would almost certainly get bogged down, besides encouraging endless future political meddling in that definition, which would be dangerously counter-productive.

Pinning down the definition of the "amateur" clubs will be critical. But an agreed working definition is now on the table so as to ensure that the exemption would go only to clubs with a genuinely open membership that permanently prohibited their members from personal financial benefit.

The beauty of the exemption idea is that for every pound the government would "lose" by way of tax exemption the citizen would have to put in £2 to £3. One could rely upon donors giving to local clubs only where there was real need, and to make sure that the money was well used. There would be no grant-giving bureaucracy, no big-brother "we know best" culture, and, above all, it would stimulate real self-help in a big way.

Not long ago the House of Lords held a debate on the state of sport in Britain during which two of England's most famous openers, Colin Cowdrey and David Sheppard, faced each other across the chamber. Both spoke passionately about the benign effect of sport, and the urgent need to nurture its grass roots as the only sure way of ensuring national sporting achievement.

What better memorial could there be to Colin Cowdrey, intimately involved in this campaign, than its success? Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are said to be keen friends of sport. If the tax exemption scheme is given a fair wind, the cheer that would go up would be heard from John O'Groats to Lands End.

Andrew Phillips is a solicitor, a member of the House of Lords and a member of the Scott Trust, which owns the Guardian.

webTitle: Hospital inquiry after bodies stored in chapel

fields.headline: Hospital inquiry after bodies stored in chapel
fields.trailText: The NHS is to investigate a hospital which stored corpses on the floor of a chapel of rest, covered only by sheets. By Paul Kelso
fields.body:
The NHS is to investigate a hospital which stored corpses on the floor of a chapel of rest, covered only by sheets.

Managers at Bedford hospital face disciplinary action and possible dismissal after confirming yesterday that bodies were kept in the unrefrigerated room for three days last week.

Nigel Crisp, chief executive of the NHS, said there was "no excuse" for the procedure. "This is utterly unacceptable and contravenes all guidance issued to trusts," he said.

"Due to the totally unacceptable nature of this incident I have ordered an urgent investigation into the circumstances which will start immediately."

A hospital spokeswoman said the room had been used because the hospital's main mortuary was full and a new temporary mortuary was closed for "health and safety reasons".

The temporary mortuary, purchased last year in anticipation of more use during the winter, was closed on Tuesday after a porter injured his hands trying to open the door.

A hospital spokeswoman said: "The decision to close the mortuary was taken on health and safety grounds because of a risk to staff who could injure their backs or hands struggling with the heavy door."

The door handles have subsequently been moved and the temporary mortuary is now back in use. The hospital stores corpses delivered by the police as well as those of patients who have died.

As a result of the closure an unconfirmed number of corpses were kept on the floor in the chapel. The hospital said up to eight bodies at a time were kept in the room, but that no body would have remained there for more than 24 hours. The hospital's emergency procedures allow for bodies to be put in the chapel at times of great pressure.

"This situation is obviously totally unacceptable. We would also apologise to the relatives of anyone who may have been stored in this way," said the spokeswoman.

Nick Court, communications director of the NHS executive eastern region, condemned the practice: "We have talked to the hospital and instructed a director to go there on Monday morning and begin a thorough investigation. We would hope to get to the bottom of what happened here by the end of the week.

"It is crucial to find out whether this room was used routinely and, if it was, to make sure that is no longer the case. Clearly we would want to see that all relatives are informed of what happened and that they receive all the help and counselling they may need."

webTitle: Railtrack faces £600m losses

fields.headline: Railtrack faces £600m losses
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The Hatfield train crash and the subsequent "national recovery programme" are expected to cost a total of some £580m, Railtrack said today.
fields.body:
The Hatfield train crash and the subsequent "national recovery programme" are expected to cost a total of some £580m, Railtrack said today.

Most of the cost - about £400m - was expected to relate to payments contractually due to the train operating companies and freight operators, the company said.

The remaining £180m was due to the cost of re-railing around 450 miles of track and renewing points to restore normal operations.

Railtrack said it had also incurred a £20m charge to cover the cost of recent flooding.

The total £600m cost would be "entirely borne by Railtrack's shareholders", the group said, adding that it would report a "significant loss for the year".

Railtrack's chief executive, Steve Marshall, said that the cost of the Hatfield crash comprised about £200m for repairs and £400m in compensation to train operators for disruption to their services. This cost would be "entirely" met by Railtrack shareholders, he said. "It is obviously painful for shareholders to take a £600m hit, but it is right and appropriate," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

He said the financial situation would be worsened by the fines payable for missing performance targets.

The scale of Railtrack's financial difficulties would be "pretty breathtaking", he said, adding that he estimated that the company's debt would be around £3bn by the end of this year and as much as £8bn by 2003.

Railtrack would be approaching the strategic rail authority to ask for investment funds scheduled to be spent after 2006 to be brought forward to help pay for infrastructure improvements. If this was not permitted, the company would seek an interim review by the rail regulator, he said.

The expected £580m cost is more than double the £250m figure estimated by Railtrack in November. Mr Marshall said the increase was because the scale of "engineering work had gone up hugely".

Railtrack also today said it had accepted the conclusions of the regulatory review, announced in October by the regulator, Tom Winsor. But it said that the immediate consequences of Hatfield, along with other factors, would leave it in a "materially worse financial position ... to that which the regulator assumed in reaching his final conclusions".

 Railtrack said it was on target to have 85% of the network back to pre-Hatfield levels by the end of January. The company hopes the entire network will be back to normal by Easter.

webTitle: Journalists launch ethnic minority recruitment drive

fields.headline: Journalists' scheme targets ethnic minorities
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Black and Asian print journalists have launched an initiative aimed at boosting recruitment from ethnic minorities. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A coalition of black and Asian print journalists has launched a media internship programme, aimed at boosting recruitment from the ethnic minorities.

The Creative Collective, a partnership of black and Asian journalists that includes former Pride editor Joy Francis and BBC London Live broadcaster Henry Bonsu, has secured £10,000 from the Freedom Forum in Washington for three media internships.

The three-month paid internships will be offered on national and local newspapers and magazines.

The Big Issue and the Nottingham Evening Post have already signed up and the London College of Printing will distribute grants for the programme.

Recruitment starts this week and the scheme will launch in July.

The initiative is being launched in the week following BBC director general Greg Dyke's outburst in a BBC Radio Scotland interview in which he described the corporation as "hideously white".

Joy Francis, founding director of the Creative Collective, said that Mr Dyke's timing had been very good for the Coalition.

She said, however, that there was a far greater urgency in attracting recruits from the ethnic minorities to the press than broadcasting, which tended to be more progressive.

The organisation has already secured the support of some high-profile journalists and media owners, including Channel 4 News's Jon Snow and Big Issue founder John Bird.

webTitle: Saverfone exploits message mania

fields.headline: Saverfone exploits message mania
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Saverfone is set to take text message ads out of the shopping centre, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Depending on which side of the technology fence you reside, the idea of being alerted to special retail offers and promotions by text message will either fill you with joy or dread.

When the world's first localised text messaging ad trials were launched at the Lakeside Shopping Centre last November "to controlled chaos", they caused mini-stampedes at the various outlets that used the service.

Called ZagMe, the promotions service run by a company called SpotFlash began signing users up at the rate of 500 people per day, with plans to extend the service to Bluewater Shopping Centre this month.

Now a rival service will go much further, when it launches nationwide tomorrow, extending coverage beyond the shopping centre and on to the high street.

Saverfone will be "targeting those 30m people with mobile phones whilst they're out shopping rather than at home reading the newspaper", according to chief executive Steve Wunker.

BT CellNet will offer the service to its customers, which will operate on both Wap phones and normal mobile phones. Customers will get details of promotions from retailers that include Dixons, Austin Reed, TK Maxx and C&A.

Desk-bound subscribers can also be alerted by email.

To entice more shops on board, BT is offering the service is free to retailers until March 31.

For the techno-doomwatchers, the prospect of further information overload will loom large, and low-speed collisions with phone wielding shoppers whose fixed stares are on screens rather than the path ahead, will no doubt have currency.

If phone rage does not yet exist, then it soon will.

And news last week that Nokia and Motorola experienced a slowdown in sales of mobile handsets last year will be scant consolation.

But for others quite happy with the prospect of easy access to bargains on goods and services - for which they have expressed a registered interest - it will merely enhance the experience of what they do best - shop.

webTitle: ITC raps Carlton over Celebrity! swearing

fields.headline: ITC raps Carlton over Celebrity! swearing
fields.trailText: 8.30am: TV watchdogs have reprimanded Carlton after a rude caption appeared on its Celebrity! showbiz programme, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The production team on Carlton's showbiz round-up programme, Celebrity!, claimed that they used the vulgar term made famous by Ali G "without knowing what it meant".

The Independent Television Commission slapped Carlton's wrist after the word appeared on a caption during an episode of the show presented by Andi Peters.

In its programme complaints bulletin, the TV watchdog takes a stern view of the use of the word "punani", which it describes as "Afro-Caribbean patois for the female genitalia".

But the Carlton team provided ample evidence for their claims that they didn't know what it meant because they misspelt the name in the caption.

The conclusion, published in the ITC's programme complaints bulletin, said: "Carlton has drawn the full meaning of the word to the attention of the production team and has assured the ITC that the word will not feature in future editions of the show."

The ITC upheld the complaint, saying Carlton must "recognise its role as a multi-cultural broadcaster".

webTitle: ITV to switch targets in numbers game

fields.headline: ITV to switch targets in numbers game
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV will today attempt to persuade advertisers that a series of scheduling changes have enabled it to "turn the corner" in its battle against rival broadcasters - despite the publication of figures showing that a smaller proportion of viewers than ever before are watching its ads.
fields.body:
ITV will today attempt to persuade advertisers that a series of scheduling changes have enabled it to "turn the corner" in its battle against rival broadcasters - despite the publication of figures showing that a smaller proportion of viewers than ever before are watching its ads.

Strong viewing figures from programmes like Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, the last ever Inspector Morse and a decision to air Emmerdale five times a week contributed to a "storming" end to 2000 after a difficult first three quarters, ITV executives will say at the publication of its annual report in London. The new year has also started strongly.

However, the executives will also be forced to explain figures for 2000 as a whole showing that ITV ads are being watched by fewer viewers as more people switch to rival commercial broadcasters like Channels 4 and 5, and the satellite and cable companies.

Last year ITV missed its own target of 38.5% of peak-time viewers and registered only 37.1%. That is despite ITV performing more strongly than the BBC over the Christmas season.

Now figures from the Broadcasters' Audience Research Board (Barb) show that ITV's share of "commercial impacts" - the number of people watching the advertising breaks in between television programmes - is also in decline, falling from 67.5% in 1995 to 50.5% in 2000.

The biggest winners during that time have been the multi-channel cable and satellite broadcasters such as NTL and BSkyB which have more than doubled their share of commercial impacts to 19.2%.

ITV says it is still the only commercial broadcaster capable of delivering a mass audience but executives are likely to be concerned by figures showing how poorly it registered with two of the most desirable groups for advertising.

Among ABC1s, ITV's share fell from 53.7% to 49.8% during 2000, while among viewers aged 16-34 its share fell from 49.8% to 44.1%.

According to industry sources, cable and satellite's combined share of the corresponding categories climbed sharply. The new figures are likely to increase pressure on ITV firms to allow Sky Digital to carry conventional channel 3 programming and its digital counterpart, ITV2. Sky Digital now has around 4.5m subscribers and ITV's share of audience has fallen sharply in those homes because viewers are not able to access ITV through their digital controls.

ITV has so far refused to let BSkyB carry the channels but the two sides have held talks about ways of ending the impasse. Two of the largest ITV companies, Carlton Communications and Granada Media, jointly own ONdigital, the main digital rival to BSkyB.
