webTitle: Blue Peter for grown-ups

fields.headline: Here's one we broadcast earlier
fields.standfirst:
Blue Peter for grown-ups

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Two of the Blue Peter's most celebrated presenters want to produce a grown-up version, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The sticky-backed plastic might look dated, but for adults who pine for the protected world of Blue Peter, satisfaction may be at hand. Two of the show's most celebrated presenters want to produce a grown-up version.

Peter Purves intends to send the idea to the BBC1 controller, Lorraine Heggessey. He and John Noakes want to sign up Valerie Singleton, reuniting one of the most memorable partnerships in children's television, to present a magazine show for adults who remember them from the first time round.

"It would be an adult version of Blue Peter, perhaps revisiting places where we went before to see how things have changed," Mr Purves said yesterday.

He was keen to stress that the idea was still at its early stages but was confident that the plan would appeal. He said that Ms Heggessey, a former head of children's television at the BBC, had expressed enthusiasm for a similar idea two years ago, before she became controller of BBC1. Mr Purves intends to lobby her again.

Mr Noakes, 66, said the pair hoped to recreate the combination of entertainment and education that is still popular with children today.

"In a way there will be no change at all," he told the Sunday Times. "When we did it first time round, we helped give a lot of bored children ideas on what to do. Now, more than 20 years after I left the show, I see a lot of middle-aged people retiring early who never did anything but work and really don't know how to fill the time."

Ms Singleton said yesterday that she was not aware of the idea. Speaking from her home in London, she was cautious: "I don't know anything about it. I tend not to like things that are aimed at a certain age group - a good programme is a good programme. But having said that, I never say no to anything before I know about the detail of it."

She said, however, that the trio had enjoyed working together on last month's BBC2 show I Love a Seventies Christmas.

A spokesman for the BBC said: "We are always open to programme ideas, but we have yet to see anything on this officially."

webTitle: Opec presses ahead with oil cuts

fields.headline: Opec presses ahead with oil cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Opec, the oil exporters' cartel, is expected to press ahead with hefty cuts in crude oil production at its summit in Vienna this week, despite a last minute tour of the Gulf states by US energy secretary Bill Richardson.
fields.body:
Opec, the oil exporters' cartel, is expected to press ahead with hefty cuts in crude oil production at its summit in Vienna this week, despite a last minute tour of the Gulf states by US energy secretary Bill Richardson.

Kuwait's oil minister, Sheikh Saud Nasser al-Sabah, who is regarded as price "hawk" within the 11-member cartel, was quoted over the weekend as saying that an output cut of at least 1.5m barrels per day was now "agreed".

Mr Richardson held meetings in Qatar and the United Arab Emirates yesterday after a visit on Saturday to Saudi Arabia, where he said that although the Americans anticipated some cuts "we believe that it is important that they are not steep cuts".

Washington would be happy with an oil price of around $25 (£16.90) per barrel, but traders have already pushed market prices back above $30 per barrel for the first time since early December in anticipation of action by Opec. Late on Friday, the February futures price for crude jumped 64 cents to $30.05 in New York, a rise of 12% so far this year. In London, the spot price for Brent crude ended the week at $25.78 per barrel.

"Our strong message is that there should not be steep production cuts at the next Opec meeting because that will spur a price hike that is unhealthy for the world economy," Mr Richardson said. His plea coincided with comments from the former Saudi oil minister Sheikh Yamani, who warned this weekend that aggressive action by Opec was likely to push the US deep into recession.

The sheikh has claimed that Saudi Arabia alone has already taken steps to cut its production by 500,000 bpd and that these measures, coinciding with a suspension of Iraqi exports, will lead to a sharp spike in the price in the second half of January.

Some Opec ministers, who meet on Wednesday, have argued that production cuts of between 2m and 3m bpd are necessary to avoid a sharp decline in oil prices.

webTitle: Europe loses faith in the euro

fields.headline: Europe loses faith in the euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Voters across Europe have fallen out of love with the euro during the past 18 months and most are now unhappy that it replaced their national currency, according to an exclusive poll published today.
fields.body:
Voters across Europe have fallen out of love with the euro during the past 18 months and most are now unhappy that it replaced their national currency, according to an exclusive poll published today.

The survey, which is being published simultaneously by the Guardian in Britain, Le Monde in France, El Pais in Spain and in five other European countries, shows that the single currency's fall in value against the dollar since its launch two years ago has triggered a withdrawal of support by voters across Europe.

The eight-country poll also reveals that there is a remarkable "feelgood factor" among British voters which is among the strongest in Europe. Some 80% of British voters say they feel confident that their personal and working lives are improving - an 11% rise over the already high levels recorded when this poll was previously conducted in May 1999.

The "feelgood factor" among British voters is even stronger than that traditionally found among Germans (where 71% say they are confident about their future), and French voters (68%). Only the Netherlands and Luxembourg have more contented citizens among the countries surveyed. This resurgent economic and personal optimism in Britain contrasts sharply with the traditional image of Britain's workforce as among the most poorly paid, inefficient and militant in Europe.

The strength of the feelgood factor may be regarded as a leading indicator when it comes to voting intentions in a general election, and bodes well for Tony Blair's hopes for a second term later this year. There is usually little desire among such a contented electorate to kick the government.

Europe's least contented citizens remain the Spanish, Greeks and Italians, which is reflected in lack of faith in their national governments' ability to improve their personal prospects. British voters have a higher than average (51%) belief that the government can improve their lives, and are more confident that it will deliver than the French (48%) or the Germans (43%).

The poll, which was coordinated by Louis Harris of France, confirms that British voters are overwhelmingly happy not to have joined the euro when it was launched two years ago: 62% of British voters say they support the decision to stay out.

Surprisingly, many voters across Europe now share that opinion, the poll shows. In Germany, support for the euro has fallen by 18 points and only 29% are satisfied that it has replaced the mark. In France, support has fallen by 14 points to 50%. In Greece, Italy and Spain, 46% or fewer are happy to have replaced their national currencies with the euro. Of the eight countries polled, only in Luxembourg - where the national currency was extremely weak - is there strong support for the euro (72%).

On balance, public opinion across the seven euro-zone countries involved in the poll has turned against the new currency, with 41% saying they are happy to have adopted the euro and 52% saying they are not. Eighteen months ago, 53% said they were happy to have joined the euro and only 36% were dissatisfied.

The poll shows that this fall in support has been partly fuelled by anxieties about the falling level of the euro against the dollar. Across the euro-zone the poll records high levels of concern about this, with 79% of voters in Germany worried about it, 82% in the Netherlands, 74% in Spain and 71% in France.

However, many commentators believe that the euro may have hit its low point. It has already begun to strengthen in value.

Sterling hit a 14-month low against the currency on Friday when it reached €1.55, its lowest level since November 1999 and 11% off its peak.

The poll, the British section of which was conducted by ICM research, involved interviews with 6,637 adults aged over 18 in eight EU countries between December 5 and 23.

webTitle: Britain must join euro, says car industry

fields.headline: Britain must join euro, says car industry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Management and unions in Britain's embattled car industry joined forces yesterday to urge changes in key European policies that might keep plants open and save exports and investment.
fields.body:
Management and unions in Britain's embattled car industry joined forces yesterday to urge changes in key European policies that might keep plants open and save exports and investment which are threatened by the high level of the pound against the euro.

As union leaders headed for Zurich to plead with General Motors to reprieve its factory at Luton, the head of Ford of Europe made a rare foray into party politics.

Nick Scheele challenged William Hague to rethink the Tory policy of ruling out British membership of the euro in the next parliament, warning that Ford's strategic planning - on which 50,000 UK jobs rest - was based on euro-entry by the middle of the decade.

Unless sterling has joined the euro by 2006 further serious damage will be done to manufacturing, both sides of industry agree. Ford, GM and Nissan, whose highly productive Sunderland plant employs 5,000 people, are all cutting back.

Last night Downing Street confirmed that Mr Blair, a local MP, had had direct talks with Nissan about its threat to move production of the new model Micra to France because of the pound's strength.

Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the engineers' union, the AEEU, and one of today's TUC delegation to Zurich, yesterday accused Mr Hague of being ignorant of industry's needs.

AEEU officials will fly to Brussels today to persuade the European commission to sanction £40m of government aid that would keep Nissan's investment for the Micra in the region.

Mr Scheele spoke out for the industry when he protested that more than 60% of Ford's UK output went to the EU - at a 30% disadvantage since the euro's collapse against the pound. Early entry into the euro zone was the answer, he suggested.

"Our strategic planning has always been on the basis that Britain would ultimately enter the euro," he said. Mr Scheele urged political leaders not to neglect the economic case for the euro, that "it makes sense for us to be in one currency". Specifically he told Mr Hague to rethink his commitment to keep the pound throughout the next parliament if he won the election.

webTitle: Public death for Palestinian 'collaborators'

fields.headline: Public death for 'collaborators'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
A Palestinian youth of 18 described by his father as
"simple-minded" may be publicly executed by firing
squad in Bethlehem within the next few days after a
short military trial convicted him of collaborating with
Israel.
fields.body:
A Palestinian youth of 18 described by his father as "simple-minded" may be publicly executed by firing squad in Bethlehem within the next few days after a short military trial convicted him of collaborating with Israel.

At his two-hour televised trial on Saturday, Hussameddin Moussa Hmeid Eslini, 18, was said to have been paid $200 (about £130) to photograph and record the movements of a local commander of Yasser Arafat's Fatah militias, Hussein Abayat, who was assassinated by Israel on November 9.

There is no appeal, though Mr Arafat can commute the sentence, and in the family home near Bethlehem the condemned man's mother went into premature mourning yesterday.

His father, Moussa, also wept, shaking his head in disbelief that his barely literate son could be capable of treason.

"He is too simple-minded. I can't believe any of this about him. If they can do this to Hussam, what about my youngest son?" he said, clutching the 10-year-old to his side.

Eslini was one of two men condemned on Saturday - two others were given life terms - and he could go before a firing squad within days, the Fatah leader in Bethlehem district, Kamal Hmeid, said.

He has asked Mr Arafat to approve a public execution, possibly near Manger Square.

Two convicted earlier were executed on Saturday, Allam Beni Odeh in front of 5,000 people Nablus on the West Bank and Majdi Mikkawi in a police station in Gaza.

Up to 40 other suspected collaborators are believed to be held in the Bethlehem area alone.

"It is useful for the Palestinian people to see what happens to big criminals who are responsible for the killing of a big leader," Mr Hmeid said.

Eslini, an unemployed building worker with a bad stammer who can barely write his own name, was given a swift trial.

His lawyer had 30 minutes to prepare a defence and uttered one sentence, asking for a delay. There was a single witness, the prison doctor, who testified that Eslini was treated well in captivity.

Eslini stammered a few words about his innocence.

Abayat was the first to die in what the Israeli government has since admitted was a policy of systematically liquidating Palestinian leaders. Its hit squads rely on thousands of informers.

"A whole network of eyes is following everyone," Mr Hmeid said. Two of the men sentenced on Saturday were said to have plotted his assassination.

Critics say the executions are meant to distract attention from Mr Arafat's efforts to step back from the 16 weeks of unrest, which many in Fatah see as a betrayal. They are also angry about the talks with Israeli officials to plan negotiations after Bill Clinton leaves the White House next week.

"No doubt Mr Arafat is cooking a deal on security arrangements with the Israelis and he does not want people to make demonstrations," said Bassem Eid, a Palestinian human rights campaigner.

"So ... he has found some big issue which is the talk of the street: the Israeli assassinations and now the executions."

Palestinian militias summarily executed hundreds of collaborators during the first intifada, and Mr Eid believes at least five men have been killed without trial since November.

webTitle: Bar on former Catholic priests entering Commons to be repealed

fields.headline: Bar on former Catholic priests entering Commons to be repealed
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Ministers are to rush legislation through parliament to repeal a series of anti-Catholic laws preventing former priests from sitting in the House of Commons.
fields.body:
Ministers are to rush legislation through parliament to repeal a series of anti-Catholic laws preventing former priests from sitting in the House of Commons.

The host of ecclesiastical acts dating back more than 400 years to the Reformation will be overturned after a Labour candidate in a safe seat discovered that, if elected, technically he would be barred from entering Westminster.

David Cairns, selected by the local party to defend a 13,040 majority in the Greenock and Inverclyde constituency, has lobbied for the law to be changed after learning that he would be unable to represent the constituency, because until 1994 he had been a priest. Any former clergymen ordained by a bishop are prevented from representing parliamentary constituencies, except those ordained by the Church of England after an exception was made in 1870.

The anti-Catholic laws were adopted in an era when discrimination was widespread.

Mike O'Brien, a Home Office minister, is expected to present the move as a non-controversial "tidying up" move when the intention to repeal is announced, possibly today.

The government is hoping for cross-party support for a measure that also applies to a number of other Christian faiths such as the Greek and Russian Orthodox churches.

Bruce Kent, the former chairman of CND and an ex-priest, would have been banned from the Commons if he had won when he stood in Oxford for Labour.

Mr Cairns, 34, was a Westminster assistant to Siobhain McDonagh, Labour MP for Mitcham and Morden and sister of Margaret McDonagh, Labour party general secretary. Ms McDonagh tried unsuccessfully to get a 10 minute rule bill passed to end the discrimination.

Mr Cairns, 34, said last night: "I'm very pleased the government has decided to sort this out. I have always believed it is not the business of the state to decide the members of which religious denominations can and cannot be in the House of Commons."

webTitle: Lynda Page wrote her first novel in her lunch hours

fields.headline: Fully booked
fields.standfirst: Lynda Page wrote her first novel in her lunch hours, while a secretary. She tells  Mabel Msonthi  how and why she still juggles two jobs despite literary success
fields.trailText: Lynda Page wrote her first novel in her lunch hours, while a secretary. She tells Mabel Msonthi how and why she still juggles two jobs despite literary success.
fields.body:
Can you imagine hitting the jackpot as a successful author with your first book? Rolling into work the following Monday would be almost unthinkable for the average person, a decision as perverse as winning the lottery and insisting on business as usual. You could say, then, that Lynda Page is in a minority. She is probably the only secretary in the country who doubles as a bestselling author.

So how did she make the leap from her start in administration to the world of books? "I was working for Land Rover Parts in Desford, Leicestershire, when I wrote my first book. It had never entered my head to write until a friend suggested I attend an O-level English evening class one night a week, after I mentioned that I'd regretted not passing any qualifications at school," says Page.

"I have no formal training as a writer, but returning to education while working full time, and with two children, kick-started my natural passion for writing, and every Tuesday I'd be thinking about my class. The next day I used to take my hand- written homework into the office and type it up in my lunch hour."

Now 51, Page acknowledges the flexibility of her boss at the time and alludes to the entirely different working environment of today's offices, where managers possess the right to read all their employee's emails. At the time, she had no such constraints, operating on the antiquated equipment of the 70s and 80s.

"I used one of the first word processors, and I was an expert in the telex, the forerunner to the fax. My boss knew I couldn't afford a word processor so he let me use the office Compaq in my lunch hour and after work. It was one of the first portable laptops and was a huge machine containing a 5in floppy disk and no hard drive," says Lynda. Its size made the journey home a memorable one, she adds.

By 1988, Lynda was embarking on her first book which was treated as something of a joke by colleagues. "Over 18 months, I spent my lunch hours writing what was to be my first novel. I actually ignored the book for six months until a persistent colleague - an avid blockbuster-novel reader - kept asking when it would be finished. Once she'd read it, she unwittingly spurred me on by pushing me about my future plans for it. I hadn't even thought of a next step, as writing had simply been a hobby. An old friend suggested contacting a literary agent and the book was accepted immediately, which is quite unusual."

Page maintains that she went into work as usual on the day of the book launch but admits to a niggling doubt that this wasn't the norm for other writers. After the launch, she downgraded from her office management role to a temping position so she could devote more time to her writing.

"My agent was very keen for a second book so I had to choose a job that would allow me to write in the evenings, one where I wasn't mentally taking work home with me."

She admits that there was a sacrifice involved in that decision. "I took a huge cut in wages when I started temping and inevitably got into debt. The tax bills are phenomenal and with writing you have to produce the goods on time; it's a business enterprise in itself.

"I do perceive myself as a writer, even in the office," she says of her job as a PA/administrator to the communications company NTL. But she admits she is lost without the social surrounds of a working office: "A major reason for returning is the people contact which I absolutely love." She's the sort of person, she says, who would be dragging the postman off the street for a chat were she stuck at home. Financially, too, she cannot afford to give up work.

So how much did the skills gained from her office life contribute to her literary success? "The project management and brainstorming sessions have been really useful for my writing, since exploring different avenues is crucial to good plot development in stories," she says. "I have also learned a great deal about human nature while working and this attention to detail has been invaluable when drawing my characters."

Perhaps no one will read her forthcoming novels more closely than her colleagues. The influence for that familiar-sounding character might have come from just across the office.

 In for a Penny, by Lynda Page, is published by Headline at £5.99.

webTitle: Small classes 'aid college entrance'

fields.headline: Small classes 'aid college entrance'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Children aged between five and eight who are taught in small classes are more likely to go on to apply for a university place, a study of US schools has revealed.
fields.body:
Children aged between five and eight who are taught in small classes are more likely to go on to apply for a university place, a study of US schools has revealed.

Children on free school meals and from minority groups particularly benefit from smaller teaching groups, the researchers report in this month's Economic Journal.

Alan Krueger and Diane Whitmore, of Princeton university, conclude that children in US elementary schools in class sizes of 13 to 17 pupils score higher on standardised school tests and are more likely to sit a college entrance exam than those in larger classes. When pupils have been in small elementary classes, the gap between black and white students in their chances of sitting the entrance exam is halved.

The study looked at 19 Tennessee schools where 11,600 children and their teachers were randomly assigned to classes of 13-17 pupils, regular classes of 22-25 and regular classes with teacher aides. After four years the eight-year-olds returned to regular classes. In 1998 the first children from the project finished school.

The researchers found that 43.7% of pupils from the smaller classes took university entrance exams, compared with 40% of those from the regular classes, and 39.9% of those from regular classes with teacher aides. They say the percentage difference is statistically significant: it is unlikely to have occurred by chance.

But it is the academic prospects of black pupils that are most improved in smaller groups. Only 31.7% of black pupils from regular classes went on to take university entrance exams, compared with 40.2% from small classes.

"Attending a small class reduced the black-white gap in the college entrance test-taking rate by 54%," said the researchers.

As class sizes were reduced from 26-30 pupils, to 21-25 and then to 16-20, the likelihood of students sitting an entrance exam increased.

The researchers do not yet know how many students who took the entrance exams enrolled in courses, or how long they spent in higher education. But US students who take entrance exams such as scholastic aptitude tests (SATs), spend on average 1.63 more years in education than those who do not take the exams.

Ian Black: Inside Europe
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson may be poised to become Sweden's most famous celebrity export since Abba and Bjorn Bjorg. But another Swede, Goran Persson, could turn out to be more important than the new England soccer coach over the coming months.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson may be poised to become Sweden's most famous celebrity export since Abba and Bjorn Bjorg. But another Swede, Goran Persson, could turn out to be more important than the new England soccer coach over the coming months.

Persson is prime minister of Sweden, which has just taken over the EU presidency after France's unhappy stint. He is thus a key ally for Tony Blair as he tries to keep the European issue cool between now and election day.

London and Stockholm have been on good terms since Oliver Cromwell and Queen Kristina signed a pact of friendship in 1654, and today's British courtiers speak in glowing terms of a natural rapport on EU affairs - in contrast to fragility of relations with the French presidency.

Yet Europe, integrationists argue, is supposed to be different from the old-fashioned game of nations, in which alliances are forged and one side's advantage is another's loss.

Sometimes, of course, it is win-win, not zero-sum, otherwise the whole thing would never have worked. But national interests and priorities still loom large - and nowhere more obviously than in the EU's northern tier, in which Blair and the bulky social democrat from Malmo are now leading lights.

Persson dined in Downing Street last October. It was just before Blair's speech in Warsaw, his most important European pronouncement since 1997, and one which declared Britain an unashamed champion of enlargement - the EU's toughest challenge since the launch of the euro two years ago.

Persson feels the same way. He talks passionately of how the frightening Baltic skyline of his cold-war childhood has given way to multi-party, free-market Poland, Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia queueing up to join the EU.

And, you hear in those parts, having only recently regained their sovereignty and independence from Moscow, they are not minded to hand over much power to Brussels, Frankfurt, or supranational points south.

In a decade or so, there could be 27 members in the EU instead of the current 15. The union is about to change far more radically than the narrow, suspicious terms of the British debate suggest. It will in future speak English more naturally than French. Germany will be its fulcrum. Governments will be more powerful than the European commission. Northerners will rule. With one significant exception - for now. Being out of euroland is another tie that binds Blair and Persson. Both watched closely last September when the Danes' "nej " to the single currency complicated their respective calculations about the sequence of elections and referendums.

Persson's minority government backs the euro. But not unquestioningly. Leif Pagrotsky, Persson's diminutive but dazzling trade minister, makes no secret of his doubts - and would certainly sign up to Gordon Brown five economic tests.

And the tone - not encoded - is cool, natural enough in a country where only 47% support EU membership and just 33% are prepared to scrap the krone. Pagrotsky talks of Sweden's "opponents" rather than "partners" in its negotiations on joining, and uses the word "cooperation" not "integration".

With such familiar resonances, it should be no surprise that Persson will help protect Blair during his first turn at the helm. Downing Street would like to play for time on a binding directive on workers' consultation - with the TUC for, the CBI firmly against.

The Stockholm summit in March will be a welcome showcase for the ambitious economic reform agenda launched in Lisbon last year, but overshadowed in the British media enchanted by the "three jags, two jets" row over ministerial travel arrangements. Both countries are also working hard to minimise the EU's post-Nice constitutional agenda - grist to the mill of the Tories' "relentlessly creeping superstate" - before the Belgians' presidency starts in July.

Persson has his own problems: it is touch and go whether his spell in the hot seat will encourage or diminish domestic scepticism. Attac, the anti-globalisation movement, has just opened a Swedish branch. Stockholm worries out loud about speeding limos, summit traffic jams and ministers for ever away in Brussels. Like Sven-Goran Eriksson with the England squad, Persson's presidency is unlikely to work any miracles.

But it should bring some quiet common sense at a time when the British debate badly needs it. "We know that we mustn't be too Swedish during our time running things," said one minister. "But maybe we can say sköl [cheers]!" Surely all Europeans can drink to that?

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText:
Observer

Sheikh Yamani, the former Saudi oil minister, has warned that a rise in crude prices in the wake of this week's Opec summit in Vienna could push the US economy into outright recession. He believes there is a 50:50 chance that the oil cartel will cut production.
fields.body:
Observer

Sheikh Yamani, the former Saudi oil minister, has warned that a rise in crude prices in the wake of this week's Opec summit in Vienna could push the US economy into outright recession. He believes there is a 50:50 chance that the oil cartel will cut production.

The institutional investment review being carried out by Gartmore chief Paul Myners (who is also chairman of the Guardian Media Group), is being extended to assess the independence of investment research carried out by City analysts.

The private finance group at Japanese broking house Nomura has become the front-runner to buy Whitbread's 3,000 pubs, which were put up for sale in December.

Sunday Business

Stockbroker Cazenove has received informal bid approaches from Wall Street investment banks Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase and Citigroup after unveiling plans to ditch its partnership structure and float on the stock market.

William Hill , Britain's second-largest chain of bookmakers, has been put up for sale again by its private-equity owners, CVC Capital Partners and Cinven. Talks with leisure group Rank are said to have failed just before Christmas, with the sellers looking for about £1.3bn for the business.

BMW has warned 1,500 staff at the new Mini plant in Cowley, Oxford, that investment plans are threatened by their failure to reach agreement on a pay and productivity package.

Mail on Sunday

British Airways and American Airlines held talks last week aimed at resurrecting plans for closer ties.

Two of the London Stock Exchange's best know non-executive directors, Michael Marks of Merrill Lynch and Simon Robertson of Goldman Sachs, are expected to resign this week after the institution finally names its new chief executive.

Sunday Times

Both General Motors and Ford are eyeing DaimlerChrysler as speculation grows that the world's third-largest car group is to be broken up. Its largest shareholders, Deutsche Bank and the Kuwait Investment Office, are said to be losing patience with its chairman, Jürgen Schrempp.

BAE Systems has decided to close its Brough plant on Humberside after production of the Hawk jet comes to an end in five years' time. At least 3,000 jobs are at risk.

Bernie Ecclestone , boss of Formula One, has held talks with the Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri about holding a grand prix in Beirut .

The British Chambers of Commerce will this week publish a poll showing that Britain's businesses are suffering from a fall in confidence and are likely to cut back on investment plans.

Sunday Telegraph

British Telecom is expected to slash its dividend payment to shareholders as part of its plan to deal with its bloated debts.

Bass and Millennium Copthorne are ready to make a joint £3.5bn bid for the hotel interests, including Le Meridien chain, being sold by Granada Compass.

Aggregate Industries is considering making a bid for its cement rival RMC , despite the fact that the target company is twice its size.

Coral , Britain's third-biggest bookmaker, lost £12m on last year's Euro 2000 football tournament through its internet gaming subsidiary, Eurobet.

IoS

The national audit office is looking into the value of Labour's New Deal job creation scheme for young people, amid claims that many of the 250,000 jobs said to have been created would have existed anyway.

The European competition commission has taken an interest in allegations surrounding the auction of third-generation mobile telephone licences in the Netherlands. The Dutch competition authorities are already looking into claims of collusion between Telfort , a subsidiary of British Telecom, and Versatel , a local rival.

Burger King is likely to be demerged from parent drinks company Diageo later this year after settlement of a potentially damaging racial discrimination case in the US.

Sunday Express

Gordon Brown has held crisis talks with Labour MPs over the threatened closure of the Llanwern steel plant in south Wales. Some 4,500 jobs in the industry are at risk.

Taylor Woodrow will launch a £540m hostile takeover bid for rival housebuilder Bryant this week after the rejection of two friendly offers last week.

webTitle: South's rich areas get richer

fields.headline: South's rich areas get richer
fields.standfirst:
Farming and manufacturing regions gain least under strong economy, says wealth survey

Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: People in Britain's richest areas have gained most from the strong economy since Labour came to power, with areas reliant on farming and manufacturing gaining least, according to a survey released today.
fields.body:
People in Britain's richest areas have gained most from the strong economy since Labour came to power, with areas reliant on farming and manufacturing gaining least, according to a survey released today.

Household income in Surrey rose by 12% over the past two years, well above inflation, while Cornwall's grew by 1.7%, well below inflation, now at 3.2%, meaning that its economy is, in effect, in recession.

The fabled north-south divide is too simplistic to describe differing income levels, with the poorest regions being the south-west, East Anglia and Wales as well as the north.

Overall incomes have risen, with the average household earning £23,200 a year, a growth of 8.6% since the last survey two years ago by the market analysts CACI, and a rise of 19.6% since 1996.

Comparing counties, household income in Surrey is 88% higher than the level in Cornwall, and 80% higher than Tyne and Wear.

In Surrey, the richest county, the average income was £33,400 followed by Berkshire with £31,700, with the rest of the top 10 comprising London and the home counties. Bottom of the county list was Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly where average household income is £17,700.

But even within counties there are huge disparities which the study can highlight by providing a breakdown of income by postcode. Merseyside, one of the poorest, contains the seventh richest neighbourhood in the UK, which is Heswall, Wirral, where the average household income is £46,600.

But nearby Liverpool contains four of the 10 poorest postcode sectors. The Vauxhall, central, Seaforth and Kirby areas of the city have an average income as low as £9,100.

The survey also highlights deprived areas enjoying a boom. One of Britain's poorest boroughs, Hackney, north-east London, experienced a 22.5% income growth in two years taking its average to £26,000. This is believed to be due to the "gentrification" of the area with professional and middle-class people moving in after finding property prices in neighbouring Islington too high. But even in Islington, affluence and poverty sit side by side. One postcode in the Highbury area enjoys an average household income twice as high as one less than 100 metres away.

The highest earning postcode is west London, with an average income of £34,200, up 13.4% since 1998. The lowest is Sunderland, with an average income of £17,000 per household, an increase over two years of 5.8%.

The highest earning postal code areas are in London and the south-east, and this is where the biggest rise in incomes over the past two years is concentrated.

The survey does not detail the causes behind why those areas that have the most wealth are doing best. But London and the south-east are where more people work in sectors such as IT, financial services, consulting, higher skilled service sector jobs, and non-public sector professions.

Highest earning area by postcode sector: South Kensington, London, average household income £47,700. Poorest: Vauxhall, Liverpool, £9,100.

Ave household income in the constituencies of Tony Blair (Sedgefield) £18,700; William Hague (Richmond) £22,200; Charles Kennedy (Ross, Skye and Inverness) £20,800.

webTitle: Police slated for murder case failings

fields.headline: Police slated for murder case failings
fields.standfirst:
Complaints authority accuses force of systemic failure over inquiry into killing of businessman and 'ill-founded' prosecution of his wife

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Complaints authority accuses force of systemic failure over inquiry into killing of businessman and 'ill-founded' prosecution of his wife.
fields.body:
The police complaints authority has found Sussex police guilty of "systemic" failure over its handling of the investigation into the murder of a businessman, Richard Watson.

The report will be one of the last from the PCA, which is due to be replaced by an independent police complaints body, and is one of the most critical it has made. One leading lawyer described it as "perhaps the most strongly worded PCA report I've ever seen".

Watson was murdered by an unknown gunman outside his home at East Grinstead, Sussex, in December 1996. His wife Linda and stepdaughter Amanda were charged with his murder, but acquitted. The PCA described the prosecution as "ill-founded".

Watson's wife, now known as Linda Henderson, said yesterday: "The energies I would have used to fight for my husband's killer to be brought to justice have had to be used to fight for my daughter and myself - two innocent victims who became victims all over again, this time at the hands of Sussex police."

Mrs Henderson, a former beauty queen, and her daughter suffered not only the grief and shock of bereavement, but also the trauma of being immediately identified as key suspects. They were questioned for days and, over a period of months, every detail of their private lives was minutely scrutinised. Their house was bugged by police, they suffered the humiliation of unnecessarily public arrests, were thrown into Holloway prison for two weeks, and were vilified in sections of the media.

When the case came up at the Old Bailey in June 1998 the prosecution offered no evidence against them. The judge said they left court without a stain on their character.

After their acquittal the women contacted the PCA through their solicitor, Jeff Hide. On behalf of the women he itemised 32 areas of complaint, starting from when the original 999 call was made.

The investigation was carried out on behalf of the PCA by a team from the Metropolitan police headed by Commander Peter Clarke and Det Ch Insp Ian Delbarre. The completed report has now been sent to Sussex police. Although they have so far refused to disclose it, Duncan Gear, the PCA member dealing with the case, has provided both women with a lengthy summary of its findings.

The PCA investigation has concluded: "Sussex police failed to properly investigate the murder of Richard Watson and this arose from a systemic failure by Sussex police."

The police case was that Watson had been shot from the balcony of the house, and that this implicated the women. The PCA, however, has found that: "Too much significance was placed upon the belief Richard Watson had been shot from the balcony - the evidence did not justify [this] scenario."

Watson had some murky business dealings, and there were a number of very obvious motives for his murder. The PCA concluded that "other lines of inquiry were not adequately pursued and officers failed to keep an open mind".

The catalogue of complaints against Sussex police began with the immediate response to the murder. At the time the two women were alone in the house. The police station was less than half a mile away. Yet for almost an hour after the 999 call the police refused to attend the crime scene, in case the gunman was still there.

Nor would they allow emergency medical services through, even though, for all they knew, Watson's life could have been saved.

In view of the wholesale failings which it identified, the PCA concluded that "it would not be appropriate to institute formal disciplinary proceedings against the junior officers. The main responsibility for the errors identified must rest with Det Supt Paul Westwood in his capacity as senior investigating officer".

Mr Westwood, who declined to assist the PCA inquiry, has now retired from the police and is no longer subject to police discipline regulations.

His deputy, and the man who took over the investigation after Westwood's retirement, was Det Insp Nicholas Siggs. The investigation found a complaint about his conduct to be "substantiated". It laid the blame for "many" of the errors with Mr Westwood and Mr Siggs. Mr Siggs has also retired from the police and so is similarly outside the scope of disciplinary proceedings.

Sussex police said: "We accept that there were serious shortcomings in aspects of the original investigation. We are constantly reviewing our procedures. This kind of review is valuable in highlighting any areas that have been missed.

"The investigation of murder is one of the most complex and difficult tasks that the police undertake. Ninety-five per cent of murders in Sussex are solved and the offenders brought to justice. We recognise that in this instance we have not brought whoever was responsible to account."

Neither Mr Westwood nor Mr Siggs could be reached for comment. Mr Gear's letter to the dead man's widow concludes by saying: "The central recommendation arising from the investigation into your complaints is that the murder of Richard Watson should be reinvestigated." That is now being done.

"We are amazed and saddened," said Mr Hide, "that a police force should have such serious faults in its murder investigation system. We are even more astounded that, having been shown its faults, the force will not even discuss redress, let alone offer a settlement, for the harm it has done."

The women will need to bring civil proceedings against the police merely to obtain a copy of the full report.

Related story

webTitle: Regulator puts pressure on Railtrack over £15bn package

fields.headline: Regulator puts pressure on Railtrack over £15bn package
fields.standfirst:
Deadline must be met today

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, has refused to bow to government pressure to give Railtrack more time to consider his £15bn package to improve the rail network, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, has refused to bow to government pressure to give Railtrack more time to consider his £15bn package to improve the rail network, it emerged last night.

Railtrack was forced to hold an emergency board meeting yesterday after Mr Winsor had told Lord Macdonald, transport minister, on Friday that he could not allow Railtrack a further extension to accept the five-year package. Railtrack will get the government money in return for improving infrastructure and increasing efficiency.

The weekend's developments highlight tensions in the rail industry. Lord Macdonald had wanted more time but Mr Winsor said he was under a statutory duty to get an answer from Railtrack by today. But the railway network operator is facing huge costs after the Hatfield rail disaster in October and is dragging its feet on Mr Winsor's package because it does not think it will be enough.

Emergency work after Hatfield is costing Railtrack millions of pounds for which it had not budgeted. It wants another £1bn tocover the unexpected costs. The costs have escalated from an initial £150m to £600m and rising, more than enough to wipe out Railtrack's profits for the year, which were expected to be around £400m. The money has been spent on re-railing 420 miles of track, mending points and giving compensation to the 25 train operating companies, who have been unable to run normal services because of speed restrictions.

Railtrack can appeal against the regulator's ruling on charges to the competition commission, a power given to Railtrack last year by Mr Winsor. But Steve Marshall, who replaced Gerald Corbett as chief executive at the end of last year, is against the idea.

If Railtrack went to the commission, it would delay the introduction of Railtrack's new charges due to begin in April by up to nine months. Given the chaotic state of the industry, this is a move which Mr Marshall has been anxious to avoid.

But Railtrack could get extra money approved by the regulator, justified because it is urgently needed for safety reasons and to bring the railway up to standard. Mr Winsor could agree that it is only money that the inadequately funded industry needed anyway, and that Hatfield exposed its desperate shortcomings. Ultimately most of it would have to come from the government.

Later this week, Railtrack must give the regulator specific details on its recovery plan. This is in response to pressure on Mr Winsor from the rail companies, who are dissatisfied with Railtrack's failure to deliver what it promised them after Hatfield.

If Mr Winsor does not like the plan, he will proceed with an enforcement notice against the company. This could mean a confrontation in court and the possibility of fines against Railtrack. The regulator would only do this as a last resort.

Last night Railtrack would not comment other than to say that it was likely to make a formal stock exchange announcement today.

webTitle: MPs press Hoon on uranium risk

fields.headline: MPs press Hoon on uranium risk
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Defence ministers will come under renewed pressure today to reveal what they know about the medical risks posed by depleted uranium in the face of fresh evidence of its potentially serious dangers to health.
fields.body:
Defence ministers will come under renewed pressure today to reveal what they know about the medical risks posed by depleted uranium in the face of fresh evidence of its potentially serious dangers to health.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, who will be questioned by MPs today, admitted yesterday there was a "limited risk" associated with DU ammunition but insisted there was no proof it had actually caused illnesses.

"We've always recognised that there was a limited risk to the use of depleted uranium weapons and we have always instructed members of the armed forces accordingly," he said. "But beyond that particular specified risk there are no risks associated with the use of depleted uranium, and certainly no proven link between its use and any illness", he told Sky television.

Lord Morris, parliamentary adviser to the British Legion, which wants a public inquiry into the handling of health problems faced by Gulf war veterans, will raise the issue in the Lords. He said: "The Gulf veterans feel provoked to say it is shameful that Britain can stand by and watch other countries taking the lead in this issue when we were among the first to use depleted uranium."

On the eve of the 10th anniversary of the conflict, Shaun Rusling, of the Gulf War Veterans and Families Association, also called for an inquiry and appealed for public support to help fund "proper testing and proper medical care".

More than 450 British service personnel have died since the war, more than 130 of them from cancer, including leukaemia. A high incidence of the illness among Italian Balkan veterans has led to demands for special screening among Britain's European allies.

The navy knew 10 years ago of the dangers when it warned firefighters tackling a fire in a DU store to use nuclear, biological and chemical warfare protective suits.

In a separate report it emerged yesterday that a report by the UK Atomic Energy Authority in 1991 warned of a "significant problem" of DU radioactivity.

Referring to use of the weapons in Kuwait, it said: "The problem will not go away and should be tackled before it becomes a political problem created by the environmental lobby."

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said: "It is necessary now for the government to make a clear statement about the position of depleted uranium, given all the evidence that has been coming out in dribs and drabs."

webTitle: Hatred outlives ceasefire in Ireland

fields.headline: Where hatred has outlived the ceasefire
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An almost nightly litany of loyalist bombings, car burnings, beatings and threats has shrouded Catholics in the Co Antrim harbour town of Larne in fear.
fields.body:
An almost nightly litany of loyalist bombings, car burnings, beatings and threats has shrouded Catholics in the Co Antrim harbour town of Larne in fear.

In the past week, two families miraculously escaped unhurt when lethal pipe bombs were hurled into their homes and there is an ominous feeling it is only a matter of time before someone is killed.

On the Seacourt estate, perched on the coast with a picturesque view of the Mull of Kintyre, window after window boarded up with ugly steel grilles bear bitter testimony to the dozens of families who have fled their homes. Catholics make up less than a third of the 18,000 population.

The Ulster Freedom Fighters murdered Bertie Shaw's father almost 10 years ago, and in the past few years loyalists have stabbed, shot at and tried to blow up Bertie, 38, with a booby trap that seriously injured one of his Protestant friends.

All his extended family, including his 70-year-old mother, have had numerous death threats, and the house in Seacourt, where he lived with his Protestant partner, Deirdre Haveron, and their son David, 14, has been attacked five times. It now lies empty, a burnt shell, while he stays in a mobile home in a nearby village.

"The ceasefire's a joke," he said. "It doesn't matter what the politicians say, it's a different ball game in Larne.

"It's not one-off incidents, it's a continuous flow. The fear is always there for Catholics. It's taken over their lives. Couples take turns at sleeping, they're on tranquillisers, they're ringing their children on mobile phones if they're five minutes late home from school."

The RUC sub-divisional commander, Superintendent Karen Kennedy, said her officers had staged more than 300 operations to combat sectarian attacks in the past two years. There had been more than 60 arrests, the vast majority Protestants.

But Mr Shaw claimed the police had proved useless at protecting his family. He said he had no idea why the vendetta started, except that he objected to loyalists putting up election posters outside Catholic homes. "There's so much in-built hatred in those people, you'd need to be able to reach into their hearts to take it out," he said.

Danny O'Connor, the local nationalist SDLP assemblyman, said Larne had always had sectarian problems, but was admitting only now that the situation was worsening by the day.

"There is such an atmosphere of terror that people are sitting in their living rooms with buckets of water and fire extinguishers beside them, in case the house is set alight," he said.

"The army and police are on the streets. With all the talk about demilitarisation, Larne is remilitarising, and just like the start of the Troubles, the soldiers have been sent in to protect Catholics."

He painted a picture of virtual segregation akin to that suffered by blacks in the United States' deep south, and said he believed that the mainstream loyalist paramilitary Ulster Defence Association, increasingly dislocated from the peace process, was behind much of the trouble.

"As a child I mucked about in a mixed group of Protestants and Catholics; but now young people in this town are more polarised than they have ever been. The UDA is recruiting young fellas hand over fist. It's the 'ceasefire soldier' syndrome: most of these ones were nowhere to be seen when the conflict was at its height, and they've turned against the Good Friday agreement - if they were ever really for it.

"Catholic children can't go downtown alone, especially not in their school uniform. Teachers are now escorting them to their buses. I've heard a 14-year-old Catholic girl who was chatting to her Protestant friend called a wee whore and told to get to the other side of the street, and a Catholic couple told to get out of a Protestant bar, they weren't welcome."

Sitting behind the bullet-proof glass in his town centre office, Mr O'Connor said that he had had death threats and that his brother, Kevin, narrowly escaped injury in a nail bomb attack on his flat a couple of months ago.

He has compiled a dossier, which he has given to the British and Irish governments, of more than 160 sample incidents in the past two years - he said the figure could easily be doubled.

Surprisingly, as many nationalists would be suspicious of covert police activity, he wants more undercover work to root out the culprits. He welcomed the fact that unionist politicians were among the strong chorus of condemnation, but said the Protestant community had to support Catholics more.

"These people are fascists. Ordinary, decent Protestants should be aware they'll not be content with driving Catholics out, they'll want rid of everyone who doesn't agree with their views. For ages, Larne was in denial. People said it was a great wee town. It's a bit like being an alcoholic. The first step is admitting you have a problem. We've done that, but it's going to be a long, long road to recovery."

webTitle: Solicitor denies claims of attack by Bulger killer

fields.headline: Solicitor denies claims of attack by Bulger killer
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: A lawyer acting for Robert Thompson, one of the boys jailed for the murder of James Bulger, has denied reports in a Sunday newspaper that his client attempted to strangle another boy with a length of flex at a secure unit.
fields.body:
A lawyer acting for Robert Thompson, one of the boys jailed for the murder of James Bulger, has denied reports in a Sunday newspaper that his client attempted to strangle another boy with a length of flex at a secure unit.

Dominic Lloyd, a Merseyside solicitor, said: "I can categorically deny these allegations. We do not know who made them, why they have been made or who they were made to.

"If this complaint is made formally then there will be an impartial investigation into these claims and I would not want to prejudice this any more than this newspaper article has done already."

The allegations appeared in the Sunday People yesterday under the headline "Bulger fiend tries to kill again" and came six days after the high court ruling granting Thompson and Jon Venables anonymity for the rest of their lives when they leave custody with new identities.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss granted the boys' application for anonymity because of the "exceptional circumstances" of the case and to protect them from "risks of attacks from members of the public as well as from relatives and friends of the murdered child". The order was opposed by several newspaper groups including Trinity Mirror, which owns the Sunday People.

Dame Elizabeth also ruled that no details of the pair's eight years in custody should be revealed for 12 months after their release. Last week the Sun ran several stories about the boys' experiences and treatment in council care.

The Sunday People alleged that almost two years ago Thompson had made "a calculating attempt" to strangle another boy after being taunted over James's killing. The paper claimed that details of the attack on a boy of 15 had been confirmed by the victim's solicitor, Stephen Smith. Mr Smith was quoted as saying the victim, 15 at the time of the alleged attack, would take legal action against Thompson.

Last year Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, reviewing the minimum tariff the boys should serve, said: "Neither has shown any aggression or propensity for violence during his period of detention." Both are eligible for parole next month.

The Sunday People said last night that it stood by the story and did not consider it a breach of the order granted by Dame Elizabeth.

webTitle: Complaints authority accuses force of systemic failure

fields.headline: 'To mentally damage people like they have done with Mandy and I - they shouldn't be allowed to do that'
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Amanda London-Williams had just begun watching EastEnders, at 7.40pm on December 10 1996, when she heard her stepfather's car in the drive. Moments later she heard two shots. Peering through the curtains, she saw the outline of a man wearing a balaclava and holding a gun.
fields.body:
Amanda London-Williams had just begun watching EastEnders, at 7.40pm on December 10 1996, when she heard her stepfather's car in the drive. Moments later she heard two shots. Peering through the curtains, she saw the outline of a man wearing a balaclava and holding a gun.

Richard Watson, 55, had been murdered by a hitman. That proved to be the start of a long and traumatic ordeal for Miss London-Williams, now 25, and her mother Linda, now known as Linda Henderson.

The two women, who were in a state of shock, were left alone inside the house while police kept at a safe distance and waited 50 minutes for an armed support unit to arrive from Brighton. Although a doctor arrived at the house by car he immediately reversed away again. Neither he nor an ambulance team were allowed to treat Watson.

Subsequently family friends, summoned by telephone, arrived, and it was they who broke the news to Linda Watson that her husband was dead.

Screamed

The police complaints authority concluded that there had been "a breakdown in communication aggravated by various staff failings".

When the police did enter the house, Mrs Henderson was hurt by the offhand way in which members of the family were treated. Although full details had been given over the phone, the police still had no idea who owned the house.

One officer gestured to the body and said: "Is that the landlord?"

Mrs Henderson recalled: "I screamed at him, 'He's my husband and' - pointing at Mandy - 'her father.' He actually said 'Oh, shit.' The only compassion shown through all of this was a message of apology from one of the uniformed police and the ambulance men, who had wanted to help that evening but were not allowed to."

The PCA told the women: "There is evidence to support some of the allegations you make of incivility towards you."

The inquiry also found that the initial mistakes jeopardised the entire investigation, explaining that "potential forensic evidence may have been lost as a result of a lack of leadership and poor communications at the scene".

The family were taken to a local hotel, the Copthorne, and given rooms on the ground floor. Mrs Henderson was alarmed to notice that the police entered their correct personal details in the register. "I was petrified that this person had seen Mandy and was going to come back to get her," she said. "They then said they had to release details to the press. I asked the police please not to put out Mandy's name. I was then abruptly and coldly told, four hours after losing Richard, 'Look, I know you have had a hard night, but would you just shut up?'

"This was where I came unstuck with the police, because I criticised them very strongly. They don't like strong women."

From that point the two women were regarded as prime suspects, and interviewed at length.

Miss London-Williams was only present at the house that evening because she had just been seriously ill with food poisoning. She was awaiting a brain scan and, according to her solicitor, Jeff Hide, was "in a state of almost total collapse". On receiving information about the murder her GP recommended that a clinical psychologist should be on hand, and personally arranged for Nigel Gordon to attend her. But although Mr Gordon waited for more than four hours, the police refused to allow him to see either of the women.

The PCA found that this part of the complaint was substantiated, and pointed to the "clear evidence" that the interviews with Miss London-Williams were in breach of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act.

"The cruelty was terrible," said Mrs Henderson. "To mentally damage people to the extent that they have done with Mandy and I - they shouldn't be allowed to do that."

Mrs Henderson sold the house: she knew she could not live there again. But no sooner had she and her daughter moved into their new house than 14 officers arrived early one morning. She was arrested and taken to East Grinstead police station. It was only later she found out that her daughter had also been arrested and taken to Haywards Heath. They were held in custody for five days before being released without charge.

They subsequently found out that police had planted listening devices in their new home. Builders saw men breaking into the house, and apprehended them. When the builders threatened to call the police, the intruders had to admit that they were the police: they had broken in to remove the bugging devices. The builders gave statements to defence solicitors.

Had the trial gone ahead, however, it is likely that the police would have tried to suppress this through the use of public interest immunity certificates.

Although solicitors for the two women had made it clear that their clients were willing to answer further questions at any time, the two women were then arrested in a public and humiliating way - Mrs Henderson as she arrived back at Gatwick airport from a trip to Scotland, and her daughter as she was walking in Brighton.

One of the major grounds of criticism of police conduct was that by this time Watson's body had finally been released to his wife. She went ahead with the funeral and had him cremated.

At that stage, she had no idea that she and her daughter would have to face murder charges. By releasing the body at that juncture the police deprived the defence of the opportunity to have an independent postmortem examination performed on the body.

The PCA told the women its investigation had found that "at the time you were documented as suspects. Your allegation is substantiated."

The PCA did not find evidence in favour of the women on every allegation. As evidence of the animus of Sussex police against them, Mrs Henderson cited officers' reactions when she and her daughter were sent to Holloway. "There were shouts of 'Yes!' from the detectives present," she said. "They raised their arms in a cheering gesture, like football hooligans." The PCA reported that the officers "refuted the allegation and the evidence of an independent witness supports their account".

There were many other leads that could have been pursued in the murder inquiry. Watson, whose company had helped to install the main telephone exchange in Moscow, had some shady business contacts, both in this country and overseas. Moreover, he had been the victim of a stun-gun attack, by two men wearing balaclavas, only a month before he was murdered.

Concealed

Crown lawyers halted the prosecution late on Friday June 5 1998, with the trial due to start on the Monday. The entire prosecution depended on the theory that the two shots that killed Watson were fired from the balcony of the house, and thus the gunman had been aided by those inside. Yet the very first scientific report made it clear that it was "not possible to determine positively from where each shot was fired".

One of the women's complaints was that throughout the inquiry the police had concealed the weakness of their case from the crown prosecution service. The PCA found that: "Too much significance was placed upon the belief that Richard Watson had been shot from the balcony. The evidence did not justify the scenario. The papers submitted by officers to the CPS overstated this issue and, although there was no evidence of malice, the investigation concludes that your prosecution was ill-founded as a result."

The inquiry also found that the initial mistakes jeopardised the entire investigation, explaining that "potential forensic evidence may have been lost as a result of a lack of leadership and poor communications at the scene". The family were taken to a local hotel, the Copthorne, and given rooms on the ground floor. Mrs Henderson was alarmed to notice that the police entered their correct personal details in the register. "I was petrified that this person had seen Mandy and was going to come back to get her," she said. "They then said they had to release details to the press. I asked the police please not to put out Mandy's name. I was then abruptly and coldly told, four hours after losing Richard, 'Look, I know you have had a hard night, but would you just shut up?' "This was where I came unstuck with the police, because I criticised them very strongly. They don't like strong women." From that point the two women were regarded as prime suspects, and interviewed at length. Miss London-Williams was only present at the house that evening because she had just been seriously ill with food poisoning. She was awaiting a brain scan and, according to her solicitor, Jeff Hide, was "in a state of almost total collapse". On receiving information about the murder her GP recommended that a clinical psychologist should be on hand, and personally arranged for Nigel Gordon to attend her. But although Mr Gordon waited for more than four hours, the police refused to allow him to see either of the women. The PCA found that this part of the complaint was substantiated, and pointed to the "clear evidence" that the interviews with Miss London-Williams were in breach of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act. "The cruelty was terrible," said Mrs Henderson. "To mentally damage people to the extent that they have done with Mandy and I - they shouldn't be allowed to do that." Mrs Henderson sold the house: she knew she could not live there again. But no sooner had she and her daughter moved into their new house than 14 officers arrived early one morning. She was arrested and taken to East Grinstead police station. It was only later she found out that her daughter had also been arrested and taken to Haywards Heath. They were held in custody for five days before being released without charge. They subsequently found out that police had planted listening devices in their new home. Builders saw men breaking into the house, and apprehended them. When the builders threatened to call the police, the intruders had to admit that they were the police: they had broken in to remove the bugging devices. The builders gave statements to defence solicitors. Had the trial gone ahead, however, it is likely that the police would have tried to suppress this through the use of public interest immunity certificates. Although solicitors for the two women had made it clear that their clients were willing to answer further questions at any time, the two women were then arrested in a public and humiliating way - Mrs Henderson as she arrived back at Gatwick airport from a trip to Scotland, and her daughter as she was walking in Brighton. One of the major grounds of criticism of police conduct was that by this time Watson's body had finally been released to his wife. She went ahead with the funeral and had him cremated. At that stage, she had no idea that she and her daughter would have to face murder charges. By releasing the body at that juncture the police deprived the defence of the opportunity to have an independent postmortem examination performed on the body. The PCA told the women its investigation had found that "at the time you were documented as suspects. Your allegation is substantiated." The PCA did not find evidence in favour of the women on every allegation. As evidence of the animus of Sussex police against them, Mrs Henderson cited officers' reactions when she and her daughter were sent to Holloway. "There were shouts of 'Yes!' from the detectives present," she said. "They raised their arms in a cheering gesture, like football hooligans." The PCA reported that the officers "refuted the allegation and the evidence of an independent witness supports their account". There were many other leads that could have been pursued in the murder inquiry. Watson, whose company had helped to install the main telephone exchange in Moscow, had some shady business contacts, both in this country and overseas. Moreover, he had been the victim of a stun-gun attack, by two men wearing balaclavas, only a month before he was murdered. Concealed Crown lawyers halted the prosecution late on Friday June 5 1998, with the trial due to start on the Monday. The entire prosecution depended on the theory that the two shots that killed Watson were fired from the balcony of the house, and thus the gunman had been aided by those inside. Yet the very first scientific report made it clear that it was "not possible to determine positively from where each shot was fired". One of the women's complaints was that throughout the inquiry the police had concealed the weakness of their case from the crown prosecution service. The PCA found that: "Too much significance was placed upon the belief that Richard Watson had been shot from the balcony. The evidence did not justify the scenario. The papers submitted by officers to the CPS overstated this issue and, although there was no evidence of malice, the investigation concludes that your prosecution was ill-founded as a result." webTitle: The secret way out

fields.headline: The secret way out
fields.standfirst: Desperate to find a new job without alerting the boss or colleagues to your plans?                                                                       Dolly Dhingra discovers some useful tips for the restless
fields.trailText: Desperate to find a new job without alerting the boss or colleagues to your plans? Dolly Dhingra discovers some useful tips for the restless.
fields.body:
New year, new job? Not as easy as it sounds, is it? Not while working full-time in an open-plan, and probably nosy office. Sure you can flick through the job ads in the toilets or at home, but what about all the telephone calls? The interviews? The salary negotiations? Job-hunting is a job in itself according to Charles Walker of recruitment agency Blue Arrow. He says that "the open-plan structure of today's office space and the mass monitoring of email and internet activity is making the job search process increasingly difficult".

Like thousands of others, office worker Paul Sainsbury, 26, decided at Christmas that enough was enough. Having worked in the West Country for several years, he was itching to return home to London and is now looking for a new job. Seeing family and friends over the holiday period, he says, made him "compare my own life and realise that certain things need to change". First thing in January, he was scouring the classifieds.

The trick for Sainsbury and others like him is to not drag co-workers into your pit of disaffection with your present job (remember: they might actually like it there). As common sense dictates, it's not good for office relations to have the world, his wife and her niece knowing that you're searching for a new career.

"Don't antagonise or alienate the people you are working with," advises Memuna Forma, spokesperson for the Industrial Society. "You may not get the job you have applied for and may have to continue working with the same people for several years," she warns. Which means resisting references to your Alcatraz workplace. Colleagues may not appreciate it.

In a word, it's all about boundaries. Walker argues that you have to respect your current employer (after all, they are still paying your wages). Phone calls should be made in private offices and preferably in your lunch break. Most companies also have pay phones. Insist on calling back prospective employers rather than asking them to call you at work, and make sure application forms are sent to your home address. If you have a mobile phone, use that rather than your office phone - there's nothing like a guilty whispered telephone conversation to make suspicious colleagues' ears prick up .

Sainsbury's job hunting was made easier by sending his CV to specialist recruitment agencies - often they are able to do a lot of the legwork and will call only when interviews need to be arranged. "I get the agency to call me on my mobile, and if it isn't a good moment I can just switch it off. However, if I do decide to take the call, I'll go for a quick walk to the toilets or somewhere quiet," he says.

Sainsbury explains that for those applying for jobs in different parts of the country there are yet further obstacles. "I had a recruitment agent saying she wanted me to come in. I asked her what she could possibly want to ask me that she couldn't ask over the phone? In the end, I offered to send her a photo and she was happy with that. The implications of her wanting to see a picture of me are, of course, awful, but it would have cost me a whole day to travel to London. Obviously I didn't send her one of my dodgy photos - I sent her one I looked professional in," he says.

Although it may be tempting to do so, Walker warns against using work email, where company seniors can pry. Instead, set up an email address of your own. Beware, too, of using the internet at work to surf for jobs, as your search history is recorded. For interviews, always use holiday or flexi-time - resist trying to squeeze them into hours of work.

Finally, if you do get the job, don't start popping the champagne and impersonating a Formula One winner. If the news is that worthy of a celebration, spare a thought for the poor sods who are stuck there until they finally see the light.

webTitle: US aid boost for Iraqi opposition

fields.headline: US aid boost for Iraqi opposition
fields.standfirst:
Plans could expose rift in Bush cabinet

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Plans could expose rift in Bush cabinet.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration has been forced to signal a new turn in US policy towards Saddam Hussein by committing fresh financial support to Iraqi opposition groups, an approach which is likely to be developed still further under the incoming administration of George W Bush.

With less than a week of his presidency remaining, Mr Clinton has done what Republicans have pressed him to do for more than two years and has submitted a plan to Congress to help opposition groups administer $12m (£8m) in humanitarian relief aid inside Iraq.

The new plan involves the distribution of food, medicine and other forms of relief through the Iraqi National Congress, the main umbrella opposition group in the north of the country.

Difficult though such clandestine distribution may be in an area controlled by Baghdad, the still more challenging aspect of the plan is that it implicitly involves the US in providing military and security assistance to the INC in plans to re-establish a US-protected "safe area" inside Iraq.

That commitment seems certain to cause an early dispute within the Bush administration between the new secretary of state, Colin Powell, who is known to be sceptical about the Iraqi opposition's capabilities, and the new Pentagon chief, Donald Rumsfeld, who heads a powerful conservative lobby in the new team committed to more aggressive US engagement.

Mr Clinton has been forced to act now by the Republican controlled Congress, which favours a more aggressive US approach in efforts aimed at the ultimate overthrow of President Saddam's regime.

Under the Iraq Liberation Act of 1998, which Mr Clinton signed only reluctantly, the administration was authorised to provide the Iraqi opposition with $97m (£65m) worth of arms and military training as part of the effort to oust Saddam. But because of Pentagon and White House trepidation about such an involvement, only $2m of that allocation has actually been spent.

Last autumn, Congress turned the screw on Mr Clinton by writing the $12m aid item into the federal budget and giving the administration until January 5 to come up with a plan for carrying it out.

The plan submitted to Congress last week proposes that INC units make undercover moves into government-controlled areas in northern Iraq to distribute relief supplies and propaganda. Given that Baghdad is fully aware of what is intended under the plan, this raises the question of the willingness of the US to protect and defend the opposition as it carries out the relief work.

For the INC, the aid plan is a preliminary to an armed operation in which it will seek to re-establish itself on Iraqi territory from which it was ousted by President Saddam's forces in 1996. That in turn is seen as a precursor to wider armed insurrection against the Baghdad regime.

The Clinton administration is prepared to go along with the aid initiative because it hopes it could boost the opposition's profile and credibility in Iraq without the US supplying the INC with arms. The current administration also knows that if the policy unravels in some disastrous way, it will be Mr Bush who has to answer for it.
