webTitle: Mortality lottery in NHS

fields.headline: Mortality lottery in NHS
fields.trailText: The government last night renewed its pledge to increase the number of doctors and promised a simple annual report card on every hospital in England.
fields.body:
The government last night renewed its pledge to increase the number of doctors and promised a simple annual report card on every hospital in England after the publication of death rates showed that mortality among patients varies significantly.

The research suggests that 17 people are likely to die in the country's worst performing hospital for every 10 who die in the best, even after adjusting the figures to take account of the patients' ages, sex, diagnoses and length of stay.

The availability of doctors, and whether or not patients were admitted as emergency cases, were far more important than factors such as social background, the study showed. It used NHS data for five years up to last March to assess performance.

Walsall NHS trust was revealed as having the worst mortality rate, while University College London Hospitals NHS trust had the best, the research for Dr Foster Ltd, publisher of healthcare information, showed.

The British Medical Association jumped on the general link between staffing and death rates to strengthen its campaign for more doctors, although some hospitals with comparatively low numbers of doctors also had low patient mortality.

Liam Fox, the Tories' health spokesman, claimed the variations revealed a "permanent structural crisis in the NHS".

The assessments, which will fuel debate about the "postcode lottery" in NHS care, were made by Sir Brian Jarman, emeritus professor of primary health care at Imperial College, London. He used official NHS data, but went far further than the government has in turning performance indicators into stark overall death rates.

Sir Brian insisted that his team had tried to be "as fair as we can". During the period surveyed, each hospital trust would have seen on average 59,000 admissions and 4,700 deaths. One thing was clear: "We need more doctors."

His team calculated a mortality index for each hospital so one that had exactly the national average of deaths, after taking into account other factors, would score 100. Those that had more deaths would score above 100; those with fewer would score below. Hospitals in Walsall scored 119, compared with 68 for the UCH trust, but Walsall also had a far lower ratio of doctors per 100 beds (23 against 63). Of 174 trusts surveyed, death rates in 17 were at least 10.5% above average, while in 22 others they were 10.5% lower.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, gave a bullish welcome to Sir Brian's work. "In the past governments refused to publish this sort of information. That was wrong," he said.

He said more information and tough inspections would improve standards. The government, already published in non-league-table form the death rate per hospital, and within a year would give information on waiting times, cancelled operations, cleanliness, length of hospital stay and delayed discharges.

The government had already promised 7,500 more consultants by 2004, and more beds.

webTitle: The inside track: Having two careers

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Having two careers
fields.trailText: Having two careers
fields.body:
'Don't give up the day job." The phrase has caused many an artistic young heart to shiver at this cold and unfeeling blast of reality withering cherished dreams. But the fact is that a solid income will give you a longer run at the big time than you might otherwise be able to afford.

This is why temp agencies are thronged with unexpected talents. "I've seen actors whose confidence was destroyed because of money worries. But I could afford to turn down acting jobs that would be bad for my career," says one thespian with a joint career in secretarial work (as a senior PA, too).

Temping particularly suits actors because time off for auditions is easy. Plus, since actors often work at night, once a play is rehearsed, an actor can run both careers back to back - a demanding life, but a more comfortable one than surviving on Equity minimum.

But it is not just actors who take refuge in office work. Many artists and writers prefer the office to eking out a living in some grossly exploited role associated with their craft (working as a television runner springs to mind).

Secretarial agencies do not look askance at such aspirations - indeed they often seem quietly proud of the achievements of their artistic temps, and employ them themselves. One West End agency hired an artist as its receptionist after he requested a job that he didn't have to take home with him. Proof that honesty really is the best policy when you're working two jobs.

With the craze for the genre of "city girl novels", many authors are using their day jobs as raw material (Lana Citron's Sucker is one of the better examples). By contrast the esteemed poet TS Eliot managed to persuade his rich friends to start a charity fund to save him from dirtying his hands with commerce. But a better icon for the two-jobbers is Franz Kafka: Prague bohemian by night, insurance man by day. And a first rate insurance man he was, too.

webTitle: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: In all the kerfuffle about teacher shortages, nobody seems to have noticed recruitment consultants Office Angels taking its own headteachery stance - presiding over a class of unruly office workers as if they were misbehaving children.
fields.body:
* In all the kerfuffle about teacher shortages, nobody seems to have noticed recruitment consultants Office Angels taking its own headteachery stance - presiding over a class of unruly office workers as if they were misbehaving children. The Angels (no relation to Charlie's) argues that we office workers can no longer afford to be confused over commas or perplexed by punctuation marks. Failure to spend five minutes checking work for spelling and grammar errors could, it says with a schoolish authority, jeopardises our chances of promotion. Apparently, 84% of employers believe excellent work is completely devalued by sloppy spelling and poor grammar. Big boo-boos are said to include confusion over similar words, such as affect and effect; misuse of apostrophes (its v it's); wrong application of endings for plurals (eg, countrys instead of countries) and the use of American spellings.

Sadly, however, the Office Angels press release emphatically argues that "reliance on the computer has lead (sic) many employees to make simple spelling and grammar errors." Perhaps it had better start its English lessons closer to home.

* But the lecturing doesn't stop there. Careless letter writing costs British industry £6bn a year, according to the Plain English Campaign, and with 385m items passing through the Royal Mail, the producers of Basildon Bond paper believe that we ought to get it right. Launched this month at basildonbond.com is a practical guide to letter writing, with examples of professional and personal letters.

You could, of course, skip the boring, worky bit and go straight to the psychology of handwriting section. Here, readers are invited to send examples of their own script (on Basildon Bond paper, of course) for complimentary analysis by an expert. A quick glance at the art suggests WPM is a hostile, insincere, pessimistic, romantically incompatible, negative manic depressive. But that's the price you pay when you reach the heady heights of an Office Hours column. WPM is happy to suffer for her art.

* The extent of her suffering, however, does have its limits and WPM is unhappy to learn that your personality could determine how accident-prone you are at work.

Dr Sharon Clarke, a lecturer at the school of management at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, told a conference of the British Psychological Society that employees who are rebellious, aggressive and unconventional are more liable to have an accident in the workplace than those who are dependable, conscientious, socially responsible and not so aggressive.

The findings came from an analysis of 100 previous studies which revealed the different personalities of people involved in car- and work-related accidents. Researchers believe that the findings could help employers to select suitable candidates for jobs where safety is paramount. If the handwriting analysts are right, it's probably best that WPM forgets her ambition to excel in the world of air traffic control.

* Our Website of the Week fixture has been taking a break in recent weeks. In fact, it has been on holiday - skiing. But now it's back. Ready and willing to satisfy all your cyber needs.

So, website of the week is workthing.com. Chosen largely for its snot-green background, workthing.com also has some useful tools and tips. Rather than trying to satisfy all workers with the same advice and info, the website has a network of sites for different industries - media, IT, health, etc. Within each section they give you latest news, a weekly lowdown, a people profile and industry views. There's also a big database of job classifieds, an events diary, training information and a skills builder. It almost takes the hard work out of, well, work.

WPM was particularly taken with the salary checker - you enter your job title and location of work and compare your salary to the industry norm - thus discovering how grossly underpaid you are. Which is exactly what has just happened to WPM. She is off now, to negotiate terms and conditions. In the event of failure, she will be holding a one-woman strike in forthcoming weeks. If comrades miss her wit and wisdom, you can find her at the picket line. We shall not, we shall not be moved . . .

Dr Sharon Clarke, a lecturer at the school of management at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, told a conference of the British Psychological Society that employees who are rebellious, aggressive and unconventional are more liable to have an accident in the workplace than those who are dependable, conscientious, socially responsible and not so aggressive. The findings came from an analysis of 100 previous studies which revealed the different personalities of people involved in car- and work-related accidents. Researchers believe that the findings could help employers to select suitable candidates for jobs where safety is paramount. If the handwriting analysts are right, it's probably best that WPM forgets her ambition to excel in the world of air traffic control. * Our Website of the Week fixture has been taking a break in recent weeks. In fact, it has been on holiday - skiing. But now it's back. Ready and willing to satisfy all your cyber needs. So, website of the week is workthing.com. Chosen largely for its snot-green background, workthing.com also has some useful tools and tips. Rather than trying to satisfy all workers with the same advice and info, the website has a network of sites for different industries - media, IT, health, etc. Within each section they give you latest news, a weekly lowdown, a people profile and industry views. There's also a big database of job classifieds, an events diary, training information and a skills builder. It almost takes the hard work out of, well, work. WPM was particularly taken with the salary checker - you enter your job title and location of work and compare your salary to the industry norm - thus discovering how grossly underpaid you are. Which is exactly what has just happened to WPM. She is off now, to negotiate terms and conditions. In the event of failure, she will be holding a one-woman strike in forthcoming weeks. If comrades miss her wit and wisdom, you can find her at the picket line. We shall not, we shall not be moved . . .

webTitle: Sec's tips 17. Good writing

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 17. Good writing
fields.trailText: 17. Good writing
fields.body:
Standards are dropping. Not helped by the advent of "e-mail speak", the level of business communication is very low. Letters that use "Yours Sincerely" with the greeting "Dear Sir"; memos riddled with spelling mistakes; impenetrable business reports that adopt a "food processor" approach to the organisation of ideas (all thrown in together, mixed up at speed, and with no discernible beginning or end). None of us wants to return to the days of: "We herewith acknowledge receipt of your letter dated 17th ult." But that's no excuse for communication that fails to deliver its message. Stick to the basics, and you won't go far wrong.

*Know your reader. Whether it's a letter, a report, a memo, or an article for the newsletter, you need to be aware of who will read it. If you don't, you won't know the tone or level of technical language that is appropriate.

* Make a mental plan of the points you want to make and in which order, before you write. Group ideas together. Work logically through them, ending with The Next Step - what you want your reader to think or do next. Is it clear that they should call you immediately, or return the invoice, or bring the information to the next meeting?

*Break up your ideas. A golden rule is "one subject or issue per paragraph, and one idea per sentence". Around 20 words is plenty for one sentence, and fewer for those containing complicated ideas.

*Avoid the use of jargon. If your reader is not in your organisation or industry, don't assume that he or she will know your common abbreviations and terms. If you have to use them, write them in full the first time.

*Use a dictionary. Spellcheckers have a limited use, and you should make it a point of pride to know whether the verb is "practise" or "practice", and whether you mean "to effect" or "to affect".

*With shorter documents, read them backwards to proof-read them. Reading it backwards divorces the sense and leaves you free to look at each word individually.

*It's up to you PAs out there to save the nation's flagging communication skills! Take time to get it right, and communicate clearly - and don't be afraid to make a stand against poor practice. Or is it practise . . . ? You should know!

Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Why Mr Hague cannot score

fields.headline: Bottom of the league
fields.standfirst:
Why Mr Hague cannot score
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Why Mr Hague cannot score.
fields.body:
The Sunday Times, we can safely say, did not intend its "league table" of hospitals to be read as anything but criticism of Labour's record. Yet Alan Milburn was able yesterday almost to embrace the (unsurprising) finding that there are wide variations in health performance, as measured by patient deaths and other crude indices. It is why, he said, Labour set up its own auditing body, the commission on health improvement. Such figures justified the hugely ambitious national plan for health promulgated last year, but only to get going after this April. The health secretary sounded convincing partly because he has so little opposition to contend with from the Tories. William Hague, who is still endowed with serried centres for policy studies, should yesterday have whipped from his back pocket a patented plan for health service reform. He could not do that for a very good reason. He has proved unwilling to rethink Thatcherite dogmatism about the public services and the public still believe him in his heart to be a one-club privatiser. He is not yet, to put it bluntly, social democratic enough. That is why his electoral standing remains as desperate as yesterday's Mori and NOP polls said.

It is not as if a more credible Hague would lack grounds for attacking the government. Labour's approach to the NHS is increasingly "Bevanite". Tony Blair sounds as if he wants to be held responsible for every dropped bedpan in every ward. In education, too, this centralising approach has got stronger. The logic of league tables for schools and surgery is yet more central intervention to secure uniform standards. The danger is that teachers and nurses spend their time ticking boxes, afraid to use their professional initiative.

Here, you might think, is fertile territory for an opposition that knows it must convince the public of its competence in running public services by addressing practical problems. Once, the Tories were the local party, advocates of the littleplatoons and all. Now, they are fixated on the private sector as the panacea for all ills. Their plans for private health insurance and school selection would provide more diversity, true, but at the expense of cutting poorer people out. Service for all, regardless of means, can only be provided in the public sector. Until the Tories get that message and its fiscal consequences, they deserve their likely electoral fate.

webTitle: Europe's BSE fear deepens as UK stays calm

fields.headline: Europe's BSE fear deepens as UK stays calm
fields.standfirst:
Public wants to see stronger central powers over member states

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Public wants to see stronger central powers over member states.
fields.body:
Worries about food safety problems linked with mad cow disease have now spread across Europe with near panic in Germany and Greece, according to the exclusive Guardian/ICM poll of public opinion across eight European countries.

The poll shows that in Germany, where two government ministers have just resigned over BSE, 86% of the public say they are worried about the disease. The public is equally concerned in Greece and there are high levels of anxiety in the Netherlands and Italy.

The major exception is Britain with only 54% saying they are in any way concerned. Across Europe the poll shows that voters feel that the problems of food safety would be dealt with more efficiently if the EU was given stronger powers over member states to tackle the issue. This view is echoed by two-thirds of voters in Britain.

Indeed a common theme which emerges from the poll, which canvassed views in France, Germany, Italy, Greece, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Spain and the UK, is that the public wants to see the EU given far greater powers. Large majorities (70% plus across Europe) in each country say the EU should be given more powers to deal with questions such as the environment, illegal immigration, money laundering, and to a lesser extent biotechnology changes such as genetic modification.

But while many voters across Europe support a stronger EU to deal with practical problems, the poll shows that they share the lack of confidence in its institutions. Both the European commission and the European parliament are unloved by voters across Europe. German public opinion (only 21% say they have confidence in the commission) is even more hostile than British voters (31% say they have confidence). The French (41%) have slightly more faith, but outside of Luxembourg (57%) nowhere else can majority support be found for the commission, proving that such anti-Brussels feelings are not a peculiarly British trait. Such lack of confidence in the European parliament is equally shared.

These findings were mirrored by similar levels of dissatisfaction with the way the EU is developing. Only 34% of British voters say they are happy with the way that the EU is going - very similar to the Germans (35%) and the French (37%). The truth across Europe appears to be that nobody is particularly happy with the way the union is evolving.

But the poll also shows that British public opinion is out of step with the rest of Europe about what should happen next. When asked what they thought of the proposal by the German foreign minister to set up a federal Europe, public opinion across the eight countries was almost equally split. Although the phrase "federal Europe" means very different things in different parts of the EU, it is notable that British voters are the most hostile to the idea (58% against). Even in Germany there is no majority support but French, Spanish and Greek voters back the idea.

All those polled but Britain say they want to see a common European army, a directly elected European president and the harmonisation of common legal and tax systems. The creation of a common European government appears to be less popular across Europe. Majority support for the idea can be found among voters in France, Italy and Spain but those in Britain, the Netherlands and Greece are hostile to the idea. Even in Germany public opinion is divided.

Generally the process of enlarging the EU by admitting the east European countries to membership finds support but it is not wholehearted, with barely a majority 51% across the eight countries welcoming the development. In Britain more support enlargement (48%) than don't (36%).

The poll took place between December 5 and 23 last year, and was conducted by interviews with 6,637 European citizens aged 18 and over. Polling was conducted by ICM research in Britain, Louis Harris in France, Emnid in Germany, Opinion in Greece, Abacus in Italy, Ilres in Luxembourg, Nipo in the Netherlands, and Demoscopia in Spain.

webTitle: BSE reaches Italy and Austria

fields.headline: BSE reaches Italy and Austria
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Italy revealed its first suspected case of BSE at the weekend, ending the hope that it had escaped the crisis sweeping Europe.
fields.body:
Italy revealed its first suspected case of BSE at the weekend, ending the hope that it had escaped the crisis sweeping Europe.

A milk cow from a breeding farm near the northern town of Brescia, in Lombardy, tested positive after being slaughtered on Thursday.

The agriculture minister, Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, said: "We are a country that imports many animals, so we cannot exclude finding cases of BSE."

The health minister, Umberto Veronesi, told a press conference on Saturday: "We are not 100% sure, and even if it was the case, it would be the first time an Italian-born cow had contracted the disease."

A Turin laboratory is due to confirm tomorrow whether tissue samples contain the brain-wasting disease bovine spongiform encephalopathy.

The cow is believed to have come from a herd of 180 owned by the Grecia family on the Malpensata di Pontevico farm. The police sealed off the area yesterday.

An investigating magistrate was quoted as saying that the cow was born and bred on the farm, but Mr Pecoraro Scanio said it appeared to have been imported.

The only previous cases in Italy were two infected cows imported from Britain, but last month Italy followed its EU partners in ordering tests on all cattle going for slaughter. In November it ordered tests on all beef cattle over two years old, and labels showing where they had been reared and slaughtered.

"The suspected case was discovered because the controls are efficient," a government spokesman said.

Italian confidence in beef is plunging, however. Even before Saturday's announcement sales had fallen 40% in reaction to French cases. School canteens have stopped serving red meat.

A ban on French imports, also imposed in November, was lifted on Friday, because the Italian tests were considered adequate. Around 600 random tests in northern Italy, where most of the country's dairy farms are found, were negative.

Consumer groups say Italy is lagging in its safety measures. The newspaper Corriere della Sera reported that EU inspectors had concluded that controls at slaughterhouses were often inadequate and sometimes non-existent, suggesting that contaminated material may have found its way into Italian meat products and by-products.

Italy slaughters about 4.5m cattle a year and imports about 1.5m, mostly from France, the research institute Ismea says.

Austria too reported its first probable case of BSE yesterday, after tests on an animal slaughtered in Germany but born and raised in the Austrian province of Tyrol.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Pinochet 'fit to stand trial'
Preliminary results from the three days of psychological and neurological tests carried out on Augusto Pinochet last week show that he is healthy enough to stand trial in Chile, according to a leaked report in the government newspaper La Nacion. The final report will be given to the magistrate investigating his alleged involvement in human rights violations, Judge Juan Guzman, within the next few days. Jonathan Franklin, Santiago
fields.body:
Pinochet 'fit to stand trial'
Preliminary results from the three days of psychological and neurological tests carried out on Augusto Pinochet last week show that he is healthy enough to stand trial in Chile, according to a leaked report in the government newspaper La Nacion. The final report will be given to the magistrate investigating his alleged involvement in human rights violations, Judge Juan Guzman, within the next few days. Jonathan Franklin, Santiago

Suspected killer ends it all
A suspected murderer on the run since 1995 killed himself yesterday when police officers surrounded him near the town of Glina, 30 miles south of the Croatian capital Zagreb. Zivko Korac is thought to have gone into hiding when the Croatian army took control of an area in the hands of rebel Serbs, and to have subsequently killed five people. AP, Zagreb

Snow claims two Italians
A snowslide in the Italian Alps near Aosta killed two Italian men in a party of 20 skiers on Mount Shaligne, a 2,600-metre (8,500 ft) peak, yesterday. Two other skiers caught by the avalanche survived, Ansa news agency reported. AP, Rome

Calm voting in Ivory Coast
There was no sign of violence in elections in 26 constituencies in northern Ivory Coast yesterday, called after the opposition Rally of the Republicans' members interfered with voting in the December 10 general election because its leader, the former prime minister Alassane Dramane, was barred from standing. AP, Korhogo

webTitle: Gun shop opens near scene of shooting

fields.headline: Gun shop opens near scene of shooting
fields.trailText: Rival demonstrations this weekend greeted the opening of a large hunting shop selling rifles in a tough Parisian suburb menaced by gang violence.
fields.body:
Rival demonstrations this weekend greeted the opening of a large hunting shop selling rifles in a tough Parisian suburb menaced by gang violence.

Local groups protested outside a new branch of Eduard Kettner's, France's largest hunting accessory retailers, only two months after a 14-year-old boy was killed with a shotgun nearby as the result of a feud between rival gangs.

But nearly 50 hunters, organised by the pro-hunting CPNT party (which stands for Chasse, Peche, Nature, et Tradition; or Hunting, Fishing, Nature and Tradition) gathered to give their support to the shop's arrival at the Tarterets housing estate in Corbeil-Essonnes, south of Paris.

More than 400 guns, mostly hunting rifles, have been put on sale at the store.

Communist and Green politicians joined with a newly-established youth group called Civil Peace and other local groups to demonstrate outside the store.

The Tarterets estate, like many high-rise estates on the outskirts of Paris, has a bad reputation in France. Street gangs frequently settle their disputes with guns and police have been attacked with stones.

In November a 14-year-old boy called Romuald was shot dead a few yards from his flat in the nearby suburb of Courconnes. He had become caught up in the gang warfare between young men living in adjoining housing estates.

After a boy from one gang was attacked by a group of 15 adolescents, a revenge expedition was launched. Romuald, who was not a member of either gang, was shot twice with a shotgun from a parked car and later died of his injuries.

Demonstrators opposing the opening of the Kettner's store argued that it could only exacerbate problems on the estate. "This shop, which has been opened right opposite the Robert-Doisneau high school in the middle of Tarterets is an incitement to violence," said Jacques Czutach, vice-president of Civil Peace. "At least two kids have been shot dead around here recently."

The Greens have called the shop a "drugstore of death", while the Communist mayoral candidate for Corbeil-Essonnes, Bruno Piriou, said: "The inhabitants of Tarterets have been waiting for years for the return of shops that they actually need, like food stores. Instead, they get a giant armoury.

"At a time marked by a rise in people using guns to settle feuds, poisoning everyday life in our area, opening a shop likes this with more than 400 guns is a real provocation."

But the director of the store, Jean-Richard Servary, said: "We've been taken hostage by politicians a few months before the municipal elections."

He estimated that only four per cent of Kettner's stores, including the new one in Corbeil-Essonnes, are devoted to guns, and that arms sales represented only 20 per cent of the firm's takings. The rest of the shop is given over to hunting accessories such as binoculars, compasses and knives, as well as clothes and shoes.

South of Tarterets is the ancient royal hunting forest of Fontainebleau, once used by kings and still popular among hunters.

The president of Kettner France, Bruno Miele, said: "Delinquency has declined in this area for three years. And what's more, we don't sell Kalashnikovs, pump-action shotguns or grenades, or any other forbidden weapons.

"Our clientele is made up of hunters who want to shoot partridges."

Mr Miele said there was no danger of his guns falling into the hands of local gangs. "We will be demanding at minimum to see the identity cards of suspicious customers."

French gun laws prohibit the sale of guns to minors. Only those who have a hunting licence are allowed to buy guns from Kettner.

Serge Dassault, the Gaullist mayor of Corbeil-Essonnes, said: "Delinquent kids will find guns if they want them. They won't need Kettner's for that."

South of Tarterets is the ancient royal hunting forest of Fontainebleau, once used by kings and still popular among hunters. The president of Kettner France, Bruno Miele, said: "Delinquency has declined in this area for three years. And what's more, we don't sell Kalashnikovs, pump-action shotguns or grenades, or any other forbidden weapons. "Our clientele is made up of hunters who want to shoot partridges." Mr Miele said there was no danger of his guns falling into the hands of local gangs. "We will be demanding at minimum to see the identity cards of suspicious customers." French gun laws prohibit the sale of guns to minors. Only those who have a hunting licence are allowed to buy guns from Kettner. Serge Dassault, the Gaullist mayor of Corbeil-Essonnes, said: "Delinquent kids will find guns if they want them. They won't need Kettner's for that."

webTitle: Past life pursues another German minister

fields.headline: Past life pursues another German minister
fields.trailText: Already under pressure because of his foreign minister's street-fighting youth, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was embroiled in a new drama last night by claims about the past of one of the newest appointments to his cabinet.
fields.byline: John Hooper and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
Already under pressure because of his foreign minister's street-fighting youth, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was embroiled in a new drama last night by claims about the past of one of the newest appointments to his cabinet.

The tabloid Bild am Sonntag reported that Ulla Schmidt, the incoming health minister, had worked in her student days as a part-time waitress in red light bars, and had later run into serious financial problems trying to help out a colleague.

It said her finances became entangled with those of a friend arrested for trying to exchange counterfeit money. As a result she had to pledge half her MP's salary to a bank.

It quoted Ms Schmidt, 51, as saying: "This has all been chewed over a hundred times. Every time I try to take a step forward, an attempt is made in this way to put obstacles in my path." Her past has already been used in an extortion attempt, it reported.

A government spokesman said: "The chancellor has not the slightest doubt as to Ulla Schmidt's integrity".

But the allegations, in particular those about her financial difficulties, are bound to lead to her suitability to head a high-spending government department being questioned.

They also revive the issue of Mr Schröder's judgment in dealing with ministers.

Ms Schmidt, a member of the Social Democrat party (SPD), and the co-leader of the Greens, Renate Künast, were appointed last week to replace two ministers accused of botching the government's handling of the BSE crisis.

Mr Schröder's decision to stand by his colleagues until days before their departure on a tide of media and public dissatisfaction has earned him widespread criticism.

Bild am Sonntag reported that before her appointment was made public Ms Schmidt warned the chancellor, the general secretary of the SPD and the leader of its parliamentary party that details from her past were likely to emerge if she joined the cabinet.

That means Mr Schröder decided to brave the inevitable row at a time when he already knew that his foreign ministerwas under pressure.

Earlier this month photographs were published of Joschka Fischer beating a fallen policeman during a demonstration. Mr Fischer admitted yesterday that he had seen fear in the eyes of the officer. Tomorrow he is due to give evidence at the trial on terrorism charges of an old friend from the 1970s.

Some of the ghosts that have returned to haunt Ms Schmidt were conjured up from the same tumultuous decade.

At the end of the 70s she worked in her native Aachen as a waitress in two bars owned by her elder sister. One of them was raided by the police, who took away 14 pornographic films, Bild am Sonntag said. The police took Ms Schmidt's personal details but no charges were brought against her.

In an interview with Der Spiegel to be published today, the divorced Ms Schmidt is quoted as saying: "I was a student and single mother and I had to earn money. So I was happy that once a week I could work as a waitress in my sister's place".

After she stood for parliament in 1990 a former partner of her sister was prosecuted for blackmail after threatening to reveal details of her past.

Four years later she faced difficulties on the arrest of a Social Democrat MEP who had become involved in a counterfeiting scam after running up gambling debts.

Ms Schmidt was found to have guaranteed a number of loans to her friend, for which she then became liable. Bild am Sonntag said she was forced to pledge DM10,000 (£3,200) from her monthly salary to one bank and hand over two insurance policies and her BMW car to another.

Ms Schmidt made her name as a leading figure in the tough and still-unresolved negotiations to reform Germany's pension system.

Her appointment, and that of Ms Künast as agriculture minister, were seen as Mr Schröder's attempt to use women to restore public trust.

The arrival of BSE in November has had a traumatic effect in a country of big meat eaters repeatedly assured by the government that German farms were free of it.

webTitle: Analysis: ad hoc international tribunals are proliferating

fields.headline: Mushrooming courts
fields.standfirst: It is taking longer than expected to set up an international court to deal with genocide and war crimes - but ad hoc tribunals proliferate
fields.trailText: It is taking longer than expected to set up an international court to deal with genocide and war crimes - but ad hoc tribunals proliferate.
fields.body:
The Lockerbie trial at Camp Zeist, now winding up, is an example of how complex efforts to bring abusers of human rights to trial have become. Even if an overarching international criminal court (ICC) got off the ground, the architecture of rights would still look far from simple.

The Lockerbie case - the judges have now retired to consider a charge against two Libyans of murdering the 270 people killed on Pan Am flight 103 in 1988 - is being tried in a Scottish court, temporarily situated in the Netherlands. This was the result of a compromise between governments approved by the UN security council.

In addition there are criminal tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda, which have been laying the foundations of a truly international criminal law. One is based in The Hague; the other has trial chambers in Tanzania and Rwanda and an appeal chamber in The Hague. International judges have been sent to Kosovo to provide objective justice and a war and ethnic crimes court has been set up there as a "national" court. The US has been pushing for an international tribunal to try Saddam Hussein for a long list of atrocities. A mixed domestic-international criminal tribunal is being established in Cambodia to try former leaders of the Khmer Rouge. And some form of international tribunal is being considered for East Timor.

Progress is being made on the permanent ICC agreed at a UN-sponsored conference in Rome in 1998. Its jurisdiction would extend to genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and eventually aggression. Some 139 countries have so far signed the proposed treaty establishing the court - at the end of last year President Clinton added an American signature, followed by Israel. But the ICC will only come into being after the Rome statute has been formally ratified by 60 states. American ratification will now depend on the Republicans in White House and Senate - unlikely. So far, in terms of ratifications, we are just under half the way there.

Last autumn Sierra Leone became the 20th state to ratify - a month after the security council asked the UN secretary-general to negotiate an agreement with the Sierra Leone government for an independent special court with jurisdiction over crimes against humanity. The special court will also apply Sierra Leonean law.

These varied tribunals differ not only in the way in they strike a balance between international and domestic law but also how they were set up. The Yugoslavia and Rwanda tribunals are subsidiary organs of the UN security council; the Kosovo court is part of the UN mission (civil presence) in Kosovo; and the tribunals for Cambodia and Sierra Leone are to be established "by agreement" with the UN.

This proliferation may simply be a phase in the development of mechanisms for enforcing international criminal law; things may calm down once the ICC is up and running. There may be good reasons for establishing different forms of tribunal - such as respect for the wishes of the state or states directly affected, goals of peace and reconciliation, world order and cost. However, it is likely that all these tribunals will be operating simultaneously for years to come, with the risk of conflicting interpretations of the law, confused applications of a mix of domestic and international rules of substantive and procedural criminal law, prejudice to the accused, and the use of funds that could have been channelled into the domestic legal systems of the countries concerned.

The jurisdiction of the ICC will not be retrospective and will be complementary to that of national courts. Since its terms of reference will be restricted, there is no guarantee that its establishment will halt the mushrooming of options for international criminal justice.

There is a legitimate concern that the ICC will be effective only if powerful states states sign up. The US joined China, Libya, Israel, Qatar and Yemen in voting against the Rome statute despite having played a pivotal role in founding the tribunals for former Yugoslavia and Rwanda. Although the Rome agreement took on many of the Americans' stated objectives, they maintained it posed an unacceptable risk that politically-motivated charges would be brought against US officials and military personnel, which might in turn curtail the deployment of US forces worldwide to protect global interests.

Since then, the US has sought to limit ICC powers and competence and reverse delicate compromises reached in Rome. At the same time, it wants to ensure that the citizens of recalcitrant states are not beyond the reach of any court's jurisdiction. Because the ICC might constrain American ability to shape the future of international criminal justice, the likelihood is that ad hoc measures under the control of the UN security council will continue to be pursued in the future.

After the establishment of the international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia in 1993 it seemed as if events were moving logically in the direction of an overarching ICC. But the new "mixed" tribunals are in some respects a step backwards - and it remains to be seen how all these institutions will co-exist. Can the tremendous efforts now being made be reconciled so that the result is a uniform system of enforcing international criminal law?

Despite the sense of disorientation, the creation of all these tribunals is epoch-making. The ICC is the product of a strand of idealistic thinking about justice between states stretching back at least to the first world war. With it, international criminal justice is acquiring an attractive new face.

 Nina Jorgensen is a researcher at the University of Leiden (the Netherlands) and author of The Responsibility of States for International Crimes (Oxford University Press, £50, published last autumn). Nils-Johan.Jorgensen@dar.norad.no

webTitle: Wanted: map for the IT recruitment maze

fields.headline: Wanted: map for the IT recruitment maze
fields.standfirst: NetNews
fields.trailText: We are on the recruitment trail again. At a time where much of the e-business news is dominated by company closures and staff lay-offs it feels good to be bucking the trend and building the team again after a couple of months' pause.
fields.body:
We are on the recruitment trail again. At a time where much of the e-business news is dominated by company closures and staff lay-offs it feels good to be bucking the trend and building the team again after a couple of months' pause.

Given the general depression surrounding the new-media environment we have been pleasantly surprised at the continued enthusiasm of potential recruits.

However, candidates are spending more time assessing us than they were doing six months ago. We spent as much time in a two-hour first interview with one candidate reviewing our business model, the market environment and company culture as we did evaluating him and his previous work.

Even disappointing personal experiences do not appear to have put some off dot.com start-ups. Our latest recruit has joined from a substantial internet exchange that went bust three weeks ago. You have to move quickly to get these guys because they are highly valued, not only for their specific expertise - in this case web design - but also for their direct experience of working in small, growing businesses.

The performance of many of the recruitment agencies that we have come across over the past six months has been consistent. Despite promises of a deep understanding of our needs and sophisticated filtering of potential candidates, our recruitment manager is still bombarded with wildly inappropriate CVs. These are regularly followed up with phone calls, further expounding on respective candidates' virtues and suitability.

But there are some exceptions and we are learning to work with these few recruitment partners.

The need to find decent recruitment agencies is all the greater at present because a focus is on building up the technical team - a real challenge. Though there is a good pool of contractors prepared to work on a short-term freelance basis, there are far fewer people looking for full-time work. This is partly because the market for contractors is so strong at the moment. Companies are being asked to pay more than £500 a day for a good freelance developer.

But it is the full-timers that we are after because we are building up the core technical competency within the business. By taking our time and sticking to our guns - even when advised by several IT recruitment agencies that it would prove impossible - we believe we have succeeded in finding the right people.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the founders of rools, an online payments service for teenagers

webTitle: Leader: Policing the peace in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Policing the peace
fields.standfirst:
The SDLP must reject a boycott

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The SDLP must reject a boycott
fields.body:
Between now and May all domestic politics will be pushed out of shape by the impending election, but nowhere will this deformation be worse than in Northern Ireland. The tightrope act of keeping the peace process alive will be made doubly precarious by Ulster unionism's growing tensions and competition for votes between the SDLP and Sinn Fein.

There is another piece of bad luck so far as timing is concerned. The run-up to the election coincides with one of the most crucial stages of peace process choreography: the implementation of the changes in the policing of Northern Ireland recommended by Chris Patten and his commission. That was always going to be hard. It may prove impossible to achieve at a time of political grandstanding.

The dilemma facing nationalists is whether to endorse the Police Service of Northern Ireland, which - while a huge advance on the Royal Ulster Constabulary - is in many respects a watered-down version of what Mr Patten and his team had in mind. The commission members themselves seem to be divided on whether the new arrangements are acceptable. One of them, Clifford Shearing, stated plainly last November that the police bill "does not fulfil the hopes and vision of the Belfast agreement... it is not a new beginning. It will not serve the people of Northern Ireland." Mr Patten, while not endorsing every element of the act, urged all parties to encourage people in their communities to join the new police service and to make it work. His words were echoed by another commission member, Maurice Hayes, who said to the SDLP and Sinn Fein: "It is not leadership to retire into a cul-de-sac."

Mr Hayes's words will fall on deaf ears in Sinn Fein, which continues to reject the new force. The position of the SDLP thus becomes crucial. Were its leaders also to counsel young Catholics against joining the new police service it would make it all but impossible to achieve the bill's requirement of police recruitment on a basis of 50/50 Protestant/Catholic.

Electoral politics kick in at this point. SDLP leaders fear that appearing to be out-hawked by Sinn Fein - which is stronger than at at any time since the hunger strikes - will cost them votes. They are unhappy about a number of organisational issues, including the future of the Gough Barracks interrogation centre and the timetable for merging Special Branch and CID and the phasing out of the full-time reserves. They distrust the arrangements for settling the so-called "cultural" issues of cap badges and flags. There are many bits of unfinished business they want to see rigorously investigated, such as the murders of Rosemary Nelson, Pat Finucane and Robert Hamill.

The SDLP leadership will - and should - continue to press for concessions on these and other points. In the end, though, they will be faced with the decision of whether to nor to nominate political representatives to the police board, which is due to be in place by the end of the month.

Unsatisfactory though the Police Act was, it is doubtful that a boycott of the new policing service would achieve anything beyond further destabilisation of the peace process. The SDLP should fight the nationalist corner, but it should do so from inside the tent. Electorally, it can point to the concessions it has already won by democratic engagement and legitimately demand of Sinn Fein what that party has achieved by pure rejectionism. Too much is at stake to play politics with the policing of Northern Ireland at this late stage of the game.

webTitle: Plea to open up Heathrow Atlantic flights

fields.headline: Plea to open up Heathrow Atlantic flights
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Airline passengers and UK business interests are being seriously harmed by the government's anti-competitive policy towards transatlantic flights from Heathrow.
fields.body:
Airline passengers and UK business interests are being seriously harmed by the government's anti-competitive policy towards transatlantic flights from Heathrow, the Institute of Directors says in a report published today.

It says strong evidence exists to suggest that the government has been deliberately obstructing an agreement with the US which would allow complete freedom for airlines to travel between Britain and America.

The IoD says that Britain should now sign an "open skies" agreement with the US. Only British Airways and Virgin are allowed to operate transatlantic flights from Heathrow, and there are severe restrictions on the number of US carriers flying to Heathrow.

Graeme Leach, the IoD's chief economist, said: "If each one of our members were to take one transatlantic business-class return trip each year, they would collectively pay an extra £100m more than they would if they made the same trip from Frankfurt."

Mr Leach said that 10 European Union countries had signed a liberalisation deal with the US. British flag carriers offered a superior service and did not need to fear liberalisation.

The report says that government policy was geared towards the maintenance of a market share for BA and Sir Richard Branson's airline, Virgin Atlantic. But the policy was very costly for consumers and national competitiveness.

fields.headline: Email: Amelia Gentleman@Staroaleyskoe
fields.trailText: Experienced Siberian drivers know when a storm is about to break. The snow on the road is lifted gently by the gathering wind and begins to curl upwards in steamy clouds.
fields.body:
Experienced Siberian drivers know when a storm is about to break. The snow on the road is lifted gently by the gathering wind and begins to curl upwards in steamy clouds. Soon it looks as if grey smoke is pouring from the soil. On the horizon trees remain motionless, their branches frozen, until suddenly they snap. It is at this point that the wise turn back home.

Roads in this part of Russia are built on a hump, with a two-metre drop on each side. When the snow is swirling it is hard to see where the track ends and the drop begins. The trail of upturned trucks and Ladas along the side of the main highway is a bleak reminder of the dangers of persisting in stormy weather. You can drive for an hour or two here without passing anything except perhaps the empty buildings of a long-deserted collective farm or the occasional squashed dog.

This is not a place to be stranded. But for us retreat was not an option. Already eight hours away from the nearest city, Barnaul, it seemed safer to continue to the remote mountain village of Staroaleyskoe.

When we arrived, the environmentalist we had come to meet was standing in the feathery blizzard. He looked worried. "Not even a drunken villager would go driving in this kind of weather," he said. We took shelter inside his shack-like office just as the wind began to groan and the sky grew dark. The bulb hanging from the ceiling became dimmer and went out, so we did the interview in the twilight. No one had any candles.

After three hours the noise of the gale was no longer simply depressing but alarming and the snow piled up higher against the shuddering window panes, transforming the village into an icy prison. "Last time it snowed like this we were stuck here from December until March," the environmentalist said.

Foreign travellers are still obliged to register with the local authorities. That evening we walked to the police station, stepping through snowdrifts, the freezing wind burning on our faces. A woman examined our papers by the light of a gas lamp and typed out forms on rough brown paper. She tried to ring the hotel to tell them we were coming but, looking doubtfully at the receiver, she said the lines were down.

It was hard to tell what kind of hotel we were staying in, because we were led, hand in hand, into total darkness. We waited in silence on a bench in what might have been the hall, listening to the battling wind, while someone searched for room keys. It soon became clear that the heating was connected to the electricity and the radiators faded from tepid to chilled. Outside, the temperature hovered at minus 30. The hotel had no food, and the village canteen was closed because of the power cut. We went to bed hungry and lay in our coats, still wearing our gloves, hats and boots; the noise of the howling storm made it impossible to sleep.

At midnight the management decided it was about time the prostitutes finished up for the night and ejected them, with much door-banging and shouting, into the blizzard.

The sky was a deep grey in the morning, but the snow had stopped and the deep drifts had frozen. During the night the school roof had blown away and several houses had burnt down. Determined not to spend the entire winter in this backwater, our driver decided it would be possible to drive back on the hardened snow without waiting for tractors to clear the road.

Before we could leave, we had to visit the deputy mayor, to avoid offending the local administration. He spoke at length and with great passion about Arsenal's recent humiliation in Moscow. It would be sensible, he said at last, to take a 150-mile detour on our way back to avoid the worst of the roads - a trifling distance to Siberians. His assistant wrapped chunks of smoked pig fat in newspaper to keep us alive in an emergency.

webTitle: Peter Preston: the Bush administration wants Star Wars

fields.headline: Yes, it's a fine strong boy - the son of Star Wars
fields.standfirst:
We need to face up to the fact that the Bush administration want this

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: We need to face up to the fact that the Bush administration want this
fields.body:
The old president, hip broken, mind tragically blank, lies almost forgotten in a Santa Monica hospital bed: yet his dream lives. And the resilience of Ronald Reagan's dream cannot any longer be brushed aside. Like the latest PlayStation or the newest Man U strip, there is always "progress": which means that there will be a Son of Star Wars. It is not, of course, going to be an easy sell - especially here. The original version, with Ronnie playing Luke Skywalker and Gorbachev bizarrely cast as Darth Vader, was always a public relations disaster here (like Frankenstein foods). George W is not, perhaps, the "son" most immediate residents of Fylingdales would have in mind - nor William Hague his ideal uncle. But it is also time to be realistic. The question is no longer whether, just when and how. The hanging chads have settled it.

Donald Rumsfeld, George Bush's defence secretary, was chairman, three years ago, of the definitive National Missile Defence commission which spurred Bill Clinton into half-hearted action. To see him emerge, second time round, on top of a Republican Pentagon is to see the future laid out before us. Rumsfeld believes in the clear, present or imminent, danger of "rogue states" - North Korea, Iran, Iraq - with nuclear missiles. Accordingly, America must have NMD. The anti-ballistic missile treaty of 1972 that stands in the way is, as he told his Senate confirmation hearing, "ancient history".

An interesting phrase, cutting both ways. Lord Roy Mason of Barnsley was Harold Wilson's defence secretary in the long ago when Gerald Ford first gave Rumsfeld the job. Even so, it's fair enough to indulge in a little archeological excavation. The ancient world of 1972, of Warsaw pact and Nato, has vanished just as surely as the world where the Shah and Saddam were the staunchest of western allies.

Why, indeed, not think afresh? That's what Tony Blair, learning the bitter lessons of the Balkans, has done over a European rapid reaction force. (Rumsfeld says American troops are coming out of Kosovo: "I've concluded over a period of years that the US isn't a good peacekeeper.") Why, indeed, not adjust to a 21st century in which the European Union is an economic competitor of Washington whose defence concerns cannot be wholly ordained from inside a distant beltway?

Why? Because any revised thinking in such areas is complicated, liable to disturb fustian concepts like the "special relationship" (words you curiously never hear invoked in DC). Ronald Reagan, perforce, had a better way. If you're selling anything new, if you're piling on extra billions of tax dollars, you have to keep it simple. Star Wars, in his bumbling, picket-fence version, was simple: a hi-tech security blanket that would keep Americans safe from alien harm. Son of Star Wars precisely replicates that pitch.

It discerns a threat - from North Korea sometime in the next 10 years, from Iran in the next 15, from Iraq in 20 (Rumsfeld commission figures) - and provides a response. It does not explicitly say that Russia, China and the Ukraine might lurk somewhere behind that thinking because, in a world conditioned by manic Hollywood villains, that would be complicated. It does not pause to explain why Pakistani or Indian nukes should always be friendly ones, and thus excluded from the reckoning.

Keep the threat simple. Make it - as Rumsfeld does - the technological alternative to deploying American boys in overseas wars, where they might get sponged by their own depleted uranium. See how cheaply such safety may be bought? "I don't personally believe that it involves much financial implication -" What's $60bn when AoL-Time Warner is worth double that? A few gallant souls on Capitol Hill have their objections, of course. They point out that North Korea is changing hugely, that any self-respecting terrorist state would probably ship its bombs to Chicago in a suitcase, that the moment you set up a small shield is the moment your enemies (if any) seek ways to find ways around it. They preach of self-delusion. But we ought to be clear that the two central arguments currently deployed against NMD aren't going to run.

One (with a long history of embarrassing failure) says the technology isn't there yet. It won't work. But Americans believe in making things work: the argument is a spur to greater effort, not a blocker. The other (with an equally long and dismal record) says Rumsfeld is wrong and that the project will, in reality, cost squillions. Of course. But that cash will go to some of the Republicans' biggest corporate donors - and to the interests served on Pork Barrel Hill. Start, and they won't stop.

In sum, if Tony Blair believes that somehow this Son won't happen, that the question about Fylingdales will never be put, he deludes himself. William Hague's pygmy interventions - snuggling up to George W, driving another surrogate stake into the European Union - are only the beginning. Mute delay isn't an option. Mr Blair must see (already) how tempting the supposed security blanket can be made to sound. Graciously extend it to cover us and we're happy. Instead, he needs to say something early - and simple.

Not impossible. 1972 may be ancient history, but Russia's 6,000 strategic missiles aren't. Abrogate the ABM treaty and bang goes Start 2 (article two, paragraph two), which is an umbilical part of the process reducing those warheads. Who wants to jettison Start 3 and the reduction to 2,000? Where's the security in that? Who can blame not just Britain, but all western Europe, for backing the idea if - and only if - Russia accepts NMD? And, of course, no one wants to cling barrenly to a hoary treaty conceived in quite other times. Let there be a new treaty which deals with the realities of a new millennium. Call for Colin Powell.

Rogue states, for what they're worth? Why not (as Senator John Kerry asks) go the US Navy way with theatre- wide defence systems that could specifically knock out Taepo-Dong Two's as they left North Korea - not rely on catching up with them much later? Easier, though not yet fully developed, technology: a specific response to a specific threat.

If security is the aim, if like most Americans you want and will pay for such security, then this is the way forward. A big tent, not a narrow blanket. Does any of it make your heart leap with joy? Not really. But observe how the weevils work, how our MoD is already reportedly "more enthusiastic" about NMD than our Foreign Office. Boys need their toys. Voters need their palliatives. George W Bush and Donald Rumsfeld will have their inquiries, their plans and their "great debate". That's a debate - for Europe and for Russia - that we can't bow out of. It's starting. Can we please begin clearing our throats?

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article headed Isolation hospitals, pages 10 and 11, Online, January 11, we referred to the number of GPs connected to NHSnet, the NHS's private network, and stated that "... only about 50% of GPs are connected". We have been asked to say that, in fact, more than 80% of practices are now connected to NHSnet. On January 10 a total of 7,320 GP practices (83%) had an NHSnet line installed.
fields.body:
In an article headed Isolation hospitals, pages 10 and 11, Online, January 11, we referred to the number of GPs connected to NHSnet, the NHS's private network, and stated that "... only about 50% of GPs are connected". We have been asked to say that, in fact, more than 80% of practices are now connected to NHSnet. On January 10 a total of 7,320 GP practices (83%) had an NHSnet line installed.

 In our G2 lead story on the Kumbh Mela at Allahabad, January 10, we correctly recorded in the text that the festival takes place every three years, at four venues that take turns, but a heading may have suggested the festival occurred every 12 years. It happens every 12 years at Allahabad and at each of the other venues in a three-year rotation.

 Judge John Deed, Television review, page 22, G2, January 10, was beset by enemies in the Lord Chancellor's department, rather than the Lord Chamberlain's department.

 Contrary to what we said in a piece on the newspaper, The Namibian (pages 8 and 9, Media, January 8), Namibia was not "the last colony on African soil". In fact, the Spanish colonies of Ceuta and Melilla still exist on Morocco's Mediterranean littoral.

 In an article on organic farming, page 8, Society, January 10, it was suggested that organic farmers did not use pesticides. They do, frequently, but only those derived from natural sources. They are not allowed to use synthetic ones.

 Apologies to fans of our Doonesbury strip cartoon who last week felt they were travelling over familiar ground. Gary Trudeau was unable to provide the strip last week and Universal Syndication (his American agents) reran strips from last April, neglecting to point out to us that that was what they were doing. Normal service resumes today.

webTitle: Creditors have little to celebrate

fields.headline: Creditors have little to celebrate
fields.standfirst: Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: The end of 2000 was marked with mutual backslapping by rich country governments and international financial institutions.
fields.body:
The end of 2000 was marked with mutual backslapping by rich country governments and international financial institutions. Self-imposed deadlines had been met as 22 countries entered the latest debt scheme - the enhanced heavily indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC). But for debt campaigners the new year was a missed opportunity for cancelling the poorest countries' unpayable debts.

Creditors agree that the rationale for debt reduction is poverty reduction. But they accept no obligation to write off the debt necessary to finance poverty reduction or to meet development targets of halving global poverty by the year 2015.

For creditors, debt relief is more about how much debtor countries can afford to pay, taking export earnings as the principal measure of debt sustainability. So there is an asymmetry between ends and means at the heart of the creditors' debt relief project. They are committed to debtor countries meeting the 2015 development targets, but will not use these benchmarks to decide how much debt cancellation governments need.

For Cafod, social justice and good economics are inseparable. The more stable variable by which to judge the capacity of a country to repay its debts is the incidence and depth of poverty.

Debt sustainability should be judged on the revenue governments can feasibly earn without further punishing the poor or developing distortions in the economy. How much government income is it reasonable to use for servicing debt?

Having calculated a government's feasible revenue, there is a trade-off between meeting debt servicing obligations and financing poverty reduction expenditures needed to meet the 2015 targets. The funding of poverty reduction should take precedence over meeting external debt servicing obligations.

Government revenues are limited by both the extent and the depth of poverty. It is not reasonable to tax those earning less than a dollar a day, and this means that the slice of taxable GDP taken by the government is limited. Even if countries managed to raise the figure to 25% of GDP - and in reality they are unlikely to get close to this - it is clear that for most HIPCs these revenues would be dwarfed by the costs of meeting the 2015 targets, such as universal access to primary health care and primary education.

But also, if the depth of poverty - the amount by which the very poorest fall below the one dollar a day threshold - is taken into account as a shortfall in people's income that can be alleviated or reduced by government financed programmes, then for all HIPCs there will be no residual government revenue available for debt servicing.

According to Cafod's calculations, most highly indebted poor countries need not only 100% debt cancellation but also substantially increased levels of grant aid. The choice for creditors is simple: either cancel enough debt to help the world's poorest countries meet development goals of halving poverty or carry on with self-congratulation over piecemeal debt write-offs.

 Henry Northover is a policy analyst with the aid agency Cafod

webTitle: Letters: Bogus deal

fields.headline: Bogus deal
fields.trailText: Your article (Labour to renew poll pledges, January 11) highlights Labour's failure to achieve its pledge to cut class sizes and to speed up youth justice.
fields.body:
Your article (Labour to renew poll pledges, January 11) highlights Labour's failure to achieve its pledge to cut class sizes and to speed up youth justice. You wrongly imply however, that the other three pledges have been met.

The government has itself commissioned research and evaluation on the "new deal", which shows that up to 80% of those going into jobs from the new deal would have gone into work without Labour's £750m scheme. Labour has missed its target by 200,000. The government's claim to have achieved its new deal pledge is entirely bogus.
Graham Brady MP
Shadow minister for Education and Employment

webTitle: Leader: Channel hopping

fields.headline: Channel hopping
fields.standfirst: A French department buys an English port
fields.trailText: A French department buys an English port.
fields.body:
It looks as if the purchase of Newhaven harbour by Seine-Maritime, the French department embracing Rouen and Dieppe, will go ahead. A bit of the French state is buying what was once a bit of the British state (the port was in the nationalised docks industry until the mid-80s). There is something rich, too, in the fact that Newhaven is being sold into state control by a company that was once one of Margaret Thatcher's entrepreneurial pin-ups, Sea Containers.

The Dieppois hope to re-establish freight and passenger links with Newhaven to revive their own port - there is now only a much-reduced service for tourists between the two, and that only in high season. Though the French bid is backed by private-sector money, it is a bold piece of public-sector enterprise, reflecting the extensive economic development powers now devolved from Paris to the regions. It is hard to imagine one of John Prescott's regional development agencies doing anything as big.

Five years ago, Vera Lynn was recruited to fend off a French bid for the Dover docks by singing about the white cliffs. The Newhavenites are sanguine. That may be because they live in a run-down corner of the otherwise prosperous south-east and need all the jobs they can get. Perhaps it is force of habit: in East Sussex the French already own water and (none too happily) Connex trains. If French managers can run Arsenal FC and the dome, they might well make a go of Newhaven.

If this is globalisation, let us have more. In the 19th century, liberal optimists such as Cobden and Bright believed capitalist enterprise across national boundaries was a recipe for international accord. If your armaments industry is owned by your neighbour and you own your neighbour's rolling stock, it ought to be harder to make war. The doctrine took a fair battering in 1914, but mutual dependence remains an attractive prospect, amended to include state ownership of each other's assets.

webTitle: Letters: Truth about Pat Finucane

fields.headline: Truth about Pat Finucane
fields.trailText: Nick Hopkins suggests (Innocent victim of Ulster's dirty war, January 13) that if William Stobie goes before a jury there "is likely to be a furious debate over abuse of process". This argument currently has three flaws...
fields.body:
William Stobie, who will claim he is a former RUC special branch agent, is now charged with aiding and abetting the murder of solicitor Pat Finucane. Nick Hopkins suggests (Innocent victim of Ulster's dirty war, January 13) that if the case gets before a jury there "is likely to be a furious debate over abuse of process" and the intriguing prospect of "an extraordinary insight into the murky world of counter intelligence".

This argument currently has three flaws: first, the secretary of state would in all likelihood use public interest immunity to prevent the critical documents being made available to the courts. Second, the government would continue to injunct any newspaper from telling this story.Third, despite a commitment to reform Northern Ireland's criminal justice system, the government refuses to contemplate any reform of the Diplock no-jury courts, let alone restore the right to trial by jury.

This is why relatives of Pat Finucane, the Irish government and the international human rights community continue to demand an independent judicial inquiry with the power to establish the truth and end the culture of impunity that has feather-bedded the security services.

Martin Collins
Britain & Ireland Human Rights Centre Rapporteur@compuserve.com

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Breakdown | Greystoke: The Legend Of Tarzan, Lord Of The Apes | Night Of The Living Dead | The Cable Guy
fields.body:
Breakdown

(Jonathan Mostow, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Married couple Kurt Russell and Kathleen Quinlan's jeep breaks down in the middle of nowhere, USA, and passing trucker JT Walsh gives Kathleen a lift to a diner while Kurt fixes the car. When he reaches the meeting place, Walsh and assorted rednecks deny ever seeing his wife. Like George Sluizer's The Vanishing, Mostow's unsettling thriller builds an air of taut menace around the disappearance; but here, lurking underneath Russell's east coast sophisticate is an action hero, and a violent reckoning approaches.

Greystoke: The Legend Of Tarzan, Lord Of The Apes

(Hugh Hudson, 1984)

9pm, TCM

Hudson's handsomely shot adventure adheres closely to Edgar Rice Burroughs' original story, combining vivid jungle action, as the infant boy makes his way in the ape family, and a deft portrait of Edwardian England, when the grown apeman is returned to his stately home. Christopher Lambert manages the physical side of Tarzan well, though the acting is primitive; and with Andie MacDowell a vapid Jane, Ralph Richardson has no trouble stealing the movie as Tarzan's moist-eyed grandad.

Night Of The Living Dead

(George A Romero, 1968)

12midnight, FilmFour

Romero's classic, dirt-cheap, monochrome cult shocker changed the ghastly face of horror movies into something altogether creepier. In the new moral order, goodies and baddies alike meet gruesome fates, and there's a gathering sense of impending doom for the dwindling survivors.

The Cable Guy

(Ben Stiller, 1996)

2.25am, FilmFour

Nightmare scenario: get the cable guy to install a little extra on the TV, and next thing it's impossible to get rid of him. Matthew Broderick, as the prim Steven, and a bordering-on-insanity Jim Carrey as the cable guy, a disturbed character formed from a neglected life in front of the TV, couldn't be better. A wild comedy, with "friends" in a medieval theme restaurant, fighting with axes and things - for real.

webTitle: Work experience

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Jack Lemmon in It Should Happen To You (George Cukor, 1954)

Who? Only one of the greatest comic actors ever. He'll probably always be best known for his winning partnerships with director Billy Wilder and actor Walter Matthau - they really were the original Odd Couple in 1968, but they also worked together on The Fortune Cookie (1966), The Front Page (1974) and - best to whisper this one - Grumpy Old Men (1993). Another great partnership, this time in drag, came alongside Tony Curtis in Some Like It Hot with Marilyn Monroe in 1959. Somewhere down the line he's managed to fit in a few dramatic roles too - The China Syndrome (1979), JFK (1991) and, most significantly, the film adaptation of David Mamet's Glengarry Glen Ross (1992), where he acted the likes of Kevin Spacey and Al Pacino off the screen. In short, the man's a legend.

The role: Pete Sheppard, a documentary film-maker who stumbles across wannabe actress Gladys (Judy Holliday) in Central Park. He falls for her, but when her face is accidentally plastered on billboards across New York, he has to fight to win her affections.

Best line: As they approach a water fountain in the park, the geeky Pete quips "Have a drink on me."

Cringe factor: Jack Lemmon has never, ever, in his entire life, done anything embarrassing.

Other wannabes: Rat Packer Peter Lawford, playing entirely to type as a slimy playboy.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin called it a "charming romantic comedy/satire."

Also not starring in: TV series Heaven For Betsy (1952), after which he re-teamed with Judy Holliday for forgotten sex comedy Phffft! (1954).

It Should Happen To You, 3pm, Saturday 20 January, Carlton Cinema

webTitle: Weekend TV

fields.headline: In from the cold
fields.trailText: A Touch of Frost | Monarch of the Glen | 2001 - The Making of a Myth
fields.body:
This was a lollipop of an idea. The pleasure, carefully savoured, lasted for some time.

A Touch of Frost (ITV) by David Gilman opened with a police line-up. Eight stubby little men were arranged for inspection by a big blonde. The shortest and the shortest-tempered was David Jason. All wore macs and moustaches. All sported perky trilbys like Jack the Hat.

George Lyttelton, father of Humphrey, was once very entertained by a hat like that. He wrote "John Betjeman's hat came in for a good deal of derision, for it was almost non-existent in depth and sat on the noble brow like the crest of a waxwing." Indeed, the eight suspects looked uncommonly like stout little sparrows on a telephone wire.

The big-bosomed blonde, who had complained of being groped by someone calling himself Inspector Frost, said "Can the short, scruffy one take his hat off?" Recognising the truth of the description, Frost did so. The big blonde shook her bosom. "No, the man who bothered me was better-looking than him and he was dressed smarter." Frost appeared torn between relief and offence.

It was like an off-colour version of Snow White.

The fake Frost's activities may have been more serious than we supposed. At the end of the first episode, a girl (last seen leaving Coronation Street with a strange cult ) arrived saying "From what Mum told me, I think you're my Dad." Mum was surely mistaken. Frost, though chummy enough, is like a prisoner in solitary confinement. Something about him, as the title suggests, has been blasted, stunted, scorched by a killing frost. Perhaps it was the bullet in the head. He often unconsciously touches the scar. Like John Thaw's Morse, David Jason's Frost can suggest a hinterland of such Antarctic bleakness that you put on another jumper.

Richard Briers plays the old laird of Glenbogle in Monarch of the Glen (BBC 1). The man is 90% batty with flashes of astuteness. Yesterday, when interviewing a prospective ranger, he suddenly said shrewdly, "I don't believe all this flannel."

None of us do. Monarch of the Glen is 100% tartan flannel. The Highlands are heart-stoppingly lovely. The castle looks as if it is twirled out of barley sugar. Even the new ranger is beautiful, particularly when diving naked into a pool by a waterfall. A most unwise thing to do as he has (he says) just donated a kidney to a sick brother. Could I have a closer look at the scar just to check his references? A great deal of golden production has been poured over this, like syrup on waffle, so it should suit a sweet tooth or a satiric eye.

In Arthur C Clarke's garden in Sri Lanka is a flat, black slab, the baby brother of the mysterious monolith in Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. A monkey was making repeated efforts to climb it, failing to find a paw-hold on the smooth surface and falling back. Remembering the opening of the film... the monolith... the apes... I found this downright eerie but, then, most people don't have monkeys and monoliths in their garden.

In 2001 - The Making of a Myth (Channel 4), Clarke, who wrote the original story, was talking about Hal, the psychotic computer. He said "Everyone who's had a laptop knows perfectly well computers can have a personality. Will a computer become conscious? I think, therefore I am... I think." Clarke, like Hal, can sometimes sound a little disturbing. "All that happens if you're exposed to space is that you feel a freezing sensation. And, of course, you die."

Kubrick was boldly going and not everyone felt like following. Ed Bishop, who played the spaceship captain, said "I wasn't on his wavelength. We'd get to the point when he'd say 'Good morning' and I'd wonder what he meant. We're not talking Greek tragedy here. The extent to which he ground the sausage was, I thought, a little excessive."

Doug Trumbull helped create that waltzing world and is now one of the world's greatest special effects artists. Sitting beside the sea, he said "I miss him a lot. It never occured to me that Stanley would die, that I would have to be on this planet without Stanley in 2001."

You could engrave that poignant human cry on a black monolith to puzzle future space travellers. "It never occured to me that Stanley would die."
