webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Rocks of ages: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District
fields.body:
My unexpected achievement in reaching 90 years of age today is largely due, I'm convinced, to almost 80 years of active involvement with mountains. Thousands of days of fresh air, wind and rain, sunshine and snow, can't have done me much harm and, for a long lifetime, there's been the exhilaration of the heights - even if they're only little hills now. It started as a small boy in school uniform, walking from Foxfield railway station to the top of Stickle Pike and back, and clearly remembering the pungent, sweet scent of woodsmoke sniffed from some farm near Broughton Mills. And today, the scent of woodsmoke always takes me back to lovely Dunnerdale. Soon afterwards, as a family, we went up Black Combe. Again, we had no boots, map or compass, and my father, the leader, had never been up a hill in his life before, but we just clambered up until there was nowhere higher to go.

My main memory of that trip is of looking down from the summit on the fields and villages, the Furness peninsular spread out below us like a map. That was the start of my continued interest in maps, especially mountain maps. Hundreds of hills and mountains were enjoyed in the following years, and then, in the late 1920s, I started rock and snow climbing and, some years later, skiing. Before foot problems restricted activities, I completed 60 adventurous years of climbing and more than 40 years of skiing. But enough about me. I'm afraid we nonagenarians do go on a bit. But I'm more fortunate than most, for I've managed to live within sight of hills for most of my life and intend to crawl about on them for as long as I can, God willing.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: From Crocodile Dung To Electrocution | Nature: Wind
fields.body:
Such is the fecundity of the human race, you could throw a thimbleful of sperm into a shoebox of ova and double the world's present population. So it's not surprising that our history has been so littered with ways to achieve pleasure without consequence. As Caroline Quentin (pictured) recounts all this week in From Crocodile Dung To Electrocution (3.45pm, Radio 4), the Egyptians thought up some pretty eye-watering contraceptives as far back as 1850BC. And you'll be amazed what the 20th century found to do with Coca Cola.

We rarely pay attention to the wind unless it ruins our picnic. Yet, as Mark Carwardine points out in Nature: Wind (9pm, Radio 4), it's one of the greatest natural influences on our life. It can carry plant and animal diseases thousands of miles, but can also serve as a great healer. Some of the woodland damaged in the 1987 hurricane created welcome new habitats for threatened butterflies.

webTitle: Mark Lawson on The West Wing

fields.headline: Office politics
fields.trailText: When the schedules were put together in the autumn, it looked like a smart move for television to inaugurate its screening of the American political hit The West Wing (Thursday, 10pm, C4) two days before the new US president takes his oath of office.
fields.body:
When the schedules were put together in the autumn, it looked like a smart move for television to inaugurate its screening of the American political hit The West Wing (Thursday, 10pm, C4) two days before the new US president takes his oath of office. Now, though, you wonder if this brilliant political fiction (previously seen in Britain only by Sky One's tiny constituency) will suffer here from the intervening realities. Channel 4 may have needed a Gore victory.

Although it contains sharp general truths about power, The West Wing is a Clinton-era piece: a Democrat fantasy about a leader with Bill's brains and charm but not his loins.

Martin Sheen's Josiah Bartlett is a Nobel-winning economist who speaks Latin and whose one dark secret (he has slow-burn multiple sclerosis) invites sympathy rather than censure. Part of the fascination of The West Wing, when it was premiered in America, was the sense that you were watching Clinton's better twin, a projection of his possibilities.

Viewed during the second Bush presidency, The West Wing will be a very different experience. Bartlett could be related to Dubya only as a distant cousin from a smart branch of the family with whom the Bushes feuded during an oil deal. Ironically, given President Bartlett's liking for quoting Cicero in the original, there's even an established Dubya joke about his thinking Latin is the language they speak in Latin America.

So, for British admirers, The West Wing will become Clinton nostalgia rather than Clinton critique. But the gossipy, knowledgeable plots remain and the teasing storytelling is a delight. Note in particular the second episode, which hinges on the American Ryder Cup team refusing to meet the President because of a joke he made. The careful with-holding of what the gag was - and the aides' sneaky but obsequious attempts to warn the President about his sense of humour - are typical of this landmark show's wit.

webTitle: Mark Lawson on Blood on the Carpet

fields.headline: The sound and the fury
fields.standfirst: Blood on the Carpet, the BBC's racy series on great corporate crises, turns the spotlight inward this week to tackle 1993's revamp of Radio 1. Can this be an objective appraisal?  Mark Lawson investigates
fields.trailText: Blood on the Carpet, the BBC's racy series on great corporate crises, turns the spotlight inward this week to tackle 1993's revamp of Radio 1. Can this be an objective appraisal? Mark Lawson investigates.
fields.body:
Anyone involved in the production of programmes for the BBC, and keen for their career to continue, knows that there are three subjects which should be treated on screen with particular care: the royal family (though, these days, only the Queen and Queen Mother), Northern Ireland, and developments within the BBC itself. More Oxbridge graduates' five-year plans have been reversed by the reporting of stories in these areas than any other. The executive with prospects will generally, as the jargon has it, "refer upwards" any contentious pieces on these themes.

But the hardest of the three is, by common consent, the BBC.

When Sir John Harvey-Jones suggested that his BBC2 business consultancy series Troubleshooter might next conduct an internal examination of the Corporation, they suddenly ran out of camera-film. Admittedly, self-criticism is generally a weak point in the media. Keen newspaper readers may have noticed that every title reports some kind of rise in circulation each month, although the overall market is falling. This is a result of what President-elect Bush likes to call "fuzzy math". And it's certainly true that the BBC reported the taxation arrangements of John Birt more fully than, for example, The Times would wish to examine the revenue set-up of Rupert Murdoch.

Even so, the viewer has eyebrows on standby to rise as the business series Blood on the Carpet, a high-class abattoir of management carve-ups, turns its attention inward.

Nick Mirsky's film follows the attempt of Matthew Bannister to relaunch Radio 1 in 1993. The story of how Batesey and DLT gave way to Ginger and Danny Baker has already been told in an entertaining book by Simon Garfield, and this documentary is an unofficial and uncredited version of that tale, although it feels rather like Ronald Reagan's memoirs as filmed by the Kremlin.

Garfield's book was remarkable for the candour of those involved, including some - John Peel and Mark Radcliffe - who still work for the BBC. But, while the Corporation can't stop its employees speaking to a Faber & Faber author, it either has more control over who appears in the shows or staff are more cautious on their own doorstep. Every speaker in this Blood on the Carpet had left the BBC before transmission.

The main narrative strand tells how Matthew Bannister, revolutionising controller of Radio 1, appointed his close friend, Trevor Dann, as head of music. The fact that Bannister hired an expensive firm of head-hunters to approach Dann and offer him the job is one of the two most entertaining revelations in the film. The other is the suggestion that Chris Evans, another Bannister friend brought in to run the crucial breakfast show, was allowed a special BBC dispensation to use his own toaster on the premises. All other employees, apparently, can eat grilled bread only from machines installed by management.

A breakfast-show presenter negotiating over a toaster may be seen as the broadcasting equivalent of the emperor who makes his horse consul, and, in as much as Blood on the Carpet tries to be a management manual, it was here advising executives against strange contractual demands. The kitchen equipment clause meant that Evans wanted jam on it, and those who opposed him would be toast. When Evans fell out with Dann, Bannister fell in with Evans and sacrificed a friendship.

This tale of chums undone is amusing, but you keep waiting for the interviews with Batesey, DLT, Evans, John Birt. They never come.

It's a general curse of journalism that the writer or producer is steered towards the people who agree to speak. This problem is exacerbated in the reporting of huge institutions, because they tend to maintain an Olympian silence, while the aggrieved are only too keen to babble cathartically. A back-bencher, however idiotic, becomes an instant hero by criticising the prime minister. In the same way, almost any broadcaster sacked by the BBC receives praise from the press unimaginable while they were under contract.

The Radio 1 film contained a classic example of this problem.

Adrian Juste recalled the morning when Danny Baker made his debut as the replacement for DLT. The broadcaster formerly known as The Hairy Cornflake telephoned Juste during the show, reportedly almost in tears as he listened to the "crap" that Baker was broadcasting.

Juste admitted he was depressed too, but congratulated himself on the fact that the programmes he made during those weeks, to follow Baker's shows, were among the best he had ever done. It seems unlikely that the film-makers believe that Juste and DLT are broadcasters of genius, ludicrously removed by a crass management, but the documentary was nudged into that position by the availability of interviewees.

Brilliant on the Dome, compelling on Benetton, the BBC business programmes unit has proved inevitably weakest at the story within corridor-walking distance. Self-sufficiency is an impressive quality, but some things are best left to others. Never try to remove your own appendix. Never make a television programme about the company you work for.

webTitle: The son of Gil Evans takes on his legacy

fields.headline: Like father, like son
fields.standfirst: The legacy of the great jazz arranger Gil Evans is safe in his son's hands, says  John Fordham
fields.trailText: The legacy of the great jazz arranger Gil Evans is safe in his son's hands, says John Fordham.
fields.body:
If ever there was a definition of a hard act to follow, it's fronting a legacy band called the Gil Evans Orchestra - and if you happen to be Gil Evans's son, your name is Miles and you play pretty good trumpet, it probably makes it harder rather than easier. Evans, who died aged 75 in 1988, was the genie of jazz arrangement, whose methods were as elusive as his own wraith-like occupation of a stage. Miles Evans led the group in London last week with an awesome obligation on his quarterback's shoulders.

Gil Evans's orchestral projects with Miles Davis (Porgy and Bess, Sketches of Spain, Miles Ahead) are some of the best-known and best-loved pieces of 20th-century music. And if this self-effacing conjuror's recorded output on his own account was sparse, his work from the late 1960s was nevertheless full of sublime balances of the arts of improvisation and arrangement - as well as exhilarating showcases for the thwarted potential of the late Jimi Hendrix as a composer.

Several former sidemen from the Evans ensembles of the 1980s were present in the band that played Ronnie Scott's last week - including alto saxophonist Chris Hunter, trumpeter Lew Soloff, and trombonist Dave Bargeron. The UK's Andy Sheppard also added an exuberance reminiscent of his whirlwind emergence 15 years ago. There is, of course, one piece of essential magic they could never recapture, since Evans's influence resided so significantly in the man himself rather than in what he casually scribbled on a score-sheet.

But though the orchestra sounded occasionally as if it was echoing the ragged qualities of an old Evans live show by accident rather than by intuitive spontaneity, and the greatest-hits programme replaced much of the open, drifting impressionism that would often roll across the stage like a morning mist at the maestro's gigs, the musicians still exemplified the Evans approach, and the repertoire is one of the most uplifting in contemporary jazz. Reckless, go-for-it solos sometimes sprayed such drama and turbulence over the gathering storms of those rich arrangements and the impassioned drumming by Kenwood Dennard that the crowd burst into wild, in-the-groove shouts as if they were at a holy-rolling church service.

Lew Soloff, the witty, diminutive New Yorker with vaudevillians for parents, has been the Evans band's lead trumpet from the late 1960s, and his flame-throwing solos are still among its big attributes. Soloff was a nervous 22 when he first worked for Evans, but found his feet when he realised that Gil "didn't care whether what was written on the score was interpreted literally or not. He wanted the human-ness in it."

Evans had the lightest touch of all jazz composers, even including Duke Ellington, and would infuse a band with his whimsically visionary presence while allowing his players - and the audience - to half-believe that the glowing soundscape they had travelled through had simply risen up out of the ground. Like Ellington, Evans had a delicate antenna for the unique musical personalities of his players. The result was that, unlike the parade-ground crackle and shout of the conventionally disciplined big band, Evans's written parts sounded improvised, and the improvisers would often play above themselves in this loose, organic setting.

"A lot of this has to do with Gil's sense of unison," Soloff says. "That was a quality he shared with Ellington. A lot of people naturally hear a pitch a little high or a little low. A lot of more tightly disciplined bands blend that quality out, but Gil wanted to hear it, he wanted that rougher kind of unison of the individual voices together."

Though the Evans legacy band is inevitably a tighter unit, Soloff pays credit to Miles s sympathetic protection of his father's legacy, and says now that "to be as undisciplined as Gil would be next to impossible for somebody else". From the start, last week's show was a well- conceived tableau of the Evans story. A rich, complex reworking of the Porgy and Bess classic Gone Gone Gone appears as Orgone, the original percussive theme interpreted though a fast-moving succession of propulsive riffs mixing old and new. Soloff will subvert the expected by opening a solo on uptempo bebop with an astonishingly prolonged single note instead of the expected hailstorm. Hendrix's yearning Little Wing (an Evans-band staple since the 1970s) has its sublime moments in its heaving harmonies and Mark Egan's bass overture, and its shakier ones in Dennard's soul vocal. But that's an Evans band - not everything works and, most of the time, it doesn't matter.

"Gil would also never tell you how to play," Soloff recalls. "Though he might just have a preference for a particular soloist to go first on a particular piece, generally, he allowed anybody to solo whenever they wanted to, and he wouldn't tell them when to stop either. Sometimes it was great, sometimes it would cause havoc. People might go on too long, or else three people might jump up at once and just battle it out until the last one was left standing.

"But the guitarist Hiram Bullock brilliantly said once in an interview in Downbeat that Gil instilled a certain 'voluntary discipline' in everybody. It wasn't imposed, but the respect of all the musicians for him was so great that, mostly, they'd impose it on themselves. What he allowed to happen was a difficult and dangerous thing, and it didn't always work. But when it did, it was the best band I ever played in in my life."

webTitle: Interview: American painter Ken Aptekar

fields.headline: Power to the people
fields.standfirst: Why would an artist want a bunch of gardeners, redheads and Spanish immigrants to help him create his works?  Stuart Jeffries  finds out
fields.trailText: Why would an artist want a bunch of gardeners, redheads and Spanish immigrants to help him create his works? Stuart Jeffries finds out.
fields.body:
Why should artists have the last word about their work? What the spectator sees in a painting, and what they say about it, can be just as engaging. Some-times more so.

"Often when people come into a museum they feel restricted rather than encouraged," says the American painter Ken Aptekar. "I am trying to show that I recognise that and want to change it." What Aptekar has done, in a project called Q&A, is take works of art from the Victoria and Albert Museum's European collection - "I chose everything from the most anonymous, dusty crap languishing in the vaults to the great masterpieces" - and show them to a series of focus groups. The responses were videotaped and transcribed, with the most interesting quotations sandblasted on to sheets of glass. Then he painted copies of details from the pictures discussed and attached the glass sheets to them. The result - to be shown at the V&A - is a series of artworks that amounts to a collaboration between Aptekar, the focus group, and perhaps even the original artists themselves, in which the spectators get to talk back to the paintings.

"I had all sorts of preconceptions about the English, and Londoners in particular, and that was reflected in my choice of focus groups. I really wanted to get a group of London cabbies to spend a couple of hours in the gallery, giving me their responses. But we just couldn't get them to take the time off work. And I was really keen to get a group of gardeners to spend an afternoon with me looking at landscape paintings. In the end, we put together a focus group of gardeners with learning disabilities, which was fascinating and exasperating. One guy took about 12 minutes to give me his response to a painting, with 10 to 15 seconds between each word. But I really respected the importance he attached to getting his response over to me."

Other focus groups included redheads ("I'm a redhead myself, so I really wanted their responses"), Afro-Caribbean women ("I wanted people outside the European art tradition and museum culture"), art students ("And those who often aren't"), and middle-aged Spanish immigrants ("I wanted people whose first language wasn't English. And what I found was that, although their spoken English may not have been grammatically perfect, it was immensely expressive and more engaging as a result"). "Generally, I wanted to reflect the diversity of Londoners."

But the unexpected responses, which themselves subvert some of Aptekar's pat notions about London and Londoners, give the exhibition its vitality. One woman was shown a picture of a supposedly haunted house, and told Aptekar she had a ghost in her own home. Each night for 10 years she lit a candle to placate it. She told Aptekar that one morning the ghost came up behind her and said it didn't like tea, to which the woman replied: "It's my house now." Aptekar used this story, sandblasted the quotations and superimposed them, not on the picture of the house, but over a still-life canvas of a tea service, illuminated by several candles.

Aptekar's exhibition consists of four galleries, each with a purportedly British theme. Thus, one is called A Landscape Short on Land and consists of paintings of landscapes in which sea and sky dominate. Another is called Man's Best Friend (dog paintings); another, Who's Who, consists of portraits and figures. The final gallery is called The Thing About Tea and includes genre scenes and still lives of tea services.

Aptekar produced a similar exhibition called Talking to Pictures at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington DC a couple of years ago, which drew the attention of the Harvard professor of art history, Norman Bryson. He put Aptekar's work in the context of the death-of-the-author thesis extolled by the likes of Roland Barthes and Michel Foucault. Bryson said there had been a shift from the production of art to its reception, from the death of the author to the birth of the reader/viewer. Or, at least, we thought there had been.

"We say that such a shift took place," wrote Bryson in his analysis of the exhibition for the magazine Art in America, "but doing so may prevent us from seeing how little of the radical potential of the death-of-the-author idea has, in fact, been historically realised. If the turn from makers to receivers had truly been allowed to develop, surely by now we would have had a generation of studies analysing how viewers actually go about their business."

But because these investigations have not happened and because the artist's mystique remains intact, Aptekar's exhibitions at the Corcoran and now the V&A are explosive affairs. They roll a grenade into museums, in which, too often, only responses acknowledged as appropriate by the institution are regarded as worthwhile.

There has always been another story of art - the spectators' personal, sometimes perverse, responses. Aptekar's projects call on spectators to respond to works of art idiosyncratically, rather than encouraging them to check in their subjective perspectives and tastes before entering the gallery. In so doing, Aptekar hopes to change the balance of power between artist and spectator.

But why should Aptekar have the last word on that? What his V&A exhibition cries out for is for visitors to talk back to his paintings, to have their own idiosyncratic responses to his artistic project. And then to mount an exhibition of their own, which would be talked back to by other visitors, and then another . . . It could go on for ever.

webTitle: Duncan Campbell on life with a new identity

fields.headline: 'It is a problem remembering which part of your past you can talk about'
fields.standfirst: James Bulger's killers are to be given new identities on their release. But disappearing from view is more difficult than it might seem.  Duncan Campbell on life in the shadows
fields.trailText: James Bulger's killers are to be given new identities on their release. But disappearing from view is more difficult than it might seem.  Duncan Campbell on life in the shadows.
fields.body:
'Every time you have a drink with someone you're worried that you're going to slip up and tell them a little bit more about yourself than you should," said 'Peter'. He has spent more than seven years living on the south coast of England with a new identity arranged for him by the police after he had given evidence against two criminals. "It's not as easy as it looks in the films and it can be very lonely."

So what sorts of lives will Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the two young men who killed James Bulger, have when they are released later this year, and what are their chances of avoiding detection? The far-ranging high court ruling by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss that prohibits the media from identifying the names, whereabouts or appearance of the two may seem to guarantee their anonymity but many others who have had their identities officially changed have discovered that disappearing from public view is much more difficult than it might seem.

The people most frequently given a new identity by police are informers or prosecution witnesses in major crime cases who might fear for their lives. Such new identities are not freely handed out and will be granted only if the police believe they or their families are in serious danger of violence from those on whom they have informed and against whom they have given evidence.

It is a complex business. The subject of the new identity will be provided not just with a new name but with all the paraphernalia necessary to create a new life. This means new medical records, national insurance number and bank accounts so that there is a minimal chance of some one stumbling by chance on the person's true identity. If they want, the person with a new identity will be given a "panic button" that alerts the local police and a mobile phone programmed to bring help with one touch. The police also provide advice on constructing a past that is easy to memorise, and will offer a minder attached to the nearest police station. Someone considered to be at serious risk and likely to be tracked down could even be moved abroad. There are such people with new identities currently in Australia, the US and Canada.

Hundreds of new identities have been granted since 1978 when records of them first started to be kept. Only a few of those given new names and homes have since been spotted and police say that where they have, it has almost always been because the person concerned has not followed their advice and has been unable to resist a journey back to old haunts. This will be less of a temptation for Venables and Thompson, who were only 11 when they were sent away to secure units elsewhere. "They've told me to go out and get a job. The only trade I know is how to rob banks. I'm in a terrible state. I could go round the corner and cry."

In fact, O'Mahoney, who took on a new identity as Peter Davies, did find himself work and was a security man on such high-profile events as David Bowie and Rick Wakeman tours. His appearance had changed since his young bank robbing days - he had a grey ponytail and had put on weight - and he managed to avoid the many criminals who had vowed to catch him and extract revenge. He came back into the public eye when he was arrested for a robbery of which he was acquitted after claiming to have been set up by the police.

Another informer, Darren Nicholls, ceased to exist in spring 1996 after agreeing to give evidence in the trial of the men convicted of killing three criminals in a Range Rover in a country lane near Rettendon in Essex. He later complained about life with a new identity: "My little boy keeps saying, 'Why can't we have our old name back? Why can't I call my friends? Why can't we go back to Essex?' Vitaly Vitaliev, the Russian author and journalist, has observed that the British tabloid press is probably more efficient than the KGB in tracking people down. webTitle: New jab hope for victims of leukaemia

fields.headline: New jab hope for victims of leukaemia
fields.trailText: The groundbreaking discovery of an immune cell that can seek and destroy leukaemia cells could lead to a new treatment for thousands of sufferers of the killer disease, it is revealed today.
fields.body:
The groundbreaking discovery of an immune cell that can seek and destroy leukaemia cells could lead to a new treatment for thousands of sufferers of the killer disease, it is revealed today.

The cancer of the blood claims more than 5,000 victims a year. Scientists will take white blood cells from a healthy volunteer, engineer them to recognise leukaemia cells and then inject them into patients. In theory, the invading T-cells will act as a healthy immune system and eliminate the cancerous cells.

Lord Robert Winston, director of research at Hammersmith Hospitals NHS Trust, said: "To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time in the world that anyone has identified a target which allows T-cells to selectively destroy cells that cause leukaemia.

"Such a breakthrough underlines the vital importance of long-term academic research in the production of desperately needed treatments."

Hans Stauss of Imperial College school of medicine worked with Hammersmith teams on the new approach. He identified a gene called WT-1 that becomes overactive in cells that cause leukaemia. This meant that the cells were, in effect, labelled and easily recognised.

The next step was to take immune cells and engineer them to destroy leukaemia cells but not ordinary ones of the same type. Drugs normally taken for leukaemia suppress the immune system, so the patient would not reject the imported T-cells. In effect, a patient would "borrow" an immune system off the hospital shelf to mop up the cancer.

So far all tests have been in the laboratory. But with backing from the Leukaemia Research Fund charity, he and colleagues are preparing for the first trials on patients.

"The principle we have developed can be applied to almost all forms of leukaemia and could signal a huge step forward in how we treat the disease," said Dr Stauss. "What makes this work even more exciting is that our findings can be applied to solid cancers where there is similar over-expression of WT-1. The possibilities for new treatments are enormous."

Various cancers of the blood affect 18,000 people in Britain every year. Drugs can be effective, but they also kill healthy cells and have side effects that make the patient feel wretched. Bone marrow transplants involve radiotherapy and long stays in hospital.

Dr Stauss's approach harnesses the natural " search and destroy" machinery that deals with microbial infection but not, normally, the body's own cancerous cells.

"It's fatal attraction of the most specific kind," said David Grant, scientific director of the LRF. "Once the introduction is made between cancer cell and killer T-cell, the immune system goes in for the kill.

"The beauty of this technique is that it does not require using cells from the patient. The killer T-cells, directed to particular targets, will be available off the shelf."

At first the treatment will be used after conventional drug therapy. But it could ultimately provide much more powerful treatments that would lessen the need for toxic drugs.

"This could well be the chink in the armour cancer doctors have been looking for," said Dr Grant.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A piper's lament yesterday ended a memorial on the Isle of Man to the seven fishermen who drowned in the Solway Harvester fishing tragedy last January.
fields.body:
Heart op fear for unborn baby

An unborn baby may need a heart transplant, according to the Royal Brompton hospital in west London. The problems were discovered during a routine 20-week scan of the mother-to-be, Cathy Proctor from Carshalton, Surrey. Half of the baby's heart is un- developed.

Piper's lament for trawler crew

A piper's lament yesterday ended a memorial on the Isle of Man to the seven fishermen who drowned in the Solway Harvester fishing tragedy last January.

Queen Mother trips on step

The Queen Mother was slightly shaken after losing her footing on a step following a church service at St Mary Magdalene, Sandringham, yesterday.

Three share £20m jackpot

Three tickets shared Saturday's £20m lottery Superdraw jackpot with the numbers 12, 23, 28, 34, 36, 40. The bonus ball was 18. No winners scooped the lottery Extra jackpot. The £250,000 Thunderball jackpot was also not won.

webTitle: Hospital inquiry after bodies stored in chapel

fields.headline: Hospital inquiry after bodies stored in chapel
fields.trailText: The NHS is to investigate a hospital which stored corpses on the floor of a chapel of rest, covered only by sheets.
fields.body:
The NHS is to investigate a hospital which stored corpses on the floor of a chapel of rest, covered only by sheets.

Managers at Bedford hospital face disciplinary action and possible dismissal after confirming yesterday that bodies were kept in the unrefrigerated room for three days last week.

Nigel Crisp, chief executive of the NHS, said there was "no excuse" for the procedure. "This is utterly unacceptable and contravenes all guidance issued to trusts," he said.

"Due to the totally unacceptable nature of this incident I have ordered an urgent investigation into the circumstances which will start immediately."

A hospital spokeswoman said the room had been used because the hospital's main mortuary was full and a new temporary mortuary was closed for "health and safety reasons".

The temporary mortuary, purchased last year in anticipation of more use during the winter, was closed on Tuesday after a porter injured his hands trying to open the door.

A hospital spokeswoman said: "The decision to close the mortuary was taken on health and safety grounds because of a risk to staff who could injure their backs or hands struggling with the heavy door."

The door handles have subsequently been moved and the temporary mortuary is now back in use. The hospital stores corpses delivered by the police as well as those of patients who have died.

As a result of the closure an unconfirmed number of corpses were kept on the floor in the chapel. The hospital said up to eight bodies at a time were kept in the room, but that no body would have remained there for more than 24 hours. The hospital's emergency procedures allow for bodies to be put in the chapel at times of great pressure.

"This situation is obviously totally unacceptable. We would also apologise to the relatives of anyone who may have been stored in this way," said the spokeswoman.

Nick Court, communications director of the NHS executive eastern region, condemned the practice: "We have talked to the hospital and instructed a director to go there on Monday morning and begin a thorough investigation. We would hope to get to the bottom of what happened here by the end of the week.

"It is crucial to find out whether this room was used routinely and, if it was, to make sure that is no longer the case. Clearly we would want to see that all relatives are informed of what happened and that they receive all the help and counselling they may need."

webTitle: Facts behind the figures that damn Walsall

fields.headline: Facts behind the figures that damn Walsall
fields.standfirst: NHS trust points to local lifestyles and deprivation as reason for highest hospital death rate in England
fields.trailText: NHS trust points to local lifestyles and deprivation as reason for highest hospital death rate in England.
fields.body:
Walsall was once famous for its leather industry - hence Walsall Football Club's nickname, the Saddlers.

These days only a museum preserves the memory of the industry. Unemployment is high and low wages are rife.

The West Midlands town, in the industrial Black Country, retains a tough working men's club culture, fuelled by bitters and baltis, in which too much attention to health can be seen as effete.

It also has a large Asian population, with higher than average rates of heart disease.

These factors may go some way to explain why the Walsall NHS trust has the highest death rates in the country, as found in the study by Sir Brian Jarman of Imperial College, London, published yesterday.

But Sam Ramaiah, the trust's public health director, who has earned local notoriety for his vigorous assault on Walsall's "curry and couch potato" lifestyle, expressed astonishment that death rates were not weighted by social factors: "I've been saying for a long time that deprivation has a major impact on health, and it certainly has on mortality rates."

Nevertheless, the finding of a link between staff levels and patient deaths has alarmed the trust, which runs Walsall Manor hospital.

Trust sources indicated that the report could be used to put pressure on the government to provide more cash for recruitment. The hospital has 23 doctors per 100 beds, compared with an average of 35 per 100 beds in England.

After a board meeting yesterday morning, the chief executive, John Rostill, acknowledged "the broad suggestion that the number of doctors we employ has a direct bearing on mortality. Of course it's got to be a contributing factor, but I can't believe it's so strong.

"That's the sort of thing we've got to look at."

He denied there were recruitment problems because of the town's unglamorous image. "Clearly there are people who like to go to places that have a slightly different background. But it is quite offensive to our staff to say that nobody of calibre would want to work in Walsall.

"It's not a question of us having recruitment difficulty. It's a question of us identifying the funding to take on more staff."

Mr Rostill stressed that on many other measures Manor hospital performed well, "such as waiting lists, how quickly we deal with complaints and breast cancer care".

The trust and Walsall health authority are expected to announce a joint inquiry, looking at Sir Brian's methodology and identifying problems with local healthcare.

Local people yesterday said they were proud of the hospital and had confidence in its doctors and nurses.

Paul Woolley, 50, who was admitted 2 years ago after a stroke and was visiting the hospital's social club, said: "I was as close to death as you will ever be. When I needed them, they were there. My mother-in-law had surgery for breast cancer here. Both my kids were born here, and the aftercare was absolutely brilliant. Out of 100 I would give them 95.

"Like everywhere else in the country, I think nurses have a raw deal for what they do and should be paid more."

Benjamin Edwards, 72, was also treated for a stroke in 1998 and regularly returns to catch up with other former patients at the social club.

"It's a good hospital," he said. "After my stroke they did a lot of therapy for me, and I'm much better now. I can stand up and get in the bath.

"I come down to the social club and have a couple of orange juices because it gets me out of the house."

Dr Ramaiah said health education was slowly eroding traditional attitudes and improving lifestyles.

"Fewer people are dying from heart disease," he said. "We are making improvements, but the improvements are slow to be recognised because we are starting off from a much lower level."

webTitle: Moscow party for Milosevic clan

fields.headline: Moscow party for Milosevic clan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The family of the ousted Yugoslav president and indicted war criminal, Slobodan Milosevic, apparently staged a family reunion in Moscow over the weekend.
fields.body:
The family of the ousted Yugoslav president and indicted war criminal, Slobodan Milosevic, apparently staged a family reunion in Moscow over the weekend.

While Mr Milosevic is wary of travelling out of Yugoslavia since foreign authorities would be obliged to arrest him under United Nations rules, his wife, son, and brother were believed to have enjoyed an Orthodox New Year family get-together in Moscow.

Mr Milosevic's infamous wife, Mirjana Markovic, dubbed the Lady Macbeth of the Balkans, left Belgrade on Friday on an Aeroflot flight, Belgrade airport officials told the Beta news agency.

The day before, Borislav Milosevic, the former president's elder brother and recently fired Yugoslav ambassador to Russia, hosted a lavish farewell party at the Yugoslav embassy in Moscow attended by the Russian elite.

The reception turned into a west-bashing event, indicating the lingering fondness for the Milosevic regime among senior figures in Russia.

Mrs Markovic was believed to have travelled to Moscow to see her son, Marko, an underworld leader who fled his homeland in the wake of his father's overthrow last October.

Regarded as an indispensable adviser to her husband throughout his 13-year rule in Serbia, she was expected to be back in Belgrade this morning for a meeting of the executive of her hardline United Left party which failed to win a single seat in the new democratic Serbian parliament. She remains a member of the Yugoslav federal parliament.

Her trip triggered conflicting responses in Belgrade. Zoran Dzindzic, expected to be the new Serbian prime minister, accused her of breaking the law by evading officials at Belgrade airport. But the Yugoslav interior minister, Zoran Zivkovic, said she was a free agent who could go where she liked.

By contrast, her husband's movements are severely circumscribed, though he may take comfort from weekend assurances from his nemesis, President Vojislav Kostunica, that he will not be turned over to the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague - which has indicted Mr Milosevic for war crimes in Kosovo and is investigating him for crimes committed in Bosnia.

Mr Kostunica met Mr Milosevic at the weekend in what was believed to be the first such encounter since October and then made a robust statement in defiance of the Hague tribunal - ahead of the expected arrival in Belgrade next week of Carla Del Ponte, the tribunal's forceful chief prosecutor.

Mr Kostunica's assurances would appear to rule out Mr Milosevic's extradition to the Hague, an issue that is dividing the new Serbian and Yugoslav leaderships.

But the Yugoslav justice minister, Momcilo Grubac, countered that Mr Milosevic could be sent to the Hague since the tribunal was a UN institution and not a court of a foreign country.

webTitle: Creche premiere Theatre's childcare first

fields.headline: Creche premiere Theatre's childcare first
fields.trailText: At the top of a steep flight of stairs, history is being made: the Playhouse theatre in London's West End has been licensed to open a theatre creche.
fields.body:
At the top of a steep flight of stairs, history is being made: the Playhouse theatre in London's West End has been licensed to open a theatre creche.

It seemed such an obvious move to general manager Sarah Overend that she was astonished to find it will be the first in any West End theatre and, as far as she knew, in any commercial theatre in Britain.

The Playhouse is packing in audiences for Thunderbirds FAB, a show that has been touring the world since 1984, and is now cashing in, since the BBC relaunch, on the 1960s puppets series becoming a craze for the third time.

The show is billed as suitable for children from six up. From next month, parents may also bring younger siblings, and leave them, for a fee of £5 an hour, in the creche. Guest appearances by cast members in what was the Upper Circle bar are promised, as well as trained child carers.

Thunderbirds runs to the end of February, but the theatre intends to provide the creche for future shows.

"When we were discussing it everyone said it was a great idea but impossibly difficult. In fact Westminster council was tremendously supportive. It's a drop in the ocean of accessibility, but at least we are doing something,"said Ms Oversend.

webTitle: The Universal Church of the Kingdom of God

fields.headline: The exorcists
fields.standfirst: It claims to offer protection from black magic and attracts millions of followers. But the murder of Anna Climbie - in one of Britain's worst ever cases of child abuse - has raised troubling questions about the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God.  Jeevan Vasagar  reports
fields.trailText: It claims to offer protection from black magic and attracts millions of followers. But the murder of Anna Climbie - in one of Britain's worst ever cases of child abuse - has raised troubling questions about the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God.  Jeevan Vasagar  reports.
fields.body:
The Rainbow Theatre in north London can hold several thousand people, but only about 100 are gathered on this chilly Friday morning. Once it was one of Britain's top rock venues, resounding to the screams of teenage fans of the Beatles, David Bowie and the Osmonds. Now it belongs to the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, a global evangelical church which originated in Brazil in the 1970s; and assistant bishop Wellington Marcelo is pacing the stage bellowing gospel tunes, leading a "deliverance service" which offers protection from "voodoo, black magic and witchcraft".

Marcelo's pastors, cleancut young Brazilian men in neatly ironed shirts, march up and down the aisles like cheerleaders, singing along loudly. The congregation is ordered to form a circle before the stage, and we all hold hands. The preacher is in the middle.

"Are there any evil spirits tormenting you? Stopping you sleeping?" he cries. A young woman who is making the loudest noise is brought to the middle of the circle. The preacher is shouting now, asking Jesus to "send his fire - burn the evil spirits!"

"Burn! Burn! Burn!" the worshippers shout in response, stamping their feet. Marcelo takes hold of the young woman, clasping her neck in what looks like a wrestling grip, and tells everyone a devil is inside her.

Marcelo shouts at the devil to leave her and she gets more hysterical, hitting him with her fists and making a growling sound. He calms her down and gives her a cup of water that he has blessed in the names of the Holy Trinity. She says that she is from the Congo, a mother of three and a care worker. In front of the now hushed congregation, she reveals that she attempted suicide that morning.

Marcelo asks her what her problem is. "Marriage problems," she says. "No," he says, "spiritual problems."

The care worker again says that she is going through problems with her husband. He disagrees. Like an impatient teacher with a slow child, he gets her to repeat that she has "spiritual problems", before letting her go back to her place in the circle.

The Universal Church has already got into trouble over its claim that evil spirits are the cause of people's woes. In 1997, the Advertising Standards Authority banned a church poster that said: "Constant headaches, depression, insomnia, fears, bad luck, strange diseases . . . These are just a few symptoms caused by demons."

But now the deliverance service has dragged the church into its darkest controversy yet. It was to one of these services that eight-year-old Anna Climbie, the little girl who died of hypothermia after being tied up in a bathtub in one of Britain's worst ever cases of child abuse, was to have been taken by her adoptive mother, Marie Kouao.

Kouao, who - along with her boyfriend, Carl Manning - was last Friday convicted of Anna's murder, had taken her to various churches, believing that the girl was possessed by demons. Throughout her trial at the Old Bailey, Kouao held on to a Bible.

Giving evidence, Alvero Lima, a 21-year-old assistant pastor of the Universal Church at Finsbury Park, told the jury about a conversation he had had with the girl in the week before her death. "[Anna] said she had a vision at night when the devil, in the form of a snake, told her to do these things [injure herself] and she was unable to stop. She said Satan made her do it. She said she hated me because I prayed for people. I told the mother I thought it was a spiritual problem. The Bible says there are evil spirits that leave people's bodies through fasting. I told her I and others would pray and fast all week."

Lima told Kouao that the congregation's efforts would culminate in exorcism of the devil from Anna at a deliverance service. The day before the scheduled service, Kouao brought Anna, who was then very cold and barely conscious, in for exorcism. A shocked Lima, to his credit, urged Kouao to take the child to hospital immediately. She died two days later, on February 25.

Kouao's barrister Michael Gledhill asked Lima: "What you were doing was playing with fire, wasn't it?" "No," he replied. Asked if he felt "at all responsible for this child's death," Lima again answered: "No."

The court case has turned the spotlight on the church's beliefs, and on the swath of society towards which its ministry is directed.

At the deliverance service I attend, almost everyone is from an African or Afro-Caribbean background. Judging by their dress, the people do not seem wealthy. Another clue to the economic realities of these people's lives appears in the church's free newspaper, City News, where an advert declares: "If money is your problem, come to the richest person in the world - God."

The church seems to be a one-stop shop for every social ill: on Monday there is a service for financial and immigration problems ("bring your CV, passport etc"); Tuesday's speciality is health and Thursday's is family problems. On Saturday there is a prayer for prosperity - "bring your Bible and learn how to be prosperous".

All this is brought into sharp focus at the end of the service when the preacher turns to the subject of fundraising. Drug dealers have plenty of money, Marcelo says. New nightclubs are built every day. But there is never enough money for God's work. "We need offerings to build more churches," he says. "Is there anyone here who will give £50 or more?"

A woman goes to the front and writes out a cheque. An extraordinary Dutch auction commences as the assistant bishop asks: "Is there anyone who will give £30 or more? £20? Anyone who will take an envelope and come back next week?"

He gives Bibles in exchange for the big donations. Then he asks for anything people have - even as little as 50p. No one seems to find this strange.

This fundraising has proved hugely successful. The Universal Church, which claims to have 4,500 members regularly attending its services in London and the west midlands, raised £2m from donations at services in 1999, the last year for which figures are available.

On its website, the church discloses that it committed £569,000 to "direct charitable expenditure" in the financial year 1998-1999, and describes some of the work it carried out: an outreach service supplying shoes, blankets and Bibles to prisoners, and a lending library of taped services for the housebound elderly. Some £330,000 was spent on "fundraising and publicity", while management and administration costs were £246,000. At the time the records were filed, the church had a bank balance of £3.3m, including income saved from previous years.

Church spokeswoman Christoulla Boodram says the main objective of the church, as a charity, is to advance the Christian faith. "This is done by means of spreading the gospel through opening churches, literature, evangelism, radio programmes etc. The donations raised during church services are spent to pursue these objectives."

Last August, further evidence of the church's wealth and ambition emerged when a company part-owned by its Portuguese branch bought Liberty Radio, a London-based speech and music station, from Mohamed Al Fayed, the Harrods owner.

Observers of the church say that it seeks media investments both for commercial reasons and to obtain a platform. In Brazil, where it was founded by a former lottery shop assistant, Edir Macedo, in 1977, the Universal Church is far more than a spiritual organisation; it is a powerful political, financial and media force. It owns one of the main terrestrial television channels, about 20 other TV stations, 50 radio stations, a football team renamed Universal and a newspaper with a weekly circulation of 1.3m.

It is estimated to have an annual turnover of £700m - which would put it in the top 100 Brazilian companies - and is the country's fastest-growing religion, with an estimated 8,000 churches and eight million followers. The church also has 18 elected deputies affiliated to it in the Brazilian congress, giving it a political clout that outweighs its size. In the early 1990s Brazil's attorney general ordered an investigation, which is still in progress, into Macedo and the church over allegations of charlatanism.

The vast majority of Macedo's followers in Brazil are from the poorest communities. They, like the members of other churches in a country where there is no national health service, are attracted by the promise that true believers will be able to find the cure for any disease. Followers are expected to donate 10% of their earnings. Many priests who have left the fold have accused the church of only being interested in making money.

Boodram says: "In Brazil, the church is a very large organisation and recognised by its active role in helping the poorest and destitute in society. It seeks to play the same role in Britain."

But the death of Anna Climbie has exposed the church's practices to unwelcome publicity that could hamper its ambitions in Britain.

"We were very shocked and saddened by the suffering and subsequent death of little Anna," said Boodram. "This must be a terrible time for Anna's family and our thoughts and prayers go out to them, especially her parents in Ivory Coast."

She insisted that "the value of prayer in positively affecting a person's health has already been acknowledged by several medical studies", and added: "It is the practice in our church to always advise people to keep to their medical treatment and follow doctor's instructions."

She also says that, as well as offering up prayers for prosperity, it refers seriously indebted people to debt advisory services. But this defence is somewhat undercut by the preacher's insistence, at the service I attended, that the troubled young woman's problems were spiritual. It is also undermined by its free newspaper, the pages of which are filled with stories of prayer curing afflictions deemed incurable by conventional medicine.

For now, the Universal Church and its pastors will have to tread carefully with everyone they advise. After Anna's death, the accusation that they are "playing with fire" could yet come back to haunt them.

fields.headline: The bad old good old days
fields.standfirst: Last week my very old friend Shirley suddenly told me exactly what her mother had done to her when she was little. Now I know why Shirley often couldn't come out to play. She was locked in a dark room with the blackout blinds down and her mummy had been hitting her with sticks.
fields.trailText: Last week my very old friend Shirley suddenly told me exactly what her mother had done to her when she was little. Now I know why Shirley often couldn't come out to play. She was locked in a dark room with the blackout blinds down and her mummy had been hitting her with sticks.
fields.body:
Last week my very old friend Shirley suddenly told me exactly what her mother had done to her when she was little. Now I know why Shirley often couldn't come out to play. She was locked in a dark room with the blackout blinds down and her mummy had been hitting her with sticks. From the blackout room, our friend could hear us come knocking at the door. "Shirley can't come out today," said the mother, told us what good girls we were and gave us some cake.

This was the worst of a flood of recent revelations. I now know that a little further down the road, another friend's daddy was two- or three-timing her mummy, who was drinking herself to death. A few doors away in my road, Mrs X pretended she was having a torrid affair with my father. Two more friends, a little further away, were being smacked about, two mistresses turned up at two other fathers' funerals and lurked behind trees, my friend Munch's father would put salt in her mother's orange juice and pass notes at table rather than speak, and my auntie and uncle round the corner lived in the same house but never spoke for 20 years.

Could there have just been something odd about Ruislip? Apparently not. In a nearby county, the infant Fielding's dad had just left home for a mistress and when Fielding's friends rang the bell to ask him out to play, he hid indoors, pretending he wasn't there, so his friends wouldn't come in and see that his Dad had left. Meanwhile Fielding's friend David hid in a bush all day every day for a week, in the cold, because school was so horrid and the priests liked smacking his bottom.

None of us knew anything about it until now, nearly 50 years later. No wonder people went haywire in the 60s. I became a beatnik, Fielding's brother became a teddy boy, Shirley ran away from home and married a batterer, Munch had a nervous breakdown and everyone else took drugs. And I have been nostalgic for nearly half a century. Well, I have changed my mind. No thank you to the Flowerpot Men and Janet and John. They may dredge up horrid memories. Look Janet, look John. See Dad be bad. See Mum go mad. Perhaps 2001 isn't so terrible after all.

webTitle: The tragedy of the women of East Timor

fields.headline: Return of the revolutionaries
fields.standfirst:
The conflict may be over, but for the women of East Timor, there is another battle to be won. Maggie O'Kane reports

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The conflict may be over, but for the women of East Timor, there is another battle to be won.  Maggie O'Kane reports.
fields.body:
The discovery of the bodies of four women murdered with machetes in different parts of the country last summer passed almost unnoticed in East Timor. Yet the Indonesian occupying army, which killed an estimated 200,000 people in its 24 years there, has gone, driven out by the UN cavalry over a year ago.

The tragedy for the women of East Timor is that those killed in the machete attacks were murdered by their own husbands or brothers. In a country with a population estimated at around 720,000 - roughly the same as that of Leeds - it is a shocking statistic.

After years of a cruel and brutal conflict, the violence learned by the revolutionaries has now been turned on their women. Domestic violence has soared in the past year, according to Milena Pires, 34, a Timorese political lobbyist funded by the Catholic Institute for International Relations. Last year, 169 cases were documented and domestic violence is now the country's prevalent crime, making up 40% of all offences.

Supporters of the Indonesian regime ran amok and hundreds were killed or forced into camps across the border in west Timor. By the time the Indonesian army had left, almost everything had been destroyed.

After the immediate violence abated, deeper, more lasting tensions were revealed as the men of East Timor's rebel army, the Falantil, returned to the homes they hadn't seen since 1975. When Indonesia invaded, they left their families behind in the towns and on the farms, and headed for the mountains and jungles. Pressure from other donor countries, such as Japan, Portugal and Australia, to introduce women-friendly policies has worked thus far and women's groups in East Timor have already succeeded in securing a deal in which local councils are made up of 50% men and 50% women.

Meanwhile, the cost of the UN's current babysitting of East Timor is estimated to be over $700m, yet there is very little rebuilding going on, no new industry and the country is proving a tough place to run. The independent East Timor was left with no electricity, no schools, no universities - even the saw mill machinery had been ripped out and taken back to Indonesia. webTitle: Pressure on NHS to offer pill for obesity

fields.headline: Pressure on NHS to offer pill for obesity
fields.standfirst: Drug launch raises fear that emphasis will shift from lifestyle
fields.trailText: A drug to combat obesity is to be launched in Britain later this year, increasing pressure on the health service to treat fatness as an epidemic.
fields.body:
A drug to combat obesity is to be launched in Britain later this year, increasing pressure on the health service to treat fatness as an epidemic.

The drug, Sibutramine, is available in Germany and the US under the brand names Reductil and Meridia. A three-month course costs £40 in Germany.

Manufactured by BASF Pharma, the drugs wing of the German BASF conglomerate, it acts on the brain to stifle appetite.

Most of the world's big pharmaceutical firms are working on medicines to treat obesity, and there are fears that promotion of a stream of pills will distract from the reality that only lifestyle changes can reduce weight effectively.

"The public wants every new drug that comes along to be a magic bullet," said Philip James, a professor who chairs the International Obesity Taskforce, a charity. "That's one of the unfortunate cultural features of our age, and I think unscrupulous pharmaceutical companies will make use of it."

Some 61% of British men and 52% of women are thought to be overweight. Some 16% and 18% respectively are clinically obese, which can lead to diabetes and heart disease. A survey this month showed that in 10 years there had been a sharp increase in overweight children.

Sibutramine is expected to be given a Europe-wide licence this year by the European Agency for Evaluation of Medicinal Products, or Emea, based in London. In February, the national institute for clinical excellence, which rules on NHS treatments, will announce whether another anti-obesity drug, Orlistat, should be available; it was to make a recommendation for Sibutramine at the same time, but is awaiting the Emea decision.

Sibutramine was invented in Nottingham in the early 1990s by scientists working for Boots, whose laboratories were sold to BASF in 1995. The drug was not designed to fight obesity.

"It was meant to be an anti-depressant, because they work in the same way, by increasing levels of brain chemicals like seratonin and dopamine," said a BASF spokeswoman, Christina von Landenberg. "When tested on 1,200 depressed people, they didn't become less depressed, but their weight decreased by several kilogrammes. So the company decided to develop it as an anti-obesity drug."

By itself, the drug will not help lose more than a few kilos, and the manufacturers say it should only be prescribed as part of a diet and exercise regime.

A BASF spokesman, Gunther Storz, said the firm's drugs wing had been sold to a US company and would be demerged within a few weeks.

BASF Pharma is one of the funders of a Washington lobby, the American Obesity Association, pressuring the US authorities to make obesity treatment tax deductible and to fund treatment for the elderly. BASF Pharma also contributes to the International Obesity Taskforce. Prof James said the money was "an unfettered educational grant" and the charity did not promote specific drugs.

Mr Storz said he saw nothing unethical about the marketing of drugs like Sibutramine. "I've discussed this with doctors from Germany and Switzerland, where the drug is licensed. They told me that, in normal circumstances, they only get 3% of obese patients to change their lifestyle; the rest just aren't able to alter their habits. With Reductil, they succeed with 30 to 50%."

Peter Kopelman, a professor at St Bartholomew's hospital in London, said: "These drugs should not be regarded as a simple answer ... but we do have a medical problem called obesity.

"I have a clinic. The average age of my patients is 35. They are very large people. Many can't get in to the clinic because they're so breathless. Some, in their 30s, have heart and respiratory failure. Many have diabetes.

"Yes, if they could have changed their lives earlier, they wouldn't have reached such a dire state, but given that they have, I need to have some kind of medical treatment to offer."

webTitle: Earthquakes are not a random hazard

fields.headline: The cataclysmic logjam, 24 miles under the ocean bed
fields.trailText: Earthquakes are not a random hazard. In places such as Guatemala and El Salvador they are inevitable.
fields.body:
Earthquakes are not a random hazard. In places such as Guatemala and El Salvador they are inevitable.

The Earth's crust is made of massive plates which move against each other, and the Central American isthmus is the creation of two such plates.

The Cocos plate, moving eastwards, is sliding under the Caribbean plate, throwing up a chain of earthquake-prone, volcanic mountains. The two plates are perhaps 60 miles thick, but more than 1,000 miles in diameter, and though they move at only inches per year, their momentum is irresistible.

But crustal rocks snag and catch, jamming the process, while the pressure still goes on. In the end, something has to give, and a movement that should have proceeded extremely slowly suddenly accelerates - for a few devastating seconds - from nothing to hundreds of miles per hour. This happened on Saturday, 24 miles below the ocean floor, 60 miles south-west of San Miguel, in El Salvador.

The violence at the focus of the earthquake is translated into several kinds of movement in the surrounding rocks. The first longitudinal shock waves, arriving at colossal speed, bounce the ground up and down. The second set of waves, travelling only a little more slowly, makes the bedrock shear from side to side. A third set of surface waves, arriving last, makes the ground roll, like an ocean.

Their combined effect can shiver mortar, tear down tall structures, fracture roads and trigger landslides in unstable soil.

The human toll depends on the local geology, the number of people who live in the path of the shock waves, the structure of their houses, and the time of day. Some of the worst tragedies have happened at night, when most people are at home.

If the shock is violent enough - and earthquakes of this magnitude happen only once or twice a year anywhere in the world- then even rescuers are at risk. Electricity and communications are shut down, petrol stations and gas services catch fire, water supplies are cut off, roads are blocked and there may be a risk of waterborne disease as sewage services collapse.

Central America was hit in 1998 by Hurricane Mitch, the worst storm in 200 years, which delivered colossal downpours and triggered calamitous landslides which killed 10,000. And in 1999 the region was again hit by hurricanes, heavy rain and flooding. The strain on economies in developing countries is cumulative: each disaster leaves people less able to cope with the next.

During the 1970s and 1980s seismologists pinned their hopes on the possibility of earthquake prediction, but precise forecasts seem as far away as ever. In the past decade - declared by the UN international decade for natural disaster reduction - the accent has been on preparedness: better building standards, less unstable sites for towns and more disaster education. But population growth meansthat each year there are another 80m potential victims, most of them in poorer countries, as more people flock to the cities.

More than half the planet's population are now urban dwellers, and the urban poor live in the least acceptable housing, on the most marginal land, with poorest access to power and water. Because of these factors, by the end of the last decade, natural disasters were taking more lives and costing more to economies than at the beginning.

webTitle: Reagan faces struggle after fall

fields.headline: Reagan faces struggle after fall
fields.trailText: Ronald Reagan faces an uphill struggle to recover from his weekend hip surgery because of problems caused by his Alzheimer's disease, the former US president's doctors said yesterday.
fields.body:
Ronald Reagan faces an uphill struggle to recover from his weekend hip surgery because of problems caused by his Alzheimer's disease, the former US president's doctors said yesterday.

Mr Reagan, who will be 90 next month, underwent surgery in Santa Monica, California, on Saturday after breaking his hip in a fall at his Bel-Air home on Friday. He was said to be alert and to have had his first meal yesterday after the operation.

Dr Kevin Ehrhart, who headed the surgical team, said that the former president should be on his feet, with the aid of a walking frame, in around two weeks.

However, the doctor warned that Mr Reagan's Alzheimer's condition could pose challenges to his recovery.

"I am sure it will complicate it somewhat more. It's a bigger challenge but one that is not uncommon in orthopaedics."

Mr Reagan publicly announced his Alzheimer's disease in November 1994 in a handwritten letter to the American people in which he wrote: "I now begin the journey that will lead me into the sunset of my life."

There have been reports in the past twelve months that he now no longer recognises anyone except his wife, Nancy, and that he has forgotten his presidency - from 1981-89.

webTitle: Guatemala owns up to role in death of street children

fields.headline: Guatemala owns up to role in death of street children
fields.trailText: In a historic gesture, the Guatemalan government has formally paid compensation for the deaths of street children at the hands of the police and military. The move has been greeted as a significant step by human rights groups campaigning over the deaths of hundreds of street children in Latin America.
fields.body:
In a historic gesture, the Guatemalan government has formally paid compensation for the deaths of street children at the hands of the police and military. The move has been greeted as a significant step by human rights groups campaigning over the deaths of hundreds of street children in Latin America.

There has been growing concern among civil rights groups about the activities in Central America and Brazil of police and vigilante groups which have targeted street children deemed to be a social nuisance, and carried out "culling" operations. Until recently most of these murders went uninvestigated and unpunished.

The head of the Guatemalan government's human rights office formally handed over compensation to one former street child who survived such an operation, Juan Jose Mendez Toc, now 25, and to members of the families of two murdered children, Marcos Fidel Quisquinay Concua, 12, and Sergio Miguel Fuentes Chavez, 17. The role of the state in the deaths and the violence was acknowledged at the ceremony.

The events prompting the settlement go back to May 1990 when Juan Jose lived on the streets in Guatemala City. Privately employed police officers took him and another boy to the basement of a downtown shopping centre. There they unmuzzled alsatian dogs and set them on the boys. The officers have never been brought to justice.

In September 1994, Sergio Miguel was shot through the head at point-blank range by a private policeman employed by a firm that was under contract to the municipality of Guatemala City. Again no one was punished for the murder.

In the same month, two men gave Marcos Fidel some hot chicken from a fast food restaurant in Guatemala City. Hidden beneath the chicken was a hand-grenade which blew up in the boy's face and killed him. No one was arrested for the crime but it is widely believed to have been carried out by the military.

The cases were brought to the Inter American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) by the Casa Alianza, which works with and campaigns on behalf of street children in Central America, and the Centre for Justice and International Law (CEJIL).

The breakthrough came last year when the newly elected Guatemalan government of Alfonso Portillo accepted responsibility for the events involving the street children. Although the compensation seems small - $11,000 (£7,500) and $15,000 (£10,000) for the deaths and $2,000 (£1,350) for the dog attack - the official nature of the settlement was seen by the human rights groups as crucial.

"It has been 10 long years since we took Juan Jose for medical treatment, and six tough years since we buried Marcos Fidel and Sergio," said Bruce Harris, the British-born regional director for Casa Alianza's Latin American programmes.

"The amounts of financial compensation are small and will never, ever, replace the children lost nor the suffering. But it is a step in the right direction.

"Guatemala is showing that the state has erred but has now taken the political decision to both recognise errors of the past and to prevent violence against homeless children in the future. We shall hold them to that. We cannot speak of justice because our kids are dead."

Although the compensation seems small - $11,000 (£7,500) and $15,000 (£10,000) for the deaths and $2,000 (£1,350) for the dog attack - the official nature of the settlement was seen by the human rights groups as crucial. "It has been 10 long years since we took Juan Jose for medical treatment, and six tough years since we buried Marcos Fidel and Sergio," said Bruce Harris, the British-born regional director for Casa Alianza's Latin American programmes. "The amounts of financial compensation are small and will never, ever, replace the children lost nor the suffering. But it is a step in the right direction. "Guatemala is showing that the state has erred but has now taken the political decision to both recognise errors of the past and to prevent violence against homeless children in the future. We shall hold them to that. We cannot speak of justice because our kids are dead."

fields.headline: Damned lies
fields.trailText: I 'm slightly uneasy about the case of John Weissberger, ex-businessman, who was taken for a ride by one Christina Wilson. She persuaded him to part with a quarter of a million pounds and received a five-year jail sentence for her troubles.
fields.body:
I 'm slightly uneasy about the case of John Weissberger, ex-businessman, who was taken for a ride by one Christina Wilson. She persuaded him to part with a quarter of a million pounds and received a five-year jail sentence for her troubles.

Her lies were many: a multi-million-pound Hollywood deal, a failed breast implant operation, and the sudden death of her daughter in Canada. But I am troubled by the prosecution of this woman. This was not a case of a smooth-talking builder persuading a vulnerable old woman to hand over thousands of pounds to replace a roof tile; there was no abuse of trust or authority, nor duress or blackmail; the victim was not mentally disabled. And it is not as if Wilson systematically forged false documents to bolster her tall tales. She had quite simply told Weissberger outrageous lies that he, inexplicably, seems to have believed without question.

If everyone who lied to wheedle some money out of another were to be prosecuted, our jails would have twice as many inmates. Do we prosecute the mendicant who assures us that he needs the money to feed his family when he immediately spends it on drink? Of course not.

Closer to Weissberger's case, do we bring to court every woman (or man) who has sworn undying love, received lavish gifts and then turns out not to have loved the giver after all? It happens all the time. The fact is that people in love or lust do strange things, including believing the unbelievable. When they wake up they realise they've been very silly and rightly accuse the other party of taking advantage of them, of gold-digging. They may sue for the return of presents or money. But criminal proceedings?

I suppose I have been influenced by Weissberger's label. Should a businessman not have a little more savvy than to be taken in so easily? He may have been a gullible sucker and she a nasty piece of work. But not five years in jail's worth.

 When James Bulger's killers went on trial in 1993, the internet was used by comparatively few. But even then it was easy to discover the names of the boys who, in the English media, could be referred to only as child A and child B. How much harder it will be to protect them from the revelation of their new identities and circumstances on the internet by those with malicious intent.

Our media will be banned from alluding to the availability of such information, let alone repeating it, but word gets around quickly on the net. And even if our authorities take speedy action against service providers to remove any references to them (which may not be easy), there will always be a time gap; and someone else, on another site, will soon restore the information.

This is profoundly depressing, and I cannot see what can be done. The truth is that the internet has made large chunks of national jurisdictions irrelevant.

 What a pleasure. Two TV courtroom dramas in a row, and neither of them getting the scene wrong. You may have twigged by now that nothing so distresses me as to see English judges on film or TV wielding gavels, which they never do. Not a gavel was spotted in either The Innocent - an everyday tale of barrister-rapes-barrister (or doesn't), well acted and with some nice final twists - or in Judge John Deed, about a cool high court judge (played by Martin Shaw) with a social conscience, Porsche, spiky hairdo, hatred of ties and a penchant for sleeping with the female defence counsel.

That last one, at least, is true to life. [Following legal advice, I ought to make it clear that nothing in the previous sentence should be taken to suggest that any high court judge has ever been known to have sexual congress, or thoughts of such congress, with any defence counsel, ever.]

It is fair to say that some of the drama was not legally accurate. In truth, it was a load of hokum, though hugely enjoyable. Take this example. The jury comes in with a verdict of guilty on a man who shot dead his daughter's killer. Our bleeding-heart hero doesn't like it. Hold on, judge tells jury, and offers the accused the chance to say a few words. He does, making all the jurors cry. Do you wish to change your verdict, Deed asks. Yes indeedy, says the entire jury, immediately switching to not guilty.

I noticed the names of two respected lawyers acting as legal advisers. I trust they laughed heartily when shown the script, and pointed out its impossibilities. But I'm pleased that their advice was disregarded. Judge John Deed was great fun, and I hope they make a series out of him. It will do wonders for the image of the judiciary.

webTitle: Pass notes: London Eye

fields.headline: No: 1800 London Eye
fields.trailText: Age: 320 days. Meant to be 381, of course, but there was a minor hiccup at the start, if you recall.
fields.body:
Age: 320 days. Meant to be 381, of course, but there was a minor hiccup at the start, if you recall.

Ah, yes. Something to do with "essential maintenance"? That's right. Faulty clutches apparently.

The much spun wheel wouldn't spin . . . Very good. Yes, the misnamed "millennium" wheel failed its initial safety inspection and had to delay its opening until March 1, to the enormous embarrassment of the sponsor, British Airways.

So why is it in the news again? "Genuinely Popular British Millennium Landmark Finally Works, Shocker!"? Er, no. It's closing for four weeks - essential maintenance.

So it's clapped out already? Perish the thought. It's just that after carrying 3.5m passengers on some 5,000 revolutions, it's having a bit of a health check. "It's a routine maintenance operation," says a spokeswoman, "which will happen every year in low season."

God I'm bored of all of this millennium stuff. That bridge of sways isn't open yet either. And we can't even go to the Dome in the meantime! Patience. Those who can hold on until the wheel reopens on February 9 can expect all kinds of revolutionary treats.

Ooh, like what? Like the special Valentine's week packages, when, for the piffling sum of £250 plus VAT, couples can hire a pod - complete with champagne and strawberries - to celebrate the event in an extra special way.

I can think of a few extra special ways to celebrate - anyone for the 135-metre high club?! Now stop that. BA assures us that all pods will contain waiters engaged both to dispense champagne and pour cold water on any attempts to make the earth move inside the pods as well as out.

Spoilsports! There are some activities, my dear, for which it is better to keep two feet on the ground.

Do say: "What a romantic view, darling. And what a relief the hydraulic drive shafts are in full working order."

Don't say: "Why is pod 27 steaming up and rocking slightly?"
