webTitle: Business news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Construction group Taylor Woodrow will make a last-ditch attempt to disrupt the merger of housebuilders Bryant and Beazer today, arguing that Bryant shareholders attending a special meeting to vote on the deal should adjourn.
fields.body:
Builder tries to halt Bryant deal

Construction group Taylor Woodrow will make a last-ditch attempt to disrupt the merger of housebuilders Bryant and Beazer today, arguing that Bryant shareholders attending a special meeting to vote on the deal should adjourn.

Taylor has conditionally offered £537m for Bryant and claimed that it has not been given enough information to produce firmer proposals. Bryant said it had already received acceptances from shareholders speaking for 77% for what it terms a "merger of equals" with Beazer.

Online shopping boom forecast

Several online retailers may be struggling to stay afloat but new figures predict those that survive will help double the rate of growth of the home delivery market over the next four years.

Retail consultancy Verdict believes the home delivery market will grow from £18.9bn in 2000 to £34.5bn in 2005. The annual increase of 13% is nearly double the rate seen over the past five years.

The growth will be driven by improvements in convenience brought by technologies such as interactive digital television and more flexible delivery times.

Japan turns to Europe

Finance ministers from 25 Asian and European nations, meeting in Kobe, Japan, concluded that world economic "downside risks" have increased due to the sharp slowdown of the US economy.

Yesterday's communique from the Asia-Europe Meeting, which made no reference to recent exchange rate movements, also noted that Japan had managed only a modest recovery and needed further structural reform to revive "self-sustaining" growth.

After the meeting, Japanese finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa said it was Europe's turn to power world growth. "The US economy is not good and Japan's recovery is slow."

webTitle: Kingfisher may split sell-off

fields.headline: Kingfisher may split sell-off
fields.standfirst: Retail sector turbulence leads group to consider cash sale of Woolworths and Superdrug
fields.trailText: Plans to float Woolworths and Superdrug on the stock market as a single company are being reconsidered by their owner, Kingfisher, as a result of unsolicited interest from potential trade buyers.
fields.body:
Plans to float Woolworths and Superdrug on the stock market as a single company are being reconsidered by their owner, Kingfisher, as a result of unsolicited interest from potential trade buyers.

Kingfisher is understood to have received various approaches for the two household names from venture capital companies and trade buyers. The two chains are valued at around £1.4bn.

Increasing uncertainty about the strength of high street sales and fears of an economic slowdown could make a cash sale more attractive to Kingfisher shareholders than a planned spring flotation, which would merely hand them shares in a new unit which would be exposed to the vagaries of the stock market.

"The demerger is still on and we are considering all options in accordance with our duty to shareholders," a Kingfisher spokesman said.

Investment bankers and private equity firms have made a range of suggestions to Kingfisher's advisers. "There are several ways you can skin this cat," a person close to the deal said.

One option gaining wide circulation would be for Martin Toogood, the Kingfisher executive lined up to run Woolworths and Superdrug as a separately listed entity, to run it as management buyout instead.

Superdrug has also attracted interest as a stand-alone business.

Supermarket groups such as Sainsbury that are interested in getting hold of chemist licences to broaden their ranges are thought to be prepared to compete with north American trade buyers such as Shoppers Drug Mart for Britain's second-largest health and beauty chain.

Asda's owner, Wal-Mart, and US drug store operator Walgreens have also been touted as potential bidders for Superdrug.

Kingfisher's chief executive, Sir Geoffrey Mulcahy, will evaluate the merits of any offers that may be made but is prepared to press ahead with the demerger if potential buyers do not bid high enough.

He is expected to try to reassure investors about the logic of spinning off Woolworths and Superdrug, when Kingfisher reports Christmas sales figures tomorrow.

Sir Geoffrey confirmed in September last year that he planned to separate Kingfisher's DIY and electrical businesses - B&Q and Comet in the UK and Darty and Castorama in France - from the slower growing general retailers, Woolworths, Superdrug and music chain MVC.

This week's sales figures are expected to confirm that growth at Woolworths slowed over the Christmas season.

The stock market has been quick to punish retailers that show slowing growth.

Matalan and Body Shop last week both saw their share prices hit heavily after announcing disappointing figures, and Kingfisher could find a trade sale that did not involve exposure to the stock market would be better value for shareholders.

Selling or demerging Woolworths and Superdrug would give Sir Geoffrey cash to expand Kingfisher's presence in the European DIY and electrical goods sectors. Germany is a main target.

A property sale and leaseback could also raise cash for acquisitions.

Sir Geoffrey will be keen to move quickly to head off a potential expansion challenge from rival retailer Dixons. Britain's largest electrical goods retailer is thought to want to unlock the value in its shareholding in internet service provider Freeserve - now part of France's Wanadoo - to expand into Europe.

While agreements not to sell its Wanadoo shares for some time prevent Dixons from making an early move, Sir Geoffrey will be keen to press home his time advantage as soon as possible.

Boots and Arcadia are the next big-name retailers due to release Christmas sales figures. Boots reportedly saw its sales hit by increased competition from big supermarket chains in the toiletries market and its international retail arm is thought to have recorded a loss.

However, Arcadia, owner of Dorothy Perkins and Top Shop, is said to have recorded a substantial jump in like-for-like sales.

webTitle: Letters: Classical composers should abandon the PRS

fields.headline: Classical composers should abandon the PRS
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss's article (Used notes only, January 11) and your leader rightly draw attention to the difficulties encountered by classical composers following recent changes in collection/ distribution policy by the Performing Right Society
fields.body:
Stephen Moss's article (Used notes only, January 11) and your leader rightly draw attention to the difficulties encountered by classical composers following recent changes in collection/ distribution policy by the Performing Right Society. Unfortunately, it's all too late. The case was lost two years ago when the publishers of classical music failed to present a robust case on behalf of the composers they represent. Now, dominated by its commercial music representatives, the PRS is likely to make only minimal concessions to its art-music members.

Radical action is therefore needed and publishers and composers should immediately deregister from the PRS and set up a new association of their own to collect and distribute performing rights and royalties. International publishers like Boosey & Hawkes, and Schott could credibly join forces with the wealthier estates of composers such as Britten and Vaughan Williams, to fund it. Fresh relationships with concert halls, broadcasting organisations and collecting agencies abroad would need to be negotiated. Better relationships between serious composers, performers, promoters and audiences would eventually ensue.

A government awash with finance should also be pressured into following the example of Scandinavia and Ireland by paying salaries and stipends to composers.
Meirion Bowen
London

You ask that the PRS thinks again about the removal of the classical music subsidy. Unfortunately, this much argued-over but little understood subsidy (a reaction to a perceived need to boost classical earnings 50 years ago) was becoming increasingly ineffective in supporting young or new UK composers.

The decision to phase out the subsidy (over three years) was taken after careful consideration with the membership, which embraces composers of every kind of music, and after the PRS had conducted years of exhaustive market research. The money that was being used to pay the subsidy is now being used to pay its rightful earners - those composers whose work actually generated the revenue.

The PRS exists to license the use of copyright music on behalf of writers and publishers, to collect licence fees and performance data, and to calculate and then distribute royalties. Support of the arts is not its primary function, but the PRS membership has given consent for a proportion of PRS total revenue to be made available to encourage the creation of new music through a charitable foundation
John Axon
Executive director, Performing Right Society (www.prsf.co.uk).

I've been a member of the PRS since 1989 and often wonder why, as many of the projects I work on are not included in any of their categories of performance. Other countries do not seem to have a problem supporting their composers and feeling proud of them. Sarah Collins
London

webTitle: Hidebound Filofax loses its appeal

fields.headline: Hidebound Filofax loses its appeal
fields.trailText: The Filofax, the personal organiser that became a must-have accessory for a generation of yuppies, is up for sale again - for less than half the amount it fetched three years ago.
fields.body:
The Filofax, the personal organiser that became a must-have accessory for a generation of yuppies, is up for sale again - for less than half the amount it fetched three years ago.

Two unnamed bidders, one British and the other American, are said to be competing to buy the firm for around £20m.

Day Runner, the US firm that paid £51m for Filofax three years ago, has run into financial difficulties as a flood of handheld electronic organisers have hit the market.

Christopher Brace, Filofax's managing director, was reported this weekend as saying: "It is no secret that Day Runner is in serious financial difficulties and making strategic asset sales. Filofax is one of them."

Day Runner's trading is said to have been hit by supermarkets cutting the number of organisers they stock. In contrast, handheld computer manufacturers like Psion and Palm have reported strong sales.

Mr Brace insists that Filofax's finances remain in good health, despite the new competition.

Graduates in their mid-20s, people with busy diaries and those who don't like entrusting their data to an electronic device are said to be among the most loyal customers.

The Filofax was invented during world war one by a British army colonel and became popular with the military and members of the clergy. Sales peaked in the 1980s and early 90s when it became a status symbol among the young affluent.

Today gadgets like Psion and Palm organisers are increasingly attracting that market but even their products cannot be guaranteed longevity.

Technological advances will soon allow people to watch video through mobile devices and it is not yet clear whether it will be the handheld computer firms or mobile phone companies who will emerge victorious in that battle.

Technological advances will soon allow people to watch video through mobile devices and it is not yet clear whether it will be the handheld computer firms or mobile phone companies who will emerge victorious in that battle.

webTitle: Letters: Can we learn from Anna's death?

fields.headline: Can we learn from Anna's death?
fields.trailText: As a child protection social worker with over 13 years' experience, I listened with incredulity to the litany of fundamental mistakes made in the investigation into Anna Climbie (Agencies failed to act, Janaury 13).
fields.body:
As a child protection social worker with over 13 years' experience, I listened with incredulity to the litany of fundamental mistakes made in the investigation into Anna Climbie (Agencies failed to act, Janaury 13). The unpalatable conclusion for many social workers is that the social work qualification and training is unstructured and does not reflect the difficulties of the job. The course seems to lay emphasis on ideological concerns, rather than equipping prospective social workers with the necessary skills.

This situation is further corroded by a widespread senior management style whose chief objective is to achieve a rise in the league table of local authorities, at the cost of good working practices, by passing set criteria (often by questionable recording) that bear little relation to the protection of the most vulnerable children. This has led to a haemorrhaging of the most experienced workers from the profession and a nationwide difficulty in recruiting and retaining staff.

This in turn has led to a rapid increase in the numbers of agency workers, many of whom are inexperienced. In my own authority, these concerns have been raised many times. Unfortunately, senior managers refuse to discuss them and appear to concede that the inevitable injuries and fatalities are an acceptable price to pay.
Name and Address supplied

 Another horrific child-abuse case, another bout of outrage in the media, more government handwringing. "Reforms of social services" will follow, with longer training courses etc. This is a smokescreen of monumental proportions.

Child protection work requires experienced, mature investigators who have time and support to do a job that carries a powerful, long-term stress load. What it generally gets is young, inexperienced (in life), appallingly paid and ill-supported workers. A trawl of social work job adverts shows salaries at best averaging £20K for frontline staff. Understaffing means higher caseloads of serious cases for existing workers. Stress, emotional burn-out and relationship problems are coupled with poor income.

You get what you pay for. The government needs to ensure social workers get real salaries and real frontline professional careers with (true) caseloads in single figures where child protection work is needed. Until that occurs, Anna Climbie will be just another in a long line of children our society fails to protect.
John Wilcock
(Ex-social worker)
Nottingham

 In "trimming the fat" from local authorities, the previous government caused a serious diminution of resources in social services departments, as in others, and the present administration has hardly begun to address this. It is appalling to see that, as a result, a deprived inner-city area such as Haringey creates a combined directorate of housing and social services. Surely this indicates a poor understanding of the specific support and leadership needed from a director in a social services department (or a housing department).

I wonder if the electorate of Haringey are happy with this? If not, they should use their votes appropriately. We all, as citizens, should realise we too bear some responsibility for such tragedies, if we have no commitment to trying to ensure all our fellow citizens have decent services when in dire need.
Rosemary Russell
Surrey

 There's much talk of bringing in a charge of corporate manslaughter when a company's negligence causes death. Surely the law has to be changed to include those running the caring agencies when they are clearly not learning from past mistakes.
John Hughes
Worthing, W Sussex

 Your leader (January 13) is a little too coy about the need for Lord Laming to review the record of the evangelical churches to which this poor child was taken. It may well be that the doctrine of satanic possession, to which some of these churches subscribe, is a major factor in Anna's murder.

According to the reports, Carl Manning told members of one church he thought that the fact that the child didn't cry, however hard he beat her, was evidence that she was possessed. No one in the church, apparently, tried to stop these beatings. While entitled to pray and fast on behalf of Anna, surely the church also has a responsibility to protect her from physical abuse?
Dr Max Farrar
Leeds Metropolitan University
M.Farrar@lmu.ac.uk

 Anna's sufferings were at the hands of an "aunt" and a stranger. Children placed by their parents with non-relatives for more than 27 days are private foster children whom local authorities are obliged to inspect. The number of children placed by west African parents is estimated at 6,000-9,000.

Unfortunately, central government has long ceased even to collect statistics about them and few councils have a proactive approach to detect them. Sir Bill Utting, in a review of safeguards for vulnerable children in 1997, recommended a compulsory register of private foster carers. The government rejected the proposal. The only way forward is for it to be illegal for anyone outside the immediate family to have children living with them unless they are on an approved register. This will not stop all abuse. It would make it less likely.
Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow

webTitle: Obituary: Alison de Vere

fields.headline: Alison de Vere
fields.standfirst: Yellow Submarine background artist who went on to present images of the highest art in her own films
fields.trailText: Appreciation of cartoon films beyond The Simpsons and Nick Park is limited. Thus the name of Alison de Vere, who has died aged 73, is known only to a small (if international) audience. When a greater value is given to much of the animation work created in the late 20th century, Alison de Vere will be seen by everyone as a great artist, in particular for her Channel 4 work, which included The Black Dog and Psyche and Eros.
fields.body:
Appreciation of cartoon films beyond The Simpsons and Nick Park is limited. Thus the name of Alison de Vere, who has died aged 73, is known only to a small (if international) audience. When a greater value is given to much of the animation work created in the late 20th century, Alison de Vere will be seen by everyone as a great artist, in particular for her Channel 4 work, which included The Black Dog and Psyche and Eros.

When she first entered an animation studio in the early 50s, women were not expected to have ambitions beyond inking and painting the men's animation drawings. By a professional dedication to the techniques of animation and her excellent design sense, she progressed to being not only the first woman auteur cartoon film-maker in Britain but also the best.

She was born in Peshawar, where her father was a company sergeant major in the Royal Tank Corps. The family returned to England when Alison was three and she spent her childhood moving from one army camp to another. She studied art in Brighton before completing her education at the Royal Academy in London.

Her first regular job was with the Halas and Batchelor Studio in 1951, where she worked as a background designer on public relations films for industry. In 1957 she moved to Guild Television Services as head of its animation unit, to direct and design TV commercials. In 1960 she made her first attempt at a personal film, Two Faces, which was constructed around some of her poetry.

During the 1960s she freelanced as designer and director for various studios until she joined TVC in 1967 to work (with almost everyone else in the London animation world) on the Beatles' film Yellow Submarine. As design director, she made a spectacular success of transferring Heinz Edelmann's psychedelia to working cartoon backgrounds - and made a cameo appearance as one of the photographed figures in the Eleanor Rigby sequence.

Between 1970 and 1980, while she was an associate of the Wyatt Cattaneo commercials studio, she began her most productive period. It is greatly to Ron Wyatt and Tony Cattaneo's credit that they gave her the scope and encouragement to make her own personal films. The commercial return on a short cartoon was virtually nil during this period and has hardly improved since. Café Bar (5 minutes), which Alison made in 1975, avoided the obscurity and artiness often associated with personal animation. It encapsulates splendidly the confrontation between "this man" and "this woman", while using true cartoon gags and symbols to examine relations between the sexes.

This film began her career of collecting prizes at every international festival at which her work was seen. Mr Pascal (7 minutes) followed in 1979, and won her the Grand Prix at the Annecy Festival, making her, so to speak, world champion. The film shows a lonely widowed shoemaker taking pity on an effigy of the crucified Christ who then comes to life. Although de Vere was without conventional religious belief, the character she gives to Christ is probably the most sympathetic in any film.

She became less attached to the Wyatt Cattaneo Studio in the 1980s, but knowledge of her films encouraged the commissioning editors for animation at the new Channel 4 to give her the opportunity to expand her range. During the 80s, Alison began to spend more and more time in Cornwall, where she established a studio.

Her love of the bleak landscape around St Just had a profound influence on her work. The Black Dog (19 minutes), which must be considered her masterpiece, was the next commission from Channel 4 and was executed largely in Cornwall. She worked on this film, completed in 1987, while caring for her progressively senile mother. To understand the size of her achievement in creating a film of this length with only a few occasional assistants, working at a distance from the camera laboratories and recording studios required, one must bear in mind that a normal production studio would need at least a dozen skilled artists to create an equal result. It has been said that The Black Dog represents the same sort of advance in animation that The Marriage of Figaro was in opera.

It is a fully entertaining cartoon film, beautifully designed and animated, but covering in its events and characters themes of self-discovery and experience of the deepest kind. There is, towards the end of the film, an image of the relationship between parent and child that is unbelievably moving. The film collected armfuls of awards internationally.

Psyche and Eros (26 minutes), also commissioned by Channel Four, followed in 1994. Again, it is a beautiful film with even more sophisticated design and animation, even if it does not carry the same personal charge as Café Bar and The Black Dog.

Alison de Vere's achievement in these films is to have created work that was always written in the accepted form of the cartoon film, while presenting images and emotions of the highest art. When pursuing their personal visions, many animators become self-indulgent and are guilty of wilful obscurity. Alison was always professional and consequently a greater artist.

In person, her modest and unobtrusive manner would lead you to underestimate her power. Small and slight, with a bush of frizzy hair, when she wore her tinted spectacles she could have passed for a female version of Mole from The Wind in the Willows. However, once you caught the glint in her eye you became aware that she had reserves of magic, and might, with an infectious giggle, turn you into a frog, or even a cartoon character. In an industry of often showy egos, she never attracted envy or jealousy and remained serenely undisturbed by her huge international reputation.

She continued to work on children's series for television up to the end of her life.

She married the painter Karl Weschke in 1948; the marriage ended in divorce. She is survived by her son Ben de Vere Weschke, who had been her companion and assistant since the 1980s.

webTitle: Letters: the late Lorna Sage

fields.headline: Letters: Lorna Sage
fields.trailText: Faith Evans writes: Soon after meeting Lorna Sage (Obituary, January 13) 12 years ago, I became her agent. Her method of writing her childhood memoir Bad Blood was extraordinary. Each chapter would take several months to conceive and, when she finally put pen to paper, what she produced was exactly what she intended. It was as though she cooked it inside her head so as to present a perfect meal. There was no question of rewriting or editing.
fields.body:
Faith Evans writes: Soon after meeting Lorna Sage (Obituary, January 13) 12 years ago, I became her agent. Her method of writing her childhood memoir Bad Blood was extraordinary. Each chapter would take several months to conceive and, when she finally put pen to paper, what she produced was exactly what she intended. It was as though she cooked it inside her head so as to present a perfect meal. There was no question of rewriting or editing.

She was an intensely social person. Talk - about people, books, the ways of academe - meant almost everything to her. When she seemed to have no physical strength left to draw upon, she could be transformed by a long gossip or an impromptu seminar. She was completely professional; she had firm views of her own on most things, but if she took you on, her trust was total.

This is not to say she was always easy. On form, she was the best and kindest companion you could hope for; when feeling low, she could push you to the very brink of your patience, then pull you back with an outrageous display of charm. It was as though she knew she must not waste the precious time she had left.

She saw through puffery in a flash, though it amused rather than infuriated her, and she would often have to force herself to behave well when confronted by academic bureaucracy and wrangling.

Her brain remained supremely active, even when she was sometimes barely able to breathe. Temperamentally opposed to the role of victim, she met her ailments head on, developing a clinical, even comic, interest in her symptoms that must have been intimidating to her doctors. She had the most intense will to live of anyone I have ever known.

Snoo Wilson writes: Memories of those who die with emphysema are generally wreathed in the ambiguous seductions of cigarette smoke. Thirty and more years ago, when I was one of the two Sages' students, I took Lorna and Vic's photographs in their flat off Earlham Street. Keen to add additional light sources as well as photogenic smoke, I persuaded Lorna to light a fresh cigarette with a match - swoosh! - for each take. This she did, with evident pleasure, saying she had never known photography to be such fun before.

Lorna's extraordinary scholarship never quite won me over to the Faerie Queene, which I pretended to study under her. However, her own keen appreciation was always laced with a humorous and deadly irreverence. She had an anarchic eye for most of life's absurdities, and frequently used her declining health as the starting point for some comic anecdote.

webTitle: Obituary: Kyra Vayne

fields.headline: Kyra Vayne
fields.standfirst: 'Lost' Russian-born opera singer who found fame in old age
fields.trailText: The perplexing story of the Russian-born singer Kyra Vayne, who has died aged 84, was highlighted when she became something of a cult figure in her old age.
fields.body:
The perplexing story of the Russian-born singer Kyra Vayne, who has died aged 84, was highlighted when she became something of a cult figure in her old age.

With the help of friends, her life was reinvented as the tale of a great singer unrecognised, her career thwarted, as she imagined, by the machinations of fellow singers, directors and agents, most of whom (she claimed) tried to bed her and lost interest when she refused.

Her anecdotal, rather sad autobiography, A Voice Reborn (1999), told of a Russian émigré mistreated by her family, unlucky in love, always just missing the main chance because of the supposed misdeeds of others.

Vayne, who had changed her name from Vronska, was eight when she came to Britain from St Petersburg. At 16 she joined a Russian Orthodox church choir, studied with various teachers, among whom the most influential was Mignon Nevada, whose mother Emma had herself been a noted soprano. At first, Vayne sang in musical comedy to pay for her lessons. During the second world war she worked for ENSA. which led, through the conductor Anatole Fistoulari, to a successful engagement alternating the two principal female roles in Mussorgsky's Sorochintsy Fair at London's Savoy Theatre. The musician-comedian Vic Oliver encouraged her talent in his radio shows, but seems to have exploited her. She also had a bad experience working with Richard Tauber in a wartime production of Die Fledermaus, under the title Gay Rosalinda. Her superiority to another, more malleable but inferior soprano was apparently evident, but she discovered that she had been hoodwinked by the management.

After the war came the most successful part of her career. She sang Fevronia in Rimsky-Korsakov's Legend of The Invisible City of Kitezh (1949) in Spain, a role ideally suited to her warm, dramatic soprano. Back in Britain she shared a concert with Boris Christoff and appeared with the Welsh National Opera in its inaugural seasons. She also appeared with a touring Italian company, most notably as Tosca, one of her best roles. Another success was her appearance in Darghomizhsky's The Stone Guest, in Florence in 1954, and the following year she undertook Tosca at Rome and sang Santuzza to Gigli's Turiddu in the famous tenor's final stage appearance in 1955. Yet Covent Garden ignored her talents.

After that, personal problems, including the suicide of her agent in 1957, left her penniless. Her appearances, broadcasts apart, became less frequent and in 1965 she decided to retire from singing and went to work as a secretary for the BBC and as a ceramic restorer.

Almost 25 years later, some old tapes of her performance, live and in the studio, were rediscovered, and issued by the Austrian firm Preiser, which specialises in issuing discs of historic singers. They revealed a voice of uncommon beauty, used with a deal of discernment and style, especially in Russian repertory and in Verdi. Vocal cognoscenti were astonished by them. There followed a media rush to rediscover a "lost" singer, with interviews on radio and an appearance on Desert Island Discs.

At the end of 1999, she was invited to sing at Moscow's Bolshoi Theatre. In her first public performance for 40 years, she sang a selection of Russian folk songs, which was broadcast live by the BBC as part of their millennium coverage. "For me to sing at the Bolshoi is beyond any fairy tale," she said.

Yet critics who had heard her in the 1950s were far from flattering, and her acting abilities were not always admired. She was also "difficult" in her relationships, both public and private.

But it would be uncharitable not to welcome the fame that came to her late in life, leavening her last years with a spark of happiness that had eluded her in her prime.

Another success was her appearance in Darghomizhsky's The Stone Guest, in Florence in 1954, and the following year she undertook Tosca at Rome and sang Santuzza to Gigli's Turiddu in the famous tenor's final stage appearance in 1955. Yet Covent Garden ignored her talents. After that, personal problems, including the suicide of her agent in 1957, left her penniless. Her appearances, broadcasts apart, became less frequent and in 1965 she decided to retire from singing and went to work as a secretary for the BBC and as a ceramic restorer. Almost 25 years later, some old tapes of her performance, live and in the studio, were rediscovered, and issued by the Austrian firm Preiser, which specialises in issuing discs of historic singers. They revealed a voice of uncommon beauty, used with a deal of discernment and style, especially in Russian repertory and in Verdi. Vocal cognoscenti were astonished by them. There followed a media rush to rediscover a "lost" singer, with interviews on radio and an appearance on Desert Island Discs. At the end of 1999, she was invited to sing at Moscow's Bolshoi Theatre. In her first public performance for 40 years, she sang a selection of Russian folk songs, which was broadcast live by the BBC as part of their millennium coverage. "For me to sing at the Bolshoi is beyond any fairy tale," she said. Yet critics who had heard her in the 1950s were far from flattering, and her acting abilities were not always admired. She was also "difficult" in her relationships, both public and private. But it would be uncharitable not to welcome the fame that came to her late in life, leavening her last years with a spark of happiness that had eluded her in her prime.  Kyra Vayne, soprano, born January 29 1916; died January 12 2001

webTitle: Obituary: William Hewlett

fields.headline: William Hewlett
fields.standfirst: Silicon Valley pioneer who co-founded one of America's biggest corporations with $538 capital
fields.trailText: William Hewlett, one of the founders of California's Silicon Valley, has died aged 87. Bill Hewlett and David Packard started Hewlett-Packard in a garage in Palo Alto, close to Stanford University, in 1939.
fields.body:
William Hewlett, one of the founders of California's Silicon Valley, has died aged 87. Bill Hewlett and David Packard started Hewlett-Packard in a garage in Palo Alto, close to Stanford University, in 1939. The order of their names was decided on the toss of a coin. Their success in building one of America's 50 biggest corporations inspired later generations of entrepreneurs, and in 1989, the garage was made a state historic landmark. HP bought the house and garage for $1.7m last year, and used it in its "Invent" marketing campaign.

HP also pioneered "the HP way" of "management by objectives". The concentration on personal responsibility and flexible working practices became a distinctive feature of Silicon Valley life. When he retired in 1987, Hewlett said: "I guess that's what I'm most proud of - the fact that we really created a way to work with employees, let them share in the profits and still keep control of it."

The profit-sharing schemes and company picnics may, however, have been less important than the close ties HP maintained with Stanford University and their mentor there, Fred Terman. HP set up a cooperative programme that enabled employees to do advanced degrees at Stanford while on full pay, and this helped them recruit bright young graduates. When the university created the Stanford Industrial Park in the early 1950s, on 579 acres next to the campus, HP was the second company to move in. The Stanford experiment helped generate the Silicon Valley phenomenon, and HP was just the first corporate giant spawned by the university.

When HP's success made them hugely wealthy, Hewlett and Packard led the way in charitable giving. With his first wife, Hewlett set up The William and Flora Hewlett Foundation in 1966 "to promote the well-being of mankind". It now has $2bn in assets.

Hewlett was born in Ann Arbor, Michigan, but grew up in California. He wanted to go to Stanford because it was where his father had taught medicine, before dying when Bill was 12. He often said that if his father had not died he would have studied medi cine, and joked that he chose electronics because he liked electric trains. Either way, it was at Stanford that he met Packard, and HP's first product - a cheap audio oscillator to test sound equipment - was based on research Hewlett had done at Stanford.

An early customer was Bud Hawkins, the chief sound engineer from Walt Disney Studios, who was developing sound equipment for Fanta sia, Disney's animated feature. "In the beginning, we did anything to bring in a nickel," Hewlett recalled in 1987. "We had a bowling-lane foul-line indicator. We had a thing that would make a urinal flush automatically as soon as a guy came in front of it. We had a shock machine to make people lose weight." Later efforts included the first non-invasive foetal heart monitor for use during labour, and an ultrasound cardiac monitor fast enough to produce real-time moving images of a heart beating.

HP's core business was in test and measurement equipment: products such as signal generators, frequency counters and spectrum analysers that are unloved by everyone except the people who use them. The company became more widely known when it launched its first handheld programmable calculator in 1972, and was turned into a household name by the success of the HP LaserJet printer, launched in 1984.

HP's sales doubled from $6.5bn in 1985 to $13.2bn in 1990, then more than doubled to $31.5bn in 1995. With the computer side of the business threatening to become overwhelming, the company's test and measurement arm was split off as Agilent Technologies. The two companies, which started with $538 in capital, now have annual sales of almost $60bn.

Hewlett continued at HP for most of his life, becoming president (1964-77) and chief executive officer (1969-78). He retired in 1987, when he was named director emeritus. David Packard continued as chairman of the board of directors until 1993, and died in March 1996.

Hewlett and Packard not only worked together, they played together. They took up cattle ranching in 1952, and most of the Hewlett and Packard children learned to swim in the pool at their ranch near San Francisco. The friends also bought ranches in central California and Idaho. Packard said: "By running the ranches together, as well as the company, Bill and I developed a unique understanding of each other. This harmony has served us well every single day in running HP."

Most unusually, Bill Gates, the co-founder and chairman of Microsoft, paid tribute to Hewlett, whom he had met through their common interest in philanthropy: "He was a pioneer whose every approach stood the test of time."

Hewlett is survived by his second wife, Rosemary, five children from his first marriage, and five stepchildren.

 William Redington Hewlett, electrical engineer, born May 20 1913; died January 12 2001

webTitle: Reviews: classical: Schnittke weekend

fields.headline: The radiant rowdiness of Alfred Schnittke
fields.standfirst:
Schnittke weekend
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Schnittke weekend
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Alfred Schnittke's music is defined by diversity. His symphonies lurch from modernist violence to quotations from Beethoven; his concertos contain everything from baroque pastiche to jazz solos; and his chamber music is brutal then beguiling. This BBC weekend was the first major retrospective of Schnittke's work since his death in 1998; it included appearances from his closest friends, including violinist Gidon Kremer, cellist Alexander Ivashkin, and the composer's widow, the pianist Irina Schnittke.

There was no more telling contrast in the first two days of concerts than that between the riotous First Symphony, composed in 1969-72, and the Concerto for Mixed Choir, written in 1985. The symphony was played in the Barbican by Martyn Brabbins and the BBC Symphony Orchestra, while the BBC Singers and Stephen Cleobury performed the concerto in the haunting intimacy of St Giles, Cripplegate.

Schnittke's First Symphony is one of the great showpieces of the recent orchestral repertoire, and the BBCSO's performance was a major event. The 70-minute symphony began with every musician playing as they walked on stage, creating a ferocious dissonance. It goes on to parody genres of music from military marches to waltzes, and the niceties of concert-hall convention.

After one outburst, a violin and piano duo started a separate performance in front of the first violins - disregarded by the orchestra, which continued to play. Violinist Daniel Hope and pianist Simon Mulligan gave a hyperactive recital, mercilessly satirising the virtuoso tradition. At the end of the symphony, the players continued performing on the journey backstage, only to reappear exactly as they did at the start of the symphony, before Brabbins finally called a halt to proceedings.

Next to this extraordinary collage, the serene concentration and austere atmosphere of the Concerto for Mixed Choir, settings of sacred verses by the 9th-century Armenian Grigori Narekatsi, could have been the work of another composer. Yet there is a profound connection between the archaic style of the concerto and the "polystylism", as Schnittke described it, of the symphony.

Although the First Symphony is often hilarious, there is a tragic tension in the piece between its hidden architecture and the fragments of music Schnittke pastes over it. The funny stuff on the surface has a deadly serious meaning; it's the modernist structure underneath that Schnittke is really parodying. So the timeless qualities of diatonic melody and plainchant in the choir concerto (and in other of Schnittke's works of the 1980s performed over the weekend, such as the Fourth Symphony) are one way of bypassing the dilemma of the symphony. Yet the ultimate irony is that these languages are no less borrowed than any passage of the First Symphony.

At the end of his life, Schnittke found a musical language that escaped the conflicts of his previous music. The London Sinfonietta gave the world premiere of Fragment, part of a piece they had commissioned from Schnittke in 1994, but which he never finished. There is an amazing conviction and clarity about the work's three existing movements. Even more striking was the British premiere of the radiant Eighth Symphony, given by the BBCSO under conductor Eri Klas. There, the earlier tussle between styles and structures is replaced by a music that is more unified but also more terrifying: a stillness and calm that seems to reflect Schnittke's gaze upon death.

webTitle: Reviews: theatre: Bertrand's Toys

fields.headline: Bleak Russians at the Purcell Room
fields.standfirst:
Bertrand's Toys
Purcell Room, London
**
fields.trailText:
Bertrand's Toys
Purcell Room, London
**
fields.body:
You come out of this show slightly deafened. Given that it's the opening production of the 22nd London international mime festival, that might seem a surprising reaction. But mime has long ceased to be a matter of soundless gesture; it's a word that now embraces almost any form of visual theatrical event. While welcoming the new eclecticism I still find myself turned off by the monotonous intensity of this particular Russian import.

BlackSKYwhite was formed in Moscow in 1988 and boasts two performers, Marcella Soltan and Andrej Ivashnev, under the direction of Dmitri Ariupin. Their show offers us strange images of death and of humankind as an overwound automaton. The bald, gnomic man appears variously as a trudging figure bound to the upper world by a strip of canvas and as a manic juggler; the woman, sporting ever more outlandish pointy-hatted costumes, contorts her body like a skeletal memento mori. Sometimes the two figures interact. More often, they are are encased in solitude. Meanwhile the score relentlessly increases in volume.

The technical skill is undeniable: Soltan, in particular, seems to have an astonishing physical plasticity. But several things disturb me about this show. One is the director's claim that "we have no politics, no messages". Rarely have I seen a show that stated with such overbearing insistence that modern people are hollow machines progressing towards a meaningless death. It is a tenable view that would have been shared by many Expressionists and Absurdists. But whereas in drama, with its interplay of characters, there would be scope for challenge and opposition, here all we get is repeated illustration of a determinist vision. This is theatre of sensation - a procession of shocks in pursuit of a single idea.

The mime festival in the next two weeks will doubtless offer many alternative viewpoints. But I wonder whether, in scorning the idea of mime as a white-faced Frenchman walking into the wind, we haven't thrown the baby out with the bathwater. Marceau, in the course of an evening, would embrace both mortality and mischief, spinning between tragedy and comedy. Today mime seems increasingly to offer us polar opposites rather than an inclusive view of human experience. Those who relished the grotesquerie of Castellucci's freakshow Giulio Cesare will probably enjoy Bertrand's Toys. Myself, I felt the need afterwards for a long walk along the South Bank both to clear my head and to remind myself that we are still, if lucky, free agents.

 At the Purcell Room, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), until Wednesday, then at Phoenix Arts, Leicester (0116-255 4854), Friday and Saturday.

webTitle: Reviews: art: I, Mancunian

fields.headline: I, Mancunian
fields.standfirst:
Lowry, Manchester
**
fields.trailText:
Lowry, Manchester
**
fields.body:
London-based artist Paul Housley may have been born and bred in Stalybridge, Greater Manchester, but there is not much in this collection of paintings and novelties to suggest the spirit of the city or its people. Housley goes for a slapdash pop-art, often thick swabs of lurid paint thrown at a (not particularly funny) visual gag. Roman Polanski's Bics shows a pile of orange razors; this painting, Housley claims, ridicules Polanski's penchant for orgies in his films, but perhaps the director's cut would have been a better idea.

When Housley gets round to Manchester-related subjects, the results are more interesting. Devotoid is a painting of Buzzcocks founder Howard Devoto's head, given a human-meets-android orange glow. Less successful is Housley's study of singer Ian Brown, an open-gobbed blur to which you can only say: so what?

Other pieces that meet the Mancunian remit include a jacket embroidered with silver sequins to read "New York - London and Stalybridge". But other gags - the Coke logo reworked to say "Enjoy Nihilism", for instance - call to mind the words of a Mancunian with a more subtle sense of humour: That Joke Isn't Funny Anymore. What Morrissey would make of the painting White Car in Saddleworth - a sports car, presumably in parody of the Moors Murderers' van - is anyone's guess.

Downstairs, as an addendum to the show, Housley has selected his favourite works from the Lowry archive. From the eerie hair and hunchback of Girl Seen From the Back to the vampyric pallor of the Head of a Boy, Lowry's grotesques deliver what Housley's work does not: a singular vision from a truly Mancunian eye.

 Until April 22. Details: 0161-876 2000.

webTitle: Reviews: art:  There is no Mountain Then There is

fields.headline: Keeping the faith in Dundee
fields.standfirst:
There is no Mountain Then There is
Generator, Dundee
****
fields.trailText:
There is no Mountain Then There is
Generator, Dundee
****
fields.body:
Instead of a press release for this group show on the nature of belief, a blank poster. Held against light, it revealed words; the light changed, they disappeared. To believe this heralded a new show at Generator required a minor act of faith - which is exactly what the exhibition consists of. Belief in love, redemption, a pop group; faith in storytelling, angels, filmic special effects: all of these combine to create an engagingly retro look at trust.

Jessica Voorsanger goes wildly secular with a forlorn shrine to Take That, while Mel Carvalho's Angel, a photograph of a shadowy angelic figure, makes you think of Robbie Williams. Kate Gray's backlit photograph, Mission, could also have pop-video roots, but this quiet show-stealer is more meaningful than that. An Edenic image for this digitally manipulated age, two smooth-thighed lovers walk hand in hand through the fields. That they are walking towards a nuclear power station, and wearing disposable plastic pants, disrupts the fantasy. But still they walk, joyfully, towards the end.

Opposite Gray's lovers hangs Paul Carter's dystopian installation, Moses Basket. A huge plastic bubble, it suggests safety, a sanctuary. Inside, though, hangs a lifeless figure, in combat gear studded with quotations from the Bible. The bubble of safety is violently burst: this is a suicidal space, a torturous chamber. In a deadly dialogue with each other, Gray and Carter's work also benefits from an apocalyptic audio backdrop, all Hawkwind space-rock meets Jah Wobble, courtesy of the Family of God.

In a second room, Alan Currall talks through miracles on video, using deliberately antique special effects. Joanne Tatham and Tom O'Sullivan's installation - white barbed wire, white trees growing from poor soil, pink fluorescent light - is like a vision of death stolen from a Steve Strange video circa 1982.

As you step out of this powerful show into Generator's industrial estate setting, another miracle is revealed. Bill Clinton is addressing the people of Dundee on a loudspeaker, his rhetorical skill laid bare in the frosty air. His fate pretty much sums up the changing nature of faith this show explores: the US didn't believe him about those "sexual relations", and yet he kept their faith in him.

 Until February 4. Details: 01382 225982.

webTitle: Headhunters are increasingly aggressive

fields.headline: 'Look love. Tell me, or else'
fields.standfirst: Headhunters are harassing frontline staff in the search for information on key personnel - and their tactics are increasingly aggressive.  Kate Hilpern  reports
fields.trailText: Headhunters are harassing frontline staff in the search for information on key personnel - and their tactics are increasingly aggressive. Kate Hilpern reports.
fields.body:
'I want to be put through to the head of IT. What's his name?" "Oh, I'm sorry, Sir, I'm not allowed to disclose that information." "Look love, I'm not getting off this line until you do . . ."

Sound familiar? If not, it may only be a matter of time. Headhunters are hot on the trail, stealing staff from companies - and using front-line staff such as receptionists and secretaries to get the information they need. What's more, their tactics are becoming increasingly cunning and aggressive, causing growing numbers of secretaries to quit their jobs as a result of the strain. Quite simply, headhunters use any means necessary to build up a database of names, job details and direct telephone lines, so they can then approach the relevant people as and when an employer becomes interested. It is estimated that secretaries at some multinational firms receive up to 50 such calls a day.

A particularly hostile story is currently doing the rounds, detailing an imposter faking an imminent conference. "I need a faxed list of the sales team right now," he demands of the innocent at the other end of the line.

"I'm really sorry, but I don't think I'm allowed to do that," she says, following the company line.

"Well, I'm allowing you. I work for this company, too, and am a damn sight higher up than you, so if you don't do it, I can assure you you'll be out of a job."

"Oh yes, OK, I'll get on to it immediately," seems the only possible answer to the threat. The list is delivered straight into the hot little hands of the headhunter.

So why the sudden explosion of this behaviour? The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development puts it down to the unprecedented growth of the recruitment industry.

"Around the world, the shortage of skilled people in many sectors of industry means that headhunting is increasing at a dramatic rate, with 20,000 companies alone in the UK," explains a spokesperson. "There is huge competition between them to get details of the best people."

Paul Sampson, an ex-headhunter adds, "A lot of young people working in recruitment realise that if they set up their own headhunting company, they could make a lot more money. Not surprisingly, they're hungry to get a database started and so they'll be as aggressive as need be to get it."

Sampson believes it's no coincidence that we are witnessing a high turnover of secretarial staff. "Understandably, they can't hack these calls," he says. "They leave the office feeling used, abused, guilty and exhausted. No wonder they get to the point where they think, 'Is this worth it?' Meanwhile, the employers suffer by losing their staff. It's bad news all round."

So severe are the repercussions, he says, that this month he has launched Anti-Headhunting UK, a service with a training package specifically aimed at front-line staff. "We've been successfully running an anti-headhunting service on the continent for two years, but since staff data is at greater risk in the UK than almost any other European market, we've decided to expand here."

Shock tactics are not spared. "The seminar starts by us making live phone calls in front of the secretaries to prove the problem exists," he explains. Perhaps he'll phone a receptionist and say, "Hi, it's Phil from IT. We've had a breakdown of a system and need to be reminded of your password to Lotus Notes." Phoney Phil may then be able to access anything from staff lists to salaries. Alternatively, Sampson might opt for a more antagonistic example. "You think you'll never give such information away, but we show it's actually very easy to take advantage of people's ignorance," he says.

The trick, he believes, is to teach secretaries specific tactics in handling callers that both protects their emotions and the company's interests. "Some employers are so paranoid about access to staff data that receptionists come across as unhelpful and rude. That's the other end of the spectrum in responding to headhunters that we try to avoid," he explains.

Secretaries within the IT industry - which is facing a particularly harsh skills shortage - are most likely to hear from headhunters, with those working in telecommunications, banking and insurance companies close behind. Indeed, organisations such as Deutsche Bank and Worldcom have recognised that there is no point investing vast sums in computer security if systems are being consistently undermined by human error.

Nevertheless, even Sampson admits that the recent surge in the headhunting of secretarial staff themselves makes such tactics only part of the solution. Employers must work harder than ever at retaining staff so that the sales pitch of a recruitment consultant won't be enough to lure them away. "We are never going to stop the problem of headhunting altogether," admits Sampson. "In some instances, you will genuinely be offered a better job."

Research shows that among the top retention techniques for secretaries are flexible perks, flexible working hours and a focus on development. At least then, secretaries suffering the brunt of headhunting can console themselves with the knowledge that the more they grow, the more justified they will be in demanding the benefits that these extra responsibilities entail.

webTitle: Struggle to promote new pensions

fields.headline: Struggle to promote new pensions
fields.standfirst:
Survey shows companies know little about stakeholder schemes

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Survey shows companies know little about stakeholder schemes.
fields.body:
With less than three months to go until stakeholder pensions go on sale, a survey out today indicates the government still has a mountain to climb in raising awareness of the new schemes.

The research, carried out by insurance group Prudential, found that almost two-thirds of small and medium-sized businesses are unaware that stakeholder pensions will be available from April.

Among companies in the technology sector, only one in 10 knew this. As a result, many employers could be in danger of being hit with fines of up to £50,000.

The findings come days after social security secretary Alistair Darling launched a £6.5m government television advertising campaign aimed at promoting stakeholder pensions. The new type of personal pension is designed to encourage people to save more for their retirement in private plans so that they are less dependent on the state.

Aimed particularly at workers who do not have access to a company pension scheme, and non-earners who are excluded from taking out a personal plan, stakeholder schemes will be available from April 6.

They are made to be cheaper and more flexible than personal pensions. All businesses employing five or more people, which do not have a company pension scheme, will have to offer staff access to a stakeholder plan.

Yet despite being warned they could face a fine if they do not comply with this rule, 31% of small and medium-sized companies without a company scheme said they do not intend to give staff access to a stakeholder pension, according to Prudential, which surveyed 500 firms with at least five staff.

"The technology, food and drink, and service industry sectors have the worst understanding of when the scheme will be launched.

Only 10%, 15% and 20% respectively of companies in these sectors knew that stakeholder pensions are to be launched in April 2001," said the insurer.

Those in the financial and professional services, education and construction industries proved to be the best informed.

webTitle: Equitable will disclose exit total

fields.headline: Equitable will disclose exit total
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Equitable Life is likely to issue eagerly awaited figures this week showing how many policyholders have pulled their money out of the company since it was plunged into crisis five weeks ago.
fields.body:
Equitable Life is likely to issue eagerly awaited figures this week showing how many policyholders have pulled their money out of the company since it was plunged into crisis five weeks ago.

Until now the mutual insurer has refused to say how many people have elected to pay the 10% penalty for cashing in a policy or transferring funds, for fear of creating panic, but Equitable said it was considering issuing surrender figures this week.

These might be published alongside information on the investment returns achieved by the insurer's £27bn with-profits fund last year - figures that will be scrutinised closely in the wake of Equitable's warning that up to 1m policyholders can expect lower returns in future. This is as a result of it losing a legal battle over pension promises made to 90,000 investors and failing to find a buyer.

The number of people who have withdrawn their funds will affect how much is raised from the sale of the company's assets, and the fact that it may be prepared to give details could suggest the level of withdrawals is nearer to a trickle than a flood.

Equitable is talks with several companies - GE Capital and Dutch group Aegon are tipped as frontrunners - about the possible sale of the whole business or parts of it.

It is also discussing proposals put forward by a policyholders' action group to cap the insurer's liabilities by putting a ceiling on the total amount paid to holders of so-called guaranteed annuities.

The insurer is imposing a 10% penalty on anyone who withdraws funds - double the 5% penalty in force before Equitable closed its doors to new business on December 8. The company said this was to ensure the interests of those remaining in the with-profits fund were not damaged.

Until now Equitable has only been prepared to say that, while the number of people pulling out "has inevitably increased from our traditionally very low level", the amounts involved "are not significant in relation to the total fund".

Some policyholders have decided to pay the penalty and move their funds elsewhere, fearing the exit fee could increase further.

While a successful sale of the business could result in the penalty being amended, it is possible the company would have to increase the penalty if the crisis worsened, in order to prevent a run on the fund.

The office of fair trading is looking into the question of whether the 10% penalty is reasonable.

webTitle: My boss, the Luddite

fields.headline: My boss, the Luddite
fields.standfirst: E-business was supposed to revolutionise our offices. So how come a fifth of British bosses can barely turn on a computer?  Laura Barton  on why the paperless office is still a distant dream
fields.trailText: E-business was supposed to revolutionise our offices. So how come a fifth of British bosses can barely turn on a computer? Laura Barton on why the paperless office is still a distant dream.
fields.body:
My mother is 52 and obsessed with the internet. "Couldn't you find it on the web?" she asks, helpfully, whenever I'm trying to root out some elusive piece of information, or hardcore porn, or whatever. I swear she'd sooner suggest I surf the net for a pint of semi-skimmed than - god forbid - pop out to the corner shop. And the curious thing is that my mother has never, ever, used the internet. Good lord, she doesn't even know how to set the video.

My dear old mum is not alone in her love-hate relationship with technology. Nearly every company in the land can dole out its website address, but how many of the head honchos can find it themselves (without the aid of a compass and a sturdy pair of hiking boots)? A recent survey for the business software company Computer Associates revealed that 19% of British bosses are "technological laggards", with 48% asking their PAs or secretaries to print out emails, and a fifth never using the internet.

Ruth, a PA with a furniture manufacturer, says she finds it infuriating that her boss refuses to learn how to use his email, never mind search the internet or send faxes. "He says he doesn't have time. But I think he's just lazy. When I'm away from the office, even if it's just for a couple of hours, I get worried about him. It's like when you leave your kids on their own and you write down all these instructions about how to use the microwave and the washing machine . . . Before I can even leave the office I put Post-it notes on all the computers and the fax machine and the telephone, telling him which buttons to press and where everything is. It's ridiculous."

The survey, conducted by interBiz, showed that there is a tendency simply to leave the IT systems to the IT department. Senior bosses, suffering a severe case of internet-envy and eager to hop on the eBusiness bandwagon, often don't have the foggiest how or why it works. As an interBiz spokesperson explains: "This led to a lot of technology being installed for technology's sake with eBusiness being seen as 'this year's magic wand'."

James Jones, the divisional senior vice president of interBiz, says: "Senior managers are not interested in the technology that is behind eBusiness. They are only interested in how it will help them run the business."

At the same time, his off-putting language - in tune with other technological enthusiasts - smacks of dictums from another planet: "We should be delivering true exception reporting, in real time, based on the organisation's business rules through a single business portal, command and control view. They should not have to run reports or utilise other tools. If this reporting is then supported by intelligence which has utilised past trends or forecast for the future, it can assist the manager in making the right decision." No, I didn't understand that either.

And maybe that's the problem. People are frequently put off learning about technology because of the lingo. If you have to spend three hours wading through the jargon just to read your email, it's going to seem a lot more attractive to ask your kindly PA to print it out for you. Furthermore, weary, overworked bosses are unlikely to have the time, or indeed the inclination, to attend a nightschool course in Microsoft Excel and Powerpoint.

So it is hardly surprising that an Office Angels survey last June showed that more than a quarter of employers require staff with internet skills, and that those candidates who can boast internet "literacy" are a third more likely to get the job. In the course of a working day, the internet may be used to carry out market research, analyse the competition, and for more mundane tasks, such as travel arrangements and booking tickets.

As dot.coms continue to spread, rash-like, throughout the business world (a new start-up allegedly launches every 29 minutes), technological know-how is becoming ever more vital. One possible solution may be Learn Direct, the UK's first e-learning network, which launched last April, and now has more than 50,000 registered users.

Over 80% of Learn Direct's courses are online. And there are hundreds to choose from, from the very ABC of computers to the European Computer Driving Licence, which can lead to a qualification recognised in the UK. Most importantly, the majority of courses are broken down into bite-sized chunks which can be followed at your desk, at your own pace, and with self-tests to help you along the way.

You can also use the computers at the centres, which is useful if you don't have access to a PC, or if your employer is a bit grumpy about you using the company computers.

Learn Direct has helped hundreds of people, from the woman in the East Midlands who insisted on putting the mouse on the floor (she thought that was where it belonged - like a sewing-machine pedal), to Jayne Reynard, a self-confessed technological laggard, who hadn't found much call for spreadsheets or word- processing skills during her 20 years in the catering industry.

When Reynard came to set up her own private and business catering business - Divine Dining - early last year, she suddenly found her lack of computer skills was holding her back. It's no good being able to roast a whole hog, if you've no way of publicising it, no menus to display, no way of writing official letters to prospective clients, or, indeed, of billing them.

At a job fair in York, Jayne and her sister-in-law, Nicole, met some representatives from Learn Direct, and soon afterwards Jayne began an IT course, with basic instruction in word processing, spreadsheets, Excel and Powerpoint. Reynard went into the centre for a couple of hours each day, when her son was at school, whereas Nicole decided to learn online.

"I'd never even used a mouse before, so I was all over the screen when I first started", says Reynard, "but it's amazing how simple it is to get on with computers." Now she feels confident enough to experiment on her own, and is no longer scared of the machine. And, she confesses, "If I get stuck I just ask my son."

Visit Learn Direct on www.learndirect.co.uk, or call freefone 0800 100 900.

webTitle: Reviews: dance:  Resolution mixed bill

fields.headline: Resolution mixed bill
fields.standfirst:
Bloomsbury Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Bloomsbury Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
There is always the hope that performances given by young, untested choreographers will announce some bold agenda for the future of dance. In fact, showcases of new work, such as the Resolution season, often leave me grumbling that choreographers under 30 have no sense of history. It's hard to get excited about ideas that were radical four decades ago.

Certainly the opening minutes of Korper, Terrain by the German duo Christina Ciupke and Manuela Fischer, where the two women lie motionless on an empty, silent stage, sent me into reflex critical mode. Hadn't they heard of Paul Taylor, who in 1957 earned a blank review for standing still in a dance show? But as the pair finally began to move, minutely adjusting their bodies through the slowest of stretches, somersaults, crouches and crawls, I saw that they weren't reiterating the mischievous deconstructions of earlier generations, but doing a very contemporary spin on minimalism. They were doing dance as designer loft living, dance as feng shui.

Dressed in muted grey and brown and tracking around a space that was fastidiously lit, the two dancers sculpted their bodies through a sequence of beautiful and contemplative forms. Low-key music subtly altered the ambience from trance to urban. We never saw the dancers' faces, so deeply coiled and twisted were their bodies, but we got to know their limbs, their spines, the soles of their feet, the sensuous precision of their breathing . If the pacing of the work was such that our minds wandered, it was always a pleasure returning to this space of elegant lines and gracious calm.

Lurking in the background of I Am Vertical, a work by the enigmatically styled group th53, was the imposing ghost of Pina Bausch. The six dancers spoke snatches of confessional nonsense and attempted tasks that were comically doomed to failure, all in familiar Bausch mode. But th53's humour revelled in a loopy wit that was all its own and the performers were slick and engaging.

The centrepiece of the programme was choreographed by Martin Lawrance, a terrifically gifted dancer and a member of the Richard Alston Company. ShELF is set to a suite of Bach solo cello music, performed onstage while Lawrance sent phrases of physically lush but emotionally introvert dance spinning along the lines of the music. The work featured deftly choreographed passages performed to a high standard, but it also appeared cramped. There weren't enough passionately held ideas and images blowing through the tidily arranged material in ShELF. Somehow the piece took up too little room.

 Resolution continues until January 28. Box office: 020-7388 8822.

In fact, showcases of new work, such as the Resolution season, often leave me grumbling that choreographers under 30 have no sense of history. Certainly the opening minutes of Korper, Terrain by the German duo Christina Ciupke and Manuela Fischer, where the two women lie motionless on an empty, silent stage, sent me into reflex critical mode. Hadn't they heard of Paul Taylor, who in 1957 earned a blank review for standing still in a dance show? But as the pair finally began to move, minutely adjusting their bodies through the slowest of stretches, somersaults, crouches and crawls, I saw that they weren't reiterating the mischievous deconstructions of earlier generations, but doing a very contemporary spin on minimalism. They were doing dance as designer loft living, dance as feng shui. Dressed in muted grey and brown and tracking around a space that was fastidiously lit, the two dancers sculpted their bodies through a sequence of beautiful and contemplative forms. Low-key music subtly altered the ambience from trance to urban. We never saw the dancers' faces, so deeply coiled and twisted were their bodies, but we got to know their limbs, their spines, the soles of their feet, the sensuous precision of their breathing . If the pacing of the work was such that our minds wandered, it was always a pleasure returning to this space of elegant lines and gracious calm. Lurking in the background of I Am Vertical, a work by the enigmatically styled group th53, was the imposing ghost of Pina Bausch. The six dancers spoke snatches of confessional nonsense and attempted tasks that were comically doomed to failure, all in familiar Bausch mode. But th53's humour revelled in a loopy wit that was all its own and the performers were slick and engaging. The centrepiece of the programme was choreographed by Martin Lawrance, a terrifically gifted dancer and a member of the Richard Alston Company. ShELF is set to a suite of Bach solo cello music, performed onstage while Lawrance sent phrases of physically lush but emotionally introvert dance spinning along the lines of the music. The work featured deftly choreographed passages performed to a high standard, but it also appeared cramped. There weren't enough passionately held ideas and images blowing through the tidily arranged material in ShELF. Somehow the piece took up too little room.  Resolution continues until January 28. Box office: 020-7388 8822.

webTitle: Keep interested in Tessas

fields.headline: Keep interested in Tessas
fields.trailText: Thousands of investors holding tax-free Tessa accounts could miss out on massive amounts of interest unless they transfer their money to different accounts by the end of the tax year.
fields.body:
Thousands of investors holding tax-free Tessa accounts could miss out on massive amounts of interest unless they transfer their money to different accounts by the end of the tax year.

The Alliance & Leicester has conducted research among 2,000 Tessa savers and says two out of three of them have no plans to transfer their funds. Only 14% said they would move their account, while 11% said they would switch providers and 2% wanted to spend the lot.

According to Alliance & Leicester, they could lose out on some £2m a week in lost interest, since Tessa savers must move their money within six months after it matures. If not, they will lose their tax-free allowance.

But the complex rules surrounding Tessas are causing huge headaches for many holders and the rules for transfer are so complex that even some bank and building society staff are mixed up.

Tessas are tax-exempt special savings accounts, launched by John MajorÕs Conservative government ten years ago. Around five million savers put around £30bn into these accounts. They could keep up to £9,000 there and keep the interest tax free if it was left untouched for five years.

When the TESSA matured, the capital - but not the interest - could be rolled over for another five years.

The Labour government replaced Tessas with individual savings accounts (ISAs) where up to £3,000 a year in cash can be invested. While this is less than Tessas, money can be withdrawn without penalty.

Although Tessas can no longer be created, anyone who started one was allowed to complete it. This year they are now starting to mature with an estimated £21bn flowing back to savers this year.

The recommended route for those with Tessa accounts is to open a Tessa-only Isa. Up to £9,000 can be invested in these. But, you can only invest the amount of capital you put in to the original Tessa Ð not the interest. Money can be withdrawn from these at any time.

A key benefit of such a move is that it has no effect on your annual Isa allowance of £7,000. That means that someone with a Tessa maturing this year can potentially take advantage of up to £16,000 in tax-free savings.

To move a Tessa to a different home, the savings need to be withdrawn at maturity, with the cheque made out to the new provider. This might mean having to make a personal visit to the bank or building society and savers must be supplied with a Tessa maturity certificate, which is necessary to open a new Tessa-only Isa.

If Tessa savers do not move their money into an Isa when their account matures, banks and building societies automatically switch it into savings accounts with low rates and tax is payable. Barclays, for example, pays just 2.4% on balances over £5,000.

Selecting where to put your Tessa proceeds is not easy, as there are some competitive rates available. Some building societies such as Britannia and Portman offer improved rates to customers who already have a maturing Tessa with them.

Both these are higher interest than many of the big high street names such as Halifax, which is currently only offering 5.45% on its Tessa-only Isa.

A number of experts believe that stock market linked options offer the best prospects for future growth. Experience has shown that Tessas linked to the performance of the stock market have produced far better returns on average than those linked to fixed or variable interest rates.

While stocks and shares mean some risk there are accounts that will guarantee no cash loss providing capital is left untouched, although interest could be at stake.

Worth exploring are the equity-linked Tessa Isa accounts from Birmingham Midshires, Bristol & West and HSBC.

The Tessa experience has also proved that those investors who opted to place their money within a mutual building society would also have come out trumps. Smaller building societies all outdid their major listed rivals such as Halifax, Lloyds TSB and Royal Bank of Scotland.

Independent financial adviser Michael Aaron, technical director of the David Aaron Partnership says he believes interest rates will go down yet further and so he favours the equity-linked route. "One of my preferences is for the HSBC equity linked Isa for maturing Tessas. Or there are with-profit bonds or zero preference dividend shares. The options are all explained in a guide we produce on investing for income."

webTitle: How to drag your gaffer into the jet age . . .

fields.headline: How to drag your gaffer into the jet age . . .
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: * Provide senior managers with an "enterprise information portal" so that by using their computers they can see exactly what is going on in the IT department. This enables senior managers to access data in an easy format and have all the information they require, quickly and all in one place.
fields.body:
* Provide senior managers with an "enterprise information portal" so that by using their computers they can see exactly what is going on in the IT department. This enables senior managers to access data in an easy format and have all the information they require, quickly and all in one place.

* Encourage your managers to use internal email instead of phoning or shouting to others in the office. Perhaps get them to send work lists to you via email. This will make them more familiar with the system.

* When the boss asks you to do something technological, pretend you don't know, or are too busy. Instead, steer him or her in the right direction, make suggestions and praise technological dexterity. Promise the reward of a chocolate biscuit if he/she can find the company website before lunchtime.

* Purchase the latest time-saving gadgets for your boss, eg wap phone, palm computer, so he can show off to his friends and colleagues (assuming he's male). Getting over the fear of technology is half the battle.

* Make sure you mention interesting or useful websites and encourage your manager to go and have a look. Mention how useful and timesaving you have found the internet for research, or purchasing goods for the office or home.

* Encourage your manager to go on an e-business course. Perhaps ask if you can go on the course yourself and then suggest that your boss comes along with you. You can make a day of it.

 Information supplied by interBiz
